Thick foamy head that sticks around for a while. Smells of sweet roasted malts. Dark ruby red in color. Slightly sweet and smooth going down but booziness is definitely noticeable. Pretty complex beer but subtle notes of cherries come through in the end.
A very balanced though complex ale. Beautiful color though the aroma does not foretell what lies ahead.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2015 Cloudy, medium amber, tall, persistent head. 
Light-medium body, rich flavor, well balance, smooth texture, frothy, much but not excessive alcohol heat, long palate, balanced finish. 
Moderately sweet & sour, just right bitterness. 
Fruity, yeasty, kriek character stands out, no hop flavor to talk about. 
Elegant and successful combination, easy to drink despite richness, not cloying.

Bottle. Cloudy, dark amber colour and a dense off-white head. The aroma consists of dark fruits, cherries, yeast, roasted malts and caramel. Heavy sweetness and somewhat acidic. The alcohol is noticeable. Complex, but very enjoyable.
2012 bottle. Slightly hazy dark amber with a layer of off white head. Aroma and taste of roasted malts, dark fruits, and some yeast.
On tap at peanut pub in Oskaloosa with nate suz lamont hakes rusty and ur mom... brownish pour with white head. .funky aroma..but nice creamy taste

Poured into a tumbler in late 2013.

A: Ruby red. See through. Fizzy head that recedes to nothing after a short time.

S: Fruity. Cherry, maybe pear.

T: Lots of malt with fruitiness. Cherry, pear. Bitter on the back end. Lots of alcohol heat.

O: My nostrils picked up a lot of alcohol heat. It was not hidden well at all. This really seemed to be an unbalanced mess. I drain poured it.

Delightful. Pours a cloudy brown. Aroma is mostly raisin, fruitcake. Taste is plum, caramel, a bit of sour cherry. Complex and satisfying. Would be too much/cloying by itself, but its truly excellent with strong cheese or a fruit/caramel dessert.
Cloudy brown with off-white head. Aroma of fruit, some spice, and fermenting yeast. Decent quad. A little acidity in the finish.

12 oz bottle. Pours a nice brown color, significant lacing. Aroma was very yeasty and fruity, with hints of cherry, raisin, and molasses. Flavor is incredible, a complex blend of malt, yeast, and fruit flavors. Quite simply, words cannot do this justice. Im looking forward to having this again. Thanks to MeisterBrauMHB for splitting a bottle with me!

Pours a cloudy deep amber body with a luxuriantly dense tan head. Substantial lacing. Black cherry and smells of other sweet dark fruits; raisins, dates, and figs. Warm wave of bourbon scents also detectable. Complex taste with layers of toffee, butterscotch, honey, and vanilla. Cloves and other spices on the finish. Extremely smooth considering the ABV. A beautiful quad...another triumph from Ommegang.

APPEARANCE - Dark, opaque, 3-finger head that dissipates, red, amber, foamy. OK lacing.

AROMA/SCENT - Hops, malts, yeast, fruit, pine, raisin.

TASTE - Hops, malts, sweet, nutty, pine, fruit, brown sugar, raisin, apple.

MOUTHFEEL/PALATE/TEXTURE - Good carbonation, bubbly, light, effervescent, crisp, refreshing.

VALUE - $10.99 for an 25 oz. bottle - good buy.

OVERALL/DRINKABILITY - Only 2% cherry. Not as fruity as I expected. Its really just a hint of cherry.
Bien sucré. Un beau côté de cassonade et de fruits confits. Bonne présence des houblons. Bien balancé. Le petit 2% de Liefmans kriek est subtil mais crée une belle douceur en bouche.

bottle. Dark ruby-red colour, slight haze. Very spicy aroma; cinnamon and pepper on top of belgian yeast and plum/raisin. Had this one in a blind tasting with other quads, and it stuck out like a sore thumb. Has some dubbel and tripel characteristics. Definitely not a bad beer, but not sure it fits perfectly in the style.

Bottle from ABC. Pours a muddy, dark brown with a medium off-white, brownish head that sticks around forever. Lacing clings to the glass beautifully. Aroma is deep, dark malts; toasted nuts, bread, molasses, toffee. An initial almost sour flavor gives way to a rather creamy, sweet finish. Long, thick, full-bodied throughout. Acquire.

From bottle, 750ml

Aroma: Cherries, Raisins, Bread, Caramel

Appearance: Brownish with a hint of red, cloudy, tan head

Taste: Medium Sweet, slight bitter/sour

Palate: Medium to full body, creamy, average carbonation, sweet/dry finish

Overall: One of my favorite all time/go-to Quads. Really enjoy everything about this and Id give it a perfect score, but then Id look foolish :) Great cherry balance along with the maltiness. Slight alcohol warmness, but not very noticeable.

Pours a fairly dark with a nice head. Has a slight alcohol taste with a finish of cherries. Nice body as well. Typically a very nice beer though in my experience the taste tends to very from year to year.
I had it from a bottle.

Drank from a pilsner glass poured from a 750ML bottle. Wonderful aroma of cherries and sweet malts. A nice amber color, with a nice beige head. Has a slight alcohol taste with a bit of cherries, and a slight hint of bitterness from hops.

Corked and Caged Bomber - served in a tulip glass - nice deep red/brown pour with a medium head. Excellent plum aroma and dark fruit taste. Has a bit of a cider taste on the finish. Not a huge fan of quads but this one is pretty good.
12 ounce bottle poured to Trappist glass. A very mature taste: figs, dark fruit and bread, some nice and easy booziness. Smooth on the palate, yet it also has some bite.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2014 In bottle .. quite nice and probably their best. Poured a nice brown. taste is quite nice and comparable to some Belgium options ..

Overall a good beer, and I would consider buying again

Aroma: Bready Malts, Raisins, Mild Fig

Appearance: Amber Hue, Passes Some Light, Off White Head, Decent Lacing

Taste: Raisins, Bready Malts, Mildly Bourbon

Mouthfeel: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Sweet,Mildly Boozy

Bottle 2011. Pours a deep burgundy with a small head that dissapears completely. Aroma is sadly a bit too oxidized, tilting it towards medicinal bitterness. On the good side there is alot of sweet dark dried fruits here. Taste is alot better. Loads of sweet malts and raisins. Hints of nuts and caramel and applecider. Also a bitter twang of that medicinal note from the aroma. Body is close to full with just above avg levels of co2.

Bottle, shared with BBGTC. Pours a near-clear deep amber body with a small off-white head. Aroma is raisins, caramel, oxidized apples, red fruits and hints of candy powder, white sugar and mild banana. Taste is raisins, caramel, candi sugars, burnt toast, alcohol and hints of red berries, banana and apple cider. Full body, medium carbonation. Decent enough, but this has probably seen better years (2011 bottle).

En bouteille dans un hôtel Disney. Couleur brun foncé avec reflet rougeâtre. Odeur plus fruit que malt, un peu dalcool, un peu de caramel. Palais complet, avec arrière goût sucré. Mêmes si cest un très bon produits nos quad québécoises nont rien à envier à Ommegang. (Rigor Mortis, Lassoiffée 12 notamment)

Bottle - big foamy head, beautiful dark amber red color, sweet malty aroma and flavor, mild cheery notes, mild Belg yeast spice, very good overall 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Corked bottle poured a muddy orange-brown hue w/ a huge rocky beige head diminishing to a full lasting cap. Big sweet fig and boozy aroma. Initial flavor is moderate sweet w/ a light to moderate bitter finish. Tastes are figs, brown sugar, dark fruits and dark bread. Full bodied with a warm finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Oh, just wow. Cloudy dark amber pour under a nice thick tan head. Sticky sweet palate, but just delicious. Cherries are in there, but nice and subtle. Alcohol warmth shows up, but not in the taste. Worth every ounce of its reputation.
Pours a dark, hazy brownish-red with a very foamy off-white head. Aroma is dark fruit and flavor is the same, with some alcohol taste to it. Sweet, with a full body. Very good.
UPDATED: APR 30, 2016 Tapp på RockBottle LA. Dimmigt mörkbrun med beige skum. Doft av körsbär och mörk malt. Söt med inslag av bär och aningen choklad. Riktigt bra.

From the bomber bottle, pours a very dark deep scarlet red with a thick bubbly off white head. I can smell the alcohol from arms length. Perhaps thats just a Vietnam flashback to drinking way too much of this on weekends in grad school. Upon further reflection, while there is an aroma of alcohol, there are also notes of sour apples, dark malts, very fruity. Thick, the alcohol, while present, is largely masked by fruits and malts. Wish I could be a little more descriptive, but it went down to quick. Really good beer.

Poured a dark amber to brown colour with a 1/2 inch cream coloured head. Aroma is sweet with notes of dark fruit (plums, raisins,and cherries), clove, and roasted malt. Flavor is sweet still with strong presence of cherries among the belgian malts. Medium bodied with carbonation and a light alcohol finish. Well done.

Appearance: Dark brown, light tan head.
Aroma: Very dark malt, roasted, sweet.
Taste: Very dark malt, dark fruit, roasted. Very good!
Bought: World of Beer (Reston), 355 ml
Info: 29/10-2014
Poured from the tap. Opaque, medium reddish brown with minimal beige head. Caramel, dark fruits, mild belgian yeast. Medium body.

750ml bottle pours a translucent, deep garnet amber with some thin, ringing, creamy white head. Nose has plenty of candy, clove and loads of raisins, some boozy notes, hints of red wine, a little red pear. Flavor has candy sugar, some nice blood orange notes, some clove, some pepper notes, dates. Full bodied, lightly hot finish.

"i like this one better than St Bernadus Abt 12, which as of now is the #4 beer on the top beer list. a great Belgian brewed in NY...whod a thunk it. might be my favorite Belgian to date. deep, sweet (blended w cherry kriek) and very complex."

Poured from a bottle. Sweet aroma and flavor.
Some alcohol esters mix well with the dark fruit and medium malt flavors.

Pours dark brownish red with a sour & tartness on the nose. The taste is almost roasted like a stout even with some tobacco but with a light bitterness and alcohol wine finish. My impressions overall are bitterness, smokiness & wine, I dont taste any cherry. Good but not the best quad Ive had.
Orangebraunes Bier mit schöner beiger Schaumkrone. Geruch röstmalzig, dunkle reife Früchte, Karamell, würzig. Geschmack sehr malzig, süß, reife Früchte, Karamell, leicht alkoholisch.

750 ml bottle produced in March 2013. Pours reddish brown, substantial toffee head. My nose detects tart cherry, wood and loads of fruity esters. Taste is herbal, fruity, muted tartness, wine aftertaste. Super stealthy abv.
A very cherry aroma and taste. Pours fairly dark with a small head. Gets a little better with every taste.

Julie thinks it is complex and good. However it is not great I think awesome Michigan states sucking

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

11-12-13-14 flight. Rated for 2011. Hazy cooper color with off white head. Herbal taste with a dry finish. Very nice. 2012 version had an apple aroma and more acidic. 2011-2013 were hazy amber, 2014 more clear. 2011,2014,2013,2012 how I liked them.
75cl from a supermarket in San Francisco. Color is brown dark copper. Head is medium and brownish. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Aroma is caramel, fruit, spices, mushrooms and wood.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2015 12 oz Bottle. Pours deep brown with reddish hue. Almost burgundy. Solid drinker, but yeast and booze a bit dominant.   Definitely interesting. Lambic adds distinct sour/ cherry note to brew which works with the banana/clove/spice/ yeasty belgian notes. Definite sweetness in there- toffee, malts and raisins.   Tempered by sour cherry and hops.  Smooth mouthfeel- not overly carbonated. Nice to sip on. One is plenty. Somewhat boozy.

Definitely a huge Belgian. I've heard the hype before trying it. Good, but not a game changer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

bottle @ Party Town / Florence KY --- Appealing aroma of malt and grass. Clear, very dark brown with a solid tan head cover, wide streaks of lace. Caramel malt and alcohol, both arriving together for a huge taste that moves with assertiveness through a palate where the alcohol is more than enough to balance. A solid sipping ale, needs time to be savored.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Deep burgundy colour, good carbonation, white foam. Interesting aroma, yeast, spicy hop, some booze, hint of cherries. But to be honest the taste is a bit disappointing. Overly boozy. Muddled yeast. Cherries are there, not overpowering, but there is something a bit cloying in there. Cant quite put my finger on what it is, but theres just some lightness of touch and balance missing which makes it rather hard work.

Couleur brune, reflets ambrés; forte mousse beige cremeuse. Nez de fruits noirs et prune, note maltée. Gout de fruits noirs, prune, figue forts sucrés, sucre candy, note de malt et alcool. Corps bien épais et petite pétillance.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2016 Deep red with a good bubbly head, on a gassy beer. Deep, a touch vinous, plenty of body, lightly spiced, berries. A find drop. Boozy, malty, and light spiced aroma. Crisp finish with a light alcohol burn.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2014 Pours a very dark brown with a full head, to the bottom. The lacing was to the bottom as well. Thickly sweet of dark malts, nothing roasted. Deceiving alcohol leaves a little warmth.
Very dark amber pour, tan/rose head with no lacing. Flavour is nice, a good sour with some fruit flavours, notably sour cherry. Nice one!
UPDATED: NOV 7, 2014 Bottle Sept 2014. Full smooth, lightly carbonated. Slight sour cherry undertone. Absolutely great beer.
Way solid beer......solid for sure...ommegang just makes great beer.........:-)..........

Pours a medium to dark brown hue with a large tan head that is mostly diminishing. Pours with a lot of fizz though and it takes a while for it to clear. 
Aroma is sweet with hints of caramel, malt and brown sugar. Hints of Maple Syrup in there as well. 
Flavor has an alcoholic beginning to it and ends pretty malty, I must say. Kind of a watered down finish as well. There is a slightly mild dry fruit flavor in there as well - raisins and dates in particular
Medium mouthfeel with lively carbonation.

Overall a decent brew!

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2015 Bottle. Appearance: brown-reddish color with thick brownish head; aroma: very strong, cherries, raisins, chocolate, alcohol; taste: sweet, malty and rich, dried fruits, chocolate, brown sugar, spices. Full body, low carbonation. Complex and very tasty, this is a fantastic beer!
Bomber. Pours a murky reddish brown. With a fingers worth of head. Aroma is sweet yeast and raisins. Taste is slightly boozy. Malts and caramel. Sweet then light hints of sour left on the palate.

Very dark brown, one finger head. Smells sweet, boozy; raisins, cherry, a little salted caramel. Taste is slightly sour cherry juice and alcohol. Body is surprisingly light. Slightly sweet aftertaste lingers. An interesting beer that seems to live in a class of its own.

Bottled. Poured into trappist glass. A caramel brown color with a sizable tan head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is caramel, raisins, brown sugar sweetness, belgian spices, definitely a yeasty breadiness. Flavor is lots of caramel and cherries up front, more raisins and dark fruits in the middle. yeasty spicy finish. Great quad.

Bottle: Murky, swampy maroon & copper with lots of yeasty sediment floating around. Semi-foamy khaki cap settles in a few moments to a relatively chunky collar. Aroma of figs, raisins, & prunes coated in a bath of caramelized brown sugar, toffee, & sweet caramel. Light cocoa dust, semisweet & fruity esters, baked cinnamon raisin bread, & a small hint of booze. Taste is even more dark-fruity with lots of red grape, raisin, fig, & prune hitting front & center. The sugary sweet aspect is toned down, but still present; lighter brown sugar & toffee coating the estery fruit. Some phenol alcohol comes out with a hint of clove, adding a nice robustness to the beer. Slightly astringent earthy perfume essence on the back-end. I love the nose on this one, but the flavor was just a little step back for me. Still a nice quad, though.

From 12oz bottle, the aroma is cherries, malt and yeast. The Pour is dark amber with nice thick long-lasting head. Cherries, chocolate, nice roasty malt to the taste, with a full creamy mouth-feel. Long-lasting roasty finish with the warmth of the alcohol.

Pours a cloudy dark brown with a light tan head. Aroma is abundant in cherry, and Belgian yeast. Taste is heavy on cherry and dark fruit, sweet, but the finish is somewhat dry, moderate carbonation. Slight alcohol presence detected but not harsh at all. Great desert beer.

Hazy copper-brown with a nice, almost-white head. Yeast, bready malt, booze, candi sugar in the nose. Nice, but not particularly distinctive. Yeast, dried fruit, booze, and a nice earthiness in the flavour. A touch of herbs and brown spice. Not too sweet.
Sweet raisin, leather. Complex. Light sugar sweetness. Alcohol is well hidden. Nice carbonation. Solid.
Bottle pour. Rich, creamy caramel, malts, fruits, spiciness. Complex and memorable.

Transfer from BA review on 10-28-12-
 Poured from bottle into tulip glass

 Appearance  The brew is poured a hazy ruby red brown color brew with a nice two finger white head. The head fades over about a two minute time span to leave a moderate amount of lacing.

 Smell - The aroma is of a yeasty and cherry nature. Mixed with these smells are nice aromas of a bready, sweet caramel, and a nice spicy nature. A rather tasty smelling brew.

 Taste  The taste begins rather large of a more bready and cherry flavor. As the taste advances the fruit flavor of cherry grows even stronger with some notes of a more yeasty as well as a lighter more wild sour and tart flavor coming to the tongue. Other sweet flavors of a more toffee nature then come to the tongue more toward the end of the taste. These when combined with some alcohol and a light toasted flavor leave a balanced, fruity Belgian flavor linger on the tongue as the taste commences. 

 Mouthfeel  The body of the beer is on the just above average side in terms of creaminess with a carbonation level that is on the average side. The creamy body is nice for the more yeasty and some of the fruit flavors. But yet with its carbonation the beer is still more on the refreshing and drinkable side (even at ~10% abv.)

 Overall  A quite tasty beer. A nice quad with all its fruit, yeasty and boozy flavor, but mixed with a nice but balanced cherry flavor. Very enjoyable and drinkable.

Bottle. Clear reddish brown wit ha beige head that lasts on the sides. Aromas of caramel, banana, toffee, cherry, and spice. Flavor is the same. Medium to full bodied, smooth with a bit of warmth on the end. Biter-sweet finish.

Bottle in a hotel room in Las Vegas. Clear dark amber pour, thick creamy light brown head. Aroma of caramel, ripe fruits, quite malty, some licorice and slightly warming alcoholic. Flavor is sweet and fruity up front, but quite bitter in the finish. Boozy aftertaste. Thick body and heavily carbonated.

Fresh out of the bottle, bubblegum like crazy, a banana after-effect and yeast WAY up in my face on the first sip. Hazy and very dark amber with a lot of light sediment floating throughout the glass. Head was nice for about ten minutes then disappeared with no lacing at all. I am experiencing lots of sour, lots of yeast and yes, bananas and bubblegum. And cherries. Very sweet and cloying cherries. Lightly fizzy and long in the sour department, and not my favorite quad.

I poured this beer into my Ommegang chalice vigorously and it produced a rather large dense foamy off white head that faded to a wispy veil inside a nice foam ring over a nice dark chestnut colored beer with ruby highlights.
Smells thick and rich with candied sugar, malts and fruit. I don,t smell cherries but i do smell the tartness.
Strong malt backbone with sweet candied sugar, fruits. Hints of cherry tartness run through it.
Medium body feel with alcohol warming and a dry tart finish.
Personally, not my style. It is a very strong tasting beer that works well as an apertif for after dinner. I could see this being a decent dessert beer. Something chocolate would compliment nicely I think.

Pours a mahogany red brown with one finger of off-white head diminishing gradually to a thin skim and moderate lacing. Nose is raisins, dark stone fruit, cherries, slight citrus and faint spicy yeast. Taste is similar, with a clear cherry kriek tang cutting through. Mouthfeel is bold yet crisp, with energetic sustained carbonation and surprisingly little alcohol warming.

Fantastic. Nowhere near as heavy as the appearance or nose would suggest, buoyed aloft by the sustained carbonation and the subtle yet distinct kriek edge. That, plus a seriously sneaky ABV, make this a bit of a wolf in sheeps clothing. Highly recommended.
dark amber color with a dark red core when held to light and a 2 finger tan head that dissipates and does not leave much lacing. aroma is molasses, dark fruit, spice, and booze. Flavor is the same.
Pours a dark mahogany with an off white head. Aroma is raisins and alcohol. This is a heavy beer. Taste is dark fruits and alcohol. Not a fan of quads but this isnt bad.

Poured from awesome 750 mL corked bottle into goblet. Dark amber- brown with cream colored sticky head. Rich malty scent with a little fruit mixed in. Yeasty/ malty taste with a slightly bitter/ slightly boozy finish. Nice, smooth mouthfeel. Solid offering from Ommegang.

Poured in to tulip glass. Aroma is deep and earthy with a roasty caramel scent. Slight notes of resin and clove. Tall off white 2 finger head that subsides down to a 1 finger and stays with little lacing. Beautiful dark amber brown color almost opaque. Taste is a nice sweet tang on the front with a malty and slightly floral flavor. The back end presents a very slight bitterness that drops in to a nutty caramel. Good fizzy feeling throughout which leaves the mouth feeling moist and slightly sticky after eating something sugary. Overall this is a fantastic brew thats easy to sip on throughout the night but watch out for that 9.7 ABV because it will creep.
Bottle: murky brown with a small light brown head. Sweet malts with prunes and almonds. Rich yeasty flavors with a cherry finish which is slightly slimy.

This dark amber colored beer has a sweet aroma of cherry. It does really smell like a kriek. It has a very yeasty but full heavy roasted flavor. It says there is a whiskey barrel aged version I this which I bet is amazing. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark brown with rimming tan head; west and spicy(cinnamon) aroma; Flava is rich sweet spicy molasses and cinnamon; feels medium and a tad flat; finishes sweet and tangy slightly sticky

On tap at Specialty Beer Cellar. Clear amber pour with an off white head. Mild malty aromas. Somewhat sweet with big malty highlights. Some brown sugar and caramel lowlights. Average body and mouthfeel.

From bottle. Maroonish dark amber color. Aroma is pitted fruit, light yeast, candi sugar, and molasses. Taste is plum, molasses, cola, yeast, banana, and oak. Effervescent and light mouthfeel for such a high alcohol beer.

Bottle - pours dark amber with medium thick head. Nose of malt, brandy, yeast. Smooth and foamy mouthfeel. Taste is of dark cherry, brandy, yeast, and warming booze.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Dark ruby red pour with an off white head. Dark fruit, dry cherry wine, candy sugar sweetness playing off a bit of dankness in the taste and the aroma follows suit. Exceptional quad.

Purchased at Bottles and Cans in Chicago, IL; enjoyed at home on a stormy late spring night. Not sure why its taken me so long to try this. Appearance is a very cloudy dark brown with a rich light tan head. Aroma is abundant in clove, Belgian yeast, dark fruit (plum), smell is pretty nice. Taste is heavy on raisin and dark fruit, finish is dry, moderate carbonation, light sweetness. This is a good quad.

Very sweet aroma. Sweetness bursts onto the tongue and then various flavors reveal as it smoothes. It's certainly sweet, but not overly. It's enjoyable.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Weird that for whatever reason I do not get much scent from this. Cannot say "notes of..." anything. Not unpleasant smell, just more lacking. Appearance is very dark with a tan head. Held to the light you can see a dark ruby hint to it. Very smooth. Cannot really taste the alcohol so much as feel it. A bit of carbonation on the tip of tongue upfront but middle to end is just smooth. I love Belgium trappist beers, and though this is not one, it immediately makes me think of it. One I cannot point out hints of anything in particular, but I dont care as I just enjoy the heck out of it.
Pours big carbonation with dark caramel brown appearance. Sweet palate with a medium body. Tastes of dark fruit with a boozey aftertaste. Very tasty

Three Philosophers is my favorite beer from Ommegang. It has a nice complexity to it and it is rather smooth to me for being a strong ale. I drink it and dont really feel a 9.7 ABV beer when it is going down. Ive had several of these and it is one of the few beers I buy regularly.

Corked bottle pour. Pours dark ruby with a fizzy disappearing head. So much dark fruit here. Plums and a little cherry. Bold flavor, but a little sweet at the same time. Finishes semi sweet fruit sugar. A lot of flavor in this. Quite impressed.

Full aroma of spices, candies and peppermint. Beautiful brownish red color. Tan head is full and lasts forever. Carbonation bubbles up like a volcano. Rich sweet, spicy candies up front. Notes of raisins, a other fruits. Followed quickly with an alcohol burn and bitter hops with roasted malt notes. Finish lingers...mostly bitter...but warming. Solid
Fantastic beer. Honestly one of my favorites. Tastes best after dinner or at night after a long day with a favorite cigar. Seeing cherries suspended throughout gives it a look unlike any other.

Taste of prunes, raisins, banana, clove. Very complicated beer. Malty and bitter. aftertaste. Booze is barely noticeable. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy

Decent beer. I chilled it though for about a week before trying it. Probably shouldn't have done that because it tasted kind of crappy after that. Probably won't have it again unless it's on sale at Costco. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

It pours a dark reddish brown with a dark and cloudy body. The head builds up to a thick pale tan head that bubbles down to a thinner layer that just covers the body. An inviting aroma of sweet dark cherries, caramel, malts and alcohol leads you to the first sip. Sweet dried cherries mixes with caramel and chocolaty malts, sour cherries, plum and raisins. All of these flavors are surrounded by a warming alcohol that fades off slowly with some bitter notes into the finish. The palate is full bodied, smooth and a little sticky.

Bottle. Had an aroma of roasted nuts and fruit. First sip and I notice the alcohol is hidden quite well, with all the strong toffee and fruity flavours going on, but none of them too overpowering. Surprisingly quite an easy drinker for how big it is.
Pours a darker reddish brown color with off-white head. Raisins, dark fruit, and some wheat on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes with a sweet toffee like note.
Bottle. Smells like sweet fruit, candy and booze. Sweet gummy bear flavor. Great stuff.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone
Bomber thanks I respertftw. Hazy, dark brown with a small, beige head. Dark fruit and burned sugar. Really great.

Flaska från Systembolaget. 2009 vintage. Delad med bokklubben. Brunorange, lite oljig vätska, lågt krämigt skum. Söt doft med körsbär i sockerlag, marsipan, kanderade mandlar, russin, sött vitt dessertvin, mörkt socker. Fina söta smaker med många nyanser där körsbären bara finns i bakgrunden, åldringen märks i väl integrerade smaker och alkohol. Lätt beska, perfekt till ost - snott rakt av från Daniel, finns inget att tillägga.

On tap. Pours a dark rich maroon with copper hues when backlit. Lasting white head with lacing. Aroma is cherries and sweet Belgian yeast. Flavor is dark Belgian quadrupel with cherries and candi sugar. Alcohol is masked, a great beer overall.

Flaska från Systembolaget. 2009 vintage. Delad med bokklubben. Brunorange, lite oljig vätska, lågt krämigt skum. Söt doft med körsbär i sockerlag, marsipan, kanderade mandlar, russin, sött vitt dessertvin, mörkt socker. Fina söta smaker med många nyanser där körsbären bara finns i bakgrunden, åldringen märks i väl integrerade smaker och alkohol. Lätt beska, perfekt till ost.
Pours dark copper with light carbonation and light tan head. Has a sweet aroma. Tastes of light fruit and bubble gum. Its a tad sweet but yummy nonetheless
Pours a deep amber color. Aroma is raisons and and dark fruits. Taste is dark fruits and sweet malts.
Bottle, from Hydes, as a birthday gift. Make (or get the Missus to make) a rhubarb, almond and polenta cake. Eat this, with this beer as an accompaniment. You can thank me later...

It's a nice beer. Don't have any strong feelings either way. I had no problems drinking a glass. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours medium brown with heavy sediment. Caramel malt aromas. Alcohol burn. Sweet and some bitter on the tongue.

Bottle. Hazy orange-brown pour with a medium beige head, settling to a nice creamy coating. Enticing, complex aromas of candied cherries, brown sugar, raisins, a little citrus and yeast. Less cherry notes in the flavour, but some nice dark fruit, along with light citrus. A bit light for a quad, with a subtle sourness and a very dry finish. Very nice and a bit different for the style.

Dark reddish brown with long lasting tan head. Let it warm up to release even more flavors of this complex beer. My first quad so maybe its expected that I didnt particularly care for it. Kinda tastes like cherry cough syrup.

Draft at Roasthouse Pub in Frederick, MD. Served in a snifter glass, dirty amber-brown color with some white head. Aroma of brown sugar, dark fruit (raisins, plums, figs), faint cherry and spices. Taste brings out caramel and faint sour fruitiness. Medium-heavy body, low-moderate carbonation, sticky with slight warming finish. Pretty tasty balanced quad, despite my description was not a Belgian sweet bomb at all.
Bue en bouteille 75cl. Arômes de prune et de fruits rouges. Acidité légère bien compensée par le côté belge quadruple. Du lourd.
Pours a deep amber color. Aroma is raisons and and dark fruits. Taste is dark fruits and sweet malts.

750ml bottle poured into a tulip glass. Pours dark brown with a frothy white head. Aromas of spice and cherries, Starts sweet with a bitter finish. This is a sticky beer that stays with you. Hides the alcohol well, I wouldnt peg this for a 9 percent. Overall a good quad, very drinkable.

Bottle from BevMo. Pours hazy, deep brown. Not much to the aroma, but balanced taste that features dried cherries, Belgian yeast and alcohol. Finishes sweet and a little tart. Good but I was expecting more from it.

Wonderful aroma of cherries, dark fruit. Taste is dark fruit, figs, dark cherries, plums, mild spice, alcohol that is very balanced, medium to high carbonation that fades fast, medium lacing that fades quickly, short to long aftertaste. Bottle from 2013. Very nice take on a quadrupel!

Served: 750 mL bottle
Look: dark amber almost black. off white head hangs around. Hazy pour.
Smell: dark fruits. Cherry flavors. Smell of alcohol as it warms up.
Feel: good amount of carbonation. 
Taste: sweet dark fruits. Taste sour cherries, 
Overall: enjoy the smooth taste. Then just a rich flavor. Enjoyable to drink. A nice after dinner drink.
First drank: home march 2014

When I try a Quad, I automatically think of Rochefort Trappistes 10, which isnt a bad place to start since I dont love, love that beer. But this Quad seems right off a little light in the pants with only a 9.8%, but maybe thats a good thing. A abruptly boozy beer isnt all its cracked up to be. So...
Pours a cloudy red-brown, with some very active carbonation resulting in a dense, and persistent, tan head. Smells of bready yeasts, berry fruit, soft malts. Tastes full of carbonation, fruits, yet dry, yet really not that sweet, with some malty hay in there. That carbonation adds some crispness to the palate. Tasty.

Bottle. pours hazy brown with a BIG really long lasting light brown head that leaves some lacing. Nose of malt and dark fruit. Very well balanced, medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation, flavors of dark fruit, light sourness, caramel, butterscotch, raisins and a lightly chewy sour sweet finish.
Bottle. Pours a nice dark brown. Nose is dark fruit. Big white head. Flavor is nice and sweet.
Tap, dark brown pour with a beige head, sweet taste of fruits, malt, and caramel, complex but nicely balanced.

Blown away. Pleasantly surprised. A oaky and dark berry notes in a well rounded Belgian that pokes through. Great beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Not one of my favorites, but very good. I could drink a lot of this. Hazy brown with red tint and light tan head. Aroma is subtle cherries and cardboard. Taste is dark berry, cherry, plum and cinnamon. Carbonation bites your lips. Can taste the alcohol before a sweet finish.

Reviewed from notes.
The appearance was a dark brown body with light edges near the bottom, one finger foamy off-white head with some light clingy lacing that eventually spider webs a bit.
The smell had cherries up front with plums, sugar, Belgian yeast, malts, light booze really faint in the background, cherries continue to dominate as the beer warms.
The taste was sweet through all of the previously mentioned flavors and combined eloquently together.
The palate was about a medium, not sessionable - good sipper over a period of time, sticky sweet cherry aftertaste and a dry finish.
Overall, nice to get one of my whales knocked off and am glad I did because I am pretty sure Ill end up coming back to this, very good for its style and very good to me (as Brewery Ommegang really starts to grow on me), also this is a very sweet cherry forward quad in the smell, taste and mouthfeel.
malty aroma. dark red in color with a foamy head. malty aroma, slight sweet finish, faint cherry taste

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2014 Bottled from New Beer Distributors, NYC. Ruby/brown colored, small beige head. Nose of malts, raisins, cherry, reminiscent of La Trappes version. Sweet fruity flavor, some cherry, some raisins, malts, pretty high on carbonation. Alcohol is noticeable. It seems a bit rough, as if it requires some more aging to make it more balanced. Still, it?s already quite nice. I?d love to try this again when aged for 5 years or so.

12oz bottle - pours a deep amber . aromas of dark fruit and sweet cherry. Fig , raisin and cherry flavors with sweet malt . Very good . 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap, poured into tulip glass..great mahogany color with thin beige head..aroma of raisins, cherries, brown sugar..malty taste with decent alcohol presence..would drink again.
Very appealing belgian quad. I dont want this to be a "limited" release. I want to be able to drink this forever. Ommegang keep Three Philosophers on the menu!

Seeing this beers stellar ratings really drives home for me that the mainstream tastes of beer enthusiasts here in the US are quite different from mine. This beer struck me as good, but didnt do it for me.

The cherries are only subtly present in the aroma, which I like. The high alcohol content is very well-masked, which is the thing I like most about this brew. Very sweet though. The carbonation is foamy and leaves the beer very quickly, leaving it a little flat, tending towards syrupy. Aroma is slightly fresh, with a bit of spice, fruit, and malt, slightly yeasty.

Enjoyable and pleasant to drink but I dont see this as an award-winning beer in my book, just a typical good strong Belgian-style ale.
Nice foam and aroma . Lots if dried fruit - cherries. Alcohol at the finish.
Backlog. Sweet with loads of fruit, apples, cherries and a hint of chocolate and vanilla.

355ml Bottle from BeersOfEurope.co.uk (£5.39):
Sweet with a solid fruity aroma that is dominated by cherries yet doesnt overpower the senses. There is some spice with lots of darker, ripe fruits. Dates and some figs feature and there is plenty of sugary sweetness & the alcohol is very well hidden too.

Amber with brownish red tinges throughout the body and topped with a decent sized, foamy beige head that is nice considering the abv. but sadly is doesnt hold all that well, turning to a single patch in the centre of the surface after a little under a minute.

Sweet with the lambic style cherries & some spice, a little sugar and various other sweet fruits and malts plus a touch of yeast. The alcohol comes through a little stronger here but again it doesnt overpower or spoil the taste.

Sweet & very well balanced with the alcohol hidden quite well, coming through just enough to give the beer a nice feel to it. The finish is dry but not overly whilst carbonation is good and the beer is smooth, creamy and frighteningly easy to drink.

Very nice beer that starts off excellent and seems to get better and better after its had a little time to settle and open up. Its smooth, well balanced and bursting with flavour. An incredible beer.

After Avere Reverand (my first meeting with quadrupel) I expected this beer to be one of the best beers ever. And it was like this, indeed. Anyway, Reverand remains quadrupel etalon for me. Kind of first love never-2-forget.

Finally got my hands on a bottle of this on 31st Jan 2014: had to share it though. Someone very kind (unknown) had brought it to a bottle exchange in De Bierboom, lucky me (I had two medium sized samples, which came to about half a pint).

Loved it.

Deep amber with a slight haze (been poured a few times before I grabbed it), tanned head on both my pours.

Malty molasses hit the nose and taste buds straight away, this is a true malty brew, but there is so much more to it than just a heavy hand of maltiness. Dark berries, chocolate and cherry hints are easy to find in the mouth, some people will pick up other notes with the flavours but my taste buds were aching from all the wonderful beers I was gorging on during the bottle swap and I most likely missed a few subtle esters and tastes.

I need a bottle all to myself!

Bright yellowish-golden beer with a thick, foamy white head. Nose is like spunky apple cider with a hint of must. Taste is mildly sweet. Medium body. Lively carbonation. Very tasty and refreshing.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Deep chestnut color , nice beige head with good lacing. Rich aroma of malt, dark fruits , cherry and chocolate. Taste is malty with notes of fruits , belgian yeasts , chocolate. Full body , medium carbonation. Light cherry notes in aftertaste. Great!

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2014 Bottle into a tulip. Pours a medium to dark brown color with a light tan head. Smells of cherry, malt, and fruity esters. Thick, pleasent mouthfeel. Tastes of cherries, raisins, plums, and other dark fruits. Excellent balance between the yeast, the malt, and the alcohol. Amazing beer.
UPDATED: FEB 17, 2014 Bottle pours murky brown with low head. Aroma is dark fruits and alcohol, taste is similar , pairs well with chocolate pudding

.75cL bottle poured into a goblet. Right off the bat, theres a very sweet aroma, mostly manifesting itself as cherry, raisin, and cranberry. As it mellows, the cranberry aroma becomes the most prevalent, the cherry takes a back row seat, and the raisin disappears. Theres also a doughiness that pops up while theres still a big fluffy head, but when the head disappear, so does the doughiness. Theres also some trace notes of banana, vanilla, caramel apple, candy corn, and cinnamon on the nose. I even thought I picked up some metal / dirty penny smells. The hazy amber / copper beer is topped by a fluffy white head that recedes slowly. It leaves a decent amount of cloudy head that laces the glass in abundance ... but its a runny lace that doesnt stick.Its a medium to medium-high amount of sweetness, but not overwhelming by any means. More of a fruity sweet than a sugar sweet - although theres definitely some sugar present. Theres a light bitterness towards the finish with a subtle, fruity tartness. This complex, full bodied beer has lots of fizzy carbonation in the mouth which lends itself to a smooth, sticky, and relatively thin texture (for the style at least). The tongue is greeted initially by roasted nutty and dark cherry combined with cranberry. There also seems to be some chocolate in there, and some hints of cinnamon from time to time. It finishes with a mellow burnt bitterness, but this fades and quickly turns to a sweet canned cranberry taste. I say canned cranberry only because theres a slight metal taste; its well hidden, but just enough to be noticeable. A nice, mild alcohol warming comes through late - it doesnt last long enough to be called the aftertaste, but it appears after I set the glass down. The aftertaste is that of a cran-apple-like juice with some fig and/or raisin notes. I definitely gave this one some extra points on aroma, taste, and palate simply due to the complexity - took me awhile to really fell confident that I knew what was going on with this one, and definitely in a curious way ... I think I just figured out the philosopher part of this one.

Presentation: 12 oz. brown bottle served in an oversized wine glass.

Appearance: It has a dark, deep amber color and develops a tan, one finger head. Eventually it dissolves into a ring that sticks around. The lacing is incredible, it covers the whole glass and slowly drips down. 

Smell: A sweet malt scent dominates, complemented by a strong ripe fruit note. Theres also an alcohol sting in the background.

Taste: Basically a mirror image of the nose. A strong and sweet malt taste dominates, and is accompanied by ripe fruit and cranberry notes.

Mouthfeel: Its creamy and smooth, very drinkable. It finishes dry and despite the sweetness it is not cloying whatsoever.

Overall: An amazing beer, with a lot of sweetness from the malt and fruit notes, but so well balanced that its not cloying. Despite the high ABV and the fact that it is a bit strong, its surprisingly easy to drink.

Tåget, rødbrun. Lille, tæt offwhite skum. Aroma: kirsebær og malt. Prikkende carb, tydelig alkohol. Mere kirsebær, mørk sødme, gær. Stor fylde. Alkohol lidt for skarp for min smag, men ellers virkelig god.

Bottle, 2012 vintage into a tulip. Deep orange/brown amber, sparkling, huge foamy head, foamy lacing. Smell - coins, sweet malts. Body - medium, low carbonation, slightly foamy. Taste - some cherry, bready sweet malts. Everything is very toned down. This is a below-average quad. Maybe the worst example Ive tried. An expensive flop.

Aroma: Heavy fruit, but also a whiff of tobacco.

Appearance: Gorgeous darkness, like an Abt 12. Thick white head.

Taste: Booziness is well-hidden by the strength of the sweetness, notes of blackberries, currants, chocolate.

Palate: Very creamy, very little bite.

My first beer from Ommegang, and it didn't disappoint. The subtle addition of cherry ale leaves just a hint to the aroma and taste. Nice job. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

750ml corked and caged bottle into a Trappist glass; served cold.

Aroma: A little cinnamon. Lightly boozy. Just a little bit of cherry/raspberry aroma. Quite nice!

Appearance: Clear, dark, ruby body with a thin, khaki, cap. Light lacing.

Taste: Just barely a little tart, some mild spice. A teen bit of sweetness.

Palate: Medium+ body, with a short finish that ends on caramel malt.

Overall: Pretty nice. Not too heavy, not too boozy, with just the right amount of sweetness.

Drought. Brown hazy apperance with small beige foamy head, caramel aroma, alcohol tainted caramel taste, low carbonation, long finish with strong alcohol aftertaste. A bit too strong in the aftertaste.

750 ml bottle poured into goblet. Clear reddish-brown color with a finger of silky off-white foam that quickly reduces to a shimmery meniscus. I admittedly dont have a great sense of smell, but the aroma seems especially faint to me. What I can detect is caramel malt and a touch of cherry. Flavor follows suit, with a slightly sweet maltiness up front with the slightest bit of tartness in the finish. Mouthfeel is very smooth, and conceals its alcohol well. Id consider this a good, but not outstanding quad.
Clear reddish brown of color with an off white head. An aroma of seets, raisins, syrup and honey. A flavor of malt, raisins, prunes and a weak bitterness in the finish.

Bottle thanks to Malaclemys. Brown/amber with medium beige head. Aroma of dark fruit, alcohol, and a slight mustyness. Medium body with a nice malt presence, notes of cherry, some sweetness, and alcohol warmth.

Good beige head with light lace. A cross between a dark amber and brown ale in color.

First impression, strong vanilla aromas. The cherry is subtle, but present, in this largely malt smelling ale.

Very strong alcohol oiliness in the taste. The malt appears in the form of mildly sweet caramel. Although a lambic was introduced to this beer, there is none of the sourness associated with that style. Moderate body for this style (which is to say that it is very, very rich) and the carbonation is relatively low.

Im not typically a fan of this style, but this was a treat--certainly a well made Belgian style ale.
herbs, caramel, leaves, clove, vanilla, nutmeg,amber, brown, red, clear, medium sweetness, lighty sour,medium body, sticky, soft carbonation, no finish, taste alcohol not in a good way

Bottle pours hazy brownish red with off-white head. Aroma of cherry, cramel, slight alcohol, clove and a little mustyness. Taste is caramel, toasted grain, cherry. medium-full body with slightly sweet finish and alcohol warmth.

Bottled. Pours hazy, amber with an average sized, lacing beige head. Aroma of yeast, caramel, dark fruit notes and spice. Sweet flavor that ends up with bitter notes. Full bodied, oily to syrupy text. and soft carb. A great quad.
This beer poured a dark brown with an off white head, smelled sweet, tasted a lot of caramel and dark fruits followed by some fruity ester.

Costco yeah. Candy sugar yeah. Viscous caramel yeah. Wood cherry wine Belgian yeast yeah duh. Good yeah. Dates yeah. Cherry Lollipop? Maraschino yeah. Fruitcake yeah. A bit thin. Something freakily appealing. Its almost great.

A - pours dark cola with high head. S - aromas of tart cherries, dark dried fruit, spices, and strong Belgian yeasts. Interesting quad and cherries. M - aggressive and full heavy body. T - tart and canned cherries, prunes and raisins, strong Belgian yeasts, spices, and dark toasted malts. O - interesting and way too aggressive. 3.2

Smells sweet, yeasty, strong and some slight cherry. Malty aroma as well. Taste is yeasty, sweet, malty and dark fruit. Nice head retention but light carbonation. Doesnt taste too strong. Very good quad. Very smooth and lots of complex flavors. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2014 Pours a very pretty amber, still bubbling with a light tan head. Malted, mildly cherry cola aroma. Far too carbonated that covers the strong alcohol but also the flavours. Nice sweet flavour, caramels and malts from what I could taste with the medium-light body.

Poured from a 750ml bomber. Reddish-brown in color with a nice tan-colored, belgian head. Tastes of spice, cherry, and yeasty goodness. This strong quad ale is a good compliment as an after dinner treat. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

What a complex and complicated ale! An amazing nutty,ruby brown colour, an thining tan head. Every time I sniff and sip, something different emerges, but a sweet cherry finish comes through every time. Although the 9.8 abv doesnt come through immediately , because the layers of flavour are so full, it really is a slow sipping ale, Im enjoying every small sip. Unlike anything Ive had before!

Poured from bottle at 55F into glass. Pours with a 2 finger head that dissipates fairly quickly; reddish orange color. Aroma - touch of cherry, caramel, toffee, a bit smoky, red apple. Taste - mildly sweet initially, followed by caramel, malt, toffee, raisins, a touch of coffee. Creamy mouthfeel and thick, reminiscent of port in that way (even though flavor profile is obviously different). The carbonation level is such that its quite lively on the tongue with a long malt finish. This is darn excellent.

Good quad. There's something here that is atypical (in an interestingly good way) for the style. Slight spiciness maybe? Not sure. Definitely the fruits are lighter in type than usual. Color is also lighter. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From a 12 oz bottle to a chalice. Noisily pours cloudy bruised brown like prune juice with a nice foamy tan head that fades to a rim. Just a touch of lacing. Aroma is pear, apples, yeast and darkfruits and caramel malts. This beer is sharp and active on the palate and suggest a delicious richness. Taste follows the aroma with rich malt and sweet cherries and darkfruits leading over a warm bed of mild and controlled booze and leaving me with the taste of fresh, crisp (and slightly sour) apples and cherries. Leaves me with fond memories of malt, sour cherries, apples and alcohol. A high quality quad - no surprise to see Omme nailing a Belgian style. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Hard to believe I havent reviewed this one yet.... Picked up the 750 from Bier Thirty in Bown over the weekend... Paid a very reasonable $9 and change... Pours with a long lasting tan head... great lacing. The brew is hazy amber.

Big Belgian malt bomb on the nose... deep malt and caramel... dark fruits with apple and hints of cherry... Peppery with a background sweet clove.

Cherry presence is much bigger on the palate... it is pretty bright almost immediately and then moves quickly into the maltiness and then resides primarily as a tart kriek essence. Malts are not nearly as complex as the aroma... light raisin and dark toast. Personally I would like a slightly sweeter malt complexity mid palate to balance the kriek acidity and make the Belgian phenols bloom.

Body is light/medium with the expected great carbonation.

Very well done... Ommegang does Belgians right and this is no exception.

0.33l bottle shared @ Blind Tiger House. The pour is cloudy and deep amber. It has a nice big kinda lasting dense off-white head. The nose is kinda caramel sweet with floral touches. Some sweet fruity tones with sunblock and lot of ripe fruits. A bit milder than I had hoped for. Perhaps a old bottle? Tastes quite alright. Soft sticky and oily on the mouthfeel with a below average carbonation level. Some spicy nuts found and a trace of a fruity substance in the finish. Had some expectations to this, but it fell a bit through to be honest. 18.06.2013

2004 bottle from my cellar.
Pours clear medium brown with a tan head.
Aroma of cherry and caramel. The flavor follows the aroma. Lightly sweet, s bit boozy. Smooth and fruity.

Bottle at tasting at Beer&Beyond shop. Hazy amber with a huge off-white head. Aroma - caramel, malts, cherries, dark fruits and alcohol. Taste - sweet, cherries, prunes, and light wood notes. Medium-full bodied.
Nose of quad yeast and cherry, cola and alcohol. Not too much cherry, excellent quad composition. Slight alcohol burn.

Bottle, thnx to Summer Secret Santa 2013. Pours a clear light brown beer with a big, light brown head on top. Head is incredibly stable and lasts a long time. Soft, fluffy substance. Amazing looking beer. Aroma of overripe red fruits, berries, blackcurrants, Belgian yeast and some booze. Flavor is quite sweet, light alcoholic and very fruity. Yeast is present in the background of the palate and not overwhelming as in some Belgian varieties. Medium long, light at aftertaste, medium soft carbonation. Very nice neer.
Bottle. Nice fruit and toffee aroma. Taste of cherry, caramel, quite sweet and plenty of alcohol.
Prefect after dinner sipping beer. A dark copper color with a thin head. Taste a bit of caramel and cherries, very complex flavor that lingers on. Outstanding beer, one Ill add to the list

Pours a dark, almost opaque copper with a small off-white head that lingers around the edges.

Medium mouthfeel with just enough carbonation. Sweet caramels notes play against the booziness. Definitely hangs onto your palate for a bit. 

The finish has a strong alcohol taste but is still smooth. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Coppery toffee colored pour. Big off-white, almost tan head. Plenty of lacing. Figs, malt and raisins in the nose. Taste is a sweet melange of the same. A peppery note as well. Finishes slightly sweet. Pretty good.

Pours a dark brown with a small off white head. The aroma is dark fruits, bubble gum and some sweetness mixed with booze. The taste up front is overpowered by maybe a little too much carbonation but after a few seconds the fruity, bubble gum taste breaks through. Overall a great beer but the carbonation takes away from its other great qualities.

Nice leathery brown pour. Aroma of toffee, booze, dark fruit, some cherry. Taste has some banana presence, with a lot of caramel, cherry, and alcohol. Fairly big beer in mouthfeel, but not undeniable by any means. Good American version of a quad.

This is a great one - all the hype and it delivered. Not typically my favorite style but you can't deny greatness

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Was not sure what to expect, quad and kriek is an interesting combo. Brownish cloudy pour with a full, creamy head. Nose of sweet, yeasty fruit. Hard sweet forward, dark cherry/cough syrup (but not in a bad way), caramel and dark brown sugar, a gradual warming back in the throat signals the alcohol. Something slightly sour, then some slight bitter. A lot going on in this very active beer, complex and interesting. Not fruit forward as expected. Would I drink again? Definitely. Would I order again? Yes please.

Very sweet aroma consisting of caramel and bubblegum. The taste is rather sweet as well. High alcoholic content is prominent, but nicely intertwined with malt. Toffee as well. Generally not fond of quads, but this is nice.

My 100th rating. Muddy brown pour with small off white head that leaves a small layer after some time. Caramel and malty smell with some acidity, which are probably the cherries and also burnt sugars. Pretty full malty taste with the caramalised sugars. Dark fruits appear nicely.  Quite warming from the alcohol in the back of the throat ending in a nice bitter. Medium bodied with tongue prickling carbonation. Lovely quad. From trade with Alehunter, thanks Dominic for this very nice beer.

Bottle 33 cl. Pours clear amber in color with a fluffy tan head. Brown sugar, dark liqour and doughy dark breadyness in aroma. Sweet sugary notes, some boozy notes, marzipan sweetness in taste. Quite nice, even if the boozyness is a bit overwhelming from time to time.
The brew gets better towards the finish with some quite smooth vinous nuttyness.

Bottled, 0.75l, shared with CanCrusher. Pours hazy brown with thick creamy light brown head and nice lacing. Aroma of mulled wine (glühwein), cinnamom, cask wood and fruits like cherries, raisins and citrus. Taste starts moderate sweet malty and fruity, follows by fresh fruity and yeasty acidity, warm alcoholic mouthfeel and moderate hoppy finish. Full body, oily texture and soft carbonation in palate. Great brew for philosophers and down to earth beer lovers...

Poured into a Chimay trappist glass. Aroma was laden with alcohol and dark fruity undertones. Poured a thin head with some lacing. Brown, minimal head. Definitely warm alcohol taste, medium to heavy and some bitterness and warmth in the aftertaste. Improved while I sipped. Very good.. Not as nice as Rochefort 10 but definitely a nice Quad.
Beautiful pour with thick, long-lasting head. Deep dark amber color with malty sweet scent. Wonderful sweet flavors which are not overdone.
Deep brown beer with lots of head. Fruity aroma with tastes of plum and currants. Excellent beer.

Three Philosophers is a remarkable limited edition strong ale brewed by Brewery Ommegang in response to a home brewers description of his dream beer. Realbeer.com, the internets largest beer website, hosted a contest called Create a Great Beer. Brewery Ommegang was chosen by Realbeer.com to brew the Belgian-style ale for the winning essayist. Noel Blake, a home brewer from Portland wrote the winning description for what his dream beer would be like.

Slightly cloudy toffee colored beer with a bit of sediment and a thin tan head that subsides audibly into a surface film. Yeasty nose of plum sauce, light vinegar, bananas, and spice. Flavor is a little sour, but quickly develops into a fruity sweetness punctuated by a tiny bit of bitterness at the back of the mouth. The flavor is not strong, but develops over time, giving it some depth. Definitely a pleasant beer with many layers of flavor, but none of the flavors makes this beer unique.

2010

A: pours a chocolate leather ale with two fingers of graham head which falls to a thick quilt in a couple minutes. The quilt dies down to a thin, broken sheet in a few more minutes. Where light can shine, clarity is excellent and reveals a nice caramel ale. Scantly spotty lacing.

S: Yeast is up front here and and maintains throughout as the baseline. There are some earthy hops and hints of candy sugar, but really seems one dimensional from this aspect. some hints of pear juice.

T: Yeast and pear juice. Some faint metallic flavors. The yeast is a little more subdued here but thrives once again in the finish. The alcohol here is well presented and only hints at its presence. I keep going back to the pear flavor, its interesting.

M: Thin with high carb. Slightly satiating finish. 

O: I think this is just average for a quad, honestly theres nothing here.

Serving type: bottle

07-11-2011

Excelente Quadruppel americana. Cor marrom escura, turva, com ótima e persistente formação de espuma. Aroma de ameixas secas intenso, na boca com ótimo corpo, ótima carbonatação, com dulçor predominante, lembrando frutas secas, licoroso. Final longo, aquecido, álcool bem inserido. Excelente breja!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Rating this beer a day later. Everything you could want in a quadruple. Great flavor, nice aroma, smooth yet tangible mouth feel! Not overly sweet. At nine and a half percent ABV one or two is all you need. If you can find it, buy it!

Definitely falls into the category of Does Not Meet Expectations.. Plus extra comments for the 75 characters...

-- rated via 'Find A Beer' for Blackberry 10

Bottle 355 ml. Bouth at Half Time (Poughkeepsie). Pours caramel brown with thick froathy beige head. Aroma: bananas, malt, sweet, vanilla, wood (?), caramel. Awesome nose! Taste: malt, honey, alcohol, dark fruits. Balance is near perfect. Full bodied beer. Alcohol has a warming effect. Milky texture. Not too heavy, despite high ABV. Really nice one!
Chestnut in the glass with nice head. Plum, raisin and a touch of chocolate and coffee on the tongue. Smooth and flavourful. This is a good strong beer in the Belgian style.
Murky brown pour. Big and boozy with dried fruits, bread. Finishes dry with a little bit of tartness and oak. Nice quad.

I had this at Global Brew. Pours reddish-brown with a tan head. Taste dark fruits, sweet, strong. I thought this was pretty good. I would drink this again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This strong beers taste is impacted by its high alcohol content but it seems to be a great blend of ales with characteristics of a saison and champagne. It pours a beautiful caramel brown with the sound of battery acid as it is rifled full of carbonation. That creates a head that is everlasting. This beer comes across a bit too sweet, with some spices reminiscent of cinnamon but also with a heavy alcohol overtone though it does coat the tongue well with its full body. The aftertaste is cumulative with a great lingering bitterness. Great pick to share with friends.

Bottle 0,75L. Thanks to Kita for sharing. Hazy, medium ruby red colour with creamy, light brown, fully lasting head and excellent lacing. Aroma of cherry, cooked red wine, cinnamon, apple, citruses and oak cask wood. Taste is light bitter at the start and moderate bitter at the end of the sip, aromated with cherry and red wine note. Full bodied, oily beer with soft carbonation.

Have always liked this beer. Light and fizzy on the one side. Yet complex esters, with chocolate, cherries, little vanilla, and a lovely mineral aftertaste. Powerful but elegant, like I am, in my mind anyway.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
8/15/2010. From bottle. 2010 version. Dark copper color with a tan head. Dried fruit aromas with Belgian yeast, brown sugar, light hops, and caramel. Up there with the best.
Unquestionably one of the very best quadrupel ales on the market today. It manages to succinctly encompass all that makes a quadrupel. Very spicy, pungent and deep toned.

750ml bottle. Appearance: large, frothy white head, excellent lacing, cloudy body. Aroma: molasses, grain, citrus, horse blanket. Taste: average duration, heavily sweet, lightly acidic. Palate: full body, alcoholic texture, lively carbonation, chalky finish. Not my favorite, but a well balanced beer.

Smells like a nice beer. Non homogenous appearance throughout. Darker in the middle. Taste is complex, did not like finish. Multiple tastes required to put words to this delicate beauty. Palate similarly complex. Did not enjoy the infusion of cherry ale. I found this beer in a 750 mL bottle at my local Costco. Good beer to give as a gift for sharing and celebration. Would not drink a whole bottle in one sitting myself.
On tap - deep burgundy color sweet on nose and palate - pricey for a 6 barrel. Really enjoyed this beer.

Bottle. Pours hazy deep copper, off-white head. Nose of fruity esters, alcohol, cherry (which blends with the esters along with the dark fruit so its hard to tell what comes from what), peppery. Flavour is alcohol, fortified wine-like, with wood and a lot of cherries in there. A very nice Big Beer.
Dark copper pour out of bottle. Opaque. Burnt caramel nose. Great beer--alcohol is very hidden in this one. strong dark fruit presence without being overly sweet.

A sweet sugary aroma, it almost smells like the taste of cabernet franc grapes in the fall. Flavor is predominantly of a gentle sweet and acididic pear with touches of caramel and golden delicious apples balanced with light hopping bitterness. Color is a light brownish, but nearly opaque, purple. Palate is light, with minimal carbonation. A very well done beer. This reminds me a lot of Brewery Vivants "Solitude."

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2014 Aroma: Fragrant fresh fruity notes with some belgian sugar cane aromasTaste: Very potent yet pleasant fruity tastes and great maltiness, full mouth of various fruit notes like cherry that gives a warm aftertasteAppearance:slightly cloudy amber body with lace white head with excellent retention

Delicious quad ale. Ommegang doesn't disappoint with this ale. Rich malts that doesn't over bear the taste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a burned caramel brown color. The nose is not overly pronounced but hints to dried fig, raisin and cherry. In the palate the dried fruit is very prevalent as is the malt. This bold quad packs a punch, so sip and savor this one!

Just lovely. A seemingly never-ending finish of malty sweetness with barely a hint of fruity-cherry sourness (zip! -- the sourness is gone just that fast). A big taste with beautifully balanced body.

12 oz. bottle from January 2013. Pour is a murky dark brown with a modest khaki head, almost no lacing. Smell is complex with dark fruit including raisin, cherries and plum with spicy and citrusy yeast notes. Taste is rich with plum and cherries, with a sour citrus note towards the end. Sour cherry and spice stays with you in between sips along with a warming alcohol presence. More carbonation than other quads that I've had. Pretty good has a dessert quality to it. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A delicious quadrupel ale. Very tasty full bodied ale with a delightful blend of flavors. Clean smooth finish.

355 ml bottle, pours deep red with a small head leaving a lacing. The aroma s very potent, with heavy banana, cherry, coriander and caramel malt. In the mouth its sweet and the finish is sweet. Carbonation average. Finish is sweet. Decent attempt.
Poured from bottle. Hazy coppery brown with big off white head. Active carbonation. Aromas of fruit and caramel. Sweet and vinous with no real bitterness. Sweet finish.
So many good things going on with this drink. Great color, taste, and mouth feel. Very impressed.

An aroma that has notes of raisin and dried cherry. I enjoy the smooth palate and was struck by the past it's prime fruit salad tastes. Not rotten mind you, just warm and starting to become one flavor (i.e. straw-nana-loupe). Drink now or dump later

This is one of the best Belgian-style beers I've ever had. It is a bit sweet with hints of cherry, fairly carbonated, and has a great palate.

Amazing beer. It has some off-flavor that is only barely there but it hurts it for me. Its almost like a burnt milk taste but its almost unnoticeable.

FROM NOTES: July 3, 12
750 mL bottle poured into a goblet. 

A: Initial smell is dark raisins, figs and cherries with yeasty bread followed by molasses and dark honey. 
A: Pours a purple garnet with a thick creamy off white head that does not dissipate.
T: Smooth, sweet maltiness. No hops, Mixture of the Belgian spiciness and sour funk. Mild alcohol. Very nice. 
P: Moderate carbonation, smooth feel, full bodied. 
O: This is fruit forward and an above-average Quad. A damn fine American attempt at the style, but not a great example compared to the revered Belgian inspirations.

Fantastic, clear, ruby red color with, frothy beige head. Complex flavors with spicy and fruity aroma, also raisin and plum. Taste is moderately sweet with a minimally tart and moderately spicy note.Huge, full body with sublime hints of alcohol. Itll have you philosophizing!
Taste of sour cherries, spicy Belgian yeast, a little alcohol, brown sugar, and maybe slightly woody too. I like it.

This is one Ill never drink young again aside from popping fresh bottles to demonstrate its improvement potential, aged vintages are complex and potent, yet smooth, balanced, and harmonized

A bright mahogany to cherry wood body flashes fiery highlights beneath a 1" frothy light khaki head which settles in a few minutes to an incomplete ring and large thin island with only a couple spots and short arcing peninsulas of lace, the older vintage offers much shorter head retention

2012 vintage bottled 01/21/13, best by 01/20/18
Moist dates set the stage for lightly spiced dough and crust, a subtle array of dried fruit with an obvious, but well balanced underlying influence of bright cherry, mild dark berry characteristics floating in the background, flavors follow with sharp esters and carbonation adding a significant edge of texture to the aroma components, some subtle alcohol and heat as this finishes out with earthy herbal-floral notes, a sweet maple residual builds to eventually balance the earthy finish, the dark berry characteristics begin taking over with warmth, the drink is a bit stark while the drying influence never quite harmonizes with the sweetness, overall this is enjoyable with solid complexity
2009 vintage bottled 01/04/10, best by 01/2015
A huge warm sweetness of caramel drizzled date, fig, and berries with a light sense of raw honey and strawberry jam flooding the senses, textures are smooth with just a touch of bright carbonation followed by a bready, crusty overlay in the finish, nose to finish is consistent and significantly smoother than the younger bottle, milk chocolate drizzled caramel apple pie seems to be intertwined with a blueberry cheese cake crumble, very nice, and significantly improved, the high rating is all about this nearly four year old bottle

2 x 12oz bottles at 55º into a traditional 16oz goblet
Bottle. Murky reddish brown pour. Aromas of berries, stone fruit, and brown sugar. Full palate with just a hint of sweet cherries. Nice, smooth finish and a good lingering taste.
Decent beer but nothing special...malty almost no bitterness...smooth..tasty but not an amazing flavor...slightly appley?!!

On tap at Beer Revolution. Dark chocolatey-brown pour with a foamy tan head, medium retention, mild webby lacing. Aroma is intense brown sugar, and sticky candy, caramel, mild kriek (tart cherry, not medicinal tho) An array of flavours on the palate, yeasty spiciness, loads of sweet notes (berries, currant, brown sugar, caramel, Finishes with a tinge of bitterness. Not a huge kriek fan but this isnt a huge kriek beer. Solid quad.

We tasted this at the public house in the Venetian in Las Vegas. It's aromatics are better than the taste.

Nice looking hazy light brow color, good thick head, excellent lasting lace. Nice complex aroma with spices and wood, and the notes of winter time, like red fruits and nut meg. Enters well in mouth, strong yet smooth development of flavors as it goea down. Medium to full body. Spicy at the end, but malty and notes of liquor too. Lasting palate, alcoholic but not overwhelming. Fantastic Quad made in NY. It even Stands up over some belgian quads.

Dark hazy crimson with a foamy head and leaves behind no lacing Nose is made up of chocolate, figs, carmael, toffee. hops and a bit of yeast. Flavor is figs, licorice, chocolate, toffee, caramel, roasted malts & barley. Body is fairly light and the carbonation is almost non-existent and allows you to savor the flavors. Excellent quad ale!
excellent aroma and taste,very smooth and dont impart any alcoholic taste.
12oz bottle pours a hazy brown with a tan head. Big Belgian yeast aroma. A juicy dark fruit taste.
Hints of caramel, almost has a wine taste at the end. Not a bad beer, but not one that Id buy again.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2014 18.06.2013, 0,35l bottle shared with Palme @ Blind Tiger Ale House NY:
Small creamy mediumlasting head. Aroma is strange, slightly neutral and sweet, grass, sunscreen, wet rope, banana, caramel, spices, malts, hints of fruits. Taste is sweet, caramel malts, dried dark fruits, grass, almond essence, wood, dark sugar, hints of fruits. Medium bitterness, dry mouthfeel. Fair enough, kind of strange, and just boring.
A nice quad. The kriek comes through just enough, not overwhelming. Malty with fruit and chocolate flavors. Alcohol is well hidden.

Murky amber,small beige head.Nose of nothing but tinfoil.tinny palate,brown sugar and alcohol. Fruity notes
A waste of time and money
UPDATED: DEC 4, 2014 Super awesome quad, bottle from whole foods venice, nose is caramel, taste is caramel, rich, sweet, some cherry flavor.
Differently standing out from other Belgian and Belgian-style quads is the slight tartness from the cherries. It makes it original. High carbo like one would expect, with a nice dark golden hue.

From 8/30 tasting notes - nutty, molasses, raisins, maple, bready. Where is the kriek? Quad flavors are dominant, big meaty sipping beer. Very nice American quad, true to the style. I wanted the kriek to be a bigger part of this, but still an excellent beer.
Very solid beer. Nice clean fruity flavor with crisp bite on the backside. Great malty flavor offset with just the right bitter notes.
Nice beer. Has this numbers of times and I brew a clone that comes close. Very sweet with a bit of the tartness of the cherries up front. Nice beer.

Poured into a Trappist glass. Minimal head on a hazy, dark straw colored body.
The aroma is rich with ripe apricot, banana and lemon.
The taste is complex and nicely balanced. Lots of fruit which brings a moderate sweetness to the overall flavor. It has a slight sour finish.
The texture is crisper with moderate carbonation.
Nicely done.
Pours a rich, caramel color. Very good, with spice, bread and malt notes. Strong and flavorful - though it is high in alcohol it isnt overpowering.

Not much aroma coming from glass. Pours dark brown with light fluffy head. Flavors of malt and brown sugar. Lively light mouthfeel. Sweet finish. Overall I find the taste lacking real flavor. A little disappointed thought ommegang could produce a better quad.

Poured from a 375mL bottle. Pours cloudy brown. Tan head; good lacing. Aroma is sweet malt, dark cherry, oatmeal cookie, with hints of spice. Flavour is dark malt, cherry, with sour lambic notes and a nice crisp well-hopped finish. Beautiful Belgian Quad.

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2016 It pours a murky brown with a brown moderate head. It has a high level of fruit with includes raisins, fig, and dried cherries. There is also a rich, bready malt aroma as well. There are additional flavors of spice and alcohol. There are high fruit flavors blended with rich malt. The fruit flavors include raisins, plums, figs, and dried cherries. The malt is mostly bread. There is also a moderate level of spice and some alcohol. It has a moderate feel to it with a high level of carbonation. It has a moderately high level of bitterness with some alcohol warming. Overall this is a complex blended beer with the fruit flavors blending well with the malt and spices.

Deep mahogany with a quickly dissipating head. Great aroma, complex fruits, blackberries, cherry, and chocolate. Grape juice notes throughout, no carbonation. Lots of leather, tobacco, really well blended.
Poured from a bottle, San Diego. Sweet aroma of sugary malts. Yeasty, with sweet malt and some sweet fruitiness. Some bitters and an alcoholic lace.
Poured from a cold bottle. Plum brown color, off white head, nice lacing. Malt and citrus smell. Smooth malt, citrus and alcohol taste.

355ml bottle. Pours an orangey brown with a fluffy head reminiscent of Belgian abbey beers. Aroma is an initial wash of dark chocolate malts, hints of cherry and a large banana yeasty presence. Taste is also heavy with banana acting above a bed of forest fruits, dates and caramel. Nice creamy mouthfeel. This was good but yeast seemed to drown out the nuances.

750 ml bottle - thanks to Dennoman. Pours dark brown amber with a orangy yellowish head. Aroma of biscuits, roasty malts and plums (jam). A bit evolved. Full body with quite some bitterness at the end (not a regular Belgian quad but I liked it). Taste is cookies & honey + somel alcohol heat.

Bottle. Dark amber. Thin head. Heavy sweet alcohol nose. Sweet plum, raisins, alcohol taste. Barely notice the cherry if at all (perhaps a note on rhe finish and aftertaste). Fine after dinner sipper. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Lagerboy hand me down. Dark chestnut, with a nice head, thick lacing and moderate carbonation. Certainly a beer to sip, not recommended on a hot summer day by the lake. Cherrys are present along with heavy malts and a shit load of alc and flavours. I wouldnt have described this as my dream beer, but it is unique and certainly packs a punch.

355ml bottle. Fantastic, clear, ruby red colour with average, frothy, half-way lasting, minimally lacing, ochre-beige head. Spicy yeasty and fruity aroma, hints of dried fruit, raisin, plum, red berries; even though the fruity notes are wider, deeper, and more complex, the spicy, peppery notes stay longer at last, also some alcohol in the background. Taste is moderately sweet fruity with a minimally tart and moderately spicy yeasty counterweight; hints of dried fruit, raisin, plum, red berries and their parings, therefore also minimally dry; full body with sublime hints of alcohol.

Great belgian ale. Filled with lots of flavors and a nice smooth finish. Nice aroma and appearance. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz bottle pours a mahogany color. Aroma is malt, dark fruit, and a little alcohol. Taste is the same as aroma but the alcohol comes on too strong on the swallow and overpowers the fruity/sweet taste that you expect. Cant compete with the Belgians.

Ommegang Three Philosophers has a thin, fizzy, beige, root beer-style head, a brilliant, orange-brown appearance, lots of tight bubble streams, and a thin lacing sheen left behind. The aroma is of sweet, rich, brown bread, strong fruit aroma (such as fig or date), sugar, and caramel. Taste is of all those elements, with nougat, brandy wine, and some hop bitterness. Cherry flavor is present, but it is quite subdued. Mouthfeel is medium and prickly (from the carbonation), and Ommegang Three Philosophers finishes mostly dry, sweet, rich, and enjoyable. This is a outstanding sipper, and I recommend it in the strongest possible way. RJT

Pours amber with moderate head. Nose is dark fruits, spices. Taste is dark fruits, sweet, done spice, some cherry. Lingers a bit. Some alcohol burn. Complex flavors. Not bad
