12oz bottle poured into a tulip glass. Pours a reddish dark brown color with a medium tan head that leaves light lacing. Smells of raisins, dates, and cloves, and spices. Tastes of all the same things in the smell with slight cherries in the back end. Mouthfeel is medium silky and creamy with great carbonation. This is a very good quad with a lot of different flavors going on here. The high abv is noticeable but pretty well masked. I will definitely be drinking this again in the new future.

Fruity notes, fig, cherry. Very tangy. Almost has a oak flavor like a barrel aging or something. Not overly hot for the high abv. Mine was very bubbly. A good find at the 5 mile station in Grass Valley, Ca.

Pours a caramel color with a fig, date, and raisin aroma. Taste of alcohol comes through with a cherry aftertaste. A minor clove left on the palate after the swallow. An interesting beer with complex flavors.

Dark brown, garnet body with a giant thick, tight, white head. Beautiful. Aroma is huge, immediately cherry, raisins, plums, strawberry, a little chocolate. Taste is also fruit forward with the cherries and a nice warming alcohol feeling. A little boozy but definitely not over the top. Awesome quad.
12 oz bottle. This thing is packed with belguimness. Loads of belgian spices clove, some banana, dark fruit. Pretty sweet. This is admitantly not my style but good for what it is.

Definitely a sipper, not a guzzler. poured from a 12 oz bottle into a tulip glass. (need to find a proper chalice glass if im going to keep drinking these Belgian strong ales) Had a very deep amber or brown color with a thick off-white head. Aroma had alcohol, caramel, and fruits that I couldnt put my finger on. Taste is sweet and spicy with some bitterness.
The addition of kriek lambic gives this beer a unique blend of aroma, taste and palate... Yet it doesn't knock my socks off.

Mahogany dirk slightly translucent pour. Very big tan head. Aroma of booze, malt, cherries, raisins, nuts, caramel, and toffee. Tastes of leather, fruit, some tangy cherries. vegetable, celery. Thick palate with some acid to help thin it out. Some smooth yeast creaminess too.

10 oz. on tap. I dont see what the big deal is. Pours a mahogany color, translucent, with a small head that fades off, little islands of head in the beer. It has a sweet and astringent smell, not bad. Its a faithful reproduction of a belgian quad, but I dont like this recipe as much, its a little too sour, and Id prefer if it were sweeter. Its quality product, but I think its way overpriced at most places - theres no way Id pay $13 for a bomber. Its good, but not epic.

Bottle. Poured dark copper in color, clear with a small off white head. Aroma of malts and dark fruits and some alcohol too, but not in an unpleasant way. Taste also fruity raisin and cherries some malts in there too as well as some spices. Very nice beer.
Pours a reddish brown color with a toffee like head... goes down smooth and not too much burn... pretty solid quad from an american brewer

Bottle. Pours a deep hazy amber with light khaki head, good retention and walls of lacing. Aroma is stone fruit, booze, plum, sweet, esters, yeast. Flavor is fruity, plum, quite juicy, sweet, with mild to moderate alcohol in the finish. Moderate carbonation, medium body, crisp texture, and mildly warm finish. A well done dark belgian, though it is not quite as good as I recall.
Pours caramel brown with tan head. Smells of roasted malts and yeast. Tastes of alcohol and malts. Nice creamy and light carbonation.

Bottle. Not a particularly strong aroma, but raisin and cherry notes are there, but faint. Pours dark ruby red with large off-white head. Taste is raisin and sweet fruit to start with a tart cherry finish. Nice well balanced beer that's sweet at the beginning with a slightly sour on the finish.

355ml bottle, 2012 bottling. Unfiltered dark wood colour, moderate almond head. Figs, dates, dust, yeast, hints of sour cherries and sweetness in the aroma. Bottle. Brownish beer with a bronze tinge and a strongish off white head. The aroma is lightly spiced and roasted, and the flavour is roasted with a mellow degree of maltyness and spice. Overall a palatable beer but could be more complexly flavoured.

Appearance: Hazy, dark copper/reddish color with two fingers of off-white head that fades with a thick curtain of lace.

Aroma: Thick, syrupy sweetness, with molasses. raisin, ripe fruit and roasted malt in the background. Some estery alcohol mixes in and out.

Taste: Thick, creamy and sweet up front, with lots of ripe fruit and some yeastyness. The malt presence builds, with a nice toasted, nutty taste leading to the finish, where there's more cherry-syrup sweetness and a lingering caramel candy aftertaste.

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2013 Bottle poured in goblet. Pours a dark hazy brown with a thick, white foam head that dissipates to a thin cap that lingers. Soapy wet lacing slides down the glass. Mouth is full, slightly tart and bitter up front, then some slight sweetness from malts, lots of caramel and toffee along with dried fruit notes (those cherries are most notable on the back end) and some bakers chocolate near the finish. Nice.
Bottle at home. Pours black with generous khaki head. Aroma is sweet, dark fruits. Delicious malty taste with a touch of cherry and booze. Dry finish. A unique and tasty quad.

Vintage 2012.  Une belle robe ambrée.  Une mousse sublime et bien épaisse.  Au nez, des malts qui versent dans lopulence.    Des parfums fruités complexes et un alcool timide mais envoûtant.  Un souffle aigre-doux.  Une apparition épicée dans la deuxième partie de la dégustation.  Sur les papilles, des céréales maltées qui offrent tout un spectacle.  Ce mélange décadent laisse une place énorme aux fruits foncés.  Les cerises et les prunes se signalent davantage.  Lalcool connaît bien son rôle : sa force tranquille évite une montée des sucres.  En bouche, le liquide montre du caractère.  Son corps est tout en rondeur.  Son pétillement à la belge rend la texture crémeuse.  En finale, les notes maltées font rapidement place à des notes de fruits épicés et presque surets.  Tout à fait mon genre de discours philosophique.

The aroma combines the scents of caramel and roasted malts, vanilla, and basement aromas, and the appearance has a auburn color and a large off-white head that dissipated quickly. The taste is mildly umami, slightly sweet, and a touch sour; also, the palate fuses a full body, creamy texture, soft carbonation, and a long bold finish.

Bouteille de 75oml. capsulée avec bouchon de liège. Bière brune ambrée foncée qui mousse le temps de crier ciseau. Le nez est sucré, du malt sucré, du toffee, une réduction de moût, des figues et raisins secs. La bouche est sucrée, lalcool se fait discret. Une touche dacidité rend cette bière plus digeste. Les saveurs de prunes, des cerises, de cassonade, de figues et de raisins secs. Cette bière est superbe. Une bière pour philosophes qui me fait réfléchir à la question suivante; Quest-ce quil y a dans la tête de quelquun qui compare cette bière avec une Triple Karmeliet ?

12oz bottle poured at home.

This is one of the first beers that got me into craft beer years ago. Its a wonderful Belgium Quad with a unique taste. The aroma is amazing, not sure why anyone would score low on this one. It smeels like a sweet belgium with a hint of cherry...fantastic!! This is a Belgium cherry ale, so no one should be surprised with the slight cherry smell and slight cherry flavor.

Pours a dark carmel colot with a great thick head. You can def taste the alcohol (9.7%) and it has a decent amount of carbonation which I think works well with this beer. Taste is a little sweet and well balanced with a hint of cherry. Great beer.

Draft at Cedar Point.  Pours a deep murky brown with fluffy tan head.  Nose of dark fruits - cherries, plum, figs, some sweet and roasted malts and a little spice.  Full bodied and a sweet finish with a little burn.  Probably my favorite beer from Ommegang.

On tap at Barleys Brewhaus on 3/21/2013.  Pours a hazy reddish brown with a two inch head and nice lacing.  Aroma is dark fruit, licorice, malts, and Belgian yeast.  Taste is dark fruit, chocolate,molasses, black pepper, and Belgian yeast.  Very delicious.

Pleasant but mostly tame malt aroma. Taste is pretty balanced, and I find the strong carbonation hinders the overall impression, but there is a remarkable aftertaste which lingers on the tongue - mostly wood/cherry/raisin which form a distinct identity. Would definitely try again, but probably not in a hurry.

A nice quad. Very typical of the Trappist method. A little too carbonated for me but all the usual attributes of the type. Its no Rochefort 10 or St Bernardus but its as close as an American brewery can get. Would buy again.

750ml bottle. Pours a slightly hazy brownish red color covered by a dense one finger of off white head. Aromas are filled with dark fruits and cherries. Taste is of sweet dark fruits, cherries, caramel, and Belgian yeast spice.

Big fan if this beer.  Very similar to a triple karmeleit. Very fruity and extremely flavorful and really smooth. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Smells like caramel and cotton candy and warm candied fruit with a hint of bubble gum. Brown with foamy cream head that dissipated and light lacing. Tastes spicy and tart and dry.  Dry finish- almost like aspirin.
From the bottle poured a lovely dark amber brew with a light white head. Rich aromas and flavors of malt, and bubble gum with floral notes. Full bodied and delicious.

Bottle - 2011 - Brown sugar, molasses, dark fruits and yeast.  Maroon, surprisingly clear with a rich medium brown head.  Boozy and sweet, with dark fruits coming out.  Alcohol is not very well balanced and dominates a bit too much form my taste.
UPDATED: NOV 6, 2013 Draft pour at Sybarite Pig in a tulip. Hazy amber. Thick head. Thick lace. Aroma of Belgian yeast, apricot, cherry. Sweet taste with cherries, yeast and leather.
My three philosophies about this beer: it tasted like an old man dipped his plums in beer, the aroma smelled like old man plums, dont buy this

Pretty standard Belgian. Smooth, drinkable, not too much of an alcohol bite. Good stuff. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a hazy auburn-tinted brown. Aroma is strong and sweet. Dark fruit...raisins and cherries. Flavor is everything Id hoped for and more. Blast of sweet maltiness with a study table of hop bitterness for it to sit on. Complex full flavors of plums and cherries make this taste very brandy-esque. This is unquestonably fantastic. As good as any beer Ive ever had.
Smells very sweet hits of cherries and spices. Pours a dark muddy brown tastes like nice quad at first with hints of spices. Finishes very sweet. Good stuff

2012 version, brewed with 5% Leifmans Kriek in this one as opposed to Lindemans in the pic.... I much prefer lindemans but............

A: Looks amazing. Reddish brown. perfect tan head with great retention.
S: A little too musty for me, but pretty balanced. Some great notes of cherry (duh!) grape, a hint of malt.
T: Like the smell. Hint of cherry, too much must for me. Very well balanced though and I found myself easily making my way through the beer. 
P: Medium body. Delicate....
Overall this is a pretty solid beer although far from perfect. Too much must for my tastes but there are some great fruit notes that really put this above other Belgian styles.

2013/02/10 - Pours a cloudy deep amber/brown color with a creamy beige head that laces nicely. Aroma is cherries, plums, raisins and a touch of cocoa. Taste is cherries, cocoa, toffee and alcohol with a slightly metallic aftertaste. Sticky mouthfeel with perfect carbonation. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Vintage 2011, Bottle from Safeway, Eugene. Pours a deep, dark reddish brown, almost opaque. Moderate amount of off-white head. Aroma is stone fruit, cherries and plums, maybe a bit of candi sugar as well. Body is fairly lively, finish is uneventful, slight bitterness and little warming. Just may be that this bottle is a little past its prime, as I remember this beer as being a bit more eventful. I may revise this when I get a chance to buy it somewhere else, but for the moment, it is what it is.
Bottle, opaque, hazy brown color with a big beige head. Aroma is some phenolics with clove. Flavor is fruity (plums, raisins) bit a bit methalic aftertaste. Palate is full, warming and a bit sticky.

Bold full body. Light fruity aroma. Nice amber color. One of the best Belgium beers out there

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours dark ruby with a fluffy white head that dissipates to a little lacing. Nose isn't terribly appealing, with some sour cherry and earthy funk. Taste is strong on cherry with some underlying sweetness and a yeasty finish. Alcohol is well masked. Palate is well-balanced with a soft, full mouthfeel and an appropriate level of carb. Good but not as good as I remembered it. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Excellent beer. This beer really delivers on several levels. Although it has a dry finish the malt complexity really shines: Cocoa, caramel balance well on the palate. Hops are subdued & really didnt get a lot of cherry from the 2% Kriek added to the beer. Well done.
Ive had this beer so many times, but had not entered a rating yet. Bananas, yeasty, bready malts. Thick and chewey. One of my favourite belgian style beers - not from Belgium.
Great brewery and great beer. Works in all seasons for me. Not too sweet for the ABV but just enough.

Aroma of black cherry, yeast and spice. Dark brown, almost red. Substantial head on first pour. Tastes sweet like cherries with some candied malt and zesty yeast. Medium bodied, very filling. Dont remember the cherry component being so profound.
Malty full favored slightly sweet with a hint of cherry. Extremely good overall. A sure pick.
Caramel and malt on the nose, dark fruit as well. Taste is on the sweet side, plums, candy, brown sugar. A tad too sweet.

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown-ish red with a think tan head. Aroma is strongly dark stone fruits with a warm alcohol scent beneath the fruits. The fruit is even more evident in the taste. Plum and dark cherries. There is also a nice aftertaste of warming alcohol. Very smooth and drinkable feel. My first foray in quads, and Im not disappointed.
Very complex, however kind of stale although fruity. Sediment is present even though settled.
Dark mahogany with pale, creamy head. Nose is dark cherries, soda, licorice. Moderate carbonation. Alcohol taste, dark fruits, brown sugar sweetness. Dry finish.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2013 Pours brownish with a burnt orange tint, very light khaki fizz. The aroma is sweet and fruity with a light grain aroma. The flavors are rich and sweet with fermented fruit and lightly musty toasted bread. Apple cider with out the spice, light pear and a little plum make the fruity depth very full. Very solid brew with enough sweetness to carry pairings with a main course or dessert.
Nutty aroma and fruity taste. Poured from a 750ml. Smooth on the palate. Will drink again

Lovely garnet colored liquid topped by a large bubbly beige head.  Intense dried fruit nose has notes of apricots, currants, plums and dark cherries. Complex dried fruit malt flavor has notes of burnt caramel and cherry coke.  Very little hops evident. This is mostly fruit and malt. Some yeast invests and prune-like notes as well. Noticeable alcohol flavor. Drink this slow and savor it, preferably close to a cozy fire place.

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2013 On tap at St Augustiines on The Drive. A dark amber color. Very sweet and fruity, less hoppy. Tastes of dried fruits and jams. Not so hoppy. Prefer more hops, but a great beer at the same time.
Copper pour with dense eggy head. Malty sweet nose. Cherry, Wood, Booze. warming boozy bittersweet finish. Very strong and complex. 3.7
Nuts, toast, roasty, floral. Great smooth drinking beer. My all time favorite..........

Pours a dark, murky brown with a beige creamy head - good retention and lacing.  Smells of dates, plums, and raisins - big caramel malt as well.  Tastes nondistinctive - meld of the fruits and malt that isnt unattractive, but is not very attractive either.  Feels medium to full with noticeable carbonation .  Good beer, but not something I would grab again necessarily

Bottle.  Appearance:  copper red with huge fluffy off-white head that quickly dissipates.  Aroma:  dried fruits, big gooey sweet caramel, prunes, raisins, dark cherries, banana, burnt sugars.  Taste: dark cherries, sweet caramel, dried apricot (?), raisins, some banana.  Mouthfeel: mildly creamy, medium bodied with medium carbonation.  Overall: wow!  Havent had this beer since before appreciating craft beer.  Its really good.  Very pronounced fruity ester character with sweet caramel...amazed I havent tried this in this long.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2013 Appearance: dark rich amber, almost brown, tan head, not that big

Aroma: molasses, plum, rich, chocolate,

Taste: plum, hint of chocolate, molasses, sweet, alcohol

Palate: pretty carbonated, leaves a alcohol aftertaste, 

Overall: very complex brew, has a Trappist feel to it, can taste the alcohol which I consider a flaw

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottled September 6, 2012.
Appearance: The body is dark and somewhat murky with a brown hue, the way I like my quads. The head is thin and dense, but boy does it last. It settles into a thick tan coating even 5 minutes later.
Aroma: The nose is complex with a blend of flavors, banana, toffee, cherries, bready malts and a light spice. 
Taste: Big and complex, this beer begs to be sipped. The intro is very malty with dark fruits with more flavor on the intro than most beers have by the finish. The mid-taste adds cherries, brown sugar, while introducing some banana and cloves spice. The finish gets a bit bready, a tad chalky, with light cloves. This is complex and very nice to sip on.
Palate: Medium bodied to thick with a light carbonation to it.
Overall: This beer is a fantastic and complex very easily available beer. This should be on every beer drinkers list of must-try beers. One thing to note is that the yeast profile makes this very easy to tell its an Ommegang beer, whether thats good or bad is up to you.

Bottle: Dark brown pour with large khaki head.  Aroma is yeasty with licorice, cherry, brown sugar and just a dab of allspice.  Flavor is  cola, licorice, dried cherry and soft molasses with some belgian yeast funk. Palate is high carbonation tingle in the mouth mixed with some mild syrupy sweetness, finishing with an alcohol warmth. Drinking this at the start of SFBeerweek since I couldnt make the opening fest and coming off a cold which has left my taste buds deficient but reviving. From what I could taste, Ill be revisiting this beer it was quite good.

One of my favorite beers. Sweet and light. This is a drink with great flavor and texture. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Deep red and white head. Aroma is very sweet with notes of dark fruit and rum. Tastes fruity and deep and rum. With cherries and sweetness. Medium body, this is awesome.

Bottle. 2012 vintage. Pours deep red, clear with no haziness. Head is a light tan. Aroma is pleasant. The initial taste is quite good, but the cherry overtones are an acquired taste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Look: Dark brown body, beige head. Smell:  Toasted malts, mild cherries, spicy yeast, some citric acidity, faint alcohol. Taste: Follows the aroma step by step. Chocolate covered cherries inside a toasted cinnamon roll. Sour notes but not lip puckering. Bitter chocolate finish. Feel: Medium body, nice tight carbonation. Overall: A fine brew that is to me "misplaced" in category. I should re-review an older bottle in the future. Might be "too fresh" to enjoy thoroughly. Right now the brew stands out like a high alcohol Dubbel or BSDA. For a Quad it falls short. This bottle lacks complexity and depth. The flavors seem to be muddled together so nothing really stands out and says excellence. Like I said before its a fresher review but it still feels like Im drinking a higher gravity version of their Abbey Dubbel. Still this is worth a shot.
Not satasfied with this. I thought it would be better. Very potent but not that tasty.

Pours reddish brown with a tan head that lingers nicely, aroma is figs, plums, leather, chocolate, tobacco, and cherries. Really nice. taste is sweet but not overly sticky on the tongue. not really dry mouthfeel but not too sticky. A really nice beer that Id be happy to have again.
Nice Belgian Ale, over all a great looking and tasting Abt amplified with a cherry finish that balance the alcohol. Kick back and enjoy!

Pours a murky brown. Aromas are classic quad: dried fruits booze and some hops, malty caramel too. Also a nice sour cherry aroma. Very good. Tastes are sweet dried fruits and malts with an underlying sourness from the kriek. A little boozy at the end. I loved this beer.

Pours amber red with a medium off white head. Aroma is Belgian yeast with some faint funk. Taste is definitely Belgian with some fruityness and yeast. Not my favorite style, but this represents it well.
This beer is incredibly enjoyable. It has subtle cherry flavor and almost no after taste. Great beer to kick back and drink.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2016 First go at rating a quad. Very strong aroma. Very sweet smelling. MAlts and sugar. Taste is very malty, very sweet, and large alcohol presence. Warms the back of the throat. A little too sweat at times but very tasty. Good desert beer. 12 oz takes a little while to make it through. Now to IC light, go pens!

2011 Edition:
Fantastic. Smooth deep cherry notes. Etoh warming but pleasant.

Bottle. 2007 vintage. Sampling session at Leftys Notes from Nov. 12, 2011. Dark ruby color. Sourish initial, with raisins and prunes. Very malty, some licorice.  Oxidized? Not my "dream beer." But quite drinkable, all the same.
Bottle shared with bros somewhere in the middle of Florida. very nice aroma, taste is sweet, slight cherry - very balanced and easy to drink...

Pours a dark copper color that lets light get through on the edges.  Foamy beige bubbly head that disappears and doesnt leave any lacing. Aroma is yeast, alcohol, a hint of chocolate and, of course, cherries.  Taste is the same and a surprisingly clean mouthfeel. Really good beer. Curious to see how this would develop with some aging.

Pours a hazy copper-brown from the bottle with fluffy tan head and good lacing. Aroma of dark fruits, cherries, and some other sweet malts. Taste follows, let it warm to open up a bit. Alcohol well hidden, good american quad.

Dark amber color with a finger of head with decent lacing.  Aroma is not strong but smells sweet with faint cherry and caramel.  Alcohol is apparent and gives it some spice.  Light cherry and spice give a taste red licorice.  Warms and coats the mouth well.  Not as complex as some Belgians but nice drinkable.  I'd try again.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
This is my favorite beer of all time. Hands down. Extremely complex with raisins, butterscotch.

Three Philosophers pours a mahogany red color.  Deep and luscious with four fingers of foam that really last.  Off the nose is grass and a subtle sweetness, cherry.  Complex.  Excellent retention and lacing.   The first sip has no alcohol taste, a little spice and a bit of warmth.  Creamy and balanced.  The body is perfectly carbonated and soft. Medium body.  The cherry from the Kriek is exquisitely stated.  Little bit of a dry finish to remind you that the hops are in there.  This beer is truly "cordial." Ommegang is near perfect as usual.

2012 bottle from giant eagle. Great pour with pretty great off white head. Sweet nose with cherry hints. Smooth initial taste with sweetness up front. Sour malt in the middle with the sweet cherry cutting through at the end. A potent beer and puts some hair on your chest. Or your moms. She's dirty anyway. 

---Rated via my mouth

Bottle sample at a tasting at Dancing Camel. Thanks davidcohen. Pours hazy reddish brown with tan head. A little cherry aroma with sour notes, alcohol and flowers. Slightly sour, sweet and yeasty. Very carbonated and a little fruity finish.

Clear dark ruby color with light brown foam head. Aroma dominated by alcohol and more a wine than a beer aroma. Taste bit too sweet, strong alochol and barley, do not actually like the taste. Aftertaste is long lingering, but not outstanding. (Houston 201301)
Nice deep copper color with a full tan head and a nice sweet aroma with the hint of cherry.  Slghtly bitter taste with a crisp finish that hints the additional alcohol content.
Sweet cherry taste, small head, strong flavors. Drinking something this sweet doesnt feel like a beer. It is good and full bodies, but I can only drink this one in small portions.
Great aroma on this beer.  The sweet cherry is very pronounced.  Small head.  Color is perfect.  Flavor is well finished with strong sweetness.  Alcohol is certainly there.

Dark red/brown in appearance.  Aroma is malty, with dark fruits, leather, and some alcohol.  Very complex and pleasant.   The flavor is good but cant quite live up to the aroma.  Taste is sweet up front, also a little spicy yeastiness, into a more leathery, earthy finish with minor bitterness.  Complex and well-done overall.

Pours murky brown with small tan head.  Aroma was of sour cherries, dark fruits and oak.  Taste follows the aroma with a slight sourness.  It has a medium body and was really pretty smooth and easy to drink for such a strong, flavorful beer.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2014 I had to update this review. I have had different tastes from the multiple bottles. The good stuff review is in"I opened the bottle and could smell its wonderful aroma. This beer not only tasted great, but left a cherry after taste in my mouth. I loved this beer. This is the best beer I have ever tasted". These later bottles have been mediocre tasting and lacked the strong cherry flavor. I was not the only one who noticed the difference in taste. These bottles are inconsistent.

2011 vintage. Poured into an Ommegang tulip.

Pours a murky reddish brown with a solid two finger tan head. Great head retention from the abundant carbonation.

Tart cherries on the aroma along with other dark fruits. Some licorice along with wood and a faint whiff of alcohol. Some sherry qualities as well.

The flavor, to me, is a little bit of a let-down. Some dark cherry along with a bit of an oxidized sherry character that clashes a little bit. Lots of dark fruit; dates and figs and a little wood. Alcohol is present throughout and I am a little disappointed it has not mellowed in all this time. Thick, syrupy mouthfeel makes this one a sipper.

Overall, not as good as I remember this beer being when I had it several years ago. It just seems like the flavors dont meld well. A decent beer but I will probably skip over it for some Belgian quads in the future.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2013 1 Jan 2013, bottle. pinkish/brown, faintly cloudy, steady bubbles. nose is cherries, granola, and alcohol. thin body and moderately fizzy. cherries, bready yeast, some alcohol. very balanced. nice.
Dark amber/brown. Soapy head. Aroma of belgian yeast and spices. Full body. Fruity.

Bottle, 2009 vintage, shared at gnoffs mead tasting. Pours ruby red brownish with a small off white diminishing head. Aroma is raisins fidges sweet floral fruity and tropical fruits. Flavor is astringent dry sourish fruity vinous a bit phenolic and bitter. Finishes bitter a bit pungent and fruity.
Caught off guard by the fruitiness of this beer - cherries front and center - but in a good way. A dangerously delicious strong ale.

Aroma: dark malt with a hit of cherry.
Appearance: beautiful reddish brown.
Taste: not your ordinary cloyingly sweet quad. Figs with dark cherries at the end.
Palate: medium to heavy mouthfeel.
Overall: great beer. Different than most quads because of the cherries but also because it is not overly sweet.

Cloudy tawny with an aroma of dark fruits and a bit of sweetness. Palate follows aroma with a hint if the cherries it's aged on 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Strong cherry flavor come out in this Belgian quad.                                             

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a beautiful ruby brown with a substantial khaki head that dissipated quick leaving lacing. 
Smells like a quad should, but with the added element of cherry in the backbone. 

 Tart Cherry surrounds the other flavors delivered to your tongue. Malt, yeast, caramel, figs, and pretty high level of carbonation.

Good stuff!

Pours dark ruby red into the brewery stemmed glass.  Aroma of dark fruit and yeast.  Excellent lacing of the tan head that lingers around for a long time.  Complex mouthfeel of plum licorice with perfect hop to malt balance.  The alcohol is not well detected.  Filling finish.

Bière ambrée, troublée par les multiples sédiments en suspension, alors que la mousse se résorbe en un mince voile à la surface. Odeur sucrée, surette, de par la cerise et fruitée par dautres fruits imprécis. Goût de malt et de levure avec des pointes acidulées. Lalcool se font bien dans le décor. Quoique jai bien apprécié ce nectar, jai éprouvé de la difficulté à cerner ses particularités. Est-ce que cest parce que cest discret, bien réussi ou alors javais de grandes attentes? Merci A-A. (Embout. 16 jan12) (474-021212)

Bottle shared by Steve!  Dark brown pour, a little carbonatiion and an aroma of slightly sweet honey.  Flavor is sweet malty honey, rich candi sugar and malt.  Enjoyable and well done beer worthy of a cork and cage.

Poured from a 750ml bottle found in an Ommegang 3-Pack. Served in a Boulevard tulip glass. Paired with the left eye of a Carvel Cookie Puss ice cream cake.

Pleasant orange-brown color, somewhat lively off-white head.  Big malts and caramel on the nose, but cherries come through more as the beer warms up. The taste doesnt quite live up to the very promising aroma, but its still very refined and enjoyable. Sneaky spice notes.Like any good quad it strikes a fine balance between thick malt and complex dark fruit. Its not very alcohol-forward; whats lost in warmth is made up for by a surprisingly crisp texture (for the style) . The finish is good and tight.

This works very well as an easy-to-find Quad and as an introduction to the style. The flavors arent gut-punchingly huge or brilliantly nuanced, but good brewing technique shines through in every other aspect.  Nearing the top tier of American Quads.

The beer is a pretty shade of ruby with an inch of fizzy, beige head. A lot of cherries in the aroma, followed by Belgian yeast. Smells malty. The flavor is fairly sweet, with prominent cherry juice. Yeast takes a backseat to the sweet cherry flavor. Booze emerges more as I progress through the bottle. Overall, a good beer and one I would have again. That said, this is best only occasionally and in small doses. Cherry flavor becomes a bit cloying midway through. Interesting and worth a try.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-28-2012

Color is an interesting reddish-orange.  Head is enormous, and the lacing is very good also.  Aroma is delightful and complex - candi sugar, caramel malts, toffee, brown sugar, vinous, yeast, fruitcake, doughy, nutmeg, some dark fruit.  Very Christmasy.  Flavor - wow, lots going on here.  Most of what I described in the aroma can be found.  Could hide the booze and acid better - this is no Rochefort, and theres a little too much sweet malt along with something a little diacetyl - but still, nice quad.
Strong cherry aroma with mild cherry taste.  Slightly sour with a medium body. Smooth finish, overall pretty good

Bottle at BA Buffalo bottleshare. Pours purpleish amber hue with a small off white head. nose of malt, dark fruits, and booze. taste is balanced if not sweet. fruits follow mid way and lead into the boozy finish. body is a bit chewy. this is not the first time sampled, but first time rated. it really makes me wonder how my 2011 and early 2012 bottle are aging. I will wait till I pick up a 2013 before I find out.

Dark amber/brown color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, dark fruit, floral, & spice; Flavor of sweet malt, yeast, dark fruit (notably plums & cherries), raisons, and spice; Nicely balanced and complex; The alcohol is fairly well hidden; Really good.
Excellent, excellent beer.  Aroma is well propelled, great yeast undernote.  Smooth on the palate.  The cherry taste is definitely there, but the overall taste is definitively Belgian.

This is unbelievable! For 10% ABV this is smooth and complex, everything is so balanced. Cherries are very prevalent but once again not out of control. The rating speaks for itself, this is near perfection!! GET IT!

From a 75 cl bottle shared at home, vintage 2011,  Pours a cloudy dark brown with an off white head.  Aroma of dark cherries.  Flavor has hints of cherries, caramel and candy sugar.  Bittersweet finish.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2014 Pours a transparent dark brown with good off white head and some lace.  Aroma is dark dried fruits, cherry, caramel and dark sugars/syrups. Flavour is dark dried fruits, sour cherries, rich maltiness, and almost a molasses characteristic. Good beer!

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2014 Pours a clear dark red with a small head and it leaves a very small off white ring. Smell is sweet caramel and booze with a bunch of added spice. Taste is caramel, spice and lots of booze. This beer needs to be aged a bit. Had a 2011 version in 2014 and it?s far better than a 2012 version in 2012.
bottle from my wife.  mahogany pour with thin head.  dark fruits, bread, banana aroma.  silky mouth,  fig, raison, warm.  rich, smooth malts.  pretty awesome.
Strong palate and bold flavor. Malt and cherry prefaces undertones of syrup. Can be a bit acidic.
750ml->stem.  Amber withlight head.  Fruit and malt aroma.  Taste is fruit, tart, yeast, and malt.  Complex and very satisfying.
A bit tinny at first, but that could be the taps. After a while it warmed up and had the aroma of grapes. Quite a nice quad.

750 bottle.  Reddish brown pour with soapy lace.  Mild cherry aromas blended with fruits followed by malt.  Cherry stands out first, but its not aggressive, with a mix of dark fruits and tartness followed by brown sugars.  All of this is well balanced. Clean mild finish with some booze.  Overall the taste is subtle and not that complex, but I still like it.
Pours dark with a heavy head.  As expected smells strong of cherries.  Has a bold flavor of cherries and oak.  Pretty well rounded beer.

750 mL bottle: Appearance I a dark brown with large, slow fading off white head. Aroma is slightly yeasty with hints of malt. Taste is somewhat sweet and malty with complex fruit esters and some yeast showing through also.
Bottle. Pours a cloudy and dark brown with a moderate head. Very strong and yeasty smell with that odd sweetness to it. Taste is oddly sweet, too. Very heavy. Not a fan.
Deep mahogany with a thin lacing. Spices, oak, dark fruits, cherries, and doughy malts. Crisp, boozy, and a long finish.

Pours a rich dark auburn. Nose is yeasty with sweet cherries. Nicely carbonated with a smooth mouthfeel.  Taste is most prominently cherries, with other dark fruits and oak as well. Pretty boozy with a yeasty finish that lingers pleasantly. One of my favorites; Id be happy to drink this every week.

Great dark amber color. Tons of lacing. Small amount of nose but good taste and palate. Dark fruit and spice. More of a one and done for me but tasty overall. Impressed overall by ommegang beers so far.

Smell isnt super potent but the taste has some sourness and a little oak bitterness at the end. Pours reddish amber with good lacing. A little weird on the aftertaste without a huge palate. Not bad but not super great on palate or taste. Tap at Blue Monk.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2014 Pours a deep opaque brown. The nose is faint cherries. The palate is more unctuous than the Abbey Ale and smoother with the cherry taste coming through. The hops are very slight. The buzz is immediate. Another great Belgian from Ommegang.
Bottle - Deep amber with ok head. Sweet yeasty aroma with hint of cherry. Dry and bubbly, tastes like the nose.  All in all, pretty good Belgian.

2011 vintage. PKG ON 06/06/11, BEST BY 06/2016. 750ml into a Chimay goblet.

A - Pours a clear dark red/brown body. Excellent two finger light khaki head forms. Very dense and creamy in appearance, a swirl produces some nice lacing and retention as well as some alcohol legs.

S - Cherries initially, then comes a wave of rich malts, caramel, dark candied fruits, toffee, brown sugar and spicy yeast. A touch of warming alcohol on the finish. Smooth and rich.

T - Ripe cherries, caramelized dark fruits, oak, brown sugar, and a yeasty finish. Incredibly delicious and smooth with all the right Quad notes. The finish has a light lactic twang, almost in the form of oxidation...but its very pleasant and complimentary. Mouth feel is creamy and medium bodied with the alcohol very well hidden. 

O - This is hands down the best American made quad I have ever tired. It really does compete with the big Belgian quads, and in my opinion is right up at the top. This beer is near perfect.

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2012 Cloudy mahogany with an big off-beige head and tons of lacing. The aroma is dark fruits, caramel, figs, malt, cherries, banana peel, spices, a bit of earthy hops, and some wood -- so is the taste, which is adequately sweet, but a bit more bitter and mineraley than Id expected. Alcohol is felt throughout.

Hazy dark amber with a beige head. Aroma of dried cherries and stone fruit with a little malt. Taste is sweet but not overwhelming - some brown sugar, fig, cherry. Finish is a alcohol and yeast. Good stuff.

A good beer, but could use a little more complexity. Not much detectable aroma, but some slight cherry on the nose. Heavy cherry flavor, but not overly sweet, which is well done. Nothing really stands out here but the cherry and it is somewhat one-dimensional. Excellent dark red color and perfect mouthfeel. Slight alcohol warmth. Good, but won't go out of my way for it. Doesn't fit the build of a quad that I expect. Dial down the cherry, please.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

750 ml bottle into chalice, 2011 vintage.  Pours lightly hazy dark reddish brown color with a nice 1-2 finger fairly dense khaki head with great retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers.  Some spotty foamy lacing clings to the glass.  Aromas of big apple, pear, raisin, prune, toast, toffee, chocolate, biscuit, cherry, molasses, earth, and yeast spices.  Fantastic aromas with great balance and complexity.  Taste of big raisin, prune, pear, pepper, earth, toast, molasses, cherry, toffee, chocolate, herbal, and yeast spices.  Lightly tart earthiness on the finish; with lingering notes of dark fruits, molasses, toast, cherry, pepper, herbal, earth, and yeast spices on the finish for a good bit.  Great flavor balance and complexity; with a nice balance of maltiness/yeast spiciness.  No cloying flavors on the finish at all.  Medium-high carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a creamy and fairly slick mouthfeel that is nice.  Alcohol is very well hidden with only a small warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is a fantastic Quad!  Great flavor balance and complexity; and very smooth to sip on.  Highly enjoyable.

750 ml bottle to snifter. Looks good; a hazy amber-brown with light beige lacing. Smells solid; dark fruit and cherry juice. Tastes like it smells, only better, with notes of caramel. Alcohol is nicely subdued. Good on the palate too. Nice.

Unfortunately the place I had it at didnt have a chalice or goblet so I was stuck using a regular pint glass. Pours a dark reddish brown color with medium head. The aroma was nice but not as good as other quads Ive had. Taste was a sweet fruityness with noticeable alcohol and slight bitter finish. Overall a wonderful beer.
Very smooth beer with a strong lingering maltiness. More carbonation than I expected, which helps to balance the sweetness. Very good and unique beer.
Dark brown with tan head, that disappeared shortly after tapping.  Has that wonderful Belgian aroma and full mouth maltiness.  Its a "big" beer for sure.

Bottle sample.
Murky brown color with a nice beige head.
Nose full of chocolate covered cherries and caramelized bananas.
Slightly tart and pleasant flavor, with caramel malts and dark fruits. Low bitterness.
Full body, creamy, complex and nice.
Dark red and with a frothy beige bubbly body. Dark malts, peppery dried fruit and dry yeast. Some alcohol. Bit sharp in the beginning. Sticky sweetness. (On my Florida trip)
I thought this would be sweeter and with some cherry undertones. It is neither. Its somewhat sour/bitter. More bitter than other quads. Prefer other quads over this.
This beer is good....not great. I didnt pour it down the sink like the Ranger out of San Antone. Bitter finish that lasts a little longer than needed. Flyin Monk Quadruple is better.
Sweet and full bodied at the start.  Slightly bitter on the finish and then a little sour.  Good but not great.
(bottle) cloudy amber colour with a small tan head; rich spicy aroma; complex dry flavour with long light bitter finish
Not a heavy quad drinker so the high score more or less reflects he surprise.  Overall this beer is bold, sweet, and very unique

Dark ruby red in the Rochefort chalice. Thin white ring on the outside. Lots of bubbles. Yeast floaties. Cherries, plums, ripe fruit, raisins. More cherries in the finish. Classic quad complexity. Definitely share this bomber. 650 of 9.8% is crazy. Overall: Really good, smooth. A little on the lighter side for a quad. 081412

Three Philo is one of my favorite beers of all time. Omegang is one of the few breweries that can do fruit style beers. Just the perfect amount of fruit hint.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
750 ml bottle pours a dark brown color with a tan head.  Aromas of cherry, fig, dark malt.  Full bodied just a great beer
This is my favorite beer! Stronger, dark, creamy, with a chocolatey taste. Not too heady, long finish. The seller is that its absolutely delicious. Usually on the expensive side, but worth it.

2010 vintage.  Cherries come through on the nose, but are a little stllted.  Not as fresh as it could have been and I think this has to do with the age of the beer (importers label has faded to nothing)
It wasnt bad at all.  Lots of cherry taste, and very strong.  i would definitely try again
Pours murky brown with two finger head. Smell fig and raisin, plum and cherry, earthy. Taste bittersweet red fruit, fig. Full bodied, mud like viscosity. Ok.

12 oz bottle pours hazy brown with a off white head.  Aroma of malt, dried fruit and spice.  Taste is the malts, sweet and spices.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2011 Three Philosophers. 750ml bottle to snifter. Pours a cloudy dark brown with medium to high carbonation and a moderate tan head that fades quickly leaving laces on the glass. Nose is tart with spicy belgian yeast, fruity, cherry. Fruity and tart tart palate, balanced nicely; taste of alcohol is present accompanied by the warm feeling. Medium bodied with a slight syrup mouthfeel but not as heavy. Finish is lasting and sour spicy belgian yeast and alcohol is present. Great ale about as complex as it gets.

Bottle.  Pours a reddish caramel color.  Nice head with fine bubbles.  Aroma of sweet caramel malts and a touch of fruit.  The flavor has similar notes, but is richer.  Caramel and brown sugar hit the front of the palate, giving way to a somewhat subtle cherry flavor.  The finish is a bit sour, which doesnt quite work for me.  Rich mouthfeel.  An interesting take on a Belgian Quad, but lacks the complexity of many of the originals.

Cherry smell is subtle. Overall sweet fruit smell. Head dissipates quick, Not the greatest lacing. Almost a cherry cough syrup taste underneath the typical Belgian yeasty quad taste. Light bitterness. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap. Pours dark brown wig a ruby tint and thick, creamy beige head; short retention and spare lacing. Aroma is cherries, cookie and caramel malts, figs, raisins, booze, faint floral hops, and yeast. Flavor is sweet malt forward followed by strong dark fruit esters; booze undertones with a dry, sweet finish. Medium/full body, low carbonation, and medium warmth.

Pours a cloudy amber with thin tan head. Lacing is nice. Aroma is of malt, cherry and citrus. Taste very nice with strong cherry flavor though out. Malty, boozy aftertaste works well with the cherries. You can taste the 9.8% abv and it works.

750ml bottle pours a hazy reddish brown with a decent beige head and good lacing. Smells of cherries and Belgian yeast.  Aroma is pretty much the same, with some spices, alcohol, and other fruits.  Taste is sweet.  Mouthfeel is lively due to carbonation.  Body is at least medium.  A very good quad, but not quite the best.  The high ABV keeps me thinking of Monty Pythons "Philosophers Song" (Rene Descartes was a drunken fart: I drink therefore I am" etc.)

A-- Poured a deep, dark ruby color. Got a massive head that slowly died down to film. Left spotty lacing on the sides of the glass. not much head retention on swirling. 

S-- Candied black cherry mixed in with some bread. Cherry fruitcake might be a good description on this. Slightly syrupy quality in the nose, still quite nice though. 

T-- Black cherry. Not candied at all. really sort of thin in a way. lacking the bread quality that it needs. 

M-- Get a slight amount of bread in the mouth but this is about cherry and more cherry. Starts as black cherry and changes to red ruby sweet cherry with small bit of sourness. Not that it is infected or anything like that. Finishes as sweet cherry. Has a bit of an alcohol burn to finish but the cherry sweetness does hide it a bit. 

O-- to me this is still the bar standard for US Quads. Like the addition of cherry to this, as it adds a fruity dimension to this. Thin taste besides cherries but the mouth does pick up the beer.

Bottle from Whole Foods, Union Square, reviewed on the train from NYC to Montreal - 03/03/12.
Poured into a pint glass to a mahogony brown colour with reddish tinges and a good finger or more of beige head.
Sweet malt aroma, yeast, candied fruits, dark fruits, cherry, and toffee.
Tastes as nose with less on the yeast front a little spice and nuttiness.
Medium bodied with moderate carbonation and the alcohol was well disguised.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: 2011 bottle.  Pours a slightly cloudy dark amber-orange color with lots of bubbly head that quickly fades.  Nice aroma of rich cherry syrup, belgian spicy yeast, and caramel malt.  Other fruit seems to be there too like raspberries, strawberries, and oranges.  Taste has a nice fruity sweetness that fades as the belgian character takes over.  High, fizzy carbonation and medium body fits nicely.  Finish has lots of belgian yeast character.  A really nice fruity quad.
Nice quad. Beautiful color. Gets bigger but loses its balance as it warms up. There are better quads out there, but this is definitely worthy.
Had in a bottle, very strong flavored beer it makes it difficult to bring out a good description of this beer. overall i was not that impressed

12 ounce bottle.  Aroma - Abundant, fruit, booze.  Appearance - ruby red with a finger worth of head and active bubble movement.  Taste - Booze burn and more fruit, cinnamon, and that dash of cherry as noted on the label.  Palate - Lively mouthfeel and medium bodied.  Overall - I enjoyed it for the first 6 ounces, but the last 6 of the bottle were a little harsh.  It became increasingly difficult to drink as it warmed up toward room temperature.  Strong ale indeed, and perhaps too strong for me.  High abv doesnt necessarily mean a remarkable rating, in my opinion.  It looks like Im in the minority view.

A taste of Belgium from the good old USA! Nicely done quad from Ommegang. Chocolatey brown with thin beige head, and rich, tangy flavor. Nice aroma greets you at the pop of the cork. Makes me miss Brussels....

Pours a cloudy leather brown color with a touch of rust in the mix.  Basic toasty malt and some Kriek notes as well.  Rich malty flavor with a slight fruity sweetness followed by a bit of raisins and dates in the background.  Overall, It wasnt offensive but it wasnt that exciting either...

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2013 This beer may be my favorite quad i ever had. I have had several bottles since my first one, and they have such a smooth hint of cherry on the back end with no boozy taste that can be found in other quads. As the beer warms the flavors really start to open up. It poured amber colored into a belgian tulip with a nice two finger head. First sip and i knew i was hooked.

12 oz bottle. Pours a brown with reddish hints. Large head. Aromas of roasted malt, raisins, and brown sugar. Flavors of dark fruit, bitter cherries, malt, and brown sugar. A bit acidic on the finish.

This is a great strong ale. Very smooth with very good finish.                                      

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This quadruple ale has quite the taste to ponder it can go from creamy to hints of cherry to hints of a Trappist brew.....

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark amber in color. Great floral aroma. Lingering off-white head. No alcohol astringency, finishis carmel and slightly fruity.

Bubblegum front, light creamy bubbles, banana on the nose. Thick head when poured, levels out and leaves no lacing.  Smooth as can be. Caramel, chocolate, coffee, toast and dark citrus flavors. This is a beautiful brew

Banana and bubblegum aromas along with a slight cherry scent and what I can only describe as "full bodied" malt.   Nice fairly clear medium orange/amber color with a light tan head.  Creamy texture and also a creamy taste.  Figs, cherries and honey show up followed by a sharper alcoholic edge (although it doesnt feel like almost 10% ABV) that nicely tames the sweet smoothness.  Definite Belgian flavor and yeastiness.  Finishes with a more bready malt flavor a bit of sourness with lingering estery banana.  Theres a lot going on in this very delicious beer.

Pours deep garnet with moderate tan head. Aroma is heavy cherry and dark fruit with malt and nutty notes. The initial taste is a blast of cherry, which transitions rather seamlessly into malt and more dark fruit with some yeast notes. The alcohol complements the flavors really well and never overpowers the taste of the beer.

As a strong fruit finish. Not a lot of head.  Nice deep amber coloring.  Would have in place of a glass of wine at dinner party paired with stake. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Good body on this belgian. There is sediment in a toffee brown color. Nice head, the alcohol is detected but not overwhelming

Now thrinking this beer, at Bottlecraft San Diego.. A clear red/brown colored beer, with a beige head. The aroma of fruits, a little bit sour, hints of cherry with caramel and a little spices. The taste also caramel with cherrie notes, sweet fruits. some spices and flavors of alcohol. The aftertaste of sweet fruits, caramel with some bitter.

Purchased at the Lebanon Co-Op about 6 months ago. 2011 Vintage. Poured into a Tulip. Served at room temp.

A - Dark reddish brown. 2 finger head subsides to nothing pretty fast. 

S - caramelized sugar, plums and figs. Tons of dark fruits. 

T - Big dark cherry taste. tons of dark fruits. Very sweet sugars. Excellent. Wonderful. no booze taste at all.

M - 20% carbonatoin on swish. Medium to heavy body. Super bitter fruity aftertaste.

O - This is spectacular. I need to find an older vintage.
Interesting and different taste. Initially it tastes good, but the after taste is a little weird.

Aroma: Sour--hints of berries and possibly raisins--with a rich caramel and toffee underpinning. This is a really complex aroma, and each time in inhale, I find something new appearing.
Appearance: Clear dark amber with a thick, tan head.
Taste: Light sweetness balanced by a light sourness, but nothing overwhelming or unpleasant. 
Palate: Full body, creamy texture, soft carbonation, long finish.
Overall: This is a really great and complex beer, with lots of flavor and aroma layers. Its a bit too tart and fruity for me, but I can absolutely see how and why this is working and would strongly recommend it to anyone who hasnt already sampled it.
My favorite beer, hands down. The flavor is more complicated and nuanced than love itself.
This beer is a liquid perfect day. I only have good memories of this beer and the times I had drinking it. Itll put a smile on your face.
Bottle at ginger man Dallas. Malty aroma. Poured a redish brown with great lacing. Taste of alcohol, caramel, and malt complexity. After a few of these youll be toasted!

Poured from a 22oz bottle into a tulip glass. Pours a dark dark clear amber color with a light head that leaves little lacing but lasts a decent while. Aroma seems light, scent of fruit and alcohol. Taste is clean and crisp. Taste of banana, light malt, and alcohol. Clean alcohol bitterness on the backend. Overall a delicious beer.
Brown with a red tint in color with a nice carbonation. The taste has a lot going on but finishes with the advertised cherry that you smell the whole time. Highly recommended, really liked it.

Atone is wonderful cherry chocolate figs. Cloudy amber color. Tastes of cherry champagne. Bubbly some toffee and pear. Great stuff

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from bottle into Chimay class.  Dark brown color, good head, lots of lacing. Aroma is caramel, bread, dough, and cherries. Loved the cherry smell. Taste is smooth, with some sourness and cherry taste. There is a lot of complexity to this beer. Really good.
Chocolate and plum on nose. Dark brown, slight head. Sweet malt, pear, cherry. Slight higher alcohols.

Aroma is fruit cake.  The bread, the dough, and the candied fruit.  The aroma itself takes you nowhere else you could imagine.  Wherever it takes you, you will have that boozy fruit-cake scent directing you to your specific destination of happiness.  Color is dark brown with a great foamy head.(although that has nothing to do with quality).  Mouthfeel leans to prickly carbonation, but nothing to the extreme.  Overall, unbeleivable, but I would certainly recommend this as a cold-weather beer.  Rich, sweet, and flavorful.  This will certainly stand as one of the greatest beers I have ever tasted.

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2012 Pours cloudy amber with two fingers of creamy head. Smells of cherries, vanilla, fruity yeast and chocolate. Taste is lightly sour cherries, roasted malt and slight alcohol. I really like this one.

Poured from a bottle into a chalice glass.  Pours a deep burgundy, brown with lots of large yeasty sediment held in suspension.  Very dense.  Looks great with a big tan head with medium lacing.  Unfortunately, the appearance is the most impressive of this beer.  The nose is cherry syrup and it just eats up everything else.  The yeast in the background, the malt, all are eaten alive by the cherry on this nose.  I just couldnt get past it.  The cherry eases up on the first taste.  There is lots of fruit ester, phenols, and of course, cherry.  Its very fizzy, and very big on the palate and finishes quite dry.  I had this beer after the Abbey Ale on tap, and I guess, maybe, just maybe, the taste of that was so good I couldnt enjoy this one as much.

Bomber: 2011 label.
Pours woody brown with a loud, crackly-fizzy head, preceeded by nice cork pop.
Nose is yeast and sweet caramel, dark cherries.....apples maybe.
Flavour is roasted malt, cherries...Quite a bit of alcohol.....
Nice , tart, sharp acidity to it.
The alcohol fades quickly after breathing for a bit  and after 58 degrees or so, was no longer so harsh.
It becomes better and better...booze is still there, but a nice warming kind rather than the initial shot...gets to be quite smooth.
Pretty complex, nice beer.

Smooth malty aroma with cherry notes and a little boozy. Difficult to get much head out of the pour without disturbing the yeast... either no head, or lots of yeast. Creamy light head when you get it, and it dries quickly. Very cloudy mahogany with an abundance of flocculated yeast. It would be an improvement if they centrifuged before bottling and re-pitched conditioning yeast in the bottle. Taste is sweet and tart, with a rich caramel malt, dark fruit esters, and cherry. Body is fairly heavy and texture is thick, but alcohol still manages to show quite a bit and gives it a boozy almost brandy-like feel. Finishes rich and sweet with little sign of hops.

A complex rosy-brown with a tan champagne head.  The beer is better as it opens up its floral notes that are earthy yet bright.  It is multilayered and tastes like different things being pulled together and balanced well. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft. Hazy dark caramel pour with a foamy head. Chewy dark chocolate malt. Bourbon soaked cherries. Burnt dark red fruits. Full body. Big dark cherry malty sweetness.

Bottle at home with fresh, steamed lobster and chocolate. Huge head. Strong, bitter, slightly sour aftertaste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2010 bottle sample from a friend. Pours a slightly hazy reddish brown with a weak beige head. Aroma surprisingly dominated by sweet/tart cherry notes over top of lots dark toffee malt sweetness with very light spice and yeast aroma. Flavour contained the expected quad characteristics of big sweet caramel malt flavours, a bit of yeastiness and very little hop bitterness, again combined with nice cherry tartness and flavour to balance out the sugar. Body full, carbonation high, alcohol well-hidden. A unique and tasty quad.

Tap at Indigos. Nose is light cherry, some dark caramel malts, sweet, yeast and spice. Taste is similar with more fruity notes coming out as it warmed up. Very spice/yeast heavy with some rich malts taking over. A great quad.

Bottle split with mcberko. Pours hazy amber brown with a white disapating head. Aroma of candied pear, black treacle, boozy notes, yeast. Flavour of the same, except candied pear, more slightly sour apple. Medium bodied, well balanced. Nice.
deep reddish brown with lots of sediment, small head. lots of sweet cheeries with roasted malt caramel and toffee. alcohol well hidden. quite good.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2015 Tasted from 12oz bottle into tulip glass. It poured a nice, slightly hazy reddish copper color with weak beige foam and some Belgian lace. Good bottle conditioning characteristics. Aromas and flavors of a true-to-style Belgian quad (or "Belgian Dark Strong Ale" if you subscribe to BJCP naming) plus a hint of sour cherry lambic. Complex. Rich malt and candy-sugar sweetness, fruity and mildly toasty melanoidins, peppery Belgian yeast phenols, and the hops plus boozy alcohol melded into a flowery perfume. Medium body, high carbonation, fairly dry finish. The subtle pie-cherry sourness did add a nice new layer to a style I already enjoy.

Bottle. Brief tan head. Pours a cloudy, sediment filled reddish brown. Nose was fruity and malty, with cherry and plum. Flavor was a mixure of sweet and tart cherry, some plum, and a touch of malt bitterness. Heavy to the palate, but balanced. Was very smooth despite the meaty appearance.

Pours a murky reddish brown with a small creamy beige head.  The aroma is  sweet, tart, and fruity with notes of cherry and caramel. The taste is sweet, malty, yeasty, and fruity, with some light tartness. I've never had a quad quite like this. A very unique brew.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I had high hopes for this one though good its not what I had hoped for. Poured into a trappist glass, nice head with good retention a nice dark amber, the aroma would be fruit, sweet, the taste is tangy citrus, alcohol is very noticeable and the carbonation too sharp, not the velvety carbonation I would expect from it, a lot of warmth going down.

2010 version, aged almost 2 years...bottled 6/3/10.  Pours translucent purple with off white bead.  Dark fruit in the nose.  Palate is dark fruit, mostly cherry, yeast and surprisingly boozy.  Finish is dry and bitter.  Honeslty, somewhat disappointed by this one.  It was good, but not great at all, and the booze stuck out more than the top beers in its style.

Beautiful beer. Pours brown/amber with a frothy light tan head, and big lacing. Lots of aromas and flavours going on in this one, toffee, mild tart cherries, yeast, cereals. Lots of fine carbonation, and good creamy mouthfeel. Finish was very acidic, and alcohol was dangerously well hidden. Love this one!
Pours a hazy amber brown with a light brown head and yeasty aroma of fruits. Taste is complex, of malt, fruits, cherries, and caramel with a lingering alcohol finish. Nice quadrupel, pleasant brew.

Pours a ruby red with a small head. Aroma is fruity, sweet and yeasty. Taste full of flavor, sweet, and fruity with some mild tart cherry. Finish is dry with mild lingering. Quite enjoyable and refrshing, and drinks very easy despite the moderate ABV. Quaff Score 9 /10

Fantastic. The nose is burnt sugar and dark fruits in the cherry and rasin range. The beer is deep brown with a sticking syrupy tan head. The taste reflects the sugar and fruit of the nose and adds some spice. The beer is medium to full bodied with a silky smoothness. I had few dried cherries that I ate with this beer and the combination was fantastic. Definitely recommended.

It poured a reddish brown color with a small beige head. The aroma was sweet and nutty malt with cherries, some yeast, and a little alcohol. The taste was fruity and yeasty, with the tart fruitiness growing to a floral finish.  A very good Quad.

Pours a copper with a good tan head.  Some fruity aromas going on here.  Raisin, orange, cherry, plum, with a heavy alcohol stamp.  Taste is mostly these dark fruits mentioned earlier, but I detect some maple as well.  However, although that alcohol nose disappears here, its content is readily apparent.   This is very much on the sweeter side.  Medium body, plenty of carbonation, with kind of a sticky impression.  This is a well made, complex beer, but I must say that it isnt really my style.
Cherry , malts and some spice on the nose. Taste is mostly sweet with cherry and dark fruits, some spice and warming of alcohol. Not bad, and kinda of interesting. A fruity quad.
UPDATED: JUN 16, 2012 Massive malty flavor and smell. Not too hoppy. Very much like raisins. Sometimes it can be a bit hard to drink but its smooth and sweet.

Pours from the bottle with a healthy but quickly fading head.  Deep, opaque brown, a little paler around the edges and bottom of the glass.  I picked up on alcohol in the aroma but not a lot else.  The taste is strong and dry but not exactly garrulous, it finishes pretty much like it starts.  Woody, heavy, slightly boozy, mild hops.  Pretty good.

Bottle. Woody dark fruit, cherry, and strong alcohol aroma. Hazy brown with a small beige head. Earthy, tart dark fruit, cherry, and big alcohol...  almost brand-like flavor. Medium body.  Too boozy for my taste.

Aroma is slightly smokey, little hint of cherry. Thin head when poured. Dark and thick. Oily palate. Lingering finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a brown with a light rusty hue. The head is light beige with good retention. The nose has a bit of raisin and red fruit. Smells like the skin of a res delicious apple. Some light spice, a little allspice. Has a medium body. The pallet has figs, Carmel, black cherry a little roasted apple. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a purple brown color with a beige head. Aroma of wood, toffee, figs,  alcohol. Flavor is of brown sugar, cherries, raisins, yeasty esters. Slight tartness. A bit of booze heat. Really nice beer.

From bottle.  Strong malty, roasty aroma.  Brown color, cloudy, with a large head.  Light sour taste.  Medium body with an oily texture.  Long, malty finish.  Overall a very good belgian ale.  Not as good as advertised, but still very strong.
Awesome. I have it in a second time  with my brother in law. I really like it but I do not remember details of it. One of the best indeed
Bottle from "The Bottle" in York.  Dark red brown with a very powerful candy suagr and cherry flavour, hints of vanilla, oak, whisky? and a very powerful rich alcoholic kick to the finish.

Bottle. Pours a dark ruby red color with a beige head. Aroma is of caramel, toffee, dark fruits like raisins and cherries, peppery notes and brown sugar. Flavor follows the nose with lots of dark fruits like raisins and figs, cherries, breadiness, peppery notes, toffee, caramel and brown sugar. The body is medium with a dry mouth feel. Overall one of the best American Quads I have had.

2006 Vtg Bottle at Monlks Cellar Dinner. Maybe the second or third best beer of the night and this isnt even from Belgium. Well played Ommegang. Poured a reddish purple color, small ring of head, not much lacing. Aromas of figs, cherries, wood, shampoo, dark plum, rich malts, vanilla. Very complex. Taste is a squashed cherry, with the most delicious and perfectly crafted malt bill to accompany the fruits and spices up front. The epitome of a quad.

A: Pours a dark ruby red color with lots of sediment floating around in the body. Im pretty impressed with its head, its a tan color with decent retention and lacing.

S: Its a bit hard for me to evaluate the smell, but it nonetheless has some notes of cherry, mint, darker fruit, and licorice. I like it, but its not as complex or intense smelling as it could be.

T: I enjoy its flavors and complexity...but theres something missing. I cant put my finger on it, but theres just something lacking. Even still, it has some nice notes going on, and it improves with subsequent sips. I can taste plenty of raisin, fig, mint, cherry, chocolate, and licorice. Good balance and complexity, but it kind of lacks the oomph I wanted it to have. Still, its a good sipper to cap the night off.

M: It has a fairly thick body with average carbonation. The yeasty aftertaste lingers nicely, and doesnt get in the way of the rest of the beer.

O: I cant figure this one out. In some aspects, its a great beer, but in the aspect of simply sipping and enjoying it piece by piece, it unfortunately isnt. Theres just something hindering its drinkability. Still a very nice quad, though.

Bottle (355 ml). Appearance: Pours dark amber/brown with a small quickly vanishing off-white head. Aroma: Heavy malt, candy sugar, dark fruits and hints of cherries. Taste: Heavy sweet, candy sugar, dark fruits and hints of cherries. Overall: A really good complex and well balanced beer. Kriek brings a + but is not overwhelming.
Drank 1/29/12 from notes.  From a 750 bottle into a Sam glass.  Nice medium-heavy belgium with lots of cherry and a kick.

Drank from 1 pint 9 oz bottle. Even in bottle large head present. This beer was pretty good but I was a little let down. Aroma is sweet and fruity. Taste is metallic hops, floral, caramel, chocolate, some peppery spice and lots of fruity sweetness. Really didnt get too much cherry. Had more of a tropical fruit taste. Nothing at all offensive about this beer but I found it a bit subdued. Alcohol well hidden.

bottle   pours a hazy  red brown with thin white head that doesnt stay  . no lacing  . aroma is cherry with malt  . taste is prominent cherry , some cough medicine and malt . carbonation could be a bit higher .

On tap in sampler glass at Judges Bench in Ellicott City, MD on 3/29/12. 

Clear, deep red copper with big creamy head. 

Fruity aroma of cherry, raisins, apple and banana and some funky yeast. 

Taste is more a complex mix of dark fruit, malt and spiciness.

Fairly full body with foamy carbonation. 

Excellent beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

750ml bottle - 3 year vertical (2009, 2010, and 2011).
Rating based off the freshest bottle as this one really doesnt age well.  Reddish brown pour with some off-white head.  Aromas of cherry and other pitter fruits, Belgian yeast, and some sweetness.  Flavors of chocolate, brown sugar, and cherry.
Actually found this at Costco with a free glass included.   Agree with the ratings this is a great beer.

Beautiful rich darker caramel color to go with malt and caramel flavors. Alcohol was evident as a quad, but not until after initial flavor impact so quite well balanced. Tastes like a Belgian quad with just a tinge of fruit.

75 cl bottle @ OHaras Freehouse. Rated on 09.03.2010
Reddish colour, disappearing head. Aroma is sweet with raisins and ripe banana. Flavour is sweet and sourish with raisins, some over-ripe banana and hints of sugar. Palate is a bit low on CO2. Good.

Pours a reddish brown with white head.  Aroma of strong cherry, toffee, and carmel.  Taste is complex with dark fruit, cherries, metal, and soy sauce.  Very good beer.  Maybe alittle too much cherry for my taste.
Dark copper pour with thin head. One of the better Quads I have had. Subtle but notable dried fruits.

On tap @ Rackhouse.  Pors a reddish amber with a small white head.  Scent of cherry cough drops, butterscotch, caramel malts, graham crackers.  All of those aromas carry into the flavor along with some gingerbread spices.  Creamy full mouthfeel, lingering spicy finish.

pours dark mahogany red/brown, minimal head, thin ringed retention, small CO2, runny lacing, sporadic mix of slow and fast moving CO2 streams. Unfiltered and some sediment in the glass. Malty dark fruit on the nose. Burst of dark malts up front, predominantly chocolate, coffee, mixed with sour cherries, raisins, slightly nutty, minor 4/10-level bitterness finish. The alcohol is initially masked by the flavours but hits in the mid until the end. Medium-high complexity, med-high depth, great carry, good transitions, quite good drinkability. A very strong and heavy ale, can be difficult to drink the whole bottle solo as a session beer.

on draft. poured dark ruby red with light head. the aroma of sweet malt and some caramel malts blended with dark fruit and/or dark cherry. the flavor is impecible. the nice sweet malt flavor mixed with the caramel malt and ending up on the dark cherry note is just mild as can be but very distinctive.

Malt, molasses, caramel, and a little fruit in the aroma.  Malt and caramel in the flavor as well, with some cherry in the finish.  Ample carbonation gives this a creamy mouthfeel.  Really, really good.

Excellent! Emphasis on malty flavor but not overly sweet. Complex flaver up front and an effervescent dry finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle.  Pours a hazy brown with a small head.  Smells a bit boozy with some cherry notes, some yeast sweetness, and a little bread.  The taste is smooth with some dark fruits and caramel malt.  The palate is very full on this brew.  Solid.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2012 Konjaksfärgad, med viss grumlighet. Stort ljusbrunt skum. Fruktig arom där körsbär framträder, medan honung och kola finns lite i bakgrunden. Alkoholen känns i näsan, men inte så att det stör. Körsbären ger en något sur smak, och där hittas också andra frukter liksom vanilj och kola. En god öl att njuta av länge.

Fantastic pour, a rich chocolate brown with a dense 2-finger head. A distinctly sweet aroma of cherry. At first sip, malty and strong, but develops to be complex and sweet, almost floral on the palate with the strong cherry scent overcome by a myriad of other flavors. Finish is smooth and slightly dry, with only a slight tinge of alcohol despite the strength. The esters are a bit strong when at the recommended temperature, but as it warms, the malts come out and the sweetness develops.

aroam, dark fruits cherry mostly, some lively yeast esters
color, medium amber white head, some lacing
taste, wow, sweet fruit, cherries I really get the most of, very smooth full bodied, malty backend, but light, perfect balance of yeast fruit esters, and malt richness
overall, One of my first true craft beers, have samled many times. large 25.5 ozer
user_location: @RED BHUT JOIKIAS!, Paulsboro, New Jersey, USA

text:
It has been a while since I had it but it is great beer. Pours dark with creamy top and has nice rip fruit. Alc is well hidden. 

---Rated via Beerology

Poured at room temperature into a snifter. Dense two finger head that dissipated quickly. Muddy brown but thick color. Not a heavy aroma, but centers on fruit notes. More carbonation than expected, but paired well with flavors. Slightly tart (probably because of the cherries) but still pleasant. Ill admit I expected a little more from such a high rated beer but still delicious :)

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Vintage 2005 Pours ruby/chestnut with a diminishing, light brown head. Aroma is oxidised and very sweet; lots of honey. Overtone somewhat of swimming pool (chlorine), but in a good way. Madeira as it warms. Flavour is sweet. Less oxidised than the aroma, but still a fair amount. Notes of fruit, honey, madeira, red vermouth and alcohol. Finish is dry, tart and bitter with notes of red vermouth and a slight alcohol burn. A bit too much carbonation. Overall this aged okay with some good notes, but could have been better. 17.02.12.
Pours a dark cherry color, medium head, white with hints of ruby colors. Great cherry and malty flavors with subtle alcohol throughout and in the finish. Great beer.

Pours hazy dark amber with a creamy tan head. Aroma is of roasted nuts, cherry, and bread. The taste is very sweet, and that sweetness is extremely malty with some yeast character. Exceptionally full-bodied, this carries through some mildly bitter caramel and coffee notes. Not my first quad but most definitely one of my favorites.
Hefig-süßer Beginn, wobei die Hefenoten stärker werden. Süßlich, rund, etwas trocken. Ausgewogen, gut! 8/9/10/11/6/11

From notes.  First reviewed 4/19/2010.  2008 bottle poured into a tulip.

This pours a dark burgundy / cherry color with a thick, off white head. Nearly opaque, but some bubbles visibly rise to the top of the glass. Decent head retention with some lace stick.

Dark fruits power the olfaction, primarily cherry. Surprisingly sugary malt on the nose as well. Alcohol is present, along with a slightly medicinal nature.

Caramel malt sweetness up front, quickly followed by sweet and tart cherries. Alcohol bursts through, and a tart cherry / medicinal flavor ends the sip. Alcohol lingers in the aftertaste. The 2008 is more mellow, with nearly no hop presence to note.

Medium carbonation, a little bit creamy in the middle as well. It loses its carbonation as it warms, although the character becomes somewhat deeper. Warming.

This is definitely a sipper. The tart cherry taste provides an interesting foil to the style. Aftertaste limits viability of having more than one or two. Probably better to have paired, than alone, as I did.

A very strong quadruple-Belgian with a beautiful pour, you can definitely taste the cherry undertones and strong scents of Bourbon from the aging process. Definitely not for the timid, I would suggest sharing a bottle among friends after dinner. The flavor is so strong it would interfere with most foods it seems. I personally would not drink this beer again, but that is simply because I find it to be too sweet for my liking.
One of the best. Great look, great taste. Stays on palate and has a great finish. Never gets old
Great beer beutiful amber color slight alcohol aroma; blend of flavors elminate any overly strong alcohol bite overall fantastic

2005 wines, 75 wine tasting CL bottle.The down Tanyutou ruby red. The aroma is full throttle, raisins, dates, esters, yeast, chocolate, quite oxidation, candy, candy and raisins malt notes and some alcohol. Oxidation of the taste of the beautiful, a strange sour cherries, port pointed out that the dark fruit, some damp quality. Obviously, this should have been drunk a few years ago

RB Scavenger Hunts, scrap #21. Team 2Pac.

First time getting this in the 12 oz four pack, sorta forgot about the sediment, whoops... still looks fantastic, bright crimson, nice clarity and an off-white head the holds throughout.

Aroma is cherries, dates, roasty malts, subtle alcohol burn, sweet but subtle... not quite as pungent as the beer that Im use to in the 750.

Really just a fantastic beer, all the wonderful complexities of the best Belgian quad - dark chocolate, dark malts, toffee/caramel - with the lively fruit and tartness of a Belgian kriek sprinkled on top - its amazing the amount of character that the lambic offers to the beer at only a 2% blend.

Feels like velvet, thick and cloying and it allows for the cherry finish to linger, I love it.

This beer is solely responsible for my love of Belgian style beers, it introduced me to a style that now represents a large portion of my beer budget and Im just as impressed by it today.
Aroma indicates caramel, chocolate, and a bit of tart fruit. Delicious harmony of chocolate roasty malt and cherries. Rich, warming and complex. Great with desserts.

Sour cherry goes great with the dark ale.   Dark color but opaque...with a ruby glow when put up to light.  On Tap at jojos tavern. Hamilton,nj.  A little over bitter, but very tasty.   A really nice beer.

Dark copper with a thick fluffy head. Excellent retention and lacing. The nose shows some nuttiness and banana. Full bodied with rich banana balanced by a bit of citrus zest. A bit of alcohol on the finish makes this more of a sipper. Will be better with bottle age as some of the sour character will emerge.
A very strong flavor and great taste, but I would have to say it is similar to their Abbey Ale, which is the only downside I have for Three Philosophers

From the caged and corked big bottle purchased at Giant Eagle in Pittsburgh.  While I really felt compelled to try and like this special beer, I cant go overboard or even award high marks for what amounts to an average Joe kind of Quadrupel.  Granted, there arent many Quadrupels on the market, so maybe I just dont have the proper palette, but my friends who shared the bottle with me over a few games of Ultimate Werewolf were also unimpressed, and politely said "its pretty good" or other lackluster responses.
Perhaps the best thing about Three Philosophers is the mystery of the bottle and who the "Three Philosophers" might be?  If anyone knows, please write and help those of us who have spent too much time at work trying to figure out this mystery for ourselves.
Bottle. Brown colored beer with a very complex herbal aroma and taste. Some anice (?), malty sweetness, caramel and banana. Nice balanced beer. Medium bodied.

Good taste, spritzy beer, and has flavor with bitterness at the end. The color and aroma was perfect, but perhaps my snack choice messed up my taste buds, but my taste changed a bit. Other then that I recommend this beer, but not to enjoy sociable but to enjoy gracefully comfort of been alone.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Amazing mouthfeel and aroma. Love taste of malty sweey goodness and slight fruitiness...

12 oz bottle courtesy of my wife for Christmas. 2011 on the neck label. The pour is a light haze ruby copper with a 1/2 inch light tan head that falls quick. The aroma is Belgian yeast, black cherry fruit, sort of a cough syrup cherry. Touch of potpourri spice. The taste is black cherry light tart, bit tannic, clove yeast, the general belgian yeast spice.
