Decent alocohol character in the finish. The palate is heavy to medium bodied, bit oily, dry alcohol finish. Lingering dustiness.  Unique beer, just didnt rerally pull off any of the Quad or Kriek flavors I enjoy.
Brown pour with a smell of cloves and banana. Flavor reminds of fruits and malts. It has a good kick to it with the 10% alcohol. Good beer overall.
UPDATED: MAR 11, 2015 Pours like apple cider with a cream colored head.  Aroma is ripe fruit and yeast.  Flavor of cherries and fantastic belgium ale.  Nice alcohol concealment.
Det här var lite av en märklig öl med en märklig smak, lite alkohol och lite belgisk jäst. Jag vet inte riktigt va jag ska tycka och vad jag ska känna men det var ingen höjdare i alla fall.

750ml corked bottle, 2011 vintage.  Served in a globe. Pours a deep ruby brown with about a finger of large-bubbled tan head that dissipates quickly.  Light lacing on the glass.  Smells fruity, oak and vanilla.  Medium body with a very smooth mouthfeel.  Tastes of vanilla and dark sugar/molasses sweetness, with hints of oak and sour cherries left behind.  The cherry really stands out as the beer warms.

I split a 750ml corked and caged bottle dated 17 November 2009 with a friend. We each poured it into tulip glasses.

Appearance: Beautiful dark cherry/maroon body with light brick red highlights. Completely opaque, but some fine carbonation bubbles are visible at the edges of the glass. Forms a thick, dark khaki frothy head which retains and laces very well for a beer of the style.

Smell: Plenty of dark fruit, massive maltiness, vanilla, and a slight woody character too. A prominent sour cherry aroma provides the backbone for these fragrances. Its almost like having a fruit basket under your nose.

Taste: To describe Ommegang Three Philosophers as having a complex palate is something of an understatement. This is a beer whose palate not only is diverse in flavor, its constantly changing (an example of inconsistency being an attribute for sure). It begins with a strong sweetness of confectionary flavors, most notably caramel and butterscotch. Theres a slightly bitter, earthy rustic flavor or two as well - akin to Cracker Jack Popcorn if it were toasted (or even burnt). The beer finishes with a kiss of tart cherry. Theres definitely some sourness to it, but in that tasty candy kind of way. It lingers on the tongue, too. 

Initially, the alcohol is completely separate from the palate and is a little distracting. Its slightly dry, but also somewhat sweet and woody like a bourbon. As the beer warms the genuine palate of fruity maltiness and the alcohol blend together for a more homogenized palate. Its very delectable to be sure, and perhaps if it had been as consistent throughout this would be a perfect beer. A "flawed masterpiece" might be a great way to sum it all up, actually.

Drinkability: "Smooth" is not usually a word I would use to describe a Belgian quadruple, but its definitely apropos for Ommegang Three Philosophers. While it is certainly robust and does have some spiciness to the palate, it drinks much easier than any other beer of the style Ive ever had. In fact, while its in the mouth theres a refreshing quality to it - amazing! It goes down very smooth and the aftertaste is a pleasant tartness that isnt cloying at all. The body is quite big at 9.8% ABV, but it just doesnt feel that heavy on the system. Theres no alcohol burn, just a gentle dry warmth that quickly melds with the genuine palate. A great beer to have for dessert.
Very smooth! Slight licorice notes with spice, but with the ABV where it is you cant tell. It is smoother than the Abbey and gets better as it gets oxygen whipping around the glass!

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Copperish and somewhat clear with an eggshell white head which fades quickly

S: Citrus and caramel/toffee malts hints of alcohol (surprise!)

T: The malty characteristics predominate... caramel powering though with some spice and alcohol giving it a bit of heat... nice... smooth finish

M: Medium bodied with healthy carbonation... clean and crisp flavors pass shortly after finishing the sip

O: For a quad, this is good.. its no St. Bernardus 12... but its a good alternative

750ml bottle in Chimay glass.  Pours amber at first then darkens to an opaque deep medium brown.  An active head dissipates slowly but leaves a film on the surface and nice lacing.  Aroma starts as a yeasty smell and as it warms you begin to encounter hints of the fruitiness.  Taste is about what you expect, a darker ale with cherry tones, and beckons you to continue drinking without being sweet.  Not really malty despite being labelled as a Quad. Carbonation is just about right, and alcohol is pretty well hidden, although there is a small bite on the front end and a bit of aftertaste.  Good stuff, would drink/purchase again.

A interesting blended Belgian style Kreik. A strong alcohol / yeasty aroma. A carmel palate with a subtle cherry under tone. The head carbonation fades quickly .. but seems typical for this style of beer.

12 oz. Bottle. Molasses, alcohol scent with a cloudy, milk-chocolate brown appearance and light, silky head. The palate was frothy, a frizzy texture, with a medium body. The typical Belgian strong taste morphed into an alcohol pinched flavor that finished with a lingering of cherries. Very nice progression through the gambit.

It was 20 degrees F when I started my first of ywo goblets, perfect whether for a winter warmer like this.  Appearance was very dark red, cant see through glass when holding up to light.  Smell of raisans or over-ripe fruit.  The taste was superb ona cold winters night.  It is now 19 degrees F.
Quite surprised that I havent rated this before. Sampled at Little Bear in Lis Angeles. Malty and caramel flavors dominate. Works equally well with chocolate and cheese. Very versatile.

A reddish brown beer with a small beige head that quickly disappeared.  The aroma is sweet and nutty malt, cherries, yeast, and a little alcohol.  The flavor starts fruity and yeasty, with the tart fruitiness growing to a floral and yeast finish.  A very enjoyable beer.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2013 75cl bottle into Chimay glass...

Aroma: Interesting. Definite grass aroma, strong caramel roasted malts, slight vinegar, VERY fruity...grapes, pears, apples, cherries, quite boozy. In terms of complexity, its up there for sure. 

Appearance: Slightly murky blood red, the head is off white and fuzzy, looks damn fine.

Taste: Ehhh...really yeasty and cigarette smoky. Very reminiscent of cough syrup surprisingly. That aside, its quite fruity...grapes, cherries, peaches...and quite sweet too.

Palate: Thick and cloying. What upsets me are the overpowering flavours that throw the beer off. Not much carbonation to speak of. And the booze? This is really 9.8% eh? Seems more like 15....

Overall: Unbalanced and annoyingly so. I was hyped up then the taste and palate threw it out the window. Too bad...this is only proving that only the Belgians can make good dark strong stuff.

Dark brownish red pour with small quickly dissapating off white head. Aroma of malts, yeast, caramel and red fruit. Taste is slightly malty, caramel, cotton candy and a definate tartness present. Slightly hoppy on the finish. Didnt detect any cherries though, just some tartness. Not bad but was expecting a little more.

Dark amber color semi clear, white frothy head. Nose is oranges, cherries, slight Apricot, coriander. At cellar temp this beer is perfect, aeration make this very creamy, sweetness like butterscotch dried apricot, light bodies and still a decent kick of bitterness for belgian style to even out the sweetness. Complex and delicious, would love to put this in the cellar for a couple years.

750 ml bottle shared at the Utah holiday tasting. There was a bit of age on the bottle sampled. I got notes of cherries, malty, plums, roasty, fruity. I enjoyed this beer with the age on it, more then fresh.

from Mondial de la Bière 2011, Strasbourg - quite clear reddish-brown beer with a poor head retention; gently sticky nose with notes of cherries marmalade and wood; moderate tartness, a fair sweetness and a solid malt backbone; no bitterness and a long tart aftertaste of cherries

Bottle. Deep brownish red color with a fizzy off-white head. The kriek really comes through on the nose, with plenty of funky cherry notes, some roasted malts, brown sugar. The taste is moderately sour and tangy. Some yeast, sugar, malts. Complex flavor. The body is medium, not overpowering. The finish is slightly hot. Overall, a pretty tasty beer.

Pours dark reddish brown with a medium sized brown head. Aroma has notes of cherries, caramel malts, sweet sugar and berries. Taste is quite malty and complex with a lot of cherry notes and hints of berries and tart. Slightly sour and sweet sticky finish with hints of cranberry and cherry.Alcohol comes through a bit in the end.

From notes: Pours hazy, red-amber with a small, light tan head that was gone quickly.  Strong, pleasant cherry aroma from the kriek, with a touch of earthiness.  Deep flavors, with a very slight thickness to it.  Tart cherry taste up front, that gives way to a strong, earthy yeast note in the finish.  As it warms, the yeast in the finish is less assertive, and it blends with the tartness of the cherry to produce a nice, smooth flavor.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2011 Bottle at Rockaway Seafood Company. My third quad of the night, so this is subject to a rerate. Aroma of wood, dried fruit, alcohol, no cherry or kriek aromas present. Full bodied, syrupy, sweet. Slightly alcoholic on the finish. Distant cherry. Somewhat cloying. Caressas favorite beer in the Poconos.

Darkish brown with a small off-white head that leaves slight lacing. Aroma is cheery, marzipan and caramel. Medium body with a slightly boozy finish. Taste is cherry, malt, toffee. Great balance, cherry is quite subtle. Delicious.
Fater long last I finally was able to try this in Regina of all places.  Should have hunted some down before I left.  it was awesome.

A- Ruby red with a thick white head that leave some nice lacing.

A- Malt, Yeasty bread smell, raisins, 

P- syrupy, and well carbonated, lot lighter than expected

F- Malty, yeasty, plums, cherries, coffee.

Overall, I loved this beer.  Nice beer to sip and savor!

Bottle @ home, bought at Utobeer, London. Small beige head that diminishes very quickly. Lovely deep dark red color. Smell wood, some fruits, lightly alcohol. Taste dark fruits, caramel, lightly sweet, slight sour-bitter hints coming though. A lot of flavor, very nice brew! The 9.8% ABV is very well hidden and carbonation is soft but present. Medium to full body.
Delicious Dark Belgian Ale, smooth chocolate espresso flavor, has a nice hint of cherry. Well defined flavors.

Bottle, 2011. Pours a cloudy reddish brown with an offwhite head. Smells of dried red berries, brown sugar and caramel malts. Tastes of red cherries and caramel with a hint of plum. Medium body. Texture is creamy. Carbonation medium. Finishes dry.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2012 12 oz. poured.  Smells of light chocolate and caramel.  Minimal head.  Murky milk chocolate colored with off-white foam.  Loaded with flavor and extremely thick.  Tons of malt, dark fruit.  Bottle indicates 2% ale brewed with cherries combined with 98% ale and i think thats the sweet spot for fruit here: just a touch of cherry flavor that blends very well with the rest of the flavors.  Far from the likes of a cherry witbier.  Leaves a nice film in the mouth and the body and flavor mask any taste of the 9.8% alcohol.  Delicious, but it would be tough to get a second one this full-bodied down in one sitting.

Corked. Pours a deep red, excellent taste, beautiful flavor of fruits, and a very strong taste of cherry. Very malty. What an excellent beer for a cold night in the desert. Gimme this, gimme this, gimme this!!!
Pours a dark reddish brown. Cherry is there in flavor and aroma. Alcohol comes through but not in a bad way. Really good one.
Pours dark amber almost red with almOst no head.  Slight aroma of fruit and cherries. Tastes like a cross between Belgian ale and sweet red wine.

35cl bottle at the Ginger Man, New York.
Decent pinkish white head.  Hazy amber red pour.  Distinct cherry flavour.  Very good!

Corked bottle from the gift set. Pours an almost opaque deep red with a small head. Smells of dark malts, alcohol, and cherries. Im very happy that the cherry flavor is very subdued in this brew. Beautiful Belgian flavors of figs, old fruits, little alcohol burn, and light cherry in the finish. I hate when the fruity flavors in beers such as this are overpowering (Samuel Smiths Strawberry Ale for ex.), but this was impeccably done.

One of the Best ive had. Pours heavy with deep dark amber/caramel color with a finger of head.
 The cherries and dark fruits can really be traced clearly on the back of the tongue. 
 I call this one a wine-beer. Best sipped. Prefferable out of a dimpled mug or short stem glass (wine goblet)

Bottle. Thinner white head on a coppery murky brown body.  Dark cherry, sweet toffee and maltiness and dark fruits in the aroma. Toffee, dark grapes, slight hint of cherry, toast, and dark sweet maltiness.  Medium slightly syrupy body with vibrant carbonation.  Great standby brew that I shouldve rated ages ago.

Bottle. Medium red when poured.  Bit of cherry, malts, caramel and dark fruit to the aroma.  Similar taste.  Has an alcohol bite to it. The cherry in it is a bit offputting as well. Overall the beer has a nice mouthfeel and nice finish. This beer seems grossly overrated on this site, but its not terrible.  Far from it, its a solid beer with a great body.  Just not my particularly favorite taste. 9.8% alcohol.

Whoever this essayist who developed the idea for the "dream beer" is, I cant help but agree.  Quads are not my favorite style.  They are usually too dominated by dark fruits or alcohol or both.  This is neither.  Golden, soft, with a hint of Kriek that delights.  Widely available and frequently drunk.

The pour is a murky, muddy dark brown with 2 fingers of yellowish head. Some nice sparkly carbonation. The nose is malted well with a nice roast with a hint of alcohol, light hops. Good dark fruit notes with a noticable prune, cherry and light toffee. A nicely spiced yeast with dark esters and a light earthy tone. the taste is sweet and well malted in the middle with tons of dark fruits. A hint of tart cherry. The finish has a beautiful spice with warm alcohol and a light, subtle dour note. Overall, a very nice brew. This is a full bodied brew with a smooth, silky mouthfeel with some light sparkly carbonation.

Smells quite sweet and heavy on the yeast and malts, quite moist in the nose. Quite hazy, brown, not a lot of head. The flavour is sweet, lasts for quite a while, you get a little bit of cherry in the later bit of it, a nice surprise. Its really a neat flavour but its not spectacular or anything.

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy reddish brown with a thick head that lingers.  The aroma was yeasty.  The flavor is slightly sour and yeasty.  The alcohol is prevalent and strong enough to provide a little burn as it is going down.  I didnt pick up much of the cherry flavor.

caramel, clove, earthy, very strong cherry flavor. medium sweetness with a thick head that lingers until the end. Personally I found the cherry flavor a little overwhelming, but it was pleasant anyway. Usually poured from the bottle.
Poured from a 12oz bottle.  The off white head was foamy.  The deep red color is very appetizing.  The aroma is malty.  The first flavor to hit me was licorice, malty licorice.  quite good.

Beautiful burnt burgundy pour with a fluffy two finger khaki head. Vibrant fruity aroma with rich notes of toasty malt and belgian candi sugar. Lots of dark fruit notes with a hint of cherry. Taste is again very rich. Dark fruit, figs, dates and plums complement a very mildly tart cherry flavor. Somewhat sugary lasting aftertaste. Voluptuous body. A great quad. I love the extra dynamic of the cherry lambic, but the aftertaste got a bit tiresome after a while.
Corked bottle. Excellent beer from Ommegang. Taste of bread, raisins, and malts. Good balance of alcohol and carbination. Great value for a quad. Highley recommend.

Bottle from Systembolaget. Helsingborg, 2011.

Pours cloudy brown with a light airy head. Sweet and sugary and fruity aroma with some esters, spice and caramel notes. The cherries are present in the background. A crisp carbonation with big bubbles makes the beer seem fresh and very drinkable. The taste have a great pear sensation but also flavours of caramel and nuts. A great take on a Belgian style.
Poured hazy brown with a creamy head.  Smells sweet with a yeast note. Tastes of granny smith apples and a little cherry.  Also has a bit of earthiness to it.

Quick notes only - 2011 verison (decided to do a more rounded review despite some disappointment yet Ive begun to appreciate the many subtle qualities here - I didnt love the one I had a year or so ago either and that one had 1 or 2 yrs age on it): Not really digging this beer, maybe it needs more time. I find the nose very dull: slight sweet candy cherry, plum, hint of spice, anise, orangy, slight alcohol, maple, caramel sweetness - a lot of things I have imagined here but it took work - too much work as I did not think this would be such a quiet brew. It has taken a very very long time for the aroma to evolve. Poured out a clear red amber brew with a thin tan head that leaves short lived speckly lacing. The taste has improved after a very long sit so I wont talk about the cellar temp flavours - Ive just poured the last half of the bottle in my glass after it sat in the fridge for a bit. Caramel, plums, cloves, moderate spice, harsh brown sugar, here and there pepper, drying, I can taste the cherry but it is hiding and blended up with everything else and still retains a background status. FUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUCK!!!!! just knocked my glass onto the floor! Almost half a bottle! ha! what a boob!
a nice belgian sweet quad.  Aroma not as strong as expected.  Cherry malty and boozy. Recommended.
UPDATED: NOV 24, 2011 Date: October 29, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Quad Tasting Event Minneapolis. Full description not available as I was sampling many beers as part of a tasting event.
Pours dark red with a white head. Aroma is tart cherries, sweet malt, yeast and alcohol. Flavor is sweet with cherry and alcohol. Not bad.

On Tap.  B-E-E-A-UTIFUL!  Wow this is gorgeous.  Dark reddish amber hue.  Creamy just off-white head. The aroma almost knocked me off my barstool!  I could have sat for hours just smelling this beer.  Sweet, some hints of fruit, cherries, cacao, maple syrup, alcohol.  The only thing better than this beers nose is its palate.  An total tastebud party!  Deep chocolate, tart cherries, sweet caramel/chocolate malts, dark fruits, plums, raisins, prunes.... honestly its so hard to put your finger on.  The finish is lasting, sweet, and then a nice alcoholic sharpness comes in mixed with the carbonation for the perfect end to a wonderful beer. 

An absolute pleasure to drink.

355ml bottle. Clear, dark mahogany pour with a fairly short head that leaves a little lace. Brandy and brown sugar on the nose with some stewed fruit and a phenol note. Warming on the palate with a real brandy feel. That deep fruitiness comes through as well and it finishes with a long warming sensation. Great for an autumn night like this.

Cool back story behind a very solid beer. I was lucky enough to be in the right place at the right time and was able to sample this beer. Pours a cloudy amber brown with a nice off white head. Nose and taste are of malts, dark fruits, and a bit of caramel.
Lots of pears, raisins, caramel, vanilla and hint of cherry. Great brew and might be the best Quad Ive had.
Pours a nice dark ruby colour with a brownish head. Aroma is light dried fruit and sweet cherry. taste is little sweetness with a nice bitterness to balance. great beer really enjoyed it

Sample at KC Beerfest 10-22.  Comes a dark reddish brown with an average tan head.  Aroma of dark fruit (mainly cherries), caramel and yeast.  Taste is sweet cherries, malt, chocolate and some alcohol.  Delicious!

Pours a murky dark amber with a large head that quickly fades into a thin off white top.  Cherries, clove, yeast, hay in the nose.  Tastes of yeast, dark fruit, rum and alcohol.  Didnt get any alcohol in the nose but it hits you when you take a sip.  This is better than their Abbey Ale, but not quite as good as their Hennepin.  All in all, this is a good example of a quad.

Bottle @mondial de la bière. An amber brown beer with low head. Nose is malty and fruity. Aroma is on caramel with huge fruit notes like cassis and over-riped fruits, bit vinous and too sweet, not really balanced.

355 ml bottle. 2011 version. BBE 04/2016.
Pours a deep mahogany colour with a thick beige head. Aroma of heavy caramel malts, syrup and plums. Strong flavour of heavy caramel malts, syrup, sweet orange, cherries, wood and plums. Full bodied, thick and somewhat sticky mouthfeel and a lovely warming, fruity finish where the cherries really feel. Alcohol doesnt come through too much. Awesome quadrupel.

355ml bottle from Mybrewerytap

Pours dark reddish brown with a medium sized brown head. Aroma has notes of cherries, caramel malts, sweet sugar and berries. Taste is quite malty and complex with a lot of cherry notes and hints of berries and tart. Slightly sour and sweet sticky finish with hints of cranberry and cherry.Alcohol comes through a bit in the end, though. Overall quite nice and well balanced.
Poured from th  bottle. Aroma is of banana and Clove, typical of a quad. Flavor is also typical of a Belgium quad. Overall id say they nailed this but, nothing that makes it special.
12 ounce bottle that poured a deep amber color.   Huge aromas of cherries, and dark malt.  Taste of cherries up front followed by some spicy belgium yeast, raisins, and a touch of alcohol warmth.

A very creamy khaki colored head floats atop a hazy mahogany body. Smell is raisin, caramel and fruit. A medium body that is very smooth and covers the alcohol well. Black currant and caramel with a touch of roasted flavor and dry bitterness in the finish. Character builds as it warms. A nice ale.

Bottle. Hazy brownish red pour with a loose, rocky tan head that quickly shrinks to patchy surface cover. Aroma is sweet and malty, a little fruity and has a faint touch of tartness, the kriek is noticeable along with other notes of berries, oak and caramel. Flavour is just like the aroma: only a hint of tartness and some solid bitterness to balance out the sweetness. Mouthfeel is quite dry and full bodied with heaps of lively carbonation and a long finish that is dry, bittersweet and ever so slightly sour. Very well balanced overall, the addition of kriek really works with this style which I find can sometimes lean too heavily on the sweet side. Alcohol is well hidden. Interesting and tasty.

Pours a mahogany color with a small creamy head and nice lacing. Pleasant aroma of spice, dark fruits hint of coffee and chocolate. Taste of dark fruit and a bit of alcohol. There is a mild coffee and chocolate in the background and a clean finish. Fairly medium body, smooth, velvety texture. Very well balanced. Nice character. First Quad, really enjoyed it. Will have to add this to my shopping list.
Three philosphers is thick and full of flavor, very sweet with a nice warmth from alcohol, I could drink this one all day.

Ever find something so complex that you just cant describe?! This brew falls smack-dab in the middle of all that complexity!! This brew is a very tasty brew and one that presents you with a different meld of flavors and texture in each sip. One thing I truly like about this brew is the warming effect of the alcohol that is detected right from the get-go! I can only compare the flavors and textures to something along the lines of a robust rum cake. Fruity, malty, sweet and theres no denying the fact that there is some alcohol in there! Definitely grabbing a few more and cellaring them for a few years to see how the flavors develop over time!

12oz bottle.  Pours a hazy dark red amber with a big creamy off-white head that retains fairly well and laces the glass.

The aroma caramel malts, dark fruits and sweet cherries and some alcohol.

The flavor is toffee malt, figs, and some cherry with a little roast bitterness and some noticeable alcohol in the finish.  The mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with smooth carbonation.

Overall, a bit pricey ($16 a 4 pack), but I like.  Its a decent quad with added fruitiness from the kriek.

UPDATED: APR 24, 2013 pours a cloudy orange-copper with a decent off-white head, little retention andlacing. caramel aged-malts with cherries, definite woodiness, spices, peppery, light to medium tartness, hint of sweetness with medium hopping - grassy-citrusy. soft carbonation, medium body, medium long grapefruity-peppery finish. first rating: 3.9
re-rate @ ABT blind tasting: 4.1. complex and very good.
Pours a clear red-brown with a lively tan head.  Smells of dough, earthy.  Taste is a balance of sweetness with minor accents of bitterness and sour.

Candyfloss, cherry and sweet malt nose,  hint of apple, dry and fruity yet full bodied, more cherry coming through along with a big hoppy tripel-style bite and faint hints of aniseed and chilli. Fascinating, like a cross between kriek and tripel.

A cloudy, deep red pour with a light tan head.  The aroma has malty caramel along with apple and grapes.  The full body has a slick texture with average carbonation.  The taste has a mild sweetness that is quickly overshadowed by a long alcohol tasting finish.

17/09/2011 12 Fl. Oz. bottle @ Ginger Man NYC (2011-448) 
Cloudy deep red to purple beer, very yellow to beige creamy head, unstable, bit adhesive. Small sediment floating around. Aroma: red fruit, lactobacillus, wood, caramel, bit of mocha and coffee on warming up. MF: good carbon, medium to full body, alcohol is very present.. Taste: sour fruity start, red berries, strawberries, lemon peel, sour apples, caramel, subtle hop bitter, wood notes, some tobacco. Reminds me a bit of Gulden Draak, but less sweet and more tangy. Aftertaste: sour red fruits, mocha, bit sweet, alcohol tickeling the tongue.

Pours dark reddish brown with a thick head and champagne like carbonation. Very strong aroma. cherries and raisins,  bread. It smells amazing. Flavour is strong and full. With flavours of malt, dark fruit, raisins and bread. All being followed by a very strong cherry flavour. it works very well in the beer and is noticeable but not over powering. This is an amazing beer! I love it. An excellent quad with an interesting twist. My only complaint is that the flavour of the alcohol comes through a little strong.

Pours a lovely light ruby brown, dense tan head; very attractive in the glass. Rich aroma of cherries, raisins, chocolate.. rich and complex, viscous & boozy, liqueur-like, tart cherry flavor, currant, chocolate, roasted notes; unique and exceptional.

Ommegang is one of my favorites all around. Ive had this one many times before. It pours with a nice, foamy head. Amber Brown. The nose is slightly cherry caramel. Mouth feel is a bit alcoholic bitey, and slightly thick. Has a great toasted marshmallow taste. 

Alcohol flavor isnt overwhelming for the slightly higher ABV. Not an everyday drinker, but a great occasional.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2014 Three Philosophers 2010 cellared -  Pours a dark ruby reddish brown.  Aroma is malty, raisin, bing cherry, caramel, yeasty, a slight tangerine citrus, molasses, soy sauce. Taste is malty and sweet, notes of caramel, raisin, fig, plum, cherry, thick tea, chocolate. Mouthfeel thick and coating the tongue. Overall an excellent version of the beer.








This ommegang brew pours a dark ruby brown with a decently but not overly fluffy head, dissipates to a thin line fairly quickly.  The aroma on it is definitely sweet fruits, cherry above the others, no booze for a 9.5%.  Tastes of cherry, almost winey, up front with a somewhat weaker finish than expected.  Has a warming sensation on the palate from the alcohol.  Definitely a good, solid beer

750mL corked bottle poured a reddish-brown color with about 2 fingers of tan head which dissipates to very little lacing.  Aromas of alcohol and caramel.  Taste is alcohol and malty sweetness with a dry bitter finish.  Overall, this is a pretty decent brew, but there are better quads out there.

Bottle from Stirchley Wines, Birmingham. Poured a reddy dark brown with a dissipating tan head. Dull aroma with some brown sugar and yeast evident, but not especially enticing. Sweet boozy flavour with a slight metallic tang. Finish was thin and lacking. Booze far too prominent. Really pretty uninspiring and lacking finesse on the whole. Overrated.

Dark red in colour with creamy white head. Sour fruity aroma. Big cherry/rasin flavours. Dry finish. Very nice.
2010 vinatge.
Very tasty.  Rich with lots of interesting flavors. I enjoyed it very much!

2010 bottle, 14C. Brown with some particle, fat coat of beige head. Aroma of dark fruits and berries, brown sugar, chocolate. Creamy mouthfeel, slightly slippery. Quite sweet with noticeable sour notes and spicy hops that add a suggestion of bitterness. No great depth to the malts but the sweet fruits, sour note and the hops are nicely balanced. Alcohol sticks out a bit, more so as the glass disappears. Half expected this to be a car crash, but its pretty good.

At a tasting in Shachars house, thanks YK23, bottle, pours reddish color with a off-white head that dissipates quickly, cloudy, very alcoholic aroma, cherries hints and malt flavor, flows, medium body, and overall an interesting beer, but nothing more.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Snifter.

Appearance: Very dark mahogany with thick cream-colored head and great lacing.

Aroma: Quite pungent with figs, plum, toffee, clove and tart cherry.

Taste: Semi-sweet figs and plum upfront with a nice clove and earthy yeast counterbalance. Cherry tartness rears its head after the initial sip and lasts for a long time. Seems as if this is more than 2% cherry-infused.

Palate: Moderate carbonation, chewy full body, quite warming.

Overall: Nice, alternative take on a Quad with the addition of cherry. Personally, I may have enjoyed it more without the cherry, but personal taste aside, this really is a great beer.

Small rusty head on a opague rusty brown pour. Can definitely smell and taste the cherry in this, but it is a tastefull amount mixed with some smooth malts that sweeten the whole brew as it warms. A slight hop kick follows. Effervescent and medium bodied palate. Nice brew with an interesting story.
Popped the cork to enter heaven. Nice cherry on the noise, bit caramel, sweet. Pretty fizzy. One of a kind. Color fairly dark.

Sweet aroma and taste of malt, brown sugar, figs, marmalade, raisins, cherries, caramel, alcohol and a slight touch of orange. This is undoubtedly a big beer that many people love, but for some reason I do not find it particularly interesting. Bitterness feels dull and the taste is actually a little watery.

Murky caramel color with off-white head that lasts.  Somewhat medicinal nose with raisins, caramel, booze, grapes, and musty cherries.  Good carbonation, medium-heavy body.  Tastes of raisin, chocolate, caramel, cherries.  Carbonation tingle lasts, but mostly a quick clean finish. Good.
355ml bottle.  Pours a reddy brown with a large head.  Aroma is Belgian candy sugars and a little cherry.  Taste has sweet cherry to start.  Sweet finish.  A little cherry too.  Good stuff.

bottle, mybrewerytap.com. Faint fruit, rich malt and yeast are the starting points in this big, big beer. Its instantly deeply warming, the cherry is ever so subtle, but spirit alcohol is very evident. Peppery and spicy, with a foaming yellowing head on top a deep red dark beer. The warmth travels well into the stomach, cherry juice becomes much more apparent late on.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2015 At Fork on Lincoln. This is quite nice. I didnt pick up on the cherry at first, which others did.  It does have an overall fruitiness. Sweet and malty. Very rich but doesnt over do it. Well done. Serving: Bottle
UPDATED: SEP 17, 2011 Roasted malty ale mixed with a kriek.  Very good stuff.  Medium bitterness.  Pleasantly boozy.  Provides a unique beer buzz.  Very existential.  Like magic!

Cloudy amber brown with medium tan head.  Aroma caramel, brown sugar, yeast, red berries.  Medium full body with medium carbonation and no sense of alcohol.  Flavor is malty and dominated by cherries, on the sweet side for sure.  Also some cloves and other spices and bread-like background.  The strong cherry is not really my style but well made and nice to enjoy now and then.

Bottle from the Brewery. WOW! If you like quads and like tart cherries, this is for you. Lots of maltiness,  chocolate, cherries, toffee,  with a dry finish. Full-bodied, Damn they did a great job blending this. BE CAREFUL because I could NOT taste the ABV and I drank the first half of the chalice quick. Then I remembered to look at the alcohol. Great beer which I will be placing a bottle in my basement to age. Top Tier. But keep in mind, you have to like Kriek.
A nice quad, not the best I have had but very very tasty.  Certainly cant complain!
Cloudy orange amber with tight light tan head. Cloves spice, cherry, caramel med body, quad feel, a bit more zesty than usual, cherry adds a complexity to the finish. Not bad.

Bottle from MyBrewerytap.com. Pours cloudy amber with a reddish hue and small creamy off-white head. Aroma of sweet caramel, yeast, winegum and fresh fruity. Taste is sweet and vinous, velvety mouthfeel, notes of port and dark marmelade. Seems like it will never end, lingers and lingers, caressing my palate, lovely beer to sip, mouthful by mouthful. Me like, a lot!

355 ml bottle, kindly shared by gunnar. ABV is 9.8%. Hazy dark brown colour, moderate off-white head with an orangey hue. Unusual aroma of cellar, preserved cherries / cherry pits, marzipan and oak. Warming mouthfeel. The fairly sweet flavour has notes of malts, cherry pits, marzipan and oak.

Unique blend of Belgian quad and a kriek. Luxury in a glass. Only wish the Belgian yeast notes were a bit more pronounced. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
The cherry is a bit overwhelming, but the taste of it is delicious. Very enjoyable overall
I was popping a straight up bone cone over the cherry in this wonderfully overpowering beverage. I do not need a woman in my life as long as this is on the shelves.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2013 Updated.  2007 bottle on 3-3-13.  Taste held up remarkably well and on fact improved with a super mellow marzipan, cherry, sweet caramel, other dark fruit.  Very easy to sip with 6 years on it.  *note-was kept in a fridge the entire life of the bottle.


Bottle on 7-30-11. Pours a deep amber with a off white bubbly head.  Smells is of fermented grapes and cherries, dark malts, licorice with some port wine characteristics.  Taste is very upfront cherry, bordering on medicine-like.  There is also the defining Belgian yeast qualities and very complex cherry, raisin, fermented grape with alcohol warmth.  Very interesting and enjoyable but maybe too much cherry for me.  Could only sip one in a sitting I think.

2009 bottle.
Pours a fantastic dark ruby colour with a large tan head.
Aroma: sweet maltiness, toffee, cherries, licorice, chocolate.
Taste: big maltiness, licorice, chocolate, cherries, toffee, a slight acidity, dry finish.
Full-bodied, moussy.
Is this 2% kriek? Theres a lot more cherries here than expected. Apart from that, this was more like a barley wine than an abt/quad.
Big, complex, sweet, hints of various fruits...a touch of cherry and just slight bit tart. This is a great beer is you like big, bold, complex Belgians. Might be too sweet for some, but I love it!

This was my first quad.  Poured cloudy with a dark amber color and heavy head.  Texture was a bit oily, fairly carbonated, with extremely heavy notes of cherry.  The cherry was almost overwhelming, but this was still an excellent beer.

botle pours a hazy dark maroon color, with small ring of grey head.  Aroma of caramel, molasses, tart cherry, fig, prune.  Flavor has a slightly medicinal quality, with lots of dark fruity notes and sugary malts.  Notes of cherry, sour raisin, molasses, burnt sugar.  The alcohol is not noticeable except for in a warming sensation, overall it is quite smooth, full bodied and syrupy, with modest carbonation.  Quite nice, there is no doubt.

Wow! Poured a cloudy, dark amber/copper with a nice frothy head and some lacing. Berries, banana, and cherry notes. Great feel in the mouth, almost like a Rochefort. Great new-old world beer combo. It could have a few less cherry notes, but I really like this.

Appearance - Ommegang Three Philosophers is very dark, not black like some breakfast stouts, but dark nonetheless. About a finger of head with an aggresive pour. Some stickage to the sides of the glass as it is swirled around.

Smell - Sweet, malty aromas with a hint of raisin and plum. Not the most overpowering smell in the world and not as strong as some other Quadrupels.

Taste - Overall, the taste was pretty underwhelming. The initial taste was a slight bitterness which transitioned into sweet near the end of the sip. With some retro-nasal breathing you could taste the raisins and plums and some maltiness. Maybe a slight caramel flavor too. Fairly complex taste.

Mouthfeel - Full bodied. Not much carbonation and very smooth. Could not feel the affects of the abv. until after I had drunk nearly the whole 750 mL bottle.

Overall - It was good, but not great. I have had better Quadrupels (from Rochefort) and better overall beers (Hopslam). The taste was very similar to the other Quadrupels, but not as strong and not nearly as sweet and pleasing near the end of the sip. I am going to be trying th Ommegang Abbey Ale next; lets hope that one blows me away.

Poured from a 12oz into my duvel tulip glass.

Pours deep burgundy/ruby. With about a finger of head on it that dissipates very quick.

The smell is figs, prunes and wine.

the taste is more of the same. Lots of dark fruit and sweet malt. with a red wine semi dry finish.

The mouthfeel is probably the best part of this beer, is is super silky with a nice alcohol warmth that finishes.

Pretty good beer, will probably pick up some more.
2010. This post with a small tan head. Its a little sweet of banana notes and cherries.

12oz bottle. Very hazy red color with a brown hue, a towering 3-finger khaki head. Tastes very much like a barleywine - prune aroma, alcohol note in the finish. Sweet taste all the way through. Very interesting and complex.

This is a glorious beer. The aroma is yeast, sugar, cherries, vanilla, alcohol, perhaps even a little smoke or licorice and more. It pours from the bottle a dark reddish brown, very hazy but allowing some light through when held up. Thick, tight head with a bit more carbonation than I initially expected. Growing anticipation as I bring the snifter to my lips...the taste cant possibly be everything the nose leads me to hope...at last the first glorious sip...it is! The taste has so many layers it is almost impossible to describe them all. The first is as expected, yeast and sour cherries. A fine blend that reminds me of my grandmas homemade bread and cherry pie that I used to get in trouble for stealing the first bites. Than comes dark candied fruits; plums, grapes, raisins and more cherries. It finishes with an earthy hop bite, some spicyness I cant quite identify, a hint of clove and anise, and a slight alcohol warmth. And then its back for another sip in hopes that the bottle is bigger than I thought. An amazing beer. Too complex to fully describe, yet simply enjoyable enough to buy again and again.

Pours a hazy dark amber/copper color with dense off-white/tan head.  Big fruit nose (dates, raisins) with candi sugar undertones.  mmmmmm   Lots of flavor with the presence of alcohol burn.  Malt is prominent but alcohol is detracting.  Raisin and date flavors continue into the taste.   Aroma is much more appealing to what should be a very appealing brew.

11 bottle.  Pours a clear rose caramel with a huge fluffy head.  Aroma is soft banana, unidentifiable spice, and a touch of candid sugar.  Straight forward taste of belgian yeast with the banana character, minor spice in the middle (perhaps some pepper), some raisin, light cherry, and sweet malt notes toward the back third, and a bit of chewy caramel with alcohol heat into the finish. Bit sticky in the mouth.  Solid and enjoyable beer.

750ml bottle. Tanx to Neeskens. Got a hazy dark amber body. begie small head. Aroma brings cherries, malt, sweets, rubber. Flavor is little sour, peppery, malty and also brings a fruity feel. Palate is quite big and bubbly.

Might as well rate this one.  Poured a dark brown/orange with a fluffy white head.  Aroma was full of candied sugar, caramel malts, light Belgian yeast and a touch of cherry.  Flavors were incredibly well rounded and much like the aroma, sweet for sure but not overly.  Lots of caramel, candied sugar too, some cherry presence.  Mouthfeel was smooth and not overly carbonated as some can be from this style.  Quite good.

Pours a reddish amber color with a light brown colored head.  Malty aroma with a tid bit of cherries mixed in.  Taste has some brown sugar and molasses with a hint of cherry that hits you at the finish.  Smooth

vintage bottle 2010, pours dark red, aroma is alcohol cherries and belgian yeast. the first couple sips started great then a sourness hit mid palate,strong cherry and alcohol then it went metallic. i was ok until the metallic taste came, but luckily it seemed to disappear after a few tastes. pretty good overall

bottle - 2010 vintage - pours a deep red mahogany, with a khaki head. Aroma is of alcohol and cherries. Initial attack is again the alcohol which fades into notes of malt and cherry. There is a little hint of sourness in the mid palate, which is nice. Overall, interesting, its a kriek without being too lambic sour, yet still has the rich creamy mouth feel of the quadruple. Very good effort!
A very strong tasting beer.  Lots of alcohol up front mixed with cherries.  I wasnt a huge fan of this.  A little too much going on for my liking.

Poured into a chalice. Appearance is a creamy mahogany beer with a dense, silky head of beige head. Aroma is prunes, raisins, somewhat funky and tart cherries. On the initial taste, the prunes and assorted dark fruits are up front with a slightly tart cherry presence with a long alcohol burn in the back of the throat. Once the alcohol taste fades away there is a nice cherry nite that lingers on the tongue. Ommegang did pretty well with this one.

Bottle from Systembolaget. Aroma has a lot of sweetness and fruity notes. Pours a dark reddish amber with a nice off-white foam. Taste is sweet and slightly sour, very Belgian. Some hints of liqourice and cherries, interesting beer. Mouthfeel is fizzy but a bit thin.
TAP: Thick brown with nicely lacing from the white head. Cherry and banana aroma and flavor. Creamy palate. Full bodied and lively flavor.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2012 On tap at TJs. Pours clear brown with thin head. Caramel, dough, figs. Fairly sweet. Thick bodied. I like it better on tap, not so much in the bottle.

4/11/12. I have to increase this rating. The last couple of bottles have been significantly more impressive. Maybe it was the temperature I was drinking it at earlier. This time I had it at room temperature, 68 degrees.

Tasted 5/2/11. 750ml Cork and Cage bottle. 2011 Vintage. First pour is hazy and sedimented with a brown-ish hue with murky, ruby highlights. Moldy bone white head. A cornucopia of fruity aromas! Raspberries, cherries, grape candy, subtle raisins, oranges and other citrus fruit, blackberries, fudge, plums, buttered toast, and all of it with a floral, musty basement aroma. What a wonderful nose! Full bodied and SUPER lively! Tart and tingling effervescence that dominates the initial palate. Im sure it will ebb with temperature and being able to breathe. A ton of similar fruity flavor in the palate as the aromatics. The palate really hits all the key spots: the tart, tangy, sweet, bitter and sour. Beautifully blended and such a bright character. Tart cherries and floral citrus. Sticky apple and pear notes. Candies dark, dried fruits and berry esters. Super smooth, bright and lively, malty and fruity. All this happens in the same beer! Stellar job from a quality brewery!

Bottle; cloudy brown with red hues and medium tan head; aroma-fruits, cherries and plums, alcohol, spice, caramel, toffee; taste-moderate sweetness, bitterness and mild carbonation. Mildly tart. What a great beer.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2012 Poured from a generously sized bottle into a trappist glass. Pours very nicely with a bout an inch or more head, very white and foamy :-). Color was nice and dark, almost like rust. The head never really comes, either because I drank it too fast or the head was so thick. First scent was extremely sweet, almost like maraschino cherries. Second good whiff came up with light caramel and lightly roasted malts, overall very sweet and floral. First sip was amazing, very carbonated, which only complimented the sweetness of malts and cherry. Aftertaste was rather mellow and smooth with dark caramel notes and alcohol. Palate was rather filling, Id say pair this with some fine (or string) cheese and fresh fruit. Might be overbearingly sweet for some, but for me it was very complex and delicious.

2010 bottle. Clear copper red pour with a quick fizzy off white head. Aroma is alcohol and dark fruit with a subtle sweetness, but the alcohol is pretty upfront. Taste is sweet and fruity with decent breadiness and yeast,but again the bozze is rather over powering. Palate is thin and slick with a fizzy chaulky finish. Ok, I found it a little off balance.

sweet sugar, dark fuit, cherries, alcohol, jam marmalade, earthy hops. 
Dark ruby colour, big beige head that creates a lid. rich quadruple style, dark malts, raisins, dark fruit, meets tart cherries in the end. ABV is evident, but not boozy. low bitterness and not overly pronounced yeastiness. Would have liked more tart cherries, but all in all very good. Smooth with low carbonation. 
This was as good as my expectations, nothing more, nothing less.

The beer pours a medium, clear brown color with a large cream-colored head. The aroma is a strong mix of Belgian sugar, yeast and dark fruit. The beer smells outstanding. The flavor is more of the same. I get a lot of dark fruit (mainly cherries) as well as some yeast, alcohol and dark candy sugar. Very sweet and fruity tasting beer. Very well balanced and very tasty. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A great American-made quadruple.

Pours a very dark read with a nice head. Aroma of fruits yeast and alcohol. Very sour flavor of cherries, raisins, and prunes. A nice fizz with the alcohol gives a nice feel on the way down. One of the better beers I have had in a while.

750 ml bottle.  What a great beer for the money.  beer pours a dark ruby tinged brown color. Nice head that disapeared pretty fast.. Big nose full of different fruits, with mainly cherries coming through. Also a yeasty breadiness to the nose.
Dark brown pour from bottle with a medium tan head. Aroma is sour cherries and sugar.  Taste is dark fruit, yeast and booze.  Complex, interesting and excellent.

2011 750ml bottle. Pours a bit of a cola brown color, dark but still translucent with a ruby hue. The head is big, white, and fairly tight featuring moderately big bubbles and minimal lace. The aroma is fruity with a distinct character of apple rind, some toffee, and some mild cocoa. The flavor is pretty complex, both fruity and richly malty with a nice cherry cordial character and a mild tartness mid palate. The beer drinks like a big beer and shows its strength no doubt but not in a cloying or annoyingly boozy way.  This stuff is an old favorite Ive not had in a few years, I still like it pretty well.

From a 750ml bottle from Picks Liquors poured into a Trappist glass. Pours a dark brown/black with ruby notes when held up to the light. A brownish/tan head, very thick and very lasting.  The aroma is very pleasant. Sweet and fruity like a bowl of Fruity Pebbles with sliced banana in it. Taste is very sweet with light bitterness and light sourness. It is full-bodied and very thick. Fizzy carbonation with a long sweet and slightly bitter finish. Overall it is a great beer. Darker than I expected and much more bitter. For $8.99, this is definitely worth the cost!
Amazing...... One of the best vie had.has a great overall taste. Super dark for a Belgium. Love it

A really impressive interpretation of an apt/quad. dark and effervescent like a quad, with a bitter almost sour dark fruit flavor from the lambic that is blended in with the traditional quad. absolutely delicious and nothing short of what youve come to expect from Ommegang

Pours a dark hazy amber with very reddish hues.  Aroma of cherry, chocolate, cinnamon, citrus.  Flavor is caramel, cherry, nutmeg, pepper, citrus.  A well rounded beer.  Spicy and fruity but with enough malt backbone to keep it from going too sour.

Chestnut brown, slight haze, brown head. Pie cherry in nose, along with complex fermentation esters and some alcohol. Flavor of molasses, with cherry very present. Quite a bit of alcohol warmth. Has a medicinal quality too (cherry cough syrup). Mouthfeel is a bit thin. A very good beer...hard to be too critical, but just not as complex as belgian from Belgium.
Bottle. Pours amber with very thin white head. Aroma is cherry. Flavor is syrupy cherry and some fig. Needs more carbonation.
Slight cherry tartness in the flavor.  The aroma also has faint traces of cherry.  Overall it has a great malt base and is very good Belgian Quad.

12oz bottle in a Trappist glass.  Pours deep ruby/brown with a thick, lingering, lacy, cream-colored head.  Aroma very strong of the spicy yeast, caramel malts, a little dark fruit, and some floral hops.  Flavor very similar, with a little bit of cereal/roasted malts in the mouth and the fruits on the finish.  Smooth texture.  A pretty good quad.

On tap at the Spring Bar Los Angeles. Pours out a dark amber with a reddish hue and a slight head. Aromas of roasted malts, cherries, plums and  Belgium yeasts. Tastes dark and complex. Tastes of ripe fruits, Belgium candied sugar and the toasted malts. One can detect the presence of the almost 10 % alcohol. Finishes slightly sweet but not too sweet. A very nice complex brew.

750ML wire caged bottle. cork popped with very little force compared to some other Belgians. pours a dark brown/red color with a little haziness from the yeast from bottle re-fermentation. nice off white head, medium carbonation. the flavor is nice and malty balanced with a fruity-currant  flavor. leaves the tongue nice and semi-wet, versus excessively dry. overall I thought it was very digestable, and had some character to it. versus other quads this one is very smooth and could be served to non belgian beer lovers.

I had this one a while back, so long ago. Tonight I had it again. Wow, this was a solid beer. From a 12 oz bottle it poured a clear ruby color with a tiny, thin off-white head, dissipating rapidly. Aroma was dried fruits (from the cherries), sweet malts, and sweet candi sugar. Flavor was sweet malts, tons of dried fruit notes, wow.

Beer pours an amber color with a nice head.  Aroma of cherries and typical Belgian beer.  Taste is rich with heavy body and heavy cherry notes.  Aftertaste is sour.  Overall very good but fruitiness threw me off.

It pours a medium brown, little darker than a coca-cola but in the light its an amber. There is lots of carbonation with a light tan head 2 fingers that lasts awhile with good lacing. When you swirl head comes back quickly and stays for a while again.

The aroma is sweet hints of raisins, chocolate, can really smell the malts. 

The taste is a bit of a letdown, its ok, but drinking next to a R10 its quite lacking. There are notes of chocolate, with a little bitter end.

Pours deep, reddish brown, light tan fluffy head. Fermented cherries, Belgian yeast on the nose. A fair amount of carbonation adding a lighter texture. Sour kick after the fermented cherries mellow out. Pleasant, long finish. Unique and worth a shot.

Thick, brownish white head, opaque reddish brown in appearance. Aroma is primarily malty. Taste is moderately bitter with yeasty hints, cherry aftertaste. Doesnt hide its ABV very well. Moderate fizziness. Worth trying a few times.

Bottle. Pours amber-brown with a gigantic biege head which leaves nice lacing. Aroma is dark fruits, cherries (surprise!), prunes, Belgo yeast. Flavor is very sweet, fruity, a bit boozy. I actually liked this better than most quads Ive had, I thought the cherries took a bite out of the boozy/sweet taste that turns me off to most of them.

Bottle pours deep red/brown with an off-white head.  Aroma shows notes of toasted caramel, prune, cherry, and a dash of cocoa powder.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of oak and licorice. Overall body is moderate, creamy, and finishes with almost no bitterness.
Oh yes.

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2012 12 oz. bottle- Pours dark brown with almost no head or lacing (WTF). The aroma is brown sugar and Belgian yeast. The flavor is brown sugar and gritty unfermented sugars. The body is medium, carbonation is low (for the style), finish is thin. Unimpressed with this one, had high hopes and was severely let down. As it warms the flavors get better, it wasnt as bad as I originally thought. Re rate, some time in October- this beer is so much better than the first time I had it, not sure what happened the first time. Aroma stays the same. The appearance goes from a 2 to a 3, not a bad looking beer. The taste is so much better, what the hell, from a 6 to a 8. Palate deserves a 4, I had it at a 3. The overall was at a 12 is all, I am bumping that up to a 16. Seriously my original score was only a 3 total, not sure what happened, maybe a bad bottle, but this is a decent  beer.

A dark cherry red type of color with an off white head that had some pretty good size, average retention and some real, real nice lacing.  The head was creamy looking.  Just didnt hang around long enough for me.  Settled to a nice ring though.  Smelled the alcohol and booze right off.  Smells like a red wine.  Dark fruit.  A bit of dark cherry in there.  The taste provided a very strong booze presence with a noticeable burn at the back.  Again, Im gathering the dark fruit flavors.  Cherry and prune.  Mostly tart.  Even getting some toasted malt.  Medium/full mouthfeel.  Really covers the palate.  A significant amount of alcohol warmth.  Sort of rough aound the edges going down.  Leaves a tremendous amount of flavor on the palate.  Im sure that this brew has a tremendous following.  A bit much on the alcohol flavoring for me however.  Not something I would want over and over.  Its definitely a "sipper."  A little too much of the wine characteristics for my liking.  I want a beer that leaves me wanting for another sip.  This beer did not provide that for me.

Bottle. Pours a deep golden brown with a slight reddish hue and a small creamy off white head. Aroma of some light sweet and slightly tart cherries and some other dark overripe fruits. Mostly a pie crust and biscuit sweetness with some grain. Flavor starts with a sweet fruity jelly like note. Gains some grains and an earthy woody character before a sweeter lightly fruity and bready finish.medium body and a crisp carbonation. Not bad.
dark brown, creamy head. burnt sugar aroma, some dark fruit. dark caramel and dark malt taste, some fruit. Ok finish, gotta say wasnt impressed, will re-try at a later date.

A - Pours an extremely deep red color, with about a finger of head that fades away, leaving behind some lacing.

S - Fairly deep fruity aroma with cherry being the most prominent. A bit of floral hops and a little maltiness behind the fruitiness.

T - Very heavy fruit flavor early on, most predominantly cherry, but not too sweet. The maltiness and floral hops join in and the beer winds up very balanced. The tartness of the taste sticks around for a bit afterwards.

M - Fairly medium-bodied and carbonated. Though it is fairly smooth and crisp.

D - Fairly bold, but very drinkable. The tartness helps to cover some of the alcohol taste and stays crisp.
Tastes just like the Belgians but cheaper! Malty fruity flavors with slight cherrys in the palate

Appearance:  dark brown with rich reddish highlights, creamy caramel head.  Aroma:  some dark fruits, but mainly burnt or caramelized sugar	.  Taste:  crème brulee:  lots of burnt sugar and caramel, dark fruits and toffee malts.  Finish:  mainly sweet alcohol and sugar water.  Notes:  Just ok for me dog.  I didnt pick up on the advertized cherries at all, which is what I was looking for.  Still, from my notes, I rated this at least a year ago.  Might be worth another try.
A nice starter. I can definitely taste the raspberry and the alcohol, but I dont care for the after taste. It has a lively beginning. I would try this one again.
A solid choice form this brewery, similar to the NG cherry stout. It is tart and fruity, yet sweet, dark, and caramally.

12 oz bottle into Trappist glass. 2010 vintage. Pours a murky brownish-orange with no head and a collar of white foam. Smells like a Trappist beer. I smell bananas, faint cherry. Taste is sweet and sour with no bitterness. Very strong cherry flavor. Medium-low carbonation, medium-bodied. A sub-standard attempt at a Trappist ale.

Reviewed from notes.

Pours a nice reddish brown with a light tan head that stays around at about half a finger and leaves some good lacing. Nose brings forward subtle hints of cherries along with some light caramel and dark fruits. Hints of molasses. The taste really doesnt bring much cherry flavor at all. Really, I cant detect it, and it was faint enough in the nose. The taste does bring some Belgian yeasty esters and some caramel. Good, sturdy body that is slightly creamy. Not nearly as complex as Id like to see, but pretty good overall.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 10-19-2010

Dream beer? Sha... Not bad, but...
Small head. Fruity fresh smell, some cherries for sure but far from overwhelming. The high alcohol isnt really noticable. The mask of flavors, bitterness and utterly balanced sugars serves well. There are malt, dried fruit flavors and some more worthy side tones. The bottle was big but disappeared quickly between me and my wife. Wouldnt call it a girliebeer though. Its better than that.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2011 Bottle poured into a tulip glass. Three Philosophers is a well done beer. Very noticeable alcohol, a lot of carbonation, very noticeable fruity flavor. Little to no head. The cherry flavor is a bit much for me, it really cuts down on the drinkability of this beer. Certainly worth trying.

2009 vintage. I was expecting a lot more from this and was kind of disappointed. Taste is rather thin for a beer this strong and with those kind of flavours. Also feels rather dry, where there should be a slight sweetness. I got two bottles, so Im gonna try to age the other one, but Im not having a lot of hopes.

Pour is a deep, dark orange, nearly a light brown, with a very light tan head. The nose is of dark fruits, such as cherries and figs. Taste has some sweet notes at first with a little bit of a sticky mouth feel. Overall has complexity and it is a very good beer.
Brown with nice head. Aroma fruit cherry, figs, malt, yeast. Taste sweet fruit, cherry malty. Full body, text thick, alcohol hidden.

750 ml bottle from Systembolaget. Dark brown, hazy apperance with medium, tan head. Aroma is dark fruits, cherries, pumpernickel and wood. Taste is really complex and quite dry with some bitterness and sourness. Medium bodied with sticky mouthfeel. Really nice adaptation of the belgian style, the americans succeeded in making a great beer.

Hazy brown color with a light brown/red head. The sweet aroma with notes of prunes, alcohol and wood. Flavor of prunes, plums and wood. followed by some hops bitterness and malt. A great complex beer.
Not sure why I have never rated this guy. Bottled, dark rich and lots of fruits and sugars. Excellent stuff

Had a 2009 vintage on Feb. 1 11.  Pours out a hazy and very dark brownish ruby, with a small light tan head with a slight shade of pink.  Smelled like a Belgian dudes beer cellar.  Tart cherries very present, some honey, figs and plums, with a slight funk aroma.  Taste was just a little funky, maybe from age.  Or maybe it was just the noticeable alcohol mixing with a honey-ish profile.  Tart figs and plums return, and a hint of molasses is there, but the cherries lie a little subdued compared to their presence on the aroma.  Maybe just a touch too boozy for me, and a little much on the figs.  Still a great beer though.

12oz bottle.  2009 Vintage.  Pours a hazy dark ruby brown colour with a beige head.  The nose is big on dried fruits, molasses, sponge toffee, honey, earth notes and just a faint hit of cherry.  Taste wise, it is surprisingly heavy with molasses.  Dried fruit is also very present.  Prunes.  Earth notes.  The cherry lies mostly in the finish, along with some cocoa and citrus bitterness.  Fruit cake in a glass.

2011 bottle.  Dark ruby color; clear.  Thick tan head.  Smells like toasted bread, yeast, sweet fruit, and a little bit of the cherry.  Taste is very malty.  Caramel, and yeast.  Some fig and raisin.  The fruit flavor is a cross between cherry and apple cider, a little bitterness but also pretty sweet.  Some of the alcohol comes through as also. Big body; kind of sticky.  Very nice drink.

2010 vintage. Pours reddish brown with fluffy white head. Smells sweet, like cherries and Belgian sugar. Tastes like sweetness and alcohol, cherry flavor is present. Full-bodied with a sticky texture and active mouth-carbonation, Ommegang Three Philosophers finishes sweet, strong, and long, and has that warming alcohol effect.
Very strong beer that is very hoppy and rather bitter.  A real beer that doesnt play around.  Dark amber with a nice tan head.  Rather fizzy.

From the bottle. Pours a clear dark brown head with a lasting taupe head. Nose of dark fruit with notes of cinnamon, dates, cherries. This beer has a surprisingly dry palate with a nice, tight carbination tickle on the tongue and throat. This is a pleasant, body-warming beer.

12 ounce bottle (2010 vintage [packaged on 3/21/10, best by 3/21/15]). Poured into Ommegang chalice. 

APPEARANCE: Pours dark caramel tone of mahogany/brown. Off-white head settles rapidly, leaving only trace amounts of thin foam film atop portions of surface. Plenty of sediment all throughout, which is dark straw color and about the size of salt grains. Inexistent lacing. Effervescence appears slow; perhaps slowed down by the viscosity and sediment. 

AROMA: Heavy caramel malt sweetness, some soy sauce, subtle dried tart cherry, faint hint of kriek. Complex aroma, though the soy sauce like scent was detrimental to overall aroma. Subtle alcohol on nose. 

TASTE: Thankfully zero soy sauce in the taste; unlike aroma. Huge caramel malt on the palate, especially concentrated on front of palate. Faint graininess on mid palate, though largely masked by alcohol. Unfortunately, some of the subtleties of the cherry/kriek, which seem to appear most prominently on back of palate, are masked by the slight alcohol warmth on the back of palate/finish. All factors combined, this beer is like a caramel-covered cherry dipped in brandy of the beer world. 

MOUTH FEEL: Full bodied. Velvety smooth. Somewhat viscous. Mild carbonation. Some alcohol warmth. Dry finish. Almost like a fine port. 

OVERALL: Wonderfully complex Belgian-style quad. Only negative aspect is the subtle soy sauce in the aroma. Excellent dessert beer for slow-slipping; would pair terrifically with cheese or chocolate. Definitely let this one warm up a bit. Thankfully the sediment is hardly noticeable on taste/mouth feel (ie, because from appearance it seemed this would be a chewy beer). Best served on rare occasion, rather than frequently.

Review from notes, sampled 1/3/2008
Pours a crystal clear deep caramel color with red highlights and has a two finger head that lasts forever. Lace almost coated the entire glass. Smells of caramel and dried fruit. Has that yeasty estery taste as well as the caramel and cherries. Has a high level of carbonation. Very nice sipper. I would have liked the cherries to be up front a little more, but still a very nice brew.

Bottle. Poured into a DFH tulip glass a murky mahagony reddish brown color with a tight light tan head. An interesting aroma; a mix between cherry fruit, grape, plum, slight smokiness, alcohol, caramel, and an almost bubblegum type note. Medium/light mouthfeel. Wow! This thing has quite the boozy punch. The booze really takes away from the other flavors for me but it still is pretty nice. Sharp fruit type flavors up front followed by a smooth caramel flavor. Some roast type notes as well. Hmm, its flavorful but for me, as I said, the booziness sort of dominates this beer.

2007 bottle, tasted august 2008.  Ruby red color. Cherry,  marzipan, vinous and yeasty notes in the aroma. Hint of cherry wine in the flavor. Marzipan. Sweet but alcoholic. Yeast and vegetable notes. Just a little off balance

15th February 2009 Hazy reddish brown beer with a pinkish - biscuit coloured head. Dry and somewhat bland ale. A hint of cherry and some slight brandy from the alcohol. A bit one dimensional but drinkable.

16-01-11 Bouteille 12 oz  2010: Belle apparence cuivrée rougeatre, limpide, avec une mousse blanche épaisse qui disparait rapidement ne laissant quun tout petit filet. Effervescence moyennement vive. Légers aromes de cerise sur des notes surettes. Petites senteurs également de boisé et de brandy. Moyennement sucrée, avec une petite amertume et une petite note surette provenant des cerises. Corps moyen, avec une texture ronde qui descend bien. Asser forte carbonisation et finale plutôt astrigente et légèrement surette. La finale est asser courte, sauf pour lastringence. Cette bières nous offre des saveurs légères de cerises (on pourrait en prendre un peu plus) entremêler au brandy et a un léger coulis de caramel.

Pours an auburn red with a tan head. Has a caramel taste but not much depth. Not my favorite. 

12oz bottle
Bottle. Pours a dark deep brown color with a nice thin lasting head. Smells of cherries, grapes and raisins. Tastes of figs with a nice oak aftertaste.

09 bottle: Pours a dark reddish brown with a foamy khaki head. Nice lacing.  Smells of cherries, bread and malts. Lightly carbonated with somewhat creamy mouthfeel. Flavors follow the aroma, with some alcohol flavor. Very enjoyable ale.

Aroma is of chocolate cordial cherries - only muted.  Alcohol present in the nose gives a very slight medicinal edge.  Color is a deep, hazy, mahogany with an indestructible tan head.  Flavor is sweet and alcoholic.  Again notes of black cherries and a bit of licorice.  Creamy mouth feel and surprisingly a rather light body.

09 Bottle. Pour into goblet is pretty dead flat, barely there head, reddish brown. Smell of dark fruit, molasses. Taste of fruit sweetness, buscuity malt, slight alcohol. I like! Carbonation seems to have mellowed. Dry tart cherry finish.

Poured into a goblet.

3.5 A: Opaque amber brown color. Head is hard to create and falls very quickly. A bit of lacing.

4.5 S: Dark fruits (raisin is big) hit first, then dark cherries. Sweet caramel malt. No hops.

4.0 T: Tastes a lot like it smells. Plum, raisin, dark cherries, caramel. A lot of flavor, but not all of it meshes that well. Still, very good. Belgian yeastiness

4.0 M: Heavy Medium body. Good carbonation, but could be creamier.

4.0 D: This isnt boring at all, but it isnt the greatest tasting, which works out to pretty good drinkability but not great.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-03-2009 18:58:54

Sampled at an ESBLS tasting.  Was quite surprised to find I had not yet rated this beer.  A medium brown pour with a smallish head.  Very nice aroma of cherry and yeast.  Flavor is also quite nice.  Wonderful cherry flavors, yeast, wood, toffee, raisins.  Delicious.
a red and caramel pour with a robust beige head.  fruity aroma...the 2% cherries really comes through.  nice sweet taste with balanced malts.  very good.

This brew poured dark auburn with red highlights. The head was about a finger in width, was a tan color full of aroma. Lacing around the glass was even. First I noticed fruity and flowery notes in the aroma. The brew was light on the tounge and finished smooth with no negative after taste. Mid taste you can really taste a woody flavor which goes well with the distinct cherry flavor. No boozy taste to be found, this brew is a rated 9.8 by volume...which hit me harder than a 12 I recently had. This was a surprising pleasure to drink.

2010 Bottle Dark 1/2/11

A-pours a cloudy apple cider brown with red edges and tons of light cork tan colored bubbly head.

S-the nose is pretty solid, a nice spicy belgian style yeast is up front, lemony phenols, dark fruits take hold in the back. plums, dark cherries, hints of raisins with some fusel alcohol in the back.

T-the taste is much of the same with more sweet dark fruits in the back. nice spicy belgian yeast, phenolic lemony flavors, plums and dark cherries, very sweet with notes of sour green apple.  hints of alcohol in the finish with a bold presence.

M-medium body, a little grainy on the palate with a semidry finish and strong carbonated crispness to accompany.

D-this has a nice balance of spicy yeast and sweet fruits with enough booze in the finish to let you know its big.  still, the booze isnt overpowering at all and it goes down easily.

2009 Bottle

A-pours a tight slightly tanned creamy head. it lingers for a little bit and crawls down the side of the glass. beer is slightly hazy with a reddish copper color and a few bubbles floating through the middle

S-hint of a clovelike yeast that is taken over by sweet dark fruits. plum comes in first with lots of cherry aromas. alcohol shows through a lot when i poured but really mellowed as it warmed.

T/M-highly carbonated with a syrupy body and smooth on the palate. the taste is sweet but the alcohol is very present, although it really fades as it warms. the taste has a hint of toasted biscuit malt and lots of sweet dark fruits. it is ripe plum with a nice taste of sweet cherry. the finish is very crisp shows just a hint of alcohol, this is again as it is warmed.

D-really serve this at 55 degrees or above. once it got closer to room temperature it really opened up and was quite tastsy. cooler temps made the alcohol quite present. any who, very tasty and extremely smooth. quite nice in taste with huge flavors of cherry.

Bottle from 2009

A: The pour is a hazed dark amber color with a finger and a half worth of fluffy tan head.

S: Smells like slightly tart cherries and cherry pie. Theres some nice caramel and toffee notes as well. A touch of chocolate malt, raisins, and plums, too.

T: A definite alcohol taste to begin with which is followed by cherry skins, raisins, and plum skins. Theres a nice maltiness that I would describe as toffee, and a bit of brown sugar. The same subtle chocolate character that was present on the nose.

M: The body is medium with a moderate carbonation.

D: Not quite as boozy and overly intense as I remember, but something Id still have a bit of trouble drinking a significant quantity of.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2014 This was like drinking a grand cheery brew.  mouthfeel was fruity and sweet, the abv was present but not too overbearing, and the malt meshed well with the cheeries.  Quite a beer here and perfect for a NYE celebration.  This is a dream beer.
UPDATED: MAR 16, 2011 Pours a beautiful muddy red with an eggshell colored head. Taste is of tart cherries, dark fruits, subtle yeast and maybe belgian spice. Almost red wine like. Very good beer.

Pour is raspberry brown with a light off white head. Dark fruits, sweet breads, and raspberry jam on the nose. Flavors are initially sweet from the dark fruit nature of this brew but it gives way to a bready malty side and a happy bitter side near the end of the finish. Belgian sugars and abbey yeasts rear their head later on. Its good for the style but....

Rich quad with the pervasive cherry notes giving this an interesting composition. Very belgian. This has the spicy phenolic yeast that Im not a big fan of, but I still enjoyed this - which speaks quantities for the quality of the finished product.

750 mL bottle from Total Wine in Tucson, served in a tulip. Pours hazy mahogany with a tall tan head and a small amount of sediment. The head slowly fades to a thin cover and leaves a small amount of loose lace. The nose has notes of cherry, brown sugar, raisin, dark fruit and a touch of yeast. The flavour is incredibly complex--at once moderately sweet with a hint of sour cherry and a touch of bitter hops. The overall impression is of a complex, balanced fruity, malty ale. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a smooth, milky texture and healthy carbonation. Overall, this is an excellent beer that is truly unique. It has much in common with an Abt, but also has sour cherry elements reminiscent of a Kriek. Well assembled, complex and elegant, it is a beautiful contemplative ale. Among the very best. 2010-12-27

2008 bottle...pours a ruby/brown color with a light mocha head.  small bits of sediment throughout.  cherry is evident in the aroma with sweet maltiness.  flavor hints at cherry but has complex maltiness...roasty with cherry, chocolate, caramel, and earhty notes.  motuhfeel is very lively and slightly oily with a malty lingering finish.  nice quad but a bit to exotic for me given the style...

How many times have I dismissed this one in the grocery store isle?  Many.  Im not even sure why.  Im seen the "Three Philosophers" staring back at me for many years, just waiting to be purchased.  Maybe I found the price off putting?  It turns out it is a nice treat.  A cherry, sweet, malty treat.  Alcohol well hidden at 9.8%  Taste more like a fruit beer than quad.  Nicely done.
Complex, fruity, plum, cherry, tart balanced by strong malt backbone.  Pours with a large tan frothy head.  Mahogany color.  Sublime.

Pours brown with ruby highlights and a small tan head that actually stays and laces.  You can hear the carbonation like it is a soda.  On the nose I get the belgian yeast breadiness.  Sweet maltiness, caramel, dark fruits, cherry and some alcohol.  It gives nive nose.  In the mouth, it has a medium full body, coats the tongue in a good way, plenty of carbonation and some not so hidden alcohol in the finish.  On the tongue, it has a complex maltiness, bready, sweet dark fruits, cherry, molassas.  Very nice beer.

Pours thick dark brown with a thick tan head with great lacing.  Sweet with a slight offset of sour, mainly black cherries.  Balanced very well.  alcohol content comes through but not in an undesirable way.  Overall a good belgian style

Poured a slightly cloudy brown color.  Med head.   Aroma swee malt and slight cherry, and dough, banana.  Taste is med sweetness. Med body, creamy velvety texture.  Complex taste, typical with strong belgiums. Just a very slight sourness picked up near end of taste.  Very good though.

aroma of whiskey, alcohol and brown sugar, not sure if its brewed with maple syrup but it had a sweet maple taste coupled with the strong whiskey, alcohol taste. i did not mind it, but not at all what it was expecting
Very syrupy, kind of has a whiskey aroma and a whiskey like flavour. Not one of the better offerings of this style. Taste quad notes but wouldnt likely drink this again
A lot of roasted malts overtake the other flavors, and theres just not as much depth or complexity as i was expecting.

Tasted from a bottle at the Parade of Darks in Denver, Colorado. Mildly hazy orange/brown appearance. Candy sugar and a sweet Belgian flavor in the head. Sweet, even a bit orange tasting, with lots of candy sugar. Pretty smooth but the fruitiness is a bit weird. Still good beer.
Ommegang Three Philosophers: väldigt god, lättdrucken trots styrkan, torkad frukt, lite, lite körsbär.

750 ml bottle. Pours a deep ruby red brown with an off-white head. Nose is rich, malty, caramel, candied fruit, alcohol. Taste is like the nose. Body is full, chewy. Finish is sticky and sweet with the cherry coming through a little. Nice beer with a lot going on.

Red brown with off-white head.  Aroma has yeasty characteristics with clove, spice, mild banana and low-level kriek is detectable.  Flavor is mostly roasted malt, gingerbread, belgian candy and some mild acidic tartness from the kriek.  Great sipper.  The warmer it gets, the alcohol is more apparent and slightly detracting.  Medium body with dry finish.

I have had this a couple times in the bottle over the past couple years, and always figured that there must be something wrong in the situation that made me not enjoy it.  It HAD to be good.  It is a Belgian-clone quadrupel with cherries!!! 

Tonight I had it on tap side-by-side with a St. Bernardus 12, and I could barely choke it down.  It was salty, and minerally, and austere.  It was both lackluster and annoying.  It was a completely unenjoyable beer, and I downed it with some effort, before being able to return to the St. Bernardus that was rich, lush, plummy/fruity, and joyous by comparison.  Im giving up on this one.  Is it the water, or whot?

Pours dark ruby, fully opaque with the bits in, under a fleeting yellow collar. Heavily muscovado and malt loaf-scented like a serious doppelbock. Fine and slippery with bags of Bertie Bassett, liquorice confectionery notes, red wine and tannin hints and a dab of cherry drop. Ordinary, slightly meaty doppelbock-like quad with cherrystone and muscovado leanings.
Wonderful cherry aroma and flavor for only a 2% blend of Kriek.  Some chocolate, esters and a hint of alcohol heat at the end.  This took me a couple tries to really understand and now I love it.

Bomber. Pours dark amber with thin head and little lace. Nose slightly on the sweet side with notes of brandy, yeast, cranberry, sour cherry, and malt. Hot alcohol taste of sweets fruits up front, booze in the middle, and tart citrus on the finish. Very complex brew. Im not a fan of the style, but this is one of the better quads that Ive tried.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2012 Vintage 2009 cons 2012-11-02 new rating 4,3
Keep old average!

SÖF 25 year feast at Haket 2010-11-13 Göteborg - big bottle
AP: hazy appricot colored body
AR: apricot, sprity
F: aged barrel, apricot
Yolk: more sour and much more fruitiness

THANKS CRIPPLE!!!! For sharing this fine brew. (2007 addition) Brew look deep dark ruby brown complete with a thin tan cap, it sure looks perty. Aroma is mild yummy and sweet, slight hints of sour cheery mild oak and hints of medical alcohol.
