Nice smooth brew but has hints of dry sourness, Im fairly sure Im tasting cherry but cant 100% confirm that. Very mild hints of coffee show with caramel and oak. This is so good!! Taste really starts to shine through when warmer it becomes richer and heavier. I love this beer

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2013 This is no dessert drink. it is very delicious. yummy on the pallet. it does smell sweet but does not taste like a dessert drink.  The cereal malt is noticed on the aftertaste.  There is a slight resin taste on the swallow and you get a molasses tinge on the tongue.  The brew is mild and approachable and the carbonation prevents you from chugging,  I would only drink in a group again, not for solo fun.

Pours brown with a fluffy off-white head.  Sweet aroma of caramel malt and sour cherries.  Great flavor of dark malts, cherries, and brown sugar.  Slightly sour finish of cherries and some hops.  Not a typical quad, but it works great.

smells really sweet, almost cloying (molasses-y), but with a yeastiness and like alcohol. great. looks amber brownish, cloudy. taste like cherries (but in a medicinal way) and booze. 

not a huge fan, but whatever.
Pours brown with an amber/red tint with quickly dissipating head. Aroma is brown, sweet malt. Medium high carbonation. Sweetness throughout is accompanied by bready malt and molasses.

Draft at Stem and Stein in Madison AL. Ive had this one many times-finally got around to rating it.  Dark brown with a small head. Nose is tangy, spicy, some cherry and chocolate malts. Taste is cherry, chocolate, dark malts. Alcohol is present in the nose. Very fluffy body and a bit thick and chewy. Delicious.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Had this beer many times, but never rated it.  This is from 2009...12 oz bottle poured into a tulip glass.  Aroma is nice Belgian quad with sweetness on the nose.  The appearance is a brownish read color with a nice light tan head.  The taste is very nice with moderate sweetness, and great balance with malt and hops.  There are some subtle cherry notes as well.  Medium to heavy body with large abv....carbonation is medium.   Overall, one of the best from the great brewery.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2010 Poured a hazy reddish-brown with a thin off-white head.  Aroma of cherries and sour yeast.  Some caramel and brown sugar also present.  Taste is very complex.  There are sour fruity notes along with bitter hops.  Everything is balanced by a good caramel and brown sugar flavor.  Slightly creamy throughout with a good amount of carbonation.  Finish is slightly sour with grapes.  Overall very good.

Pours dark amber, hints of red, with a very small, but fluffy, off white head that laces down the cup.  Cherry and malty. Doesnt really mask the alcohol, but I dont mind it.  Im getting cherries and malts again in the taste, with some chocolate. A really enjoyable beer that warms you as you drink it.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2013 Thanks Ariel. 7/5/6/4/9[3.1]

At a tasting, thanks YK23, pours brown to red with a small tan head, aroma of cognac, cherry liquor, cherry sourness and noticeable alcohol tones, flavor of sour cherries, cognac, cinnamon, medium to full body. 8/3/7/3/14[3.5]

The best beer in the world, bar none especially when you quaff it at the brewery itself. It was served to me room temperature which really brings out the cherry notes. Its a beer best consumed slowly and with great reason.

A hazy brown beer with a huge beige head. Aroma is yeasty and fruity, notes of caramel, dark fruits and dark sugar. Taste is malty and fruity, roasted notes, some spiciness, woody, sherry.Very nice mouth feel, chewy. Noticeable but balanced alcohol. Very good beer.

Color is like a dubbel with a slight pink haze, headless.  It smells like a spicy, cured meat; like pepperoni.  Flavor is foremost sour cherries, and lots of yeast.  Palate is not as contemplative as a quadrupel should be in my opinion.  Bottle from Graces Plaza, Nashville, TN.
Pretty, burnt sienna, opaque color. Each sip is a strong prune juice and cherry flavor, earthy aroma.  Lingers on the palate, good beer, but the kind Id nurse.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a reddish amber with a small white head leaving little lacing.  Aroma is sweet with alcohol, cherries, and yeast.  A bit cough syrupy.  Taste is sweet cherry going into fig and other dark fruit.  Finish is bready yeast and alcohol.  Light bodied.  Low carbonation.

I had this a few year ago, but never rated it. A truly amazing brew, indeed! A gorgeous dark ruby brown color with a light tan head that goes to lacing and hangs around a while. Aroma is dark and sweet, but with a notable alcohol nose. The flavor - oh the flavor is sweet, dark cherry and chocolatey. Not overly done and muddy. Lingering cherry flavors. Slight tartness too. Gets better and better with each sip. However, the ABV really creeps up as it warms. Not a problem - let it breathe a bit, and youre all set!
Complex taste with hazelnuts, port wine, vanilla and dried fruit. Beer is dry enough to make your tongue curl

At a tasting, many thanks Shachar, small quickly dissapearing head, beautifull hazy deep red with rusty hues, aroma of hay, biscuit, sour spiciness and cherry liquor, flavour of cherries, dark chocolate amd dried fruits, alcohol much to strong, bitter alcoholic aftertaste with a hint of lambicy sourness in the back. Dissapointing

Bottle, brought back from Montana, had for my (Canadian) Thanksgiving dinner, along with a 1989 Chateau Palmer, which was admittedly better, but yeah, its an 89 Palmer. Pours clear to slightly hazy reddish-brown, thin to medium off-white head, light lacing. Nose is sharply boozy, even above anything else, I get a harsh alcohol rasp, though it does fade as the beer warms, or I got more used to it. Also notes of tart cherries, rich "root beer" maltiness, nice cocoa/vanilla/oak notes as well, some light tea-like notes as well. Flavours also show the alcohol, along with cherries, a sound and well-built Belgian malt base, and light fruit throughout. Finish is tart, boozy and astringent. Maybe I had this too young?

Bottle at a tasting: dried fruits, sweet and sour cherry brandy, raisins, bit of toasted malt, caramel, honey, floral, some toasted bread, yeast, the alcohol ia a bit too noticable but not too much, funky sourness in the finish and aftertaste, really good.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2013 Re-rate 12/28/12: Bottle sample at tasting. Thanks Ariel. Aroma full of fruity esters, bubblegum and malt. Sweet malty flavor with some cherries, fruit esters, candy-ish hints and a bit of alcohol. Finishes slightly drier with a light tart-bitter note. Medium-bodied, a bit over-carbonated. 7/3/6/3/13=3.2

Bottle at a tasting. Thanks YK23. Hazy reddish amber with a beige head. Aroma of malt, dark fruits, caramel, a bit of wood, light chocolate notes and alcohol. Sweet and somewhat vinous flavor with caramel, plums, cherries hints, a bit of raisins and a slightly drier finish. Medium to full-bodied. 6/4/7/3/13=3.3

Pours cloudy apple cider brown with thin, evanescent, light-tan head.  Smells of appetizing apple pie, cherries, slight brown sugar/rum, a little boozy.  Taste is cherry, fruit cake, bread, alcohol, lemon rind bitterness.  This is my first tasting back-to-back with the abbey ale and it is remarkable how similar their flavors are.  This is much boozier; I guess theres the same amount of flavor here with more alcohol.  Perhaps theres also a little bit more cherry, but Im not sure if I would have pinned it down as cherry had I not known a sweet kriek was blended in.  It feels thin and dry on the palate with lots of carbonation despite the lack of head retention.  Very boozy.  Im definitely ready to admit the flagship deserves a higher score than this; while it is interesting and certainly special, it lacks the perfection of balance that OAA has.  Still, this is delightful!

Bottle share with Andrew56 fantastic brew. Deep mahogany ruby red with a thin head. Sweet almost port like nose with definite cherry, malt and booze. The mouth is a little weird at first.. the mash of Belgian strong and cherry. Its warms up and smoothes out. Delectable brew with a very well balanced marriage of sweet malt, yeast, alcohol, candied sugars and dried cherry. Great Brew.

Corked and Caged 750 ml Bottle. Pours a reddish brown wood color with a half inch of milky light brown head. The aroma is caramel, spiced bread, butterscotch, candied dates and rum. The taste begins with fresh caramel and toasted malt flavors along with raisins, brown sugar, molasses and a little bit of woody alcohol at the end. Theres also an undercurrent of sour cherry flavors in there as well. The mouthfeel is smooth and full-bodied with medium carbonation and a dry, malty finish. Theres a nice interplay between the dark, sugary malt flavors and the tart sour cherries. The overall flavor is rich and complex and not nearly as sweet or boozy as you would expect.

(Bottle)  An aroma of tart cherries and malt.  The head quickly dissipates and complexion is medium amber.  Flavors of alcohol, cherry and malt.  Good mouth feel.  A unique Quadrupel that should be tried.

Bomber, corked and caged. Pours a ruddy reddish-brown, lively tan head. Nose is nearly all fresh, tart cherry with some sweet roots underneath. Taste is much more mellow, with the cherries and earth coming through, as well as hints of sugar and molasses. Clean finish, good carbonation, gentle mouthfeel.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2010 2009 Release. Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a Chimay goblet. Packaged on 12/21/09. Best by 12/2014.

Appearance: Pours an opaque chocolate brown with a 1/2 finger foamy white head which dissipates almost instantly. No lacing. A little disappointing.

Smell: Dried fruits with cherries being the most dominant. Just a hint of alcohol in the background.

Taste: Delicious flavor which mixes sweet dried fruits and spices. The alcohol is evident at the finish and provides a nice warming sensation. Mildly phenolic aftertaste.

Mouthfeel: Medium-to-full-bodied with a good amount of carbonation and a mild alcohol bite.

Drinkability: Very high drinkability, especially considering the very high ABV. This is one to drink slowly and savor.

Overall: An excellent beer overall. The style doesnt get much better if its not brewed in Belgium.
Birthday dinner beer from my wife. Pours nice reddish brown with thick head. Smells of sweet cherry and spice. Taste is nicely balanced, smooth, sweet cherry and alcohol kick. Nice beer!

Pours a cloudy crimson mahogany color with a thick foamy head. The aroma is understated, but notes of yeast and a dry cherry sweetness are discernible. The flavor is more of the same with notes of dried cherries, Belgian yeast, and grapes. The flavor is not overly sweet with the big cherry presence, though, and it has a bit of tartness to contrast the sweetness. Not quite as big in flavor or body as I would expect from the style, but an interesting, flavorful, and satisfying beer nonetheless.

bottle: dark red pour with no head. Dark cherries, tannic wine, raisins, and caramel. Light chocolate notes. Aroumatic fruits and a light tartness. Slight boozey warmth in the finish, but not all that strong. Very tasty. Heavy, but still quaffable. Not your run of the mill quad,  I dont think.

Pours a light brown with reddish highlights.  Big tan head that recedes.  Aroma of slight belgian barnyard yeast, fruit, alchohol and sweet malt.  Taste is sweet malts up front, with cherries, raison and alchohol.  The sweetness keeps this from allowing the other flavors to shine, which is what I love about quads.  With everything that goes on in a quad and the high alchohol taste usually associated with them, they are usually still very bright.  This didnt have that, but still pretty tasty overall.

Boy was this beer promising - I skipped out on another night of Stone Imperial Russian Stout for this one because it looked so interesting. And boy did it disappoint. Mouthfeel was surprisingly thin. Aroma was malt and cherry. Flavor was dominated by the cherry sweetness. It was too much, and it drowned out what tasted like a very promising maltiness. It was like cheap yeasty wine - in fact the closest thing Ive ever had to it was Two Buck Chuck. Some nice earthiness in the finish but this one couldnt be saved. Maybe Im just not a fruit beer guy, as this was my first fruit beer ever. But I really didnt like it.

Aroma is fruity with wild yeast and earthiness.  It has an extraordinary appearance, with a huge billowing head and artistic lacing.  The taste is a subtle blend of fruit and malt, with a strong ethanol presence.  I detect some wild, barnyard flavors with the sweet and sour balance intact.  I really love this beer, it is one of my favorites.

Perhaps the hype led to my disappointment, but I found Three Philosophers to be too filled with malty sweetness.  Beautiful to look at, but the carbonation was a bit sharp for my liking and the lingering sweetness let me down.

750mL bottle, pours dark maroon / brown with a medium off-white head. Aroma of black currant, grape, some cherry, caramel, yeast and honey. Flavour of caramel, cherry, black currant, lots of yeast and a bit of an alcoholic kick. Palate is very carbonated and complex. Excellent quad.
Alcohol is apparent, but not overwhelming.  Color is muddy brown.  Aroma is yeasty and bready.  Dark fruits abound.  Overall, an excellent beer.
A rich dark beer with a light tan head. The aroma is sweet smelling and you know it will taste delicious. Then the taste is amazing, leaving a great sense flavors on your palete.

THX to Olav. Tasted yesterday with friends @ jome from 75 cl. bottle. Amber colabrown with reddish shine, and a darkwhite head. 
Aroma little olderness, caramel, alc. touch. 
Medium body.
Taste bit olderness, sweet, caramel; malts; alcoholic.

The pour is a very nice ruddy complexion with a tan creamy head that stays soft and pillowy.  The aroma is a mild aroma with sweet brown sugars being the first accessible.  The alcohol is definitely in the nose with some yeast and rich dark raisins and plums.  Plums and raisins are very strong on the palate up front.  Rather sweet from the brown and candied sugars.  The finish is a bit dry and a little shorter than it should be.  Overall, this did not disappoint and is a fantastic renditiono the style.

Belgian brown body with an adequately foam beige head. Aromas of mild roast, pale chocolate nut, and caramunich deliver a similar flavor punch. Perhaps a note of chocolate cherry. Smooth chocolate roast with subdued Belgian yeastiness. Full biscuitiness endows the brew with plenty of body. Alcohol is well contained within the elements. Well crafted from start to finish. Good stuff.

355ml bottle from Whole Foods in Maui. Pours a murky cola brown with thin tan head that reduces quickly to a thin ring. Aroma is alcohol, wheat, and honey. Didnt really notice much of the cherry lambic in the aroma. Head is about an inch deep, light tan coloration. Taste is a bit strange, light alcohol to begin with, then the cherry taste comes in with some caramel. A pretty good beer but not as appealing to me as the ratings would have foreshadowed.
Pours a deep dark amber with a creamy beige head. Smell of sweet cherry and raisin. Taste or cherry, raisin and nuts. Slight tart and boost finish. Interesting blend and strange but decent beer.

Aroma: caramel, chocolate, resin.
Appearance: amber, brown, cloudy, sparkling, frothy, white foam.
Taste: medium sweetness, lightly bitter.
Palate: full body, thick feel, fizzy, long finish.
Overall: This big beer is one of my favorite Belgian ales of all time, and one of the top two on my list for the quadrupel style. I like the rich, sweet, complex flavor, the thick, full body, and the high alcohol content, which hits you real fast. This ale is as elegant as any wine, making it a perfect choice for any special or romantic occasion.

From the 750 ml. corked bottle.   It has a cloudy dark amber pour with a large fluffy beige head that sticks around.  The bottle conditioning lends to the haziness. The aroma has a mild floral hoppiness to it with a berry-like quality as well. The taste blends a bit of cherry with mild caramel malts, spices, and powerful hops.  The alcohol is also fairly obvious. Nice take on the style.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy brownish amber with an off-white head.  Nose is moderately sweet with some prunes, dried cherries, yeast, caramel.  Medium body with more of the nose throughout, some alcohol towards the finish and some wood.
UPDATED: AUG 29, 2010 Nice quadrupel. Nice and dark with nice head and full body. Very enjoyable taste of malty caramel and fruit.

750 ml bottle. Pours dark brown with a nice off-white head. The aroma is nutty, toasty, with an undercurrent of tart cherries. The flavor is malty sweetness, with a little bitterness and a hint of tartness. The mouthfeel is heavy, creamy and smooth, with a crisp finish. A very well done beer.
A little on the fizzy side but not too bad. I could definitely taste and smell the sherries in it yet I wouldnt say that it was strong enough to classify it as a "fruity" beer.

Pours a red cloudy beer, with low head and not too much bubbles. Aroma is chocolate, cherry, caramel. Taste is cherry, Lots of cherry, Its sweet, but its not like a cherry-drink, its still beer. Medium body and medium carbonation. Some bitterness at the end.

I retried this beer because the last time I had it (couple years ago, I think) I didnt realize that it was blended with cherry beer.  Upon retrying it, I figured out that it is because the cherry isnt exceptionally strong.  Great beer though!

12 oz bottle, pours a clear garnet w/ a half finger off white head, aroma is a pleasant blend of cherries, caramel, and rum, flavor is similarly cherries and rum w/ some caramelized sugar and a boozy warming finish, very nice
Pours brown with a 3 finger head. Smells of cherry and some yeast. Taste is round roasty malts, cherry, grapes, very complex. Dry finish, almost smoky. Fantastic.

A damn fine beer, I would drink it until my liver gave way. Nothing offensive at all, just beer bliss. Would get again fo sho.
lots of heat, but in a good way, very deep dark stone fruit notes, rich but drinkable. great beer.

Ruddy brown/amber brew with a nice white head. Served in goblet. Very complex aromas of caramel, oak, and banana. The taste follows the nose but also adds some cardboard, wheat, dough, and a tiny hint of grapefruit. Very complex, heavy mouth feel. Bitter finish. Tasty and unique.

Red / brown body, white head.
Sour cherries and raisins in aroma. Also some alcohol and yeast.
Flavour has  more raisins and little chocolate. Sweet, mild bitterness
from hops. Little too  much alcohol on aftertaste, otherwise this would be really top brew.

Bottle at the hotel in NYC. Redish/brown body with a medium beige head. Aroma is yeast, fruit, camamel and alcohol. Flavor is alcohol, yeast, cherries, caramel. Light sour finish. Well carbonated. Not the best I´ve had.

Wild yeast smell. Pours dark red to brownish with a moderate white to tan head. Taste of sour cherries with a wild Belgian yeast funk. Is very tart and has a medium to low hop bitterness. Sweet. It is low to medium bodied leaving a lingering tartness in the back of the mouth. Overall a very good beer. Fits the style.

Ommegang
Three Philosophers
Pours brown with a reddish tinge and a medium cream colored head and good retention. Somewhat oily with minimal lacing. Aroma of yeasty bananas and some sweet maltiness to the nose with a little alcohol. Slightly sour yeasty flavor with some light cherries and other stone fruits. Some alcohol on the palate, but its nicely balanced by a medium maltiness. Nice brew and good value.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2011 Pours medium brown with a medium, light brown head. Nose is very sweet with a blend of caramel, brown sugar, and fruit. Flavor is big and sugary, with caramel, apples, a little cherry, and light hops all joining the mix. Finish is also sweet and a little oily but quite good. A very impressive quad and a great value for the quality and price tag.

Appearance - This beer poured a nice amber color with a nice off white head. Lacing was present throughout.

Smell - Huge smells present. Orange, lemon cherries and spices. The fruit smells dominate. Also a hint of alcohol.

Taste- Man this is a good beer. Great spices and fruits clearly present. I do get a sour cherry taste along with citrus fruits as well. Very complex.

Mouthfeel - Medium body with medium carbonation.

Overall - Incredible beer. Not something I could drink on a regular basis and would love to taste this aged. Im glad it came in a 12oz bottle also because the 750ml would have been a bit much.
Bottle. Big aroma of roasted malts, sweet fruit, and I got a little bananna dont know where it came from.  taste: nice sour taste with the mixture of caramel and kind of poached pear

From 750 ml bottle. Pours deep reddish-bronze with a light tan, rocky head. Aroma of bread, cereal, dark chocolate, and after a while some cherry comes through. Chocolate malt and sour cherry predominate in the mouth, creating a nice interplay of rich sweetness with the sour. A little thin on the palate for such a big beer. The sourness lasts on the palate, precipitating another sip. A fine beer, and perfect for sipping on this cool summer night.

Poured from a 750ml bottle. Smells absolutely perfect with strong cherry smells and some alcohol notes. Pours a beautiful reddish/brown color with medium off white head. Tastes sweet and slightly sour.  Good beer.

Strong aroma of dark, dense fruits with a slight woodiness. Chocolate covered raisins on palate with a slight sourness. Lovely, lingering finish that will keep you coming back for more. One of Ommegangs best brews.
Deep roasty aroma hinting at cherry flavor. Appearance is deep red with a small tan head. The taste is a complicated mix of spices with a definitive cherry flavored ending.

750 ml bottle. From the US. Courtesy of Brandman.
Dark reddish brown colour with small tan head.
Belgian yeast, dark fruits, sugar, berries, malt and some alcohol notes in aroma. 
Flavour is roasted malt, alcohol, chocolate, raisins, some sugary sweetness and burned something. Rich and thickish.

Another "wow" beer, and the last from my Chicago trip. Im sad, as with the last drop of this, Ill have nothing physical to show for my trip. Guess Ill just have to go back! Anyway... Im struck by just how beautiful this beer looks in the glass. Deep ruby red with a caramel head. Tiny bubbles rising from the etching on the bottom of the Chimay glass Im drinking it from. It looks like a dream. The aroma... um, Im not sure how to say this, but it reminds me of polished wood. Theres nothing bad about this though. Its a beautiful, deep, woody aroma, with hints of cherries, plums, and toffee mixed in. The flavour is hard to pin down. Cherries are there, certainly. Some oak? Caramel, plum skins, almonds. It shifts and changes as you drink it. Full in the mouth, and amazingly complex. The finish is drying but with the memory of sweetness. A beer Id never get tired of.
75 cl bottle, Mulmur, ON, Canada, smuggled in the move back. Raisin and spruce aroma, some hop bite with a sweet alcohol finish.
12 ounce bottle -A murky brown pour tan head-aroma and taste of floral, fruit,spice-super sweet alcohol finish

Served from bottle into a La Chouffe tulip.  Pours a dark brown with a 3+ finger off-white head that subsides to minimal after sitting a bit.  Maintained nice lacing throughout.  The only aromas I could pick up on were fruit wtih a trace of alcohol.  The flavor followed the smell with only fruit and alcohol showing up.  It had a medium feel on the palate with medium carbonation.  Overall this was not bad for a quad.  It was very smooth and drinkable.  I would definitely purchase more and drink it again.

Ive had this a lot but finally rating.  enjoyed last night while playing poker in brooklyn.  pours reddish brown.  taste is of dark cherry and plums.  its slightly sour with good carbonation.  i really enjoy this brew

Classic label - Bobby likes the silhouettes of the philosophers.  This fine looking dark brown ale flashes its red hilites as it leaves its champagne-corked vessel.  At first the aroma is a nice of wave of cherries followed by funky yeast, which sticks around longer.  The flavor is first rate - sour cherries and floral sweetness blended with robust malt and an earthy hop finish.  Complex on the palate.  This is excellent - one of the best American examples of an abbey ale.  If brewers like Ommegang continue to release such fine brews, they are going to start getting a little nervous over in Bruxelles.

Bottle at Winking Lizard Crosswoods. Hazy reddish brown pour with a medium tan head. Aroma of cherry twizzlers, caramel and booze. Cherry liquer flavor giving way to banana esters and a sweet caramel finish. Very good, but minus a bit of heat it would be exquisite.

Draft at Magic City Brewfest.  Pours a deep mahogany with a nice beige head and lots of lacing.  Aroma and flavor are caramel malt, some yeasty funk, earthy, a bit of spice, some fruit (cherry and other dark fruits).  Thick but not heavy mouthfeel.  Delicious.

Pours a nice deep reddish brown with a frothy head that subsides quickly.  Aromas of alcohol and an almost banana like hint.  Spicy attack which fades to a warm almost fruity and sour finish, long finish on it.  Very nice mouthfeel.

bottle - pours really deep amber and frothy.  Smells of chocolate flavors.  Aroma is chocolate or coffee and alcohol: quite flavorful.  Taste is a little sweet and somewhat bitter.  Medium to full body and not much carbonation.  Long finish.  Whoever write the "dream beer" description didnt have mine in mind.  So far this is my least favorite Ommegang  brew.

On tap at Flying Saucer. Pours a cloudy amber with a small frothy white head that diminishes quickly. The aroma is a sweet fruit cherry and toffee. Medium mouthfeel with a mild sweet flavor with a nice smokey finish. Hides the alcohol decently, a very impressive Quad from Ommegang.
Very little head and a sour flavor but still tasty.  Not as great as I was expecting given the other reviews.

Aroma of alcohol and sweet fruit, banana maybe.  Pours a cloudy brown with a slight red tinge.  Not much in the way of a head and what does exist fades within a couple of minutes.  Taste is slightly sour and has a sour fruit note.  There is sweetness as well but probably more  factor of the roughtly 10% alcohol.  Not particularly bitter. 

Enjoyed it and will enjoy consuming the other 3 in my fridge.

Poured a 12 oz bottle that Ive been cellaring since last summer into a tulip. The molasses-colored liquid raises a thin head with relatively large bubbles, both of which disappear quickly. The beer has mellowed quite a bit over the last twelve months, but retains strong flavors of sour fruit, stone fruit, and funk. There is just too much lambic and not enough malt in there for my taste. Lots of folks love it, though, so you should read the other 1000+ reviews before making up your mind.

2005 Vintage
2/14/2010:  Ommegang Three Philosophers...  Aroma:  Lots of sugary caramelized sugar and malt with just a slight hint of cherry hiding underneath; high amount of alcohol; note of oxidation.  Appearance:  Has the color of dried dates with a red plum hue; 1-finger, bubbly beige head that quickly dissipates.  Flavor:  Sugary, chewy, caramel; sweet sugar; barely, if any cherry; quite a bit of oxidation coming out; slightly spiced apple cider; sweet breadl trippel-like bite up front; dry prune-like finish.  Palate:  Medium-full; fairly smooth.  Overall:  This beer may have cherry-lambic added, but the proportion must be quite low (25% or less?) as the cherry is pretty much non-existent; this particular vintage is probably about 1-2 years past its prime at this point (probably best 0-3 years from bottling date); overall, this beer definitely did not meet my expectations; I am fairly disappointed.
750 mL corked and caged bottle (9.8% ALC.VOl.) from Rivers Bend Wine and Spirits in Maineville, Ohio.  Rating #1587 for this beer.

From Bottle,  the nose is of dark fruits (fig/plums) and cherry, and of dark malts.  Light and thin, medium high in carbonation.  Good malt hops balance...malt up front and bitter fruit ending.  Fits the style except for the CO2.  Nice deep ruby-brown color.

Notes say on tap at The Annex AP, NJ. Cloudy dark red/brown with small, thick head. Aromas of cherry, banana, clove, fig and tobacco. Flavors of cherry, toast, roasted nuts, banana, fig, caramel, tobacco. Medium-full body with foamy mouthfeel and low carbonation.

Pours ruby red with thin off white head.  Aroma is toffee, molasses, almost cookie-like, with a tiny touch of cherry.  Taste is nice and sweet with toffee, molasses, some cherry and a sticky sweet finish.  A little too sweet overall, but a tasty brew.

The aroma is sweet, cloves, raisin, banana/bubblegum. It pours a golden brown, clear with a light brown creamy head mostly diminishing, good lacing. The taste is a little sweet, a little bitter, creamy, maybe even a touch sour. The body is medium, the texture creamy, the carbonation a touch fizzy and the finish long.
bread, toast, grass, citrus, amber, hazy, tan foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, salty, light body, creamy, soft carbonation, bitter.
Golden-brown and hazy. Has an off-white head, lasting. Aroma is yeasty and spicy, pepper. Candis-sweet too. Flavor starts heavy sweet and finish moderate bitter. Syrupy texture. Lively carbonation.

Pours brown into the glass with a small off white head, becomes bright red when held to the light.  Aroma is some dark fruit and spice.  Flavor is plum and raisons with some bubblegum like notes.  Body is somewhat thin, I dont get the expanding carbonation like I am accustomed to with Belgian styles.  Overall a really nice beer though.  Well balanced for being so potent.

Hazy, dark, red-amber pour with a short off-white head which fades quickly. Cherries and caramel predominate the malt body which supports the ale throughout, but there are hints of licorice, cheese, toast and wood in and amongst the complex but not overly-sweet aroma. Medium body and carbonation, but taste is slightly too sour and salty for my preferences. An excellent example of a Belgian high-ABV style ale

aroma - strong scent of cherry, with a hint of roasted nut and a slight hint of alcohol

apperance - Thick frothy head. Dark amber, with a lively carbonation

taste - Strong cherry flavor, alcohol is present but well masked, with a nice subtly malted finish

Palate - Light, slick, and lively.

The beer was fairly sweet with a good cherry presence and a nice Belgian yeast character.  Very easy to drink despite its 9.8% alcohol content, the beer appears to be the perfect blend, and is well brewed.  I would highly recommend this beer to anyone.
Dark and cloudy with a touch of dark reddish tints. The aroma is somewhat sweet, while the flavor is creamy at the start but ends with a bitter finish.

Bottle: 2008. This was really good stuff. Pours a deep red color with beige head. Sweet, spicy, malty aroma. Sweet caramel and candy, yeast, fruits and lots of spices. You can taste the alcohol but it was just the right amount before becoming too much. Great beer. Give it a shot
Heavy beer.  Great Beer.  Let it warm up a little before drinking.  The flavor is very nutty and floral.  The color is a fantastic burnt amber.  Enjoy.

Outstanding.  Ive never had Westy 12 but have had Rochfort 10.  I do not feel this is similar in body to Rochfort 10 but is definitely still an excellent beer.  It remindes me a lot of their Abby Ale but with a lot more to it.  The 2% Kriek adds a real nice fruit flavor to the experience.  I was really worried about this being too sweet, but my fears were quickly alleviated at first taste.  By far my favorite american-made belgian-style beer.  (note I have not yet had anything from Russian River or new belgium).

Ommegang Brewery--Three Philosophers Belgian Style Blend Quadrupel Ale--2004 25.4 oz. Bottle.  9.80% ABV.  25 IBUs?  (4.0 / 5.0)  Belgian Ale--Quadruppel.  Rich lacy head.  Hazy Bottle Conditioned dark amber brown color.  Mild Belgian floral malty fruit ester mild hop front.  Rich sweet tangy  malty toasted estery caramel cherry lambic body.  Spicy Belgian end.  10/27/2004.

From 750ml bottle-poured into my 25cl Chimay chalice.

A- Body is a very hazy-almost opaque medium reddish brown hue. Pours with a relativly thin slightly off-white head that fades quickly and leaves a fine white collar around the glass. Minimal lacing is left behind.

S- Nose is strong of cherries, alcohol, chocolate, caramel, and a spicy Belgian yeast strain.

T- Upfront is sour cherries with sweet caramel malt backbone. Spicy Belgian yeast and alcohol emerge for the finish and seem to make the initial flavor disappear. All of these components linger equally-which is the highlight of the flavor. The intricate complexity of all these characters that dont usually mix together plus the addition of sweet chocolate. Its good and it really makes you think.

P- Carbonation is low and mouthfeel is mostly smooth and yeasty with hints of an alcohol slickness/burn.

O- This is a very interesting and complex brew that I do enjoy-but the blatant booziness of it all keeps the drinkability above average-but less than "good." This is my 5th quad and it falls in the middle of the 5 for me. I love Ommegang and their brews and through this isnt my favorite quad I will certainly have it again.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-25-2008 02:22:19

[Bottle, 2009] Pours a deep rusty color with a small amount of dense beige head. Sweet aroma includes spice, alcohol, yeast and sweet malts. Taste is of sweet caramel malts, candi sugar, yeast, cherry, plum and assorted spices. The alcohol was a bit harsh for my liking. The beer was pretty well made besides that.
pours a dark brown with a reddish hue with a giant billowin head. the smell of belgian spices and subtle cherries abv is apparent in the first sip but as this brew warms the cherrys overpower alcohol
Heavy malty aroma. Huge, frothy, off-white head. Good lacing. Mostly lasting longevity.  Clear, amber body. Flavor is light raisin and cherry. Medium palate.

Bottle pour to Trappist glass dark brown/red with thin brief head.  Aroma sweet with dark and light fruits.  Taste currants, raisins, malts with a little cherry.  Very smooth with nice tart finish.  A little bit of alcohol.  Very nice.

Bottle. Creamy off-white good mostly lasting head. Amber colour. Heavy malty and moderate hoppy aroma. Really nice rasin notes. Moderate bitter nice fruity flavor. Long moderate bitter finish. Creamy palate. Good but not great.

Bottle pour.  Aroma is sugars, raisins, cherries, alchohol.  Poured a reddish brown.  The cherry is unique and fantastic, subtle but everpresent, nice blend of tart and malt.  Great brew, look forward to trying again.

Poured a dark reddish brown with a thin off-white head. Aroma: malts, sweet, some fruit, a hint of alcohol. Taste: malts, yeast, spices (pepper), notes of alcohol, sweet. Medium body with some depth, decent finish. I can not say I noticed any cherry. Overall good.

Pours a dark reddish brown color with a small head. Fruity and malty aroma also some sugar, cherries and yeast. Taste of malt, yeast, some cherries, fruit, slightly tart. Very tasty and drinkable ABT/Quadrupel. The alcohol was well hidden.

Pours a hazed deep reddish brown with 3 fingers of light brown foamy head. Aroma is belgian yeasts, candi sugar, molasses, rasins, nuts, roasty malts, acidic cherries and fruits. Flavor is belgian yeasts, spices, cherries, a little earthiness, dough, rasins, oak, some bitterness lingers in the finish. Enjoyable beer.

Pours a dark, cloudy umber color with only about half an inch of white head that fell quickly. 

Yeasty, bready smell with sweet caramel notes and an undercurrent of the cherry. Almost cloying.

Taste of  complex malt, finishes with a tart cherry note, the balance of malty start and tart finish is nice. A faint note of resiny hops throughout the sugary malt, overall very pleasant.  Alcohol is certainly strong but not out of balance. 

The palate is medium to full and carbonation is nicely balanced per the style. 

Overall very tasty take on the Quad style, the cherry is noticeable which is nice for only 2% inclusion. A worthy ale for certain.

Muddy light brown pour with very little head. Aroma of lemon and cherry as well as Belgian yeast and Belgian candi sugar. Initial flavor is brown sugar but there is some dark fruit on the finish. The cherry is only somewhat present as you would expect from only 2% cherries added. The alcohol is strong. A very good Belgian-style quad.

2008 bottle consumed at least a year and half if not two years later. Pours deep copper-brown with bubbly light beige head.  Nose of slight cork, old wood, cherries.  A bit of rust and blood.  Similar taste, with slight addition of raisins, figs, and overripe bananas -- which was a bit surprising.  Been awhile since Ive had this, but I think I might have liked it better fresh.  Excellent for the price, but just good in relation to other quads... actually very good if just compared to quads from the US.

Bottle at home.  Pours a dark ruby color with a tan head that fades quickly leaving very slight tracing.  Smells very faintly of cherry and an almost robitussin-like nose. (not that thats a bad thing)  Its very smooth with a mildly sweet flavor. The palate is nice and heavy with a refreshing finish.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2011 Bottle. Poured a nice rich murky brown with a large frothy light brown head that lasted throughout and had some really excellent lacing that remained on the glass until the end.

The aroma was nice and enticing with a moderate dose of sweet malts, a smidgen of resin hops and a nice sweet yeast with notes of caramel and dried fruit and a mild alcohol tinge. 

It tasted quite sweet and a little acidic with a note of caramel and maybe a little brown sugar at first and finished with a nice sweet-bitter flavor and had hints of dried fruit and a slight alcohol flavor at the end with the flavor staying with you for a nice enjoyable duration. 

Mouthfeel was light to medium in body and dry yet slightly oily in texture with a mild carbonation. 

Overall a superb Belgian Ale with the sweet flavors meeting the bitter ones very nicely with just a hint of alcohol. Not one flavor in this brew overpowers another, giving you a tremendous taste.

Pours a very dark read with thick creamy head. Fruit and yeast aromas, the flavor is slightly tart from the kreik and also a little dry. This is a great blend of flavors, I had this a while back but this seems so much more flavorful than the previous one I had. I highly recommend this to anyone!

750 mL bottle from Total Wine in Chesapeake, VA (2008 bottle).  Muddy light brown pour with very little head.  Aroma of lemon and cherry as well as Belgian yeast and Belgian candi sugar.  Initial flavor is brown sugar but there is some dark fruit on the finish.  The cherry is only somewhat present as you would expect from only 2% cherries added.  The alcohol is well hidden.  A very good Belgian-style quad.

0.75 l bottle at OHaras, Tampere. Dark reddish brown color with small head. Sweet raisiny aroma with ripe banana, chocolate and cork. Sweet flavor with ripe banana, chocolate, plum, raisins, musty cork, clove and pepper. Exellent barley wine like Belgian ale with plenty of dark fruits and banana skin.

Pours a dark brown with a light head and adequate lacing. Aroma is strong malt with fruit undertones. Flavor is strong malt, sweet, and fruity in the finish. Alcohol is masked nicely for an overall pleasant flavor and finish.

Doughy, earthy nose that pours with a thick dark cream-colored head.  A red/brown body that is largely hazy.  It goes down with a creamy feel.  Overall, a pretty good beer.  It has a great lasting after taste that hangs around your mouth for minutes after the sip.

Pours a dark reddish brown with a nice thick white head. Aroma is full of alcohol notes and fruit. Mouthfeel is full bodied with a bit of carbonation. The flavor is fullbodied with heavy bread/dried fruit notes. Aftertaste has a bit of an alcohol tinge, but very nice full bodied beer.

Dont know anything about the quad style so its hard to summarize; dark-ish with heavy fruit presence, aftertaste is extreme, abv% is well hidden initially but comes to life on the aftertaste for better or worse. Really intense brew, not really my style but quite good.

Purchased at Winslows Tavern, Greenville NC

alcohol, cloudy, hazy, frothy, lively
Dark reddish brown with a thin head. Aroma-candi sugar, deep malt, bit of cherry juice. Taste-syrupy, malt, earthy, cherry undertones. Finishes smooth and full bodied.
Great Belgian.  The yeast give it a great sweet, fruity tone.  The body and sediment give helps the beer develop a beautiful caramel/amber color.

(2009 edition.) Aroma is pungent grape, coriander, Belgian spice, cherries and champagne. Slight, but pleasant enough.

The appearance is deep ruby red; minimal head. Nice color, not much body.

The flavor is spicy funk with white wine grapes. A little earthy and soil-like. Cherries are cloying, but mellow out as it warms up. Earthy grapes.

The palate is silky in a coat of grittiness. A nice feel for sipping. Fizzy at the end. Let this sucker warm up and youll get a nice, fizzy, chewy, cherry-laden Belgian quad.

750ml bottle pour to goblet type glass.  Very nice.  Hides the high ABV well.  Just a slight alc. burn in the throat about half way through a glass.  Smell of grapes and cherries.  Has the mouth feel of a 7UP.  Very refreshing with the taste of cherry cola dominating.  Some Hop notes in there too.  If I may be so bold as to say it would be an excellent summertime quad.

Poured from bottle. Nose is dark fruit, dark spices -- cinnamon and allspice, vanilla. Pours with a heavy head and lace; color is a medium red-brown. Taste is toast, slight cherry, malt, and an odd boozy hotness that Im not sure I like. Mouthfeel is creamy and elegant, but with a prickly carbonation that offsets the richness nicely. Overall, very good but not great.

12 oz bottle from the Four Firkins.  Deep caramel brown color, tan head, nice lacing.  Sweet, dark fruit aroma.  Creamy mouthfeel, dark fruit flavors with a touch of hops.  Finish is a bit hoppy too.  Awesome beer.

Sour cherry and banana dominate on the nose.  It is a beautiful beer to look at, a cloudy reddish brown with a light brown head.  I felt the flavor was lacking, a bit weak for a quad on many levels.  The palate made up for it, though, soft with a not too light but not too full body.

750 mL bottle.  (2007 vintage).  Rusty red-brown with a thin film of head.  Heavy (but pleasant) aroma of dates, cherries, cola, and cough syrup.  Flavour is heavy as well, but the carbonation lightens it up a bit.  Dried dark fruit, black cherries, red grapes, and maybe a little licorice.  Hard to detect the alcohol at all.  Dryish finish with a little bitterness.  Nicely balanced beer.

Nose on this one is tons of dark fruit, musty dusty basement notes, sweet notes throughout, cherries, figs, raisins. Wow a nice nose most definitely. Pours hazy reddish brown, some big bubbles, a still somewhat frothy head. The flavor is all dark fruit, figs, raisins, musty notes followed by a sweetish/tartish cherry flavor that comes in the finish. Lightly tart, super fruity, wonderfully balanced with not hint of 9.8%. Lovely.

Pours reddish brown with an off-white head.  Aroma is yeast, malt, cherries and alcohol.  Taste is very complex.  Malt and cherries with an aftertast of alcohol and sweer cherries and maybe a little carmel as well.  As it warms the cherries become more pronounced.  Nice alcohol warming sensation as it goes down.  Really nice stuff.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2011 Revised: This purports to be a quadrupel mixed with a kriek, but the the sour cherry flavor is pretty much imperceptible. Syrupy and oily, it has too much of a bitter chicory taste to it for my palate.

My gateway beer into being a beer snob. Shared a bottle at the local bar. Malty with a twinge of cherry and yeasty sweetness. Probably my favorite Belgian style beer and my go-to beer when having a nice dinner or having friends over.

Dark brown with a light tan head.  Aroma of molasses and sweetness.  Tastes malty and sweet with flavors of dark fruit such as raisins and figs.  Finish is short with raisin aromas as you breath out.  Really nice.
Deep dark amber color.  Aroma is of coriander, wheat, yeast, malts, and spices.  Flavor includes malts, spices, pine, and floral.  Has a malty floral finish.

Pours a ruby brown with an off-white head.   Aroma of Yeast, alcohol and spice.  The tastes are of alcohol heat, mild funk, some raisons and dark malt.  Also a licorice note.  On the palate it is very smooth and rich with more alcohol on the finish.  I think if I liked raisons and licorice I would love this beer. It is very well done, but some of the flavors I dont personally care for.

2009 12oz bottle from Brewforia 
Appearance: Slightly hazy copper/brown with a large off white head, very little lacing 
Aroma: Belgian candy, sweet malts 
Taste: Sweet malts, alcohols, caramel & cherries. The finish is dry. 
A good solid beer, tasty.

2009 Bottle - I wonder if I got a bad bottle, because I remember this being much better. Pours mahogany with a small cream-colored head. Sharp alcohol dominates the nose, covering up faint caramel and cherry notes. The taste is better, with smooth, sweet malt and a nice cherry and booze finish. Its decent, but not what I remember. May have to revisit just to make sure it wasnt the bottle.

Bottle.  Dark brown pour with ruby highlights and an off-white head.  Aroma is brown sugar, aromatic yeast, prunes, raisins, cherry, and spice.  Flavor has a doughy maltiness as a basis with a good helping of caramel.  Theres loads more complex dried fruit, with cherry and fig notable, as well as some spiciness towards the finish and some warm alcohol.  Nice full mouthfeel on this.  The flavor combination of this brings to mind a good raisiny bread pudding.

Serving: 750 ml. bottle.
It pours a murky, reddish brown color with a sizeable off-white head.  The nose is decidedly Belgian with notes of yeast, fruit, cherries, and spice.  The flavor follows the nose to some degree, but is also much lighter than expected.  The malt makes more of an appearance with some sweetness and caramel note.    There is also a greater earthiness in the taste, but it still plays a minor role.  The palate leans towards the rich side but the high effervescence helps lighten things up.  In the end I am left wanting something more out of this beer.  For all the hype, I dont think it lives up.  A Rochefort 10 or Rigor Mortis blows this beer away.

(bottle from Cheers Liquor Mart in Colorado Springs; sampled 2/3/10). Cloudy brownish red color. Medium off white head, which is mostly diminishing. Light aroma of cherry, malt, and alcohol. Light tart flavor. Avg duration. Dry finish. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Spare lacing.
Ruby-brown color in the glass.  Fruity ester notes in the aroma with yeast, bread, and toasted malt.  Fine carbonation with a rich mouthfeel.

bottle from Kjs liquor.  poured brownish with ruby highlights and an off white head.  aroma was very nice with lots of spices and belgian stuff going on with a light aroma of cherry hiding in the background.  flavor was same as the aroma plus some dark fruits, grape, and some alcohol.  body was medium-heavy with high carbonation.  i enjoyed this one.

This is a Belgian Quadrupel mixed with Kriek. The color is amazing and it is a truly great representation of a Belgian Quadrupel. As a lover of Kriek I would love if the cherry flavor was a bit more than a faint hint, but an overall fantastic beer.
heavy yet undistinguished...more like a high-alcohol english ale than the complex belgian brew it aspires to be

Bottle at home.  Wow, a great Quad!
  Aroma is a blend of malts and fruits.  Caramel and raisins sit behind a big cherry aroma.
  Appearance is a hazy amber that pours a frothy off-white head.  Head retention is good with nice lacing. Island of foam stick around throughout the experience.
  Taste and palate is as expected, sweet from start to finish.  Great flavors of cherries, caramel, and a touch of vanilla swirl around without ever becoming cloying. Nice average carbination delivers the creamy, medium bodied beer smoothly down the throat.  Finish is a long release from the sweet fruits that dominate the palate.
  I havnt had a Quad yet that Ive been disapointed with, and this carries on the tradition!

This beer pours a deep dark ruby/amber with a large off white head .  The aromas are cherries, candied sugar and figs.  The flavor is sweet on the front leading to a slight dryness in the middle followed by a wollop of sweetness at the end (full of lasting cherry flavor).  I was quite surprised by this one!  I didnt think Id like it much but I do!  Cheers!

From a 12oz bottle into a snifter.  Pours a medium brown with an inch of thick, foamy head which dissappears, leaving no lacing.  Smell is of tart cherries and brown sugar.  Mouthfeel is medium-thick but not syrupy, which is good considering the style.  Unfortunately, its way too overcarbonated and fizzes with every sip.  Taste is of tart cherries up front with sugar, brown sugar, banana and alcohol bringing up the rear.  Overall a very good beer but the carbonation kills the mouthfeel.  It also doesnt have enough of that "Belgian" taste considering its a Quad.
Cloudy amber with a fluffy white head that settles quickly to reveal scant lacing.  Aroma of dark fruits and light spice.  Full bodied.  Malty flavor with prunes and raisins.  Nice.

Big, bold brew right here.  Taste is very malt-driven, a syrupy sweetness, and some fruits as well.  Pretty thick beer in your mouth, and alcohol certainly doesnt overpower the taste of the malts and the cherry - mild bite at the end of it.  Very interesting beer, something to really examine and enjoy.
Amber color with thick tan head. Yeast and fruit aroma. Raisen and prunes flavors with yeast.  Slight alcohol burn finish.  Great brew.

I love Ommegang products, I have yet to find one that I do not like.  This beer pours a mixture of hazy red, black and brown. Produces a quick head and minimal amounts of lacing.  Very sweet aroma hat has hints of black cherry and is malty.   The taste is as it smells. Being high in alcohol it is well masked, one bottle will warm you up nicely.  Very nice.
2009 Quad Sample tasting at A Demise of the Jets season party. Nice dark deep amber pour. Sweet Creamy bold full bodied taste. With a furity zesty finish. Fantastic!
Nice reddish-orange color with a beige head. Complex nose with the cherries and malt well balanced. Great full mouthfeel.  Malt shows itself on the front palate and throughout, the cherry is subtle.

750ml bottle 
Appearance :  Clear dark amber with medium head that stays quite a bit
Aroma : Some red fruits, small hints of cherries. Some yeast, alcohol and very metallic.
 
Taste : Hints of cherries, yeast, red fruits, brown sugar, slightly metallic and some alcohol.. Finsih has lots of cherries that stays very long in the mouth. This was very nice.

Overall : The metallic aroma and taste was very disturbing. Faded a bit with time but never was completely gone. The finish is truly awesome. A bit too much alcohol. Kinda disapointed about this one. Maybe my bottle was not top shape. I have yet to find any tart in there like other raters did...

Bottle, pours dark brown with thin head.  Aroma of fruits, caramel, and alcohol.  Sweet flavor of malts, cherry, caramel, and dark fruits.  Alcohol on the finish, this is a strong beer.  Very enjoyable but not as complex as other quads.

Bottled. Pours mohogany, with minimal off white head. Smells of soap and yeast. Tastes of cherry, raisin and is moderately sour. Finishes long on the tongue. it feels thick and ends with sour raisins. Pretty darn good.

Pours reddish brown with enduring head and swirls.

Nose is sour brown ale like, with some fruitiness and fresh bread.

Palate is a rather ordinary sour lambic, perhaps sour brown like New Belgiums la folie, but with a modest amount of the cherry kriek in the mix. Honestly I cant figure out why this beer exists, and why it is reviewed so highly. It tastes neither like a traditional quad, nor like a good fruit lambic. Its almost as if it was a mediocre quad so they had to add the cherry lambic to offset the poor results. Nothing extraordinary here other than the cool name and bottle.
A very strong alcohol aroma - I should have let it warm a bit more to open up.  Taste is pretty nice considering the aroma.  Should try again.

Amber pour strong aroma of cherry and dark fruits .... taste of a lambic kriek nice tart with a little bit of yeasty/alcohol taste and dark fruits plums raisins .... overall a solid beer nice addition of the kriek would def do this one again

1 pint 9.4 oz bottle poured into a Ommegang glass.  Pours a slightly reddish brown color with a medium tan head.  It has the aroma of raisins, prunes and cherries.  It tastes of raisins, prunes and a bit of cherries as well as coriander and resin. The carbonation is champagne like. I didnt notice the high alcohol content at all while drinking this. This is a wonderful and complex beer. I look forward to drinking this again.

750ml bottle.  Pours a clear, mahogony body with a thin, light brown head.  Rich aroma of raisin, prune, toffee and light caramel.  The aromas persist in the flavor profile along with some dark cherries and chocolate.  Some light alcohol adds balance.  The palate contains lively, champagne-like carbonation.  Medium bodied with light alcohol warmth and slickness.  Overall a super rich and complex beer, but also suprisingly light for all its complexity.  Excellent and well-crafted.

Poured a dark orange/brown with a thin tan head that disappeared to just a film. The tart cherry aroma was very good. The initial taste was also tart and crisp with a good cherry flavor as well. There was also a good amount of carbonation in the beer. The flavor had a mild roasted malt sweetness underneath the tartness, but the tart flavor remand on throughout to the finish. The alcohol was hidden very well with hardly any in the aroma or taste. This was good and refreshing with nice flavor.

Bottle from Keg Liquors in Clarksville, shared with Brothers Eric and Nathan. Pours deep brownish red with minimal beige head. Nose is mild belgian notes and slight faint cherry. Flavor is smack in the face hot with surprisingly smooth belgian taste and sweet/sour cherry finish. Im gonna go ahead and throw it out there that I pourously mishandled this beer due to frozen tundra weather the past week...all that aside I think it is decent even in this tasting and definitely has potential. I feel obligated to revisit.

Bought this for New Years night. A lot of thick, pillowy head, otherwise average in appearance. Id need another bottle to truly describe its aroma and taste, but the feeling in ones mouth is incredible. Really made me hungry for a slice of homemade bread with butter.

Pours out a deep reddish brown, with a tannish head that lingers and leaves a bit of lacing. The smell is of cherries, malt and a bit of alcohol. Tastes a bit of tart cherries and chocolate with a tad of malt in it.
Vintage 200i8. Clear mahogany with a medium beige head. Sweet aroma with roasted malt, caramel and chocolate. Flavour like wise. Finished sweet. Slightly oxydized.

750-ml bottle pours a dark amber with thick lacing foam.  Aroma issweet malt and candied sugars, dark fruits.  Flavor is sweet malty full body with hints of fruits/raisons.  Very good beer any time of the year.  One of my favorites.

Bottle from SL... Pours a murkey red/brown color, nice head. Nice aroma of some dark fruits, light tartness. Taste is borderline tart/sour. Grapes, cherries dark fruits, yeasty and a little bready... Not bad the tartness is throwing a curve ball. Texture is highly carbonated and pretty easy to drink. Overall not  bad just not like most quads I have tried.

Bottle.  Pours a dark amber color with a large, frothy white head.  Lacing is very strong.  Aromas of cherry, malts, citrus, and dough.  Mouthfeel is somewhat soft for such a large head, and it has a nice creamy finish.  Taste consists of cherries, roasted malts, and banana at the end.  A very good beer, but I think it falls short of my "dream beer."
Pours brownish red and is hazy with a medium sized off-white head. Aroma- caramel, plum, roast malt, nut, ripe fruit. Taste is fruit sweet with a roasty finish.

12 oz. bottle -- 2008 brew. Deep red amber pour. Light head. Strong wine aroma -- alcoholic and fruity (cherry). Flavor comes in two stages. The primary stage is malty cherry and dark fruit. The secondary stage is alcoholic -- with a cherry base -- with some limited floral hints. The body is of medium thickness. The flavor and aroma are sophisticated and complex and lead into a delicate finish. If philosophy is an intellectual method of elucidation compared to a scientific doctrine of propositions, then beer philosophizing is too an activity that clarifies our thoughts of the fine brew. The Three Philosophers quadrupel exemplifies this activity.

Beautiful looking beer, ruby red with a huge head. Smells extremely malty and faintly alcoholic. A bit of fruitiness. Extremely thick beer, too thick for my liking, I drank it at room temp (from a basement, in the winter, think cellar temp) though and might have had better luck colder. Huge and complex flavour with lots of fruity and malty flavours all over the place. Very sweet. A nice beer overall, but not what Im personally looking for in a quad. Well made.
This is a nice beer. Pours dark and looks delicious. The aroma is malty. The flavor was complex and what you would expect from a good quad. nothing too amazing though.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2015 12 ounce bottle 2009. Text above says limited edition, but going on 1,500 ratings right now. Pours dark, red-tinged, superfluff head. Full body with soft carbonation. The cherries are subdued both in nose and tongue. Instead, its a very yeasty brew, lots of raisin-like notes. Not in the cocoa/chocolatey range of many Belgian strongs. 

Re-rate: finding it richer than I did in the past. Still light on the cherries.

750-ml bottle NapaCabs.com - Aroma: sweet (malt), fruity esters of raisin, prune, date, cherries, spicy (yeast/spices), alcohol; Appearance: cloudy, reddish-brown color, tan head, some laces; Flavor: sweet, salty (malt), bitter (hop), sometimes sour, spicy, fruity esters of raisin, date, cherry, nutty, bready (yeast/spices), alcohol; Mouthfeel: full bodied, creamy-sticky texture, lively carbonation, long-dry finish; Overall: an extremely enjoyable beer with a wonderful balance of complex fruity and malty aromatic and flavorful with a slight sweet backbone, and malty, bitter, and long-dry finish.

Bottle.  Pours a faintly hazy super dark, brownish amber with a tan, red hued head that leaves sporadic whisps of lacing.  Aroma is incredibely rich, with a yeasty bready character.  Flavor is potent, sweet, spicy with a somewhat sour bitter finish attributable to the cherry kriek infusion.  A lot going on, and fairly aggressive flavor-wise, but not unpleasant.  Full bodied, creamy in the mouth with an overriding hint of sweetness in the middle that gives way to a mildly sour finish.

A dark almost plum colored body.  Aroma is rather sweet, strongly resembling dark fruits such as prunes and dates, with notes of cherry.  In the background are some toasty notes.  Body is nice and thick with qucikly fading carbonation.  Flavor is rather toasty with a noticeable liquorish character.  The mouth feel is nice and full with a finish that tapers off slowly, leaving the slightly stick flavor behind.  A great beer from Ommmegang.

Picked this up as part of a three beer gift pack during the 2009 holidays.  Some fruit notes upon initial pour but is dominated with nutty aromas, very roasty even woody, with hints of caramel ... reminds me of a dessert wine.  Clear amber red pour with a hazy off white head that laces the glass.  Medium sweetness, with hints of alcohol.  Solid body with a  creamy texture, average carbonation with a  long finish.  This is a great beer to warm you up in the winter months.

clear dark red, thick smooth soft light brown head. Looks great.
very very nice aroma of dark fruits, caramel, faint perfumy berries. very low bitterness and a strong aroma.marcipan or almonds, apricot. interesting and definetly nice.
flavor is pleasantly tofee and caramel bitter, faint boozy,faint berries sweetness which balances the brew greatly. something about the bitterness i dont quite like, but overall very intersting and smooth flavor profile. extremely well done twist on a belgian style. the 2% blend works perfectly.
Pours a deep copper red with almost no head.  Aroma is sweet malt and cherries.  Taste is sweet malt, cherries, belgian yeast.  Nice beer, but not groundbreaking.
Delicious boozy beer (the booziness works in its favor). Cloudy brown, cgherries really come through. Dark fruit Belgian flavor, easy to drink.

This is great stuff.  Poured from a 750ml corked bottle:  dark clear amber with a light tightly lace head.  Did not stir up the sediment from the bottom.  Aroma is light with caramel, banana and hops. Taste is complex with malt, hops, toast and some citrus and yeast.   An expensive beer but well worth it.
Pours a nice dark amber with a light tightly lace head.  Aroma is light with caramel, banana and hops.  Taste is complex with malt, hops, toast and some citrus and yeast.  Very good beer.
Refrigerated bottle poured into a glass. Dark copper with very little head and smells of spice. The taste is dark fruit, candy sugar, and fairly strong alcohol flavor.
Aroma is of alcohol and cherries. Appearance is deep red with a this lacing on top. Taste is chocolate, cherries, and some alcohol. palate is carbonated. Overall a great sipping beer.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2011 Bottle. Pours a clear dark amber with a bit of brown and a lasting beige head. Aroma has plenty of dark and sweet malt notes giving notes of caramel and molasses as well as some cherry. Flavor is sweet with grain and caramel notes with a growing cherry note in the finish.

750mL  Poured into a Trappist glass a deep amber/brown color with a pretty thin white head.  Aroma is malty, some nuts, definite dark fruits (obviously cherries), and booze.  Taste is about the same.  I didnt think the alcohol was too overpowering.  Theres a good amount of sweetness and drinkability with this beer.   I loved it.  Definite sipper.  Ommegang puts out a lot of good beers and this is one of them

355ml bottle (Beertopia, Nebraska) - 2007 cellared for 18 months - thanks Annas parents!
Rich reddy brown, brief head. Some pleasant roasty aroma, a touch of caramel and chocolate. Gentle carbonation, smooth palate - molasses in spades in the retronasals. First taste after swallowing was definitely primarily quite hot, but followed by some lovely burnt edges, and just a touch of barky bitterness. Alcohol too prominant, alas, this really ought to be toned down a fair way to excel. Fairly drinkable though, even considering the strength. Adding some yeast made the aroma softer and more caramelly, the taste too, but also once got a tiny hint of glue in the taste, which for me is a big no-no. Strangely, I burped kriekenbier. Definitely no quad, just a good sweet dark belgian ale. Finish a touch spicy too - clove.

Great plum, pear, and cherry aromas.  Dark amber color with a think tan head.  Thick and bubbly mouthfeel with an alcohol burn.  Cherry flavor with a strong alcohol presence.  Almost a chocolate covered cherry flavor.  Interesting.  Will probably taste better as it warms (I am drinking it too cold I think).  I like it.  Very warming.

In fairness to this beer:  Im rating it at 2am after the gators got whipped in the sec title game against alabama.  that giant influence aside...  big bottle - 1pt 9.4oz - clear copper brown pour with a big frothy head and lots of lacy stick.  aroma is brown sugar and dark fruits.  thinner than expected syrupy light to medium texture.  candy sugars, dark fruits and molasses in the taste - a pepper spice vibe also.  finishes dry, sweet and hoppy all at once somehow.  for a quad, interesting - but my only true comparison is rochefort 10 and this aint sh*t to that.

Beer has a distinct cherry and belgian aroma that intrigues the senses for a first taste.  The beer porrs a deep amber with a full white head.  Taste is nice balancing rasin,and fig flavors with an undlying mild sourness from cherry additions.  Palate is a bit sticky but nice for style.  Overall I really enjoyed this beer and look forward to purchasing it again.

Location: Cant believe Ive never rated this one, anyway, this is from a 12 oz bottle that Dave brought over on 11/30/09 


Aroma: The nose has hints of nuts, dark fruit, alcohol, woodiness

Appearance: Pours an orange-amber with a nice head

Flavor: It combines the strong flavors of the nose with some alcohol tastes

Palate: The body is pretty full with some burn from the ABV

Overall Impression: 
I was drinking a bit out of a 12 oz bottle, and I realized I somehow havent rated any of the Ommegang beer, a slight oversight on my part.  Really surprised by my oversight of this nice brewery, I know Ive enjoyed a few of their beers over the years.  Anyway, I like this beer, its a sipper for sure, but these guys make a really quite solid quad.

Complex aroma - something like raisins, detectable alcohol, and maybe even some resin. Decent head, but disappeared a bit quickly. The cherry flavors are present but well-balanced - this beer is full of flavor but the sweetness is not at all overpowering. Fantastic blend of fruits and malts. Finishes bittersweet and acidic -- red wine (Pinot?) on the way down. There is a definite earthiness to this beer. It is lively on the palate and not as heavy as I anticipated.

Pours dark brown w/a thick, frothy head from the 12oz. bottle into a trappost glass at Abraxas (Miami Beach, FL): Aroma of dark cherries, blackberries, plum, and maybe some brown sugar. Tart bite. Reminds me of Cherry Coke with added grenadine and sour... and a few shots of vodka. Did I mention tart? Drinkability: Alcoholic and sinfully sweet. Rebuy: Sure. #226 on 28112009, DG.

2008 vintage.

Dark reddish brown, almost more red than brown actually. Slightly hazy. A very big yellowish head fizzes away rather quickly but leaves stylish lacings.

The smel is interesting, but kind of hard to pinpoint. Plenty of malts, dark bread yeast and prominent notes of berries. Quite a lot of chocolate as well, herbs and grass. After a while an unusual smell of roasted and tart aromas develops. This is really a complex smell with a wide range of different components. Its slightly edgy and perhaps it doesnt make it all the way, but its still pleasant and interesting.

In the mouth, theres a nice character of sweet Belgian style dark ale in the fore, with the typical mix of powerful malts and vinous notes of cherries and other dark berries and spicy and herbal yeast. Some caramelized sugar, chocolate and grass. Faint notes of bubblegum and soft candy. In the middle, a gentle tartness develops (might this be the kriek lurking in the shadows?). The finish is slightly bitter with notes of coffee, iron and stale bread, perhaps even some hop notes. The alcohol is noticeable in a not entirely integrated way.

The body is not as big as I think I would have wanted it to be, and the lack of body results in the flavors coming out as a bit thin as well. The finish is slightly dry, whilst the mouthfeel is smooth.

An impressive tasty and complex beer which I enjoyed quite a bit. But its slightly edgy and I dont think it really manages to succeed in the ambitious task it sets up for itself.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

Dark brown with a small but solid beige head. Very malty and "brown" aroma with light esters and yeast related fruit notes. The malt itself doesnt supply a very fruity character here. Flavour is similar to aroma but with a even heavyers malt character, a bit raw, clean and ruff around the edges but overall very pleasant and suprisingly heavy on the flavour. Better than other atempts..

Bottle from Food World, Kalamazoo. Dark brown colour, tan head. Aroma of brown sugar, dark fruits, some nuts. Flavour of light toasted malts, dark fruits, brown sugar, molasses. Has a slight sourness. Rich and developing beer.

Beautiful red-amber (like a dark honey) hue. Heady, malty and slightly fruity nose redolent of cherries and plums.  Body is stupendous as is taste!  Sampling the best of two worlds; belgian abbey excellence intermarried with the fruity wonderment of a cherry lambic!  Great stuff!

Pours and earthy dark red.  Aroma is mellow with largely of cherries with a hint of oranges.  Nose is sweet cherries but the body is far more sour.  Finishes just slighly bitter with the fruit flavor returning.  A wonderful beer that I can never seem to get enough of.

750mL bottle. Pours dark brown with a fluffy tan head. Aroma is sweet and fruity with just a little hint of spice (clove?). Taste is full of molasses and crisp apples followed by a warming alcohol bite. The 9.8 ABV catches up with you by the end of the bottle, leaving you nice and warm. Good, but not great.

Golden brown pour with modest tan head. Sweet aroma and flavor, too sweet to me. And the palate was quite syrupy and thick with minimal effervescence. I had high hopes for this beer but was fairly unimpressed.

This pours a nice tan head with medium lace and a pleasant chestnut brown. In a tulip glass the initial aroma of toffee. But once you drink it, its all boringly and repetitively molasses. The carbonation is acceptable for its style. But - so disappointingly - it just lacks the complexity of a real Belgian. Too one note. I wont repurchase, especially since its only $1 less than a real Belgian ale.

Hah! This was the second beer that I recorded actual ratings although I didnt enter it in that order. Im sure I havent had this beer in several years. This was a 2009 bottle, and I have since discovered an 06 bottle in my cellar. Now I am looking forward to popping that cork some day soon. This beer pours a deep reddish brown with a big, thick head and lots of sweet caramel notes, with raisins and dates that give way in the mouth to a cherry and sour finish. This one gets to move to the head of the line and it gets a regular place in the cellar.

Pours and opaque medium brown with a frothy head made up of large, light brown bubbles.  The aroma is fairly fruity and malty with a hint of vermouth.  The flavor is very malty and a bit sweet.  However, there are enough other flavors thrown in to cut some of the sweetness.  The beer is easy to drink and leaves a pleasant flavor in your mouth.

(Draught at BAs BBF09) Poured deep dark brown with medium sized and tan coloured head. Aroma of alcohol, malts and chocolate. Full bodied palate with medium carbonation. Tasted of malts, chocolate, sweetness, molasses, lightly bitterness and tiny amount of hops. Strongly malty aftertaste.

12 oz bottle. A generous off white head sits on top of this red mahogany gem. Nose of dark cherries, toffee, and other sweet malts swimming around. Distinct raisin and cherry flavors, darker malts come out as it warms. The finish is sweet and dry with the alcohol more apparent at the back of the throat.  More fizzy than I expected, almost a sweet champagne feel. A few things could be balanced better in this one but overall very enjoyable.

12 oz bottle.  Pours dark red brown with an off-white head.  Aroma is sweet dark fruit, caramel, apple, nuts, and cloves.  Maybe a touch of soy sauce.  Flavor is led by raisin with a strong molasses flavor, apple, nuts, and caramel.  Finishes just like maple sugar candy.  I like it, but something just seems a little too much out of balance, maybe a little too richly sweet.  Still rather enjoyable.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2010 2009 bottle. A small white head gives way to a thin web of film atop a cloudy amber body with red hues. Nice quad aroma (dark fruit, toffee, caramel, etc.) with a sweet abundance of cherries. Slight alcohol presence protrudes as it warms. The flavor is similar for the most part, but brings with it candied sugar, some light alcohol, and a slightly tart cherry finish. The flavor isnt as bold as the higher rated abts, but the cherry lambic adds a nice touch. Medium bodied with very light carbonation. A little on the sweet side, but pleasantly complex.
bottle, pours amber with a medium off white head.  Aroma is carmely with maple syrup brown sugar and green raisins.  Lots of the same flavors.  Very nice quad.

Bottles from various places.  Many of them.  Overall, the best beer Ive ever had.  Its got a great dubble-like malt profile, but you can instantly taste the sour mash.  Smells of sweet cherries.  Tastes like cherries, but definitely not overwhelming.  Nice head, good lacing, and definitely a beer that gets better with age.  My brother purchased a case of bottles from 2006 and 2007, and we cracked a 2006 cellar aged bottle last weekend.  Even better than my first!

(Draught at Ft. Worth Flying Saucer) Pours clear brownish-red, little bubbles on top. Nose of cherries and dried fruits with light chocolate. Taste is cherries, dried fruits, and chocolate, quite sweet without any roastiness whatsoever. A nice creamy finish too, but perhaps slightly syrupy.

The cherry aroma is overwhelms the first sniff, but as the beer warms in the glass, the aroma more complex with hints of citrus and  sugar.  The flavor is good, very fruity, containing a complex sweetness.  Nice color and nice thickness, creamy but slightly crisp.
Draft: Apple and brown sugar aroma. Cloudy brown with a thick yellow head. Malty flavor which tastes as it smells, with a spider web imperssion. Apple core finish.

The head on this one was awesome. Very alive beer. Nice carbonation and great color. Smells just as good as it tastes. Rich colors and rich taste. Taste like a great Belgian beer with the twist of cherry thrown in. Loved the alcohol finish. Speaking of cherry totally caught me off guard at first! (should have read the label) but loved them. Very strong cherry taste comes through near the end of this delicious beer. 9.8 ABV... oof what a good one. Lots of bread , flavor galore and the head was fizzing like crazy and actually grows which is really cool and gives this one a great personality. Three philosophers = three thumbs up!
This beer has a nice mild barley wine aroma with a hint of fruit.  The feel is not too thick.  It hits the tongue with a subtle malt taste and finishes with a note of raisins.

Cloudy amber-brown pour with a disappearing head, aroma has strong fruit and yeast.  Flavor is strong with cherry and roasted caramel, great mouthfeel.  Finishes fantastically smooth, strong alcohol presence.

Bottle.  Definite cherry smell and taste, as advertised.  It has the quad feel to it - the richness, the spiciness, the dark fruits, but its balanced with the cherry flavor.  I like cherry flavor, dont get me wrong, but I honestly think it would be better sans cherry.  I liked it, Ill buy it again, but I wasnt "oh my god" wowed by it.

Cherry vinegar, brown sugar and cinnamon on the nose, some hints of peach.  Dark brown/orange color, big frothy tan head, nice lacing.  Clove caramel  sweetness, some lavender oil and tart cherry pit bitterness.  Huge carbonation, medium body, orange pith bitter finish with sweet and tart cherry brandy alcohol warming finish.  Very tasty and interesting beer.  The cherry component is somewhat subtle, but it makes a big impact throughout this beer making it complex and unique.
DØE Valby 09. Pours copper with a beige head. Aroma is light caramel, light hop, dried fruit. Flavour is medium caramel, fruity esters, banana and light alcohol.
2008 bottle...tart cherry/alcohol aroma... dark amber.. medium head...alcohol flavor well balanced with the cherry... nice aftertaste...  warming power

2008 Bottle - Thanks dand645! - Pours a deep amber with a medium off white foamy head...aroma is dk pit fruity, sweet molassas malt, dough...flavour is nicely malty and bready, with a tart fruity finish...subtle fruit, but makes a great addition without overpowering...thick in the mouth, finish is a lingering sweet warmth...that was nice...

750ml bottle poured into a plain ol clear glass beer stein (sorry, I dont own any fancy glassware).   Dark brown pour with some red tint and a nice beige head.  Complex fruity taste, can really pick up the cherry taste.  Thick, creamy mouthfeel.  Very smooth.  I consider this my "stand by" Quad, not the most amazing Ive ever had but affordable and easy to find.

Pours a deep brown with garnet tints and a super tight beige head. Aroma is loaded with fruity esters that fill the room before the first sniffs even transpire. Plum, prune, dates, raisin, caramel, toasty sweet malt, molasses, brown sugar and light fruity notes that seem to proliferate with the accompanying of some mild alcoholic warming notes. Fruity esters that showed up in the aroma make a similar impression in terms of the light fruit flavor profile. Dark fruits, however, take the day with nearly every facet making its respective way in the swirling dark sugar torrent that is so prevalent. Dark syrup like sugars are complemented nicely by a wholly evident alcohol note that warms the nasals but doesnt detract from the experience. Palate is effervescent with lots of bubbly prickling amongst a high viscosity torrent. Mouthfeel is thick and quite rich- even chewy with warming booze and an ever so slight roasty dryness. This is only very subtle, though, for the overall theme of the finish strays away from attenuation and presents itself with a sticky smacking fullness. I was pleasantly surprised by this American example of a style that American brewers rarely edge out the Belgians in...

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2011 Cloudy amber with a off white head. Dried fruit and cherries in the aroma. Also soma acidity. The mouth goes along  same line but with a fair amount of alcohol to it.  Some yeasty spices as well. Less sweet and rich compared to my hazy memories.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2009 An unclear almost dark brown beer with little head. The aroma is fruity & is like apple pie. The taste is very smooth, fruity, & like the other offerings from Ommegang would not think that it is made outside of Belgium. Has some characteristics of wine as it warms up.
750ml bottle poured into a trappist glass.  Almost identical in color, taste, and aroma to the Abbey Ale from Ommegang, however, it seemed a little "fizzy", more like a champagne than a beer.

Poured a dark brown with a ruby red tint with a tiny white head, aroma of cherries with some other fruits lingering and a sweet taste maybe caramel? and pretty malty with some alcohol in the finish, pretty well hidden, excellent beer.
