deep amber with a thick head. smells of nice malts and of course cherries. taste is very malty with overpowering cherries and tart finish. the cherry taste is not distracting from the the other flavors such as caramel, oats and barley with a sweet twist. an excellent example of how beer should taste when having one single fruit dominating the palate. one of my all time favorites.
Tasted the 2008 batch.  Pours dark brown with an amber lacey head and a strong cherry aroma.  Alcohol taste dominates with a hint of cherry.  The cherry aftertaste lingers.

Bottle. Pours a deep, cloudy amber, with a foamy, pale amber head. Aroma of cherries, vanilla, roasted malt, and very slight hint of clove. Full, crisp body with a sweet, tangy finish. The taste of the cherries and malts hide the alcohol nicely. Excellent quadrepel from Ommegang. This will be my 100th beer ratings, so I raise my glass to all the other craft beer lovers and look fondly towards the future and my next 100 brews.
Alcohol.  Cherries.  Alcoholic cherries?   Like Robitussin,  but actually  kind of good.

Great color and aroma from 22 oz bottle. Pours nice foam and good veil. Flavoring is OK but alcohol taste is overpowering with faint charcoal, coffee and caramel undertones. Would like to try it from the tap
next. Prefer Abbey Ale to this.

Im happy to have this one as my 200th rating since its one of the beers that opened my eyes to great beer.  2008 vintage.  22 oz. bottle from Kellers IGA, shared.  Pours a cloudy dark brown with a fairly small off-white head that didnt leave much behind or last long.  Aroma is alcohol, cherry, caramel, roast malt, and dried fruit.  Alcohol leads the flavor, also cherry, roast malt, dried fruit, caramel sweetness.  Complex and really satisfying and fun to drink.  Could use a little more balance since the alcohol sticks out a lot, and I might take the advice of MmmcKay and let it age a little longer to make it two full years next time.  Excellent overall.

dark brown pour wiht a nice light colored but lacy head. beautiful belgian maltiness mixed with a little hint of cherry that works oh so well together. great mouthfeel. nothing too overpowering in the alcohol department....jsut a well balanced delicious twist on a belgian.

Bomber. Big tan head, dark brown to orange non transparent appearance. Cherry alcohol dominate the aroma, with faint malty sweetness. Bursting alcoholic  floral taste, balanced with a long finish that complements the alcohol nicely.

Upon surfing the local liquor store isles for a new beer, a friend of mine stumbled across Three Philosophers. With such a fantastic name and exquisite bottling, I had to get it. I drank this beer at only slightly below room temperature due to time restrictions. First to note is its fine aroma, with a sweet and fruity smell. Its taste was strong and satisfying - like nothing I have ever had before. As my first lambic, I was blind going in. I was very much impressed by the powerful flavor and cherry after taste.

Aroma of fruits, big, slightly roasty malt, caramel, cherries especially. Rather rich malty flavor with chocolate, cherry and dark fruits. Rich and tasty though not up there with the classic Belgian abts. Very nice anyhow.

Sampled at DØE Beerfestival 2009, Valby. Pours a dark ambercolored beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is sweetness, dried fruit and caramel. The flavor has a lot of sweetness. The palate is sweet with some dryness. Overall a good beer.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2009 Vertical tasting of the 2007, 2008, and 2009 batches or vintages. As it turns out the tasting went exactly as we would have expected. Heres some brief notes on each vintage.

2009 - Reddish in color. Hot, sweet, sharp fruit flavors, lacks balance. Most fruit of all three that we tried. Least favorite.

2008 - Stuck right in the middle of the two vintages. Color fading as well as the fruit. Less sharp than 2009. Better in quality but not by much.

2007 - Hands down the best of the three years that we tried. The red color has almost completely faded. Brown now in color. Malty lush nose. Fruit flavors are now faded to the point where they are very well integrated.

Conclusion - 2 years seems to be a nice sweet spot for aging this beer. The 2009 had just been released when we did our tasting. It would have been interesting to have a bottle of 2006. However, I think a 2006 would have tasted old by now.

Ommegang should not sell this in 750s.  The color was ruddy brown with a little bit of carbonation and a decent off-white head that held for a bit.  The flavor was bud light with a smidgen of cherry.  Where is the kriek with which this was supposedly blended?  I found this pretty disappointing and was kicking myself that I had such a big bottle of it.
750 ml bottle @ Tivu. Thin whitish head. Reddish brown colour. Cherry and malt in the aroma as well as in the taste. Aftertaste dominated by cherry.

750 mL bottle.  Opaque amber reddish pout with a nice thick tan head.  Aroma of dark fruit and malt.  Slightly stale taste of malt, yeast and plums with an even finish and faint alcohol present.  Overrated if you ask me.

Pours dark brown with a ruby tint when held to the light and a thin, creamy, light tan head that has o.k. retention. Aroma is lots of sweet, nutty banana bread, dark fruits, lots of ethanol, bavarian cream and cherry danish, caramel, a little port and figs. Flavor is dark fruit, licorice, fig, banana oil, brandy, ethanol, metallic notes, sharp bready yeast and a little roast. Palate is medium  body with a boozy-dry feel throughout and a light (especially for the style) carbonation. I really expected alot more from this brew, I thought at first that I served it too cold. I let it warm and was still pretty disappointed. Stirred in a little, then all of the dregs from the bottom of the bottle, still disappointed. Metallic booze greeted me every time. Oh well. Not incredibly terrible, but definitely not very good.

Pours a rich dark brown with a small creammy white head. Aroma is sweet like cheeries, dates and fig. Taste is full bodied with hints of dart fruit and caramel, keeping it on the sweet side. The flavor last on the palet but the alcohol taste seems to linger and over power the finer notes of the beer. I thinnk the "big" bottles are a little more mellower in the alcohol than the 12 ouncers. A good beer no the less.

From the Bottle at Dr Bills Tasting Falling Rock Tap House, Denver 09/10/2008
Rich fruit aroma. Amber red coloured and strong in alcohol with a sherry flavour. Crisp and slightly bitter malt finish.

12 oz. bottle.  Vigorous pour revealed a thin white head and a dark brown body with ruby highlights.  Strong aroma of malt, caramel, cherry and fig. Flavor is dry and bready with traces of tartness and dark fruit. Finish is a little overly boozy, which makes me want to try cellaring one a year or so. Excellent example of a Quad at a great price.

Pours dark brown with a thin head.  Strong aroma, bread, cherries, caramel, and some other dark fruit.  Good flavor, the 9.8% ABV was there though, because it seemed a little boozy.  A very good, readily available beer.

Looks good, though not much in the way of head, something a belgian usually takes for granted. Nice color though.

Smells of bread and cherries, with some other malty goodness in the mix. Very good.

Tastes bready and dry, I have a difficult time discerning the flavors added by the lambic. Very good however.

Mouth is again very crisp and dry, medium in body, and high in carbonation. Perhaps my pour was the reason for the lack of head, because the bubbles are there.

Overall, this is a great, cheap example of the style.

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2009 [2343-20090103] 750mL bottle. Heavy fig malt aroma has roasted wood and mild anise and evergreen notes. Murky, dark brown body with quick foamy tan bubbles. Heavy boozy malt flavour has lots of roasted yeast and some hints of evergreen. Medium-full body. Very nice, a lovely brew. ( 9/3/8/3/17) 4.0
(Vintage 2005; c/o DuctTape, w/ him, jerc)

[2435B-20090809] 650mL bottle. Rich yeasty sugary malt aroma. Hazy, dark amber body with a long-lasting creamy light tan head. Rich malty syrup flavour has heavy yeast notes. Full body is boozy. Also very tasty! ( 8/4/8/3/17) 4.0
(@ Beerfest at the Condo; w/ DuctTape, jerc, others)

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2009 So sophisticated, I ponder it while I write. Has a very dark apperance and a very strong cherry flavor, which was almost too much for me, which is incredible due to the fact only 2% of the ale is infused with cherry. Still, I couldnt put it down. It is that addictive.

Aroma is fruity/estery with a hint of cherries and alcohol. The flavor is about the same, with subdued cherries and a touch of astringency. My bottle was 2008, and I wish I had an older bottle to try. I will probably try to pick up another bottle of this and age it for at least a year and try it again.  I in fact did age another bottle, and was disappointed.  The alcohol fades, but so does the cherry significantly.  The first bottle was amazing and one of my favorites, though!

750 mL bottle (2007).  Pours a murky mud-brown with some reddish highlights.  The high carbonation creates a medium-sized frothy beige head but quickly dissipates to nothing.  Aroma is bready malts, caramel, raisins, light yeast, and a hint of cherry from the 2% kriek.  Flavor of rich malts, caramel, chocolate, and dark fruits.  Though somewhat lacking in the nose, I do get a quite a bit of kriek in the flavor.  I dont find it as sweet as many of the other reviewers -- perhaps because it is slightly aged?  Rather light mouthfeel.  A good quad.

Pours a dark amber with creamy mocha head.  Left very little lacing.  Aroma is alcohol, cherry and chocolate.  Nice silky mouthfeel.  Flavor is a bit sour with abundant cherry, plum and dark bitter chocolate with a nice bit of alcohol in the finish.  Very nice beer and a bit different from other quads that I have had.  I also like the Portland connection :)

Very complex brew. Pours a dark copper with a tan head. Lots of cherry on the nose. The initial taste is of cherry with generous amounts of malt in the background. Very drinkable too considering the 9.8% abv there. Solid. Definitely worth a shot if you come across it.

Bottled - dark red color with decent golden head.  Smelled of chocolate, cherries and fruit.  Tasted coffee (?), chocolate, cherries and an underlying spice....I liked it - it reminded me of a home-brew we made last winter that had a little too much sugar (boom!).

Big bottle.  Aroma was fruity with raisin and plum.  Pour was a golden brown with thin head and good lacing.  Malt and plum and raisin and caramel fused with alcohol at the end.  Strong presence on the palate.  Many quads have a hard time balancing the high alcohol with enough other flavors to make it enjoyable.  Not a problem with this one.

Pours an odd dark amber with medium off-white head, decent lacing.  Couldnt keep yeast out of pour despite 2 month sit in fridge.  Aroma of tart fruit, strong toasted malt, caramel, yeast, and lots of spice.  Flavor matches well, but just doesnt come together in my opinion.  Drinkable, complex, but just not my style.

Pours a hazy amber color with a substantial  tan head.  Aroma is of yeast, fruits, and perhaps some spices.  Cherry is rather present, as would be expected, but cloves and cinnamon are also there, if in the background.  A very intriguing beer.
Pours a lasting ring of beige head and a hazy, copper color body.  Smells of dried fruit, yeast, and tart cherries.  Same flavor.  Nice carbonation and body.  Nice finish.

2008 bottle. Nose is pretty boozy, but a generous swirl brings out musty cherries, bourbon wood and a healthy dose of sugar. Flavor is Cherry and brown sugar upfront, with a boozy middle and a nice sharp finish with the malt showing through. Not a lot of complexity for the style, but the flavors that are there a nicely done. Would like to try it with a couple years age on it and see the difference.

Big bottle with the guys at work.  Pours a vey murky brown with decent beige head.  Nose of caramel, plums.  Flavor of cherry juice, raisins, and molassis.  Vey enjoybale.  And well hidden alcohol.  Very nice.

Poured into a Chimay glass.

The color is a nice dark amber.

The smell is cherries, some barely flavor. Is sweet with a light malt flavor.

The taste is sweet sugar with a nice dark cherry taste. Some hints of malt, a little grain and some brown sugar.

My first Belgian quad and it was a great experience. The mouth feel to this beer was nice and light and was easy going down. Overall it was memorable beer experience.
Bottle, Pours dark brown with light carbonation and head. Its very strong, alcoholic, burns your mouth. Tastes of cherry, sour dark fruits, sweet malt finish. Not my favorite beer.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2009 Admittedly not my type of brew. This stuff just turns me off like others in ABT group....I know I can hear some of you..."NOOB", well I would love to like it but I dont.....yet. Tried again with the wife, still dont like it...she of course LOVES it and the ratings now reflect her opinion....

Bottle. Pours hazy dark red with a small, short lived head. Nose is very fruity, sweet malt and alcohol.  Full body with sweet malt, brown sugar, yeast and cherry flavor in the beginning with floral hops pleasantly kick in the finish.  Wonderful beer.
Bottle Pizzeria Uno - Poured a caramel brown. Instant smell of fruit and malt. Somewhat strong, yet smooth. Actually reminded me of Palo Santo. Good beer, definitely not a session beer though.

Very malty smell when you pop the cork. Heh, corks on all these "beers", its really kind of funny. Color is dark caramel. Head is 2 inches and thick tan, and holds well. Caramel, malt, alcohol, and dark berry fruit aroma, like strawberry. Smooth beginning, rough middle, and smooth finish. Flavors are dark plum, cherry, chocolate, cinnamon, mineral, and toffee. A little bittering hops are present. The beer is very, very dry.

Bottle. Pours reddish brown coloured with a small light brown head. Nose is caramel, chewing gum, blackberries, chocolate and dried fruit. Dry flavour with notes of licorice, berries and some molasses sugar. Great!
Just a great tasting beer.  Very easy to drink and at 9.8% alc youre left with a smile on your face after your first 25oz bottle.  If you try it youll like it.
We are in a beer tasting club, several of us get together in honolulu and rate 8 beers every week.  We have our own scales as well as the scale used on this website to record our fun weeks!

Bottle at The Winking Lizard. Absolutely striking aroma. My friend smelled it across the table and wanted to try it immediately. Overall, the aroma was what made the beer. The taste itself was very good (although not as much cherry Kriek flavor as expected), but the alcohol was a bit too noticeable. Also, worked better solo than with food. But, overall, I was pleased and recommend this beer.

3 Phils arrived in the glass with appropriately three fingers or so worth of a foamy light brown head on top of a body of dark brown, indeed almost black.  Very little aroma to speak of, however the taste was far better, featuring what I thought to be coffee, chocolate and spices for sure.  Mouthfeel was moderate.  Finish was good, although on the sweet side.  I found this a hard beer to review but far, far easier to drink!  A good beer.

Weak aroma like most Belgians. Alcohol and candy sugar. Small head retreats quickly.  Flavors of apples and burnt sugar. Bubbly champagne style carbonation. This was fantastic. Better then any Rochforte or Westmalle Ive had!
This beer is absolutely decadent! Pours a dark brown with a thick tan head. Aromas of sour cherries, brown sugar, and some yeast. Flavors of brown sugar, cherries, and some alcohol. A winner!!!

Delicious.  I just love this brewery and Belgians :)  This is a keeper.  I shared a bottle of this with BeerBaron617.  It was a dark amber brown with a very tight gray white head.  It had a very sweet, malty aroma with hints of cherry from the lambic.  Tasted very malty and and of cherries and other darker fruits.  Its a great beer, yet again not dissapointed with Ommegang.

I shared a 750 of this with MereLikesBeer. Ive really come to like this brewery and this style over the last few months, and this was no exception. It poured a dark brown with surprisingly small offwhite head. The aroma was sweet, malty, and yeasty, with some hints of cherry. The flavor followed suit, with a lot more cherry up front. Good stuff. Cheers!
Me being a believer in "the more hops the better", found this beer to be too sweet and too carbonated.  Good beer but not for me and time to expand my beer tasting horizons.

750ml bottle, 2008 edition. Pours a muddy, rather unattractive, reddish brown color with a thick beige head. Aroma is a rich mix of malt, cherries, smoke, and caramel. Palate is thick and heavy with a moderate amount of carbonation. Flavor was dominated by the malt with undertones of cherry. Also, notes of raisin, dates, figs and spices. All in all, a wonderful drinking experience. Highly recommend.

Pours deep red with a very nice head and great retention.  Very nice caramel aroma with a hint of cherries in there as well.  Very strong, but very satisfying too.  It may be a little much for the regular American Light beer drinker, but for people with more robust tastes, this is a knockout.
Great looking beer upon pour.  A nice head a a great dark amber color.  Taste a bit of smoky raisen flavor with a nice smooth aftertaste.  A very nice beer!!

Enjoyed from a 750ml bottle in a tulip glass.  The beer pours a medium brown with some deep red to ruby highights.  The head is just about white, and lingers for several minutes.  The nose brings  a strong not of caramel and a finish of kriekesque cherries at the end.  On the palate, the malts come at the palate first, giving hints of Belgian character malts like Special "B" and CaraMunich, along with caramel and just a touch of cherry that becomes more evident as the beer warms.  A little bit of alcohol comes through in the mid- to late-palate, but not enough to destroy the flavors mentioned.  Overall, a great Quadrupel.

Cherry red with a thin beige head.  Aromas of malt, yeast, earth and slight cherries--fairly subtle.  Tastes just a little of dark fruits, slightly malted, subtle spices.  Can taste the alcohol but there really is no lingering aftertaste.  Bottle seems a little off and so will rerate if possible.

2008 12oz bottle. Red pour with slight haze and ncie lace. Aromais light - belgian candi sugar and yeast, with a very slight hint of cherries. The flavor is very hot and all quad... where is the alleged kriek that the quad was blended with? Medium to light body and over carbonated. Overall: what?

Clear ruddy brown with fine medium size tan cap that settles in the Westmalle chalice. Faint sweet aromas and good flavors of cherry, dry plum, apple, raisi,n caramel and some spice. Some wine-like tartness and a touch of hop dryness are interesting. Alcohol is forceful before I chill it down. Moderately full body, some nice stickiness. Aroma is a bit short. Ommegang makes a few fine beers that seem restrained and maybe a little too understated to really stand out. Nothing wrong with em though. Polite refined belgians!

A soft brown body pours out into a Chimay goblet; off-white, gently settling head--storng head that holds sway...fragrant, ester-laden bouquet strikes immediately--the lambic quality plays nicely in the crisp Hallertauer hops--malts are balanced well enough to hint at something amber...light, soft flitter on the lips and teeth; smooth enough to sneak through to the throat without much fanfare...definite acidic grape presence...hops keep the taste tartthe 9.8 % alcohol is present, yet overall accomplishes a mellow, malty finish; almost no aftertaste--this beer excels in its self-control... a wonderful Easter ends with this Quadrupel, amd a great end at that--with the bold passion of a merlot, Three Philosophers displays body and taste sophisticated enough... the Ommegang guys miss little, and this beer could keep me philosophical with a rather clear buzz as the bottle drains...
Pours brown with thin off white head.  Aroma of raisins and cherries.  Taste of dark fruits, yeast, and slight spicy flavor.  Some notes of caramel in the finish.

Lately this seems to have gotten a bit sweeter. Less tart cherry aspect more malt sweetness. Still a very nice beer and ages for a few years. Also was fortunate enough to try batch 1 recently. Supposedly with no Kriek added but still had a slight sour thing going on. Maybe it is age.

Bottle. This a tasty brew, but a little too much of the kriek character for me to rank it amongst my favourite quads. Pours deep ruby red with beige head. Nose big on cherries. Flavour has more cheery, spices, and caramel.
Bottle. This quad is full of fruit flavor and you can feel the alcohol presence but not too much.
Rich and full of malt. Black cherries, concord grape, a hint of alcohol, but not too much. Good looking beer - dark with good carbonation and nice lacing.

Bottle @ København Ølfestival 2009. The aroma has apple, grass, raisin, cherries and caramel malts. Hazy, red-brown coloured beer with an off-white, thin head. The taste is sweet, slightly alcoholic, has some sugar and some grass. Well brewed.
On tap at the Muddy Pig.  Pours brown with a decent beige head.  Sweet cherry, caramel malts, spicy yeast.  Tastes a little weaker than it smells.
Bottle. Brownish colour with a small off white head. Aroma and taste of yeaste, fruits, caramel and spices. Good beer.

Pours a ruby deep brown. Nose is a melody of dark fruits, belgian yeasts, plum, raisin, candy sugars, earthy hops. Flavor is much of the same. Sweet malt flavors mixed with rich fruits. Dry finish. Lovely beer.
Sample at CPH beerfestival. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are dark fruits, spices, yeast, caramel and malt.

Rating # 16 from the danish beer festival 2009.
The closest ive seen to a classic belgian beer from a foreign brewer. Powerfull fruity/yeasty aroma of raisin and plum with sweet dark suger notes along with berries and some spices. Powerfull sweet and alchoholic flavor in a fine balance.

Bomber- poured a crisp amber red with decent sized off white head.  Slight malts, yeast and cherry on the nose.  Palate blends with a fizzy malt cherry Lambic style, light and flavorful with some spice but not as sour as anticipated.  A well blended drinker and probably a better attempt for me to enjoy a muddled Lambic style.  Sorry about the yeast afire!

Small bubble structure to the creamy head on this one. Gorgeous brown / red color to the body. Only the slightest hint of cherry on the nose. 

I get brown sugar and plum on the first taste, with raisin on the finish. Great carbonation on this one, with an easy-drinking style. Wonderfully complex and deceptively easy to drink.
Flaske: Mørkebrun øl. Ikke synderlig vinøs, måske en smule ung. Men diskret aroma, smagen er igen diskret, overraskende at den ikke udnytter alkoholen lidt bedre. Kedelig for en quad.
Comparable to some of the better Belgian style ales that Ive tried.  Seems like it should have a stronger flavor than it does, but the flavor is outstanding.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2009 12oz Bottle A muddy burnt amber color body with a lasting small to medium offwhite head, huge amounts of sheeting and nice lacing.  Aroma of dark cherries,apple,rasins, earthy spices and tobacco. Flavor is fruity without being tart,malty,yeasty,cloves,peppercorns,tobacco,somet I wonder if im getting hops or alcohol they seemed to have mixed well because it seems more spicy than alcoholic in flavor and finish. Slightly dry/slightly sweet. This shit is the bomb.

Poured a dark ruby-red with a pretty good size head of creamy white. The aroma wasnt particularly noteworthy, some dark fruits but mostly alcohol. What a great taste though, full of cherries and chocolates. The balance of flavors in this Quad made this a very smooth brew indeed. LC - CP

Bottle...  Poured deep ruby with a thin off-white head.  Toasted burnt/caramelized sugars, spices and warming alcohol on the nose.  Big, chewy palate which accentuate the strong alcohol notes.  Roasted malts and dark fruits--like prunes or raisins.  Swee, fruits in the finish with reminiscing alcohol and a nutty almond character.
Ive always liked this beer.  The aroma and flavor are unique and delicous which are two things that dont always go hand in hand.  When I feel like something special, I reach for this one.
Pours dark brown/red, medium head.  Aroma is sweet with some cherry fruitiness.  Taste is interesting, not overly fruity, some sour notes, like unripe cherries.  Bitter finish.  Interesting mix.
dark amber read with no head. aroma is cherries and rich malts. drinks smooth with cherry sweetness upfront and a hearty malt backbone with a bit of a bitter bite at the end. very well done

12 oz bottle into a brandy glass. Cherry, light malty, and overripe fruit aroma. Dark red color with ring of off-white head. Medium bitter, medium sweet, and medium sour, all blend well hiding the alcohol. Medium bodied, thin textured, fizzy on the tongue. Kriek initially on the palate, into sweet raisins, and malt finishing sweet abruptly then into long bitter-sour. Overall, a worthy Quad.

Bottle pour.Aroma is cherries and a hint of malt.Burnt red color with a decent off-white head.Cherries and a little hop and malt and some other sweets.Drinks smoothly and alcohol isnt overdone.Really good beer.

750 ml. bottle (2008) in an Ommegang goblet. The Lindemans kriek blended nicely with what must have been a middling Quadrupel. Ar: Splendid nose, dominated by cherries, candied sugar and secondary overripe fruits. Abv well masked in the nose. Ap: Beautiful, beautiful color- reddish brown that reveals a deep honey color in the light. It could have perhaps poured a better head w/ more retention on the sides of the glass upon swilling. Nevertheless...Fl: Candied sugar, molasses, some dark fruits, malt and a surprising hops presence that lent it a unique balance. High abv comes through in the end with some metallic booziness. Pa: Lively carbonation makes it a sprightly brew in the mouth, rolls around nicely and is dry. A solid sipper on the whole- I have soft spot for Ommegang brews.
bottle (big thanks go to JFM for sharing this one) dark red brown color with a big head. Taste has the slightest hint of cherries. Good aftertaste

Pours a quick diminishing tan head...dark mahogany color with ruby highlights.  Sweet malt and cherry aroma.  Remarkable taste.  Heavy malt, raisins, cherries, a little bitterness on the back end.  Great mix of sweet and sour.  Alcohol is well hideen for the high ABV, although the warming sensation hits you.  One of my favorites.

2008 edition.  Rich brown pour with a ring of off white foam.  Yeasty aroma with spice, cherry, ripe bananna, and some funk.Very complex mouth:  sweet, sour, bitter, coating and vibrant.  Taste is woody and ripe fruit, cherry is in the back, but there.  Overall an intoxicating beer for the more mature palates.

Bouteille de 12 oz, édition 2008. Arômes de fruits (cerises) et dalcool. Robe ambrée assez foncée, belle mousse et effervescence active. Moyennement ronde en bouche, on retrouve des notes fruitées et un malt caramélisé intéressant. Lalcool est cependant très présent et déséquilibre un peu lexpérience. Finale dalcool légèrement amère. Peut-être un peu trop jeune.

I always love what Ommegang puts out. It pours a deep dark amber color with a touch of red that wants to come out. Plenty of cherry notes in the aroma, but not too much in flavor. A perfect clean finish you would expect from this brewery.
Love this beer. Mahogany with a nice tan head and good lacing. The balance of sweet and tart with the cherry is perfect and the strong ale base is wonderful.

Excellent pour and head; dark caramel color; cherry aroma is immediately present; initial tasting did not contain cherry, although dried fruits clearly present; aftertaste almost metallic with sweet cherry notes

Nice mahogany color; aroma about the same as any ale. Head was nice and thick, good cream color. Excellent flavor; not too hoppy, with the kriek flavors in the background... not overwhelming but not overwhelmed. Nice and well balanced.

Thanks biggcb.  Medium brown, translucent, garnet highlights.  Medium beige head, only transient lacing.  Mild roast aroma, tree fruits, wild yeast funk, penetrating alcohol elements.  Flavor is led by alcohol and wooden resinous elements, very penetrating, overall too much solvent character for me. Background flavors that round out its complexity include tart cherries, molasses, and yeast. Somewhat thin in body in contrast to the full flavor.  Hot, chemical palate.

Acheté à Lombard au état-unis dans létat de lillinois au famous wine and spirits. Bouteille de 750ml millésimé 2008 et déguste dans un verre trappiste de westmalle avec Glandine. Apparence brune rubis au reflet orangé avec une mousse moyenne brunâtre très collante sur les parois et un faible dépôt de levure en suspension. Arômes de sucre à la crême, cerise, caramel, fraise, prune, mûre et fûmé de bois et une trace de canelle. Un goût de cerise, miel, mûres, fruits des champs et caramel avec une touche de pelure de pomme et de poire. Au palais, un équilibre entre le sucré et lamertume. Le goût reste longtemps avec un début crémeux et réchauffant suivant par la suite à une amertume sec en explosion et velouté en même temps. Une bière balancé et pleine de surprise portant à mes lèvres une plénitude orgasmique.

750m bottle from Ryans Party Store in Port Huron
Pours a dark hazy ruby red with a small white head 
The aroma is malty cherry 
The taste is strong malts and light sweet cherry
Pretty good
Very dark, and heavy content...but surprisingly smooth. Not overpowered by the cherry side...worth the try if you like dark and complex beer.
Ruby brown with a small and lasting off-white head. The aroma is bubblegum, winegum and spicy - classic quad. Malty flavour with a hint of licorice, and some sherry. Vineous and dry malty finish.

75cl bottle @ HJHansen, Odense. Pours cloudy amber with a reddish hew and a small creamy white head. Nose is sweet of yeast, winegums, alcohol, caramel and fruit. Sweet and vinous with some port notes. Warming alcohol. A sipper. Nice!
Very wonderful pour.  Great color, aroma, everything.  Wonderful brew.  Will definatly have again and share with a friend.  Thanks DJ.

12 oz bottle from Total Wine here in Jacksonville, Florida.  Pours a nice rich amber/copper/brown color with a little head.  Aroma is sugary and some cherry notes.  Taste is similar and every drop was drinkable.  Wow, a nice beer and the alcohol seemed to be well hidden with this one.
Poured nice caramel color smelled of alcohol hints of cherry, tasted sweet at beginning faded to nice clean aftertaste with hints of cherry
Poured a pale head on top of a tan/cherry body.  Aroma was of alcohol masked by caramel.  The palate finished with a yeast and touch of cherry which left one with a clean fealing.

Aroma of brown sugar and alcohol.... Caramel in color... Brown sugar and sweet malts dominate the flavor initially but the distinct flavor of cherries predominate towards the finish... Tartness of the cherries linger on the palate long after the last swallow... Very nicely done by ommegang...
Cherry, dark brown. Lots of alcohol. A rating that should have been done awhile ago.
I enjoyed this beer!  Dark brown ruby.  fruit, spices,  bottle from city wide liquors.  what a treat
This is a very strong and tasteful beer.  Just a little fruity and yeasty for my taste.  I tried it at JKO and was already drunk so I may rate again later.
beautiful ruby highlights, sweet warming alcohol, green apple, dark fruit, bright cherries, slight nail polish, dark chocolate, chocolate covered cherries, sweetness, candy, excellent

~Pours a dark reddish brown color with diminishing head.
~Fruity yeasty scent, crisp and refreshing.
~Light fruit, bananas, apples, cherries and yeast taste, some spices as well.   
~Light feel. Clean sweet finish.
~Good beer. I really like the fact that it is so light and not overbearingly sweet like other Belgian brews that I have tried
Bottle says it was bottled in 2007 and I bought it in 2009.  Strong cherries scent with a bit of cherries in the taste as well.  The taste was very yeasty but that is to be expected from a quad.

Bottle. Mostly an earth yeasty smell with hints of caramel, bread, and dried fruit. Clear amber with an off white bubbly head. Medium sourness, light sweetness. Medium body, lively sparkling carbonation with a nice sweet finish where the cherries come through. Very well balanced beer and the alcohol is masked very well. Definitely try this beer.

Pours a reddish-brown with a big foamy tan head.  Aroma is yeast, dark fruit, cherry, some caramel.  Flavor is heavy malt up front which eases into the dark fruit flavor, and ends with a lingering bready spice to it.  I like how the beer kind of works through the flavors as you taste it and it has a nice complexity to it.  Pretty good stuff.

Limited head retention. Sweet but doesnt cover noticeable bitterness; not overwhelmingly unbalanced though.
 Generally sharp with dark fruits. Slightly thin mouthfeel. Almost tastes like wine; but not a very profound wine.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2009 Yummy!  Aroma of malt, dark chocolate and cherries. Flavor is more of the same, plus raisins, plums, belgian yeast and a little alcohol.  I love a good quad and this one is fantastic.

Looks great in the glass and the aroma was pungent and appetizing.  I think this beer is too bold in the flavor and alcohol departments, and it is not very refined because of that.  Perhaps this is a brew that could use some aging, but the sweetness of the alcohol is what dominated the palate for me.

Dégusté avec Agaguk, Pyrozoid.  Apparence cuivré foncé avec reflet rouge limpide et une belle mousse beige qui colle un peu au verre.  Aromes de chocolat suisse, fromage gouda fumé, raisins rouge, prunes, mures.  Explosion damertume et de sucré bien balancé au debut avec une finition tres vélouté. Corps tres rond et bien rempli avec une bonne effervescence.  Gout de fruits des champs, pommes rouge, miel, cassonade et chocolat.   Rien dextraordinaire mais tres bien balancé.

Bouteille de 750 ml. Dégusté avec french tickler et agaguk. Bière de couleur ruby avec un mince collet collant. Odeur de sucre, son, bananes, un soupçon dalcool. Saveur dépices, cerises, bananes, un peu le sel et réglisse.
In my opinion Ommegangs worst offering - and their most expensive. Dark chocolate and cherries, but in a strange way.

750ml. 2008 bottle. Poured in too much yeast, glass is murky but still looks nice mahogany and rich. Dregs boost the yeasty aroma, which is also vineous, a little hot, and with tonnes of ripe fruit, just loads of it. Smooth soft carbonation. Deceptively drinkable, quite smooth. Great breadlike background adds depth, complexity, and solidity to the fruit-forward brew. Some wet wood character and a lingering sour cherry finish. Nice stuff, nice balance of flavors, stronger than it seems.

Subtle aroma of cherries and vodka.  Looks very murky, hazy with good, but thin head retention.  Flavor is a mix of dark fruit and brown sugar with some alcohol on the back.  Palate is great, smooth, full body and creamy.  Overall, very enjoyable beer that drinks like a strong dark belgian with a dark cherry twist.

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2017 2017 Rating: Was 2.4 now 3.7  Lots of carbonathion that never stops as would be expecteed from a quad.  Very light nose but it is chocolate cherry.  Flavor is light sweet and hint of cherry and lots of carbonation on the tongue.  Ends with a balanced bitter.  2009 Rating: Excellent aroma, had me excited until the first drink.  Strong burnt dark chocolate flavor. No hint of cherry, would be good as a mixer, but at this price not worth it.

750ml corked and caged.  Pours a clear light brown/dark amber with a moderate sized tan head, nice retention and lacing.  Aromas are pretty mellow, some fruit, cherries, malts and caramel.  Flavors are were its at in this brew, its basically the same but more mention to the fruit and cherries.  Palate is smooth and slightly creamy.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2012 On tap at the Bavarian Lodge, Lisle, IL. Presented in a 3 Philosophers logo tulip for the occasion. Poured a dark brown color with ruby tones. The head was  light tan, foamy, and left some nice, clingy lacing. The aroma was sweet, with vinous and tangy fruit notes, mellowed by a light blanket of caramel. The flavor was sweet malt, wine notes as the aroma, and tangy fruit, more specifically dark cherries, with a little cranberry tartness. Cant forget the nice, warming alcohol. A fine sipper. Only got better with a little warmth. Enjoyed the 12 oz. bottle version recently at Lunar Brewing Co., and was equally impressed. A little lighter in color, more reddish amber. Fruit and floral, rich malt, complementary hop bitterness, and again, the pleasantly warming alcohol.

This one scores high for appearance. A very beautiful beer. Sparkling dark red color with a one inch foamy lasting tan head. This looks great in the glass. The aroma is of raisins, plums, brandy, chocolate covered cherries, yeasty fruity alcohol and overipe fruit. Taste is overipe fruit, chocolate, a touch of oakiness, (maple syrup? ) sweet and sour leading to a mild tart bitterness in the finish. Its meduim body leaves a nice lacing on the glass. Not as outstanding as some of the other world class beers of this style, but definitely a tasty, enjoyable brew that I will have again. The fact that its brewed with cherries adds a touch of a lambic feel to it as well.
TAP: deep brown pour, nice white head with good lacing. Cherry and banana on the nose, more of the same on taste, and a nice creamy mouthfeel. Exceptional beer.

Bottle from Greens.  Pours a deep brown with hints of red and a two-finger lingering white head.  Spicy malt and cherry aroma with roasted character.  A lot of flavors at play.  Difficult to distinguish some of them although there is definitely cherry and some other citrus flavors, malts, a little hops and a strong twinge of yeast.  Despite the taste amalgamation it is nonetheless a rather light beer.  Delicious, although a bit sweet for large-scale consumption.
Never have had much of a taste for quads. Strong alcohol taste is prevalent with a slight taste of cherry to finish.

2005 bottle - Ive had many of these over the years, but I thought this one deserved a rating.  Darker brown color with a cherry-heavy aroma that features, caramel, candy, vinous fruits, and yeast.  Flavor is pleasantly cherry-ish with lots of tartness, dark sugar, yeast, and some vinousness.  Nice feel.  Overall, a solid quad that never seems to telegraph its true strength.
Bottle from tasting at K&B, finally got around to tasting this.  Tast of either prunes or figs, nice reddish color with tan head.  Nice carbination

(bottle from Skyview) Pours a medium, hazy, reddish brown with just a thin off-white head.  Aroma is musty and filled with cherry skin right away, but the maltier scents of caramel appear along with another smell that reminds me of a barbeque sauce.  Theres a constant shifting between the cherry and the malt here, and its a pretty pleasant effect.  The taste isnt nearly as strong of cherry as I wouldve guessed from the smell, and theres a lot of sweet caramel in here.  Some sweet cherry appears mid-palate.  Only upon the beginning of the finish do I get the spike of tart cherry skin, and the finish itself imparts a taste of crushed peanuts with a bit of bread.  The mouthfeel is medium, and the carbonation is a bit too spritzy for the style.  This is pretty good, and its definitely an interesting take on a quad. Thanks Bob!
Bottle at home ... Deep brown ... sweet yeast malty nose ... sweet juicy deep fruits again a little yeasy ... Really just ok. wasnt inspired at all by it.

What a fantastic beer. Hints of cherries and spice in the aroma. Flavor is great balance between tart cherries, yeast, and some other hints of tart fruit. Body is very light and crisp. Alcohol is nearly undetectable. Overall, this is a great beer to sip and enjoy anytime of the year.
My wife bought a case of this after I bruised a rib working on our house.  $80 and worth it.

On tap from Stuff Yer Face.  I nice dense head and cloudy reddish-gold pour.  The sweetest smelling quadrupel Ive tried with a solid amount of yeasty earthiness worked in as well.  The taste was wonderful!  The heaviness from the alcohol wasnt off-putting because I was too wrapped up in working out some of the subtle flavors of this strong brew.  These flavors included a certain tartness as well as that classic quadrupel

750->tulip: Pours a huge, frothy, light brown head, atop a cloudy, ruby body.  Aroma is of light malt, cookie, and caramel.  The body is medium, the texture thin, with an astringent finish.  The flavors duration is average, being lightly sweet, acidic, and bitter.

Caged/corked bottle of a classic Ive somehow been remiss in databasing.  Solid head on a bright red beer.  Aroma is of a musty farmhouse.  Drinks with a nice earthy character with just the simplest hint of the cherry plus-up.  This goes great with chocolate desserts.  (#3519, 2/23/2009)

Bottle.  Aroma has notes of yeast, raisin, toasted malts.  Deep dark amber hue with a large off-white foamy head that mostly lasted and left good lace.  Flavor is yeasty, malty, earthy, and a little sweet.  Palate is medium to full bodied and oily lively.  Was hoping for more cherries which were barely noticable.  A solid abt/quad but I wouldnt buy another bottle.

Pours reddish brown. White head diminishes to a thin lace cap. Dark fruit and malt on the nose. After several sips Im able to pick up the cherry notes. Carobonation is a nice foil to the big alcohol.

2007 Bottle. Poured a bright brown with a tan head. Aromas of raisin, prune, roasted malts, and a light alcohol background. The flavor has prune, chocolate malts, and light alcohol. Medium to full body with a fruit aftertaste. Nice!!

12oz Bottle. $3.99 Julios Liquors. I found this to have just the right amount of cherry in it. The label states 98% ale blended with 2% cherry ale. Seemed like the right formula. The head made nice circles that remained throughout. Surprised to find that there was no sediment. This is a well crafted beer which I will definitely have again.

2008 Bottle. Pours a dark translucent caramel with a diminishing tan head. The aroma is strong of effervescent cherries with some yeasty qualities in the background. The initial flavour is sweet with the berry citrus cherries and cranberriesand some yeasty notes. The yeast notes fade a little as the brew sits in the mouth. As the brew passes, allowing the taste buds to breathe, the hops become slightly evident and the citrus bite heightens. After its peak, the citrus diminishes allowing some caramel flavours to awaken and making the yeast more evident again. The beer is pretty smooth throughout the tasting up until the finish. The finish becomes moderately dry, much like a dry citrus, with some light bitter notes. Its a delicious beer, but as a quadrupel it seems to me to be a little too sweet.
Paired with a Wenslydale (with Cranberries) cheese. 
The cheese: It is mildly sweet and initially creamy, but becomes dry towards its finish. The cranberries are almost too overpowering, though, as there are quite a bit of cranberries in this cheese. However, consuming the cheese itself, it has the perfect amount of cranberry flavour.
The pairing: As expected, the cranberries pair well with the citrus flavours of the beer. The flavour of the cheese is too mild to affect the flavour of the beer save for slightly accentuating the sweetness of the beer. But its the texture of the cheese thats the magic of this pairing. The initial mouthfeel of the beer becomes smoother as the finish no longer becomes dry. The hops in the finish is now masked with the creaminess of the cheese which also extends the smoothness of the beer into the finish. The cranberries in the cheese brings more attention to the berry citrus in the finish. I really enjoy this pairing.

Malts, caramel and slight berries, notably cherries and raspberries.  Medium amber color, slightly slick and medium to light body.  Toffee, caramel, light pear, orange and cherries.  Medium finish, light sweetness but not distracting.
Flaske 2005. uklar lys rødbrun med et beige skum. Duft og smag af tørrede mørke frugter, brun sukker, karameller. Er noget støvet i smagen og der er noget gammel dumle.
great bomb from wooden.  light fruit notes up front and sour at the end.  bubbles take the malts away from the glass.

750ml bottle poured into a shaker.  My only Trappist glass is dirty and Im WAY too lazy to wash it.  OTP pours murky and reddish brown with a medium-sized head that settles quickly into a small ring of carbonation.  The aroma is pretty subtle with cherries and lima beans being the only thing I can detect.  This medium-bodied beer is carbonated a bit higher than expected, possibly to avoid overpowering the taste with alcohol.  The cherries, while evident dont dominate but add a great subtlety of tart fruitiness.  The finish kind of sticks in your craw a bit.  The beer doesnt quite finish off the way Id like.  This is a pretty nice beer but it could be touched up here and there.  Thank you Phil and Noel.
Bottled. Hazy and dark brown coloured. Malty and very sweet with notes oxidation, caramel, spices and leaves you with a dry mouth. Might have been great, but feels a bit over the hill.

12 oz 2008 Bottle.  Pours cherry mahgony in colr with a fair amount of off white head.  Smells of cherry and brown sugar are prominant.  Tastes of cherries and molasses tart-sweetness are foremost, with hints of grapes and banana in the background.  Some tastes of red wine and a smooth liquor blend nicely and balance well with the fruity tartness.  Excellent and unique beer.

Pours a deep mahogany color with a nice light tan head... Sweet aroma, yeast, noticeably belgian, with mild notes of cherry... Slightly tart flavor, complex up front followed by a slightly tart cherry finish... A bit more carbonated than i would like... This beer is remarkably drinkable for this style... Props to Noel Blake...

12 oz bottle 2008, pours brown with ruby hue and moderately high carbonation. Fruity aroma and flavor, plus brown sugar, plum, carmel and cherry. Medium viscosity with velvety mouthfeel and mineral finish that hides alcohol.
Truly a great ale.  Lovely sweet malty, toasty aroma.  Taste to match... and a good body.  This one is definitely a keeper.
Beautiful dark reddish brown color. Pour from the bottle with a light brown head which dissipates quickly. The light cherry taste adds a pleasant change to the already flavorful beer.

Bottle at House of Brews in NYC.  Solid showing from the gang from Cooperstown. Borderline candidate for the Hall of Fame.  Dark reddish color with a beige head.  Aroma of malt, spices, and dark fruits.  Flavor is vinous with sweet malt with lots of cherry flavors. Fairly strong alcohol.  Fairly full palate.  Not for rookies.

Bottle vintage 2007:  Pours a dark amber with a nice, creamy beige head.  A malty and intimidating nose with sweetness and Belgian spices.  A little yeast and light florals.  Taste is a deep malt flavor with a sweet caramel and vinous blend.  Belgian spices and a fruity tingle before the malty tail takes over.  Very nice.
pours a red color with a great big head that quickly dissipates to a small film. spicy with an acrid, acidic cherry flavor that cuts in sharply across the malt flavors

Bottle.  Pours a rusty red with tan head which disapperars quickly.  Aroma is malty sweet with a hint of spice, nutmeg mostly.  Sweet flavor with hints of cinnamon, cherries, banana, and malt.  Nice palate, has a kick without being too fizzy.  Alcohol is present.  Very good, worth a try.
Reddish copper color with a generous head.  Interesting beer, the lambic adds a twist.  Noticeable alcohol strength.  Cherry and sweet maltiness in the flavors and the aromas.

750 ml. from Trinity Liquors in Spring Hill, FL. Aroma of toffee, malt, and some alcohol coming through. Pours red/brown color with a thin beige head. Flavor is great; mollasses, toffee, alcohol, a bit or cherry. Pretty smooth on the palate. Very very solid...a great beer to drink in the winter....Just another solid selection from Ommegang.

2008 bottle,  OMG was this beer awesome. Pours a murky candy apple red with brownish highlights. Big, fluffy head. Sticky lacing is prominent. Aromas of plum, caramel, licorice, cinnamon, fig, and chocolate. Nice. First touch on the tongue is frothy and smooth. Plum and dark candy, brown sugar, fig, and sweet banana. Dont get a lot of cherries, but the other flavors really make up for it. Very smooth-bodied, and full and savoring. Very enjoyable i want more.
bottle.  a tasty belgian style beer.  great flavors and not an overwhelming yeast taste (why i dont drink many belgian beers.  good stuff

Perhaps the sweetest Belgian style Ive tasted. Malty as it should be with cherries, cherries, a little chocolate and brandy and then more cherries. Distinctive taste works well as a 2nd or 3rd round choice as you wont confuse it with anything else. Very pleasant.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a rich caramel brown color with a big foamy tan head that has great retention and very nice lacing.  Aroma is slight cherries and a touch of yeast/bread with a slight note of alcohol at the end.  Flavor is a semi sweet, malt with a slight fruit, mainly cherry.  Very pleasant and enjoyable.  Easy to drink, and almost refreshing...?  A "refreshing" quad?  Im on crack.
UPDATED: FEB 11, 2010 Pours a light red color. Very little head. Alcohol nose. Taste is rife with cherries and other fruits. Sweet and heavy, with nice yeast notes. I like it.
Super pleasant, light head with a clear amber hue and cidery aroma with traces of cherry and belgian spices.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2009 Murky reddish brown with sediment, non lasting cream top, like fresh cider, opaque. Smells of maple, wood, grapes, cherries and dark chocolate. Tastes of bitter chocolate, CARAMEL APPLES, cinammon with warm alcohol finish. Smooth and slightly hearty.

2003 bottle thanks to dchmela.  Smells really strong of alcohol.  Dark red color, with age particles.  Big cherry and chocolate.  Id like to have a fresh one ot see how it stacks up.  Sweet malts..really like this one...Thanks dave.

Poured deep brown and ruby red, almost opaque and a bit hazy. Nice two finger head and great lacing. Big malty aromas, including cherries, tart granny smith apples, licorice and mint. Sweet malt flavors, nothing roasted about it, featuring black cherry, apples, and slight coffee, chocolate and brown sugar. Very smooth on the palate, generously carbonated and a very pleasant dark fruit aftertaste. Alcohol has a wonderfully warming effect on a cold winter night.
Bottle from 3 bottle craft pack.  Pours a nice dark amber with a off-white/tan head.  Tastes of cherries and licorice with a bitter finish.  Best of the three beers.

Bottle. [Trade with hopscotch and the Florida Crew, thanks buddy]  Huge thick beige head that really lasted. Excellent display of lacework. Cloudy dark amber color. Aroma was very explosive with notes of fruit and dried fruit. Strong undertones of alcohol, Port Wine, thick malt. Over the palate notes of raisins, prunes nuts was picked up. Almost mild sour cherry notes as well. Full bodied with a soft carbonation and thick alcoholic texture. Heavy sweet flavor the way I like it. Lingering warming vinous dried fruity finish. One more please. Once again thanks for the trade Eric, see you and your lovely wife in Copenhagen in 2010.

Pours an opaque dark brown with a small light tan head that dissipates pretty fast. Smells kind of like those chocolate covered liquor cherries. Has a strong and sweet malty nose with dark fruit and a hint of yeast and alcohol. Sweet malts meld with the dark fruit with hints of molasses and caramel to make this a very tasty beer. Nice sticky palate, I was a little concerned that I would be turned off by the cherries but they are just a small part of the complex array of flavors in this excellent beer.

Pours an excellent murky reddish brown.  Smells like cherries and chocolate.  I cant wait to drink this.  Tastes like alcoholic fruit roll ups.  Bitter and dangerous finish.  Cherries dominate the finish.  Almost a sour bitter cherry finish with a hint of birchwood.  This beer gave me a premature
hangover.  Don’t try to drink this if you already have a buzz.  Danger...

Bottle, John’s Grocery in Iowa City. Very pretty russet pour, small layer of off-white head, settling into a sticky ring. Pungent cinnamon nose, along with a bit of ruby port, old boat wood, and (can I say this in a rating?) dog fouling. For some reason the British euphemism for that seems slightly less off-putting in the description of a beer. And it isn’t actually off-putting here either. Just earthy, rustic. Flavor is dry plums, cinnamon, tree bark, refined clean finish. Lovely suede-leather mouthfeel. Lively, interesting beer. I dig.
POURS WITH A NICE THICK FOAMY HEAD WITH A SWEET FRUITY SMELL. IT TASTE VERY SWEET SLIGHT CHERRY FLAVOR ONE OF MY FAVORITE QUADS.

Bouteille, avec bouchon de liège, de 750 ml partagée lors dune dégustation Ratebeer Montréal chez MartinT. Arôme: Odeur de caramel et de cerises. Apparence: La couleur est bourgogne. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût très fruité avec une présence de caramel. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût légèrement fruité. (Rating #2055)

Bottle. Pours a very dark reddish brown with a small tan head that leaves a nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of caramelized malts and dark fruits. Slight hint of alcohol. Very smooth and sweet on the palate. The malts are front and center with hints of fruits. A like this very much and will buy again.

Bottle, trappist glass. Strong fruit aroma which was mostly cherry. Dark color of brownish orange. Beautiful tan colored head. Light glass cling. Slight fizz, great bitter character, and a dry finish. I mistakenly called it a Belgian ale before seeing it was made in Cooperstown, surprising. Delicious. A new favorite.

Poured from a large bottlle into a trappist glass to enjoy.  A rich floral hop aroma with alot of dense fruits, especially cherry; grassy hops and barley malt too.  The beer had a good-sized, creamy dark tan head with average retention and cling.  A slightly cloudy, brown-orange color.  Great sweet fruity and cherry flavor, with some bitterness too and a touch of sour.  A healthy amount of carbonation, with good fizz, and a lively, thinner feel.  Slightly drier finish with a slight feel of alcohol.  Definitely a really good beer, thoroughly enjoyed.

12oz bottle, 2008 release. Pours dark ruby brown with a small head. Great balance of fruit, malt, and hops with an awesome caramelized sugar flavor at the finish. Nice lacing in the glass. The flavor does not linger. A great beer and one of the best American brewed Quads I have tasted.

Bottle shared with me by my friend Chris- A rusty auburn pour created a frothy beige cap with pretty lace. Nose of over ripe dark fruits, lots of caramel and Belgian candy sugar, floral notes, some perfume, molasses, and a hint of red cherry. Tastes of sweet candy, dark pit fruits, molasses, with added cherries and a good dose of balancing bittering hops. Finishes sweet, fruity, quite creamy and no trace of the high ABV. Nice brew. Thanks Chris.
Bottle pours a deep brown with ruby edges.  Aromas of cherries and sweet malt.  Flavor is sour cherry, ripe fruit, very lively in the mouth.

750ml bottle from 2007, drank in December of 2008.  Very attractive, thick,reddish brown color.  The aroma has turned a little off at this point.  Ive only had it a handful of times in the past, but I believe it as a more noticeable cherry taste when fresh.  Tastes like a less carbonated and alcoholic La Trappe Quad to me, which is a good thing, to capture some of the Quadrupel subtleties.  This rating only reflects the aged version, Id assume the fresh one would score much higher.

The beer has a cloudy, deep red appearance in the glass. The head is off-white with a dab of mauve and foamy. Full bodied with a defined cherry flavor, Three Philosophers buzzes in your mouth initially and then dissipates into a sweet round finish. The sweetness does not overwhelm however.This ale is truly a delight.

A very good blended quad and cherry lambic that flirts with greatness.  Brightly brown liquid if you let the yeast settle.  Bubbly head.  Somewhat strong carbonation.  Strong sour cherry smell and taste.  Also bananas cloves pepper dark wood and funky earth flavors.  The cherry dominates more than I would prefer.  It is clear that an immense amount of effort goes into this beer.  Ommegang is an excellent brewery with a delicious yeast strain in their Belgians that is only a notch or so below the Trappists.  Now the size of that notch varies in my mind from beer to beer.  At any rate a very interesting beer that would be great for introducing to non craft beer drinkers but there is a tad too much cherry flavor for a higher rating.  Great idea but I am not a big enough fan of fruity lambics to love it.

Bottle.  Pours cloudy scarlet-brown, with a medium-thick biege head.  Strong malty aroma, leather, brandy and cherries.  Thick body.  Wood and leather flavor, fermented cherries, and a little nutty.  Slightly dry and bitter aftertaste that helps balance all of the malt.
Deep deep red with nice carbonation.  Smells like alcohol and cherries.  Lots of malt i the flavor with some alcohol and a noticeable bitterness at the end.  Great beer that deserves to be sipped.

Orange brown with some head in the pour.  Malts and cherry aroma, with some caramel in the hint.  Taste was a bit carbonated and bubbly alcohol, with only a hint of cherry.  Great beer but it would have been even better if the taste matched the great smell.
Pours an orange brown with an off white head.  Aroma of malts and a bit of alcohol.  Taste of malts with some bitterness and alcohol at the finish.
Reddish brown, smooth, sweet, dark fruits, yeasty, caramel, malty, spicey, wood.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2009 Bottle, 2006. What an amazing aroma. After smelling the beer for five minutes, I was prepared to hand out my third 5.0. Awesome tart cherry notes meshing seamlessly with a yeasty, nutty, caramelly, dark-fruity quad base, wow, what a thing of glory. Unfortunately, while the age seemed to have done wonders for the cherry aspect in the nose, the base beer suffered just a bit in the mouth, yielding a bit too much of a soda characteristic and losing some of that rich, earthy nuttiness. Perhaps a 2007 bottle will reveal the best of both worlds...10-5-7-4-14/4Rerate 1/15/09 2008. An incredible desert beer. Cake-like, sometimes like a rum cake, earthy, sweet, rich, decadent, cherry much more subtle than the aged bottles, but there, adding to the rich, semi-chocolatey cake feel. Intense and luscious. 8-4-9-4-17/4.2

(Bottle, 7 Nov 2008) Reddish brown colour with firm, frothy, pale brown head. Fruity, malty nose with notes of cherries, black-currant, toffee, chocolate and dried fruit. Malty, fruity, toasty taste with dried fruit, toffee, chocolate and dark cherries. Spicy, herbal bitterness and a touch of liquorice in the finish. Slightly oaky character. Medium to full body, balanced sweetness throughout, with a warming puff of alcohol towards the end. Nice and warming beer. In short: Rochefort the Cooperstown way.

75 cL bottle at Svea. Pours hazy dark brown with a slowly diminishing tan head. Wineous aroma of cherry and roasted malty notes. Light metallic and mild fruity aroma. Dark fruity and wineous with a solid caramel and roasted flavour beneath. Lingering yeasty, fruity and subdued malty into the finish.
Pours a deep caramel red color with a thin off white head. The nose and flavor are full and rich with all things manly. Leather, earth, dried fruits and a touch of funk. Creamy on the palate.

(Bottle.  2007 edition).  Very sweet ripe fruit aroma.  Dark reddish brown body, moderate off-white head.  Flavor has lots of complex fruit notes, cherries, raisins, and figs mostly.  Very sweet, but not as candyish as I was fearing.  Alcohol is well disguised.  Good stuff, though can’t compete with Rochefort.

Thought I had already tried this beer, oh well! The beer has a nice red/orange caramel color. The beer also pours along with a nice thin layer of head. The aroma smells like sweet figs. I cannot smell the cherries, but maybe somewhere in that sweet aroma there is the cherry smell tied up. This beer packs a strong flavor. Lots of sugar, candy, and fruit flavors going around. Slight alcohol taste, but hidden well by the fruit and sugar taste. Not as creamy as the other Quadrupels that I have had, which are few. Overall, this beer packs a nice fruity punch with a nice sugar/candy taste. I probably wouldn’t drink again, but a damn good beer to try.

2006 bottle. Pours a murky brown with a thick tan head. Aroma of a sweet cherry lambic...ah, I could smell this beer all day! Flavor of sweet cherries, raisin, dark fruits, raisin bread, soda. Smooth mouthfeel. Excellent quad and probably the best of the American versions that I’ve had so far.

2008 vintage out of small bottle.  Pours a very rich ruby/brown color, with very pleasing head and good retention.  The aroma is somewhat faint but sweet with some candied malt.  The overall taste is sweet, but there is good depth to the flavors, with some raisin and some roasted sugar flavors.  I was expecting more sweet/sour cherry flavor but I am actually glad that it ended up being a background flavor, it made it more of a full beer.  I liked the carbonation, it was somewhat high which made the beer a little on the thin side, especially considereing the high ABV.  Very smooth for a quad, extremely drinkable.  It’s worth the money for sure.

Pours a hazy dark brownish amber with a creamy two-finger head that shows very good retention and lacing.

The aroma is very sweet with candy sugar and caramel malts dominating. There are generous amounts of dark fruits as well, raisins and the like.

The taste is as sweet as the aroma suggests, tons of caramelized sugar, dark fruits and caramel malts. Cherries are in there as well, with a hint of sourness.

The mouthfeel is medium bodied with lots of carbonation. It may be just a tad thin.

This is a decent example of a quad despite not being extremely complex. Very drinkable.
Crushed with Jakebra.  Cherries on the nose.  Flavor, like burnt wood and some awesomeness.  Pretty damn enjoyable.  Definitely smells better than it tastes, but that smell is beautiful.

75cl corked bottle from 2007.  Let this sit about 18 months before opening.  Very easy to drink quad overall.  Pours a dark brown with ruby highlights and a tan head that settles quickly.  Aroma of candied fruit, oak and sherry.  Big flavour that had more fruit notes plus a little yeast.

750ml Bottle:  Aroma of cherries, alcohol, grains, malts, and caramel.  Poured deep amber with a hint of ruby in color and a large tan head that diminished into a thick film that lasted throughout.  Clear.  Lightly sparkling.  Lightly sweet flavor.  Tastes of alcohol, cherries, malts, wood, dark ripe fruits, light tar, and slight chocolate.  Medium body.  Slightly tingly, smooth texture.  Average to lively carbonation.  Dry, woody, cherry-sweet finish.
Pours dark brown with a fresh fruit aroma, mainly bananas and cherries. Smooth and refreshing taste with a nice cherry backdrop and an alcoholic finish. Solid effort and the booze is well masked.

Bomber 2008: pours dark red/brown with tan head.  Aroma: sherry wine with brandy-esque and liqueur notes.  This beer started out sharp, dry and with a cherry tartness.  Also with a noticeable alcohol taste.  It got smoother although still dry, with a slight cherry aftertaste as it cooled.  I was hoping for more of a cherry and sweet taste after reading the description on the bottle.  But this is quality nevertheless.  I bet this taste awesome after being aged longer.

Pours a deep, murky light-brown. Aroma has subtle hints of fruit, mainly cherries and bananas, with some sweet bready undertones. Big Quadrupel taste, although not as complex as some. Flavor is dried dark fruits, a touch of cherry and nuts at first with a lot of banana and yeast on the finish. Maybe slight hints of caramel. Certainly a tasty beverage, but I’ve yet to have a Quad touch the Roc 10. Still waiting for that elusive Westy 12.
Decent lightly fruity aroma. Appearance is dark brownish red and hazy. Flavor seems a bit yeasty. Medium-full mouthfeel. Not terrible. Had better.
Bottle. Pours dark red. Aroma is cherry and alcohol which carries through in the flavor. My impression is that this tastes like cough syrup. Might have to try it again sometime.

Pours a dark amber and having an off white head. Aromas of bannanas, cherry, spices, wheat, and a note of hops. The flavor is sweet all around. Some of the aromas carry to the flavor, those being the bannana (but lightly), spices, cherry (more noticeable towards the end), and wheat. Other notes of caramel and a touch of liquorice. The alcohol is slightly noticeable but mostly well hidden. i would of given this a 9 for flavor if there was no alcohol noticed. A very well balenced Quadrupel and a very good tasting beer!

Another year-round staple and fine American example of Belgian brewing from the brewers at Ommegang. This time I am presented with their Three Philosophers, a Belgian quad, or quadrupel, with a bit of a different twist. Brewed with dark cherries, Three Philosophers combines the rich complexity of a Belgian quad with the sweet yet tart succulence of a Belgian kriek, or cherry beer. Only so much is made each year, so each batch has the year in which it was brewed and then bottled from. Today I get to partake of a 2008 Three Philosophers and sate the philosopher in me.

A huge head chides me to pour my Three Philosophers slowly so as to not waste her pomp and prominence, and at the same time to savor her seductive amber brown body as it slowly fills my glass. Not as dark as a traditional quadrupel, this is but one unique aspect of this brew and a beautiful reminder of the cherry which lies within. Her head slowly settles into a soft off-white blanket with a tinge of pink. Of course, with a head such as her head, brussels lace sticks all over the sides like a spider web of brewing intrigue. I can definitely smell the rich dark cherries along with sweet caramelized sugars and a tart sour nip. Caramel, nuts, and some dark fruits round out the nose. Her body is sweet, clean and smooth with a light sour puckering effect after the initial sweet impression. Mildly effervescent, I can definitely taste the cherries right away. Holding it all together is a full and subtle palate of caramel malts, nuts, dark fruits and a growing warmth from the high ABV. Sweet and tart, clean, smooth and succulent with rich dark fruits, nutty malts, and a pleasing finish. About the only improvement I can think of is a bit more of a fuller body. For a quadrupel, even considering the kriek aspect, it feels and tastes a bit too thin.

I can definitely appreciate Three Philosophers for what it is and what Ommegang has done with this particular quadrupel. It isn’t a quad I would quaff when in the mood for a traditional quadrupel, but when the mood strikes for something of a different twist, Three Philosophers can definitely fill the bill.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy copper with an energetic tan head that departs far too soon.  Plentiful aromas of cherries, wine, brandy and freshly baked bread.  Thick and malty with a hint of cherries (a little less than I was optimistically expecting from the 2% cherry beer mix).

Monster quad.  Dark fruit and roast in the nose (baked bread character).  Flavors of raisins and plums as well as dark roast malt, slight banana and a tiny bit of citrus.  Has a sort of leathery character to it.  Great brew.

2007 Bottle
Brewery Ommegang are realy good at interpert belgian beers. 
This one is blended with 2% Kriek which gives an interesting touch

probably the best offering from ommegang. poured this into a white wine glass. Color was deep caramel amber that was light on the edges but seemed to deepen at the center of the glass. the fruity cherries are subtle in the nose but a sweetness from caramel as well. those sweet smells transfer to the taste with a bit of alcohol int he back. Really the best part of this beer is the sharpness of the carbonation that nearly burns my tongue like holy water burns Emily Rose. Full body that makes me want to fill my glass over and over again.
Bottle. Dark copper. Thick head. Wonderfull complex aroma of strawberries, belgian yeast and soy. Dry, fruity and refreshing flavor. Good but not great.

2008 Bottle. This beer is among the best I’ve had in the category for its wonderfully balanced flavor that is simply pleasurable.  The aroma of this beer is moderately close to that of cherry hard candy mixed with malts and dried fruit complexes.  The taste of the beer is yeasty and there is somewhat of a hint of caramel present.  This beer has a sizable amount of alcohol due to its style, which somewhat impedes the flavor complex.  The head pours moderate and settles to a thin and uniform layer of perfect tiny bubbles. The head does lightly lace the glass. This beer is great with food, and is also good as an after dinner beverage. I simply cannot get enough of this beer.

75 cl bottle, thanks ekstedt. Brown, cloudy, with a fully diminishing off-white head leaving virtually no lacing. Roasted, nutty notes with a touch of raisin. Lightly acidic with a short finish. Medium bodied with lively carbonation.

Bottled. Ruby color, thick off-white head. Aroma of malt, some hop, hint of rasin, bit yeast, cherry. Sweet fruity taste, cherries, caramel malty, brown sugar. Finishes cherry fruity. High complexity, moderate balance though.

750 ml bottle uncorks to smell of cherries.  Pours to dark body with the thick caramel head that lingers clinging to the sides. Flavor in complex with the alcohol well hidden.  The is a legit quad...and at a great price

La bière se présente avec une couleur rougeâtre et une belle mousse fauve qui dure et colle à la parois du verre. Au nez on respire des arômes de cerises confîtes, de sucre candi, de banane, de baies de gomme baloune et d’alcool. En bouche le corps est moyen avec une effervescence pétillante. On goûte des saveurs de cerises confîtes, de sucre brun, de pain brun ainsi qu’une finale très alcoolisée.

2008 bottle. Poured a deep dark red with a small white head.  Aromas of bananas, cherries, and maple sugar.  Flavors of black cherry, chocolate, and hop spice.  Perfectly smooth, with a flavorful linger.  An MVP for performance and price.

Amazing palate! The cherry flavor blends well with wild yeast flavors, but comes off a bit too strong with the alcohol flavor.  I’m not getting as much depth or complexity as I was expecting.  As it warms a bit of chocolate and oak come out, but the main flavor is still of alcohol followed by cherries.  Also, I expected more cherry flavor, I have seen this much coaxed out of malt in a few imperial stouts.

Pours a deep dark copper red.  Looks like Beaujolaiswith a beautiful head and nice lacing as it dissipates.  The nose is licorice and candied fruit with underlying alcohol notes.  Flavor is bitter with a big hit of alcohol.  Not getting the cherry I expected nor much else as far as flavor goes.  A little bittersweet chocolate?  Definitely seems to open up as it warms.

Big bottle 2008.  Smell cherry and wood.  Creamy head reduces to lace.  Clean sides of the glass.  Deep red in color.  Serioous chunks of yeast at the bottom.  The bottle says to serve at 50 deg., and I should have waited for it to warm up before I started drinking it.  At a crisp cold temperature it was bitter and lacked much flavor.  I couldn’t taste ANY of the roundness or cherries I expected.  As it warms, the flavors start to really open up.  Still bitter at the front of the mouth, but there is an explosion of cherry, alcohol, and who knows what else.  Enjoyable, but not amazing.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2009 Pours a dark ruby/amber with a medium tan head.  A beautiful looking beer.  Aroma is rich and complex, with cocoa, caramel, and cherry flavors.  Alcohol is also present.  The taste has chocolate malt, hints of coffee, and the cherry lambic is also evident.  Finish includes chest warming alcohol - this is a nice beer anytime, but that makes me think of enjoying one on a cold winters night.

750 ml bottle, cave aged 06 batch.Poured a cloudy brown with no head. Very cherry nose. I was very surprised by how nicely carbonated this was. Mouthful was very similar to a rochefort 8.Cherry, and chocolate flavors. I believe that the cave aged improved the overall flavor considerably. But this beer had a nice complex flavor to it,

very enjoyable.  Not aged, had to try it.  very interesting  brew in that it starts off with some dried friuit and maltness and finishes with distinct taste of chery.  Will re-rate botte that has been aged.  Anyone have suggestions on optimal aging time?

One of my favorites from the belgian beer tasting in Boston 9/27/08.  A really unique and amazing cherry tartness coupled with the usual strong malts.  Great reddish color, a pleasure to drink slowly.
Very sweet but not overpowering.  Similarities in both flavor and aroma to a scotch style ale.  Definitely impressed and will purchase again.

12 oz bottle.  Rather subtle aroma for such a big beer, yet pleasant, shortbread malt and cherries, with minor red wine.  Absolutely gorgeous beer, if i could give it a 6 i would, big cream colored fluffy almost fake looking head, good lacing all around, not completely opaque bright sangria red color with a smoke signal type carbonation flow.   Very malt dominated flavor, cocktail cherry flavor evident right from the start, but not in a syrup-like cherry cough drop sense like other beers, this flavor is counterbalanced well with sweet Belgian malt,  and a super smooth, medium-full body that feels great the whole way.  Really, just a very nice and unique beer, not much else needs to be said.

Ommefest on tap.  I’ve ever only had this on tap but can’t wait to open my 07 at home.  Pours dark with a malty cheery chocolate nose and follows straight up on the pallet.  Very complex and a great desert beer with dark chocolates.  It’s one of those beers I can’t wait to see in 5 years.

Bottle, Big monster malts, alcohol is very present, lots of chocolate, a bit of cherry tartness balances it out. Very big without question the flavor is much darker than many quads, almost sinister. I liked it.
This is good stuff.  Has the depth and character of a Belgian strong, with the added but subtle bonus of the 2% Kriek.  A very fine sipping ale.

Cherry aroma.  Never liked cherry this much.  Wow.  Monster head.  Lacing lasts for days.  Powerful ale.  Not sure what I taste, but what I taste is what my dreams are made of and that is all I need to know.  Hop bite works fine with the malt and yeast and cherrys.  Cherry cola color, hazy.  Drink this with Low by Flo Rida on and enjoy!

12 oz bottle from Johns Grocery.
Pours a really rich looking red. Hazy, can see some of the yeast/particles floating around making it even more cloudy. Big and fizzy, beige head with a good amount of lacing. A very potent aroma of sweet malts, toooons of dark cherry, a hint of alcohol, some caramel/brown sugar and licorice. A definite Belgian yeast strain smell to it too. A medium to full mouthful with an extremely chewy texture. A really interesting take on the Belgian Quad. Very malty with an initial spice, followed by a dark cherry/licorice/whiskey taste, with an ending that lingers and warms as the alcohol taste kicks in. A slight hint of roasted malts with the dried plummy taste. The candy sweetness is very well balanced with the liqueur-esque dark fruit and the slightly yeasty/bitter/burning finish. A fantastic Belgian Strong taste with a tremendous balance throughout. Not the "knock-out" strong ale that I was expecting, which I really really really enjoyed. Mmmmm.
more filling taste supurb lots of flavors of fruits and malts taste good like a belgian should
Red chestnut body, sparkle, beige head; Lots of caramel and age in nose; Quite full a little harsh body; Harsh very aged finish. To old or never really good???

Nothing negative to report about this beer at all. I mean, this is a very nice interpretation of the quadrupel style. Sweet brown sugar, dark fruits, licorice, and whiskey flavors are apparent, amongst others. No perceptible creaminess however, unlike Bernardus 12 and Rochefort 10, making it different though not inferior. Large and long alcohol burn, more than to be expected for under 10%; a treat for us who enjoy the sensation. Overall, between great and excellent. Thanks Ommegang

Deep crimson with hints of brown toward the center of the glass.  Solid 1/2 inch eggshell head...foam night as tightly packed as others.  Aroma of Belgian yeast, brown sugar, spice, and cherry.  Medium mouthfeel...drinkable and not filling.  Flavors of tart cherry skin, ripe sweet dark fruit, and caramel would make me return to this one again.

2008 Version. 330 mL bottle. Fairly clear amber pour with a large, fizzly, cream colored head that goes down after a few seconds. Looking closely you can see the added yeast that dissipates and turns the glass slightly cloudy. First taste is spicy- almost a sting from the near 10% abv. The aroma is likewise nutmeg, cloves, etc. There are many fruit flavors in the mix besides cherries once you get to drinking. Reminds me a lot of Aventinus.
750ml bottle. Hazy amber brown with a huge off-white head. Spicy, fruity aromas. Sweet caramel malt flavors to start with a sour twang to it. Dark fruit flavors.

cloudy brown, relatively light for a quadrupel, nice pale head... the lambic smell is pretty strong and mostly overwhelms the malts and regular yeast... very smooth malty with the kriek clearly noticeable... i almost wish the kriek wasnt as strong so i could enjoy the complexity of the rest... nevertheless yummy

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2013 12oz bottle shared by a friend at a work picnic. I remember the very first time I had this brew I wasnt prepared for the combination of styles. But its grown on me quite a bit, as its another very well done offering from the might Ommegang. Basically, its got all the virtues one expects from a nice quad  dark pour, thankfully not thinned out too much, lively spices combining with flavors of overripe fruits, and so forth. But the addition of the cherries really adds something, not sickly sweet or syrupy, but simply a distinctive quality that makes this brew stand out from others in the style. Not something I return to very often, but I enjoy it when I do.

750ml. bottle.
