Pours a pleasant happy head which dissipates rapidly to a thin foam, dark reddish brown color, nose of fruits, sweet spices, malts and yeast, tastes initially of malt spice and fruit, then evolving more to fruit flavors, very voluptuous and rich on the finish, with a final mild touch of hop bitterness.

Party Source growler.  Poured Dark, murky brown with thick beige head.  Aroma is dark fruits, malt, a little bit of yeast, and alcohol.  The flavor is very typical of Belgian-style ale.  I enjoyed it.

750ml.  courtesy of Paul.  Dark ruddy amber pour with a brown tinted quickly fading head.  You can smell the kriek and malt sweetness in the nose. Sweet and fruity with a slight hint of bitterness.  Nice quad!

Growler shared by bigmmartin.   Dark burgundy brown with a small head.  Lots of dark fruit in the aroma.  Very sweet with a slight touch of vinegar.  Full bodied feel and low carbonation.  Extremely drinkable and enjoyable without being complex.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2010 [RERATE]2009 Bottle.  This one kicks ass.  Better than I remembered it from the growler.  Tons of rich, sweet dark fruits in the aroma and flavor.  Lots of raisin with a bit of alcohol.  Similar to before, just more refined and balanced than I expected.  Damn good quad. 
[Original Rate]
Growler from Party Town tap. Dark brown beer with ruby hues and a beige head.  Smells of raisins, plums, rich malt, and alcohol...as well as a few hints a red wine aroma.  Flavor is deeply malty with lots of dark fruits and a little oak. Very little bitterness. The alcohol might be a bit too present but I dont mind.  An enjoyable Belgian representation.
Nice red color with a large bubbly head.  Not bad by any means. The flavors meld well together. I like the boosiness of it too. Not too shabby!

750 ml corked and caged bottle 2008 vintage poured a clear reddish brown with a lasting creamy tan head with excellent lacing. Aromas of cherry, toffee, carmel, wood, light vanilla and light spice. Palate was full bodied and smooth. Flavors of cherry, cocoa, carmel, toffee, light vanilla and a hint of spice with a smooth lingering bittersweet finish.

If beer came direct from heaven, this is what it would taste like. (...at least on even days of the week; on odd days it would be Speedway Stout.) Lovely rich sweetness with caramel and slight molasses with strong dark fruit, along with a cherry sourness from the 2% kriek. This is so rich and tasty. Fantastic yeast flavor with tiny champagne-like bubbles. This yeast is very similar to Lost Abbey’s Judgement Day yeast. I simply love this beer...

A beautiful-looking beer that pours a deep red with a creamy white head.  Aroma is sweet, with faint cherries and alcohol.  Flavor is astringent, with notes of caramel malt and sweet fruits.  The alcohol is readily apparent and really gets to you. I have to agree with the poster below me who called this a "mess".  It’s like they tried to blend several different flavors, but didn’t really succeed.  It’s respectable, but I just can’t buy in to this beer’s high rating.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2011 The Quad pours dark ruby amber with a big creamy tan head that has a ruby hue. This well-respected beer is delicious, refreshing, fruity, aley (if thats a word), and  boozy (in a good way) all at once. In the tradition of those Trappists, I can smell Belgium when I breathe in that sweet, boozy, rich beer flavor!

A deep brown core that is clearly lighter on the outside with a very thin tan head.  Aromas were of plum, raisin and an herbal spiciness.  The palate showed a balanced and restrained sweetness with a nice mix of dry and bitter hops added in.  This seems to need some age.

Unfortunately not as complex as the label might imply, with a weakness that doesn’t complement the flavors, but rather waters them down. An aftertaste that comes and goes without leaving much impression. There are worse beers, but there are better ones, and this one is forgettable
Bottle, 9.0%. Weak fruity aroma. Cloudy orange colour. Very small head. The has some cherry, but it is quite subtle. It is quite thin for its ABV, but it gets better after half a bottle or so.

750 ml bottle. 2005 vintage. from a trade but i cant remeber from who so i apoligize for the inadequate shout out but if your reading this thank you very much for the beer! i shared this bottle with jessem and ryanmac13 as well as a non-ratebeerian. pours dark amber with a nice tan head. lots of dark malt aromas with some cherries. no funk. not really Abt/Quadrupel or cherry Lambic to the nose. its not unpleasent but if i was smelling this without knowing what it was id have no idea what style this beer was. flavours are solid. complex with a very progressive change from the dark malt almost sorta belgian ale to the cherry lambic. the blending of the two styles into one beer make for an interesting beverage but im not sure that i wouldnt prefer to enjoy the two halves of this beer by themselves. to sum up, this was enjoyable while being somewhat confusing. thanks again to the person who sent me this!

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2008 2005 vintage 750mL bottle, shared with Matt7215 and his brother, his bottle (thanks Matt). Pours a very nice ruby-brown, mostly clear, with a small tan head. Aroma is actually a lot like the Koff Porter we had earlier, very weird for a Belgian ale of any sort, but I guess that could be viewed as a good omen. Sweet, slightly boozy, inky Baltic Porterness, and some cherry. Very interesting smelling. Flavour doesnt disappoint either. Great complexity with the cherry lambic aspects really shine through. Tart, a touch sour, with decent malty fruity aspects showing up. I  guess you could almost call this a Quad of sorts, but I think it might be better classified under the umbrella term of Belgian Strong Ale. Pretty smooth for the abv, though the bottle is 3 years old. Surprisingly good, although I dont know why my expectations were slightly low to begin with. Flavours blend together decently enough, but the cherry and lambic components really steal the show very quickly into the performance.

12 oz bottle, 2008 Vintage, liberated from BCTC VIP dinner, enjoyed at home.  Pours a clear reddish amber body with a fizzy off-white head that settles to a thin film.  Big syrupy malt nose with a sweet cherry syrup and chocolate accent.  Very noticable alcohol when you get your nose deep down in the glass.  The flavor is a bit of a mess, heavy syrupy fruity malt with a cough syrup like cherry flavor that’s only re-enforced by the prominent alcohol.  Figs, a little murky yeast and earthiness on the hot finish.  Mouthfeel is sticky and cloying with slightly overactive fizzy carbonation.  Overall, this was just pretty bad.  My least favorite Ommegang beer by far.

Pours brown with a reddish tinge around the glass. Foamy, eggshell colored head. Aroma is sweet, caramel, toffee malts, with sour cherries and a bit of alcohol. Caramel taste with a great sour, cherry finish. Not quite a dream beer, but great nonetheless.
Bold maroon in color with an assault of malts. It drinks cool and replenishes warmth.  Has a bite thats washed in cherries. Crisp and clean with foamy head, but not as dreamy as the aesthetic.
Bottle. Nice light fruity aroma. Reddish brown color with a small white head. Sweet light malty body with a nice light sour and cherry flavor. Nice and balanced sour palate.

This beer tastes very good. It reminds me of some sort of beer wine mixture. It is also very economical for a bottle brewed beer. If i could have a conversation with this beer i would say "Never gonna give you up, never gonna let you down."

The bottle pours like a jewel; rich amber with bright red tones and billowy tan head settling into about a quarter inch. Take it into the light. The aroma is splendid; candied fruit, cherries, melding into a subtle chocolate roastyness (roastyness not a word, but hey...). The complexity is something to keep up with, but not overwhelming. Different flavors from lips to gullet. Slightly tart at start, with lush caramel, oak(?) and alcohol. It’s INCREDIBLY smooth as it warms just a bit. Full mouthfeel, for sure, but I think the yeast has had enough sugar to mellow a bit and actually allow the other characters to come through.  How could I not love a beer named as it is, and created in strive to reach someone’s description of a perfect beer?? It’s awesome. Quite a shame I’ve got the big  bottle to myself, really.

On tap at Flying Saucer in Nashville TN.  Great looking and refreshing beer that exploded with many different flavors for the nose and tongue.  Very easy drinking quad with hardly any aftertaste until about 8oz into it when it started to saturate my mouth.  Not boozy whatsoever, and even at 10%, you could enjoy these on a porch in the dead heat of summer.  Great!

Three Philosophers is hard to fault on any count.  It smells, pours, and tastes like a good tripel plus a small amount of kriek.  What’s more, the total experience exceeds the sum of its parts.  The Trappist beers are a bit more complex, but this is very well balanced in every aspect.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2009 PIB 07 Just retried this beer and more or less blown away. The cherry kriek comes through as a pervasive note. Bready body, very solid, Belgian yeast comes through the quadruppel without overpowering the whole beer.

Pours dark red-amber with a huge head. Aroma is sweet like candy. Apples, cherries, yeast, and just a hint of roasted malt. Flavor is full but subtle. More fruit. Apples. Banana. Caramel. Fresh baked bread. It is medium bodied, but light and airy. Very nice all around. I felt relaxed from the first sip.

This is a great "quad." It has the distinctive "Ommegang" yeast smell; Brewery Moortgat has done a great job with this one. Spced caramel aroma with the Cherry note coming in. Reminds me of a chocolate ice cream with the marachino cherries aroma. Nutty maltiness with the slight Kriek tartness in the finish. Enjoyed in the corked 750ML bottle. A vortre’ sante!

Tasted during outage: This is another one of those OMG beers with great complexity.  Aromas of cherries, bread, caramelized fruits of apricots, peaches, dark fruits.  Pours a clear dark mahogany stain, almost enough to block the light.  Flavor is just as complex as the aromas coming forth, swirling the glass evokes new delights, palate is creamy, oily and crisp with fine effers that tickle the tongue, overall, extraordinary beer.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2010 A re-rate of my initial rating, done in my craft beer infancy: Aroma of caramel apple, light chocolate and cherry. Appearance is dark ruddy brown with tan head. Flavor matches the nose. Palate is creamy and bubbly. A great beer, but not the 4.8 of my initial rating.

12 oz bottle purchased from Cool Springs wine and spirits.  Pours a clear mahogany color with a 2 finger tan colored head.  The aroma consists of cherries and yeast.  The flavor is mild alcohol up front and a tart cherry aftertaste.

[Bottle] Pours a caramelly red with a medium tan head. Aroma is a lot of dark fruit, cherries undoubtedly, and doughy yeast. Flavor is great. Caramelly and spicy, some warming alcohol, and subtle but very well done cherry flavor. Leaves a nice tartness on the edges of the tongue.

Pours a ruby brown with a large tight tan head that fades slowly. Aroma is belgian malt, candy sugar, dark fruit tones with some cherry though it’s not predominant.
FLavour is sweet malt, tart fruit in the mid palate, a boozy alc. finish with some lingering cherry.
Not bad, though doesn’t hold a flame to the Bernardus 12 I had last night.

Pours a reddish brown with a thick tan head with lots of lacing.Smells of plum and cherry. Also very sweet and malty. Hope it tastes as good as it smells.Heavy alcohol flavor to start. I can also detect the plum and cherry. A little bitter at the end but not bad. Not as sweet as I was expecting.Mouth feel was good. Carbonation was light and fairly smooth.

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2010 Bottle from Kegs & Barrels in McKinney, TX.
Pours a slight hazy, Dark Amber with nice beige head. Aroma of light cherry, alcohol spice, barn yard, dark fruit, yeast. Flavor doesnt stray far, nice cherry and dark fruit, faint signs of licorice, toasty grain and has a nice light tang at the end. Mouth feel is medium body with fizzy carbonation. Overall, this is a very tasty and enjoyable brew!

cloudy brown pour, large off white head that remains for a while.  sweet, malty aroma with a hint of fruit.  sweet molasses up front then a bit of fruity tartness in the middle, the end is surprisingly roasty and dry .  Enjoyable.

brown pour with an amber orange tint. big billowy cream colored head, slow to dissipate- really nice looking beer. Aroma has malt, dark cherry, walnut, some sweetness like cream or vanilla. Flavor is delectable- malty with the sweetness still there, but subtle. I think if it was better aged, seeing as this is the 08, that the cherry would have been more evident. Great mouthfeel, really nice beer.

2007 bottle served in a trappist glass. Somewhat of a cloudy brown pour with a thin tan colored head. Aroma is fruity and alcoholic in a familiar Belgian fashion. Flavor is sweet up front with a tart fruity middle, you can taste the cherries, and finishes with a dry mildly roasted flavor that is rather nice. Not too shaby.

(USA) Courtesy of AFI96, thanks waylo !! Pours a hazy amber color with a nice med tan head. The aroma is sweet and malty with some fruit and alcohol. The taste is really good, caramel, cherries, and some brown sugar. This brew was extremely yummy and worth a 2nd go around !!!  :)

(bottle) A dark ruby body with a medium light brown head. A rich aroma of apple, cherry,berries, sweet malt and alcohol. Its full bodied, and has a soft mouthfeel. The flavor is strong with alcohol, wood, berries, chocolate, and some hop and dry malt in the finish.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2010 This nice treat of a beer has a lightly airy, light-brown head that mellows out to leave behind a nice, thick collection of froth around the edge of the glass and heavy, but bubbly, lacing.  Its appearance is dense and muddy, with an orangeish light-brown color and an orangeish hue.  The aroma is actually really, really good, with hints of honey, spice, fruit, roasted malt, and light alcohol and yeast.  If you think the aroma sounds nice, dont worry... so does the flavor.  Personal note: this beer actually tastes alot like a homebrew I made to celebrate the birth of my first son that was malty and highly alcoholic.  Three Philospophers is just that: malty sweet, fruity (but not sugary) and alcoholic with traces of yeast.  Im actually pretty impressed by this beer.  I suspect cherries might be whats making this beer so good.  Its dense, and the bubbles floating near the surface of the beer make that density obvious.  Its meaty, sweet and smooth.  It leaves an almost sweet/tart sensation in the mouth with a finish of warm, sweet alcohol, much like what youd experience in a double IPA, but without the IBUs.  Unlike many beers of thr Belgian style, this isnt that yeasty.  A great, well done beer that has a wonderful palate and is really enjoyable.  Im really quite surprised.  FOr such a high ABV, this is really drinkable.  I could drink this all night.  Warning, though... the yeast is much more noticeable when served at warmer temperatures, making it more of a sipping beer in those conditions.  So if youre drinking this solo, try it a little cooler.

I should like tart finishes a lot more than I seem to do.  The concept is perfect--take a break from bitterness and end some good malt flavors with a sour snap.  I do like them in lighter beers like Gueze, but the flavors here come across like Otto von Bismark--Blood & Iron.

Appearance: Pours a clear, mahogany-hued body with a small, though diminishing white head.

Smell: Malts drenched in cough syrup and blended with a strong, repellent alcoholic scent like taking a big sniff of rubbing alcohol. Egads!

Taste: Vague upfront maltiness with a sugary sweetness. And while some tartness it coming through, I’m not getting much cherry flavor. Stray bitterness. Splash of Dr. Pepper on the otherwise warm, tart finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation. Sticky mouthfeel.

Drinkability: I wasn’t overly enthralled with this one, no.

Bottled, pours dark brown and has a light colored head.  Smells of alcohol and malts.  This beer tastes a little fruity, but I don’t really taste the cherry flavor that everyone else does.  Still an excellent beer.  I’m very curious about the cave aged version.

12oz bottle, 2007 vintage..   hazy amber with a fine beige head.   Yeasty, alcoholic, and sweet-tart aroma.   The flavor is quite sweet, malty and alcoholic, with a tart cherry fruitiness.   Syrupy, medium thick body with typical belgian style bottle conditioned carbonation.   The sweetness, in combination with the tart bite, becomes a little one-dimensionally intense, though its a nice blend of flavors.   Interesting stuff, though seemingly not for consumption in larger doses.

12 oz bottle. lots of foamy light-brown, though quickly dissipating. alcohol aroma, maybe some (dark) fruit mixed in as well. good amount of carbonation (leaves a foamy tingle on the upper-lip when consumed). Can’t really say what it tastes like; a mixture of dark fruits but is also tart, puckering the mouth in an odd fashion.  Good beer, but not something I’d pay $4 for again. Not a personal favorite.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2008 Poors a dark brown with ruby edges.  Reminds me of a root beer or something of that sort.  Minimal head that doesnt last long at all.  Weakly carbonated and heavy bodied brew.  Very rich caramel flavors along with some cherry fruitiness.  Pretty filling in the mouth and also smooth and somewhat sticky.  Creamy finish with noticeable alcohol--perhaps too much alcohol.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2008 Really good. Strong flavor, rich and sweet .Plenty of complex flavor and aromas This beer should be enjoyed and savoured I only wish I had the fireplace and red leather armchair it deserves.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2008 This rating is for the Cave Aged Quad.  Im putting it here, since i cant find it.  Pours a dark amber body with an off white head.  Cherries, raisins, caramel, a note of wood and smoke, tobacco and a bit chewy.  Etoh is in great balance. A  solid offering i really enjoyed it.

Reg 3P: 3.8

2003 vintage in 2008.  Poured a hazed amber color with an off-white head.  The aroma was of aged malt, caramel and sweet cherry.  The flavor matched with the aroma with notes of caramel and cherry.  Their was less age character in the flavor.  Light tartness.

This beer pours with a nice thick head that sticks around for a while.  This beer is a very dark amber, almost the appearance of a cognac.  I prefer my Belgians sweet and this one is a little bitter for me.  It is also a bit too carbonated and tangy for my personal taste.  This is obviously a great beer, just not one of my personal favorites.

I have this beer in front of me. The immediate sensation of aroma was of kriek cherries, in fact I wouldnt be surprised if some were added to the fermentation. This is a deep and mature beer. One that is a pleasure to the senses. Murky to see through, but a persistent head and a mouthfilling flavour.

I wish I had more of this beer.

Pours a dark red with a 1" light brown head.
High alcohol aroma initially, but became more complex as it warmed in the glass.
Big cherry, malt, and a little smoky flavors were noticed. A great beer.
Brown/ ruby  clear color with moderate head. Sweet aroma of cherries, caramel and malt. Moderately sweet with notes of wood,  plums, walnut and spice. Very nice indeed.
Pours red brown with a thick fluffy head that dissipates quickly. Somewhat boozy of a scent also sweet. Flavor is of sweetness and brown sugar. The cherries are very mild.
Aroma and taste of fruit and alcohol.  The cherry kriek is a nice addtion.  Nice head as well.
I had this beer at a friends house in Atlanta. It was strong in terms of alcohol content, but the taste of cheeries was subtle. Overall very crisp and tasty.

I loved the sound when I popped this beer open....It was like a champagne....but oh so very beer-licious.  You can smell the cherrys, and it makes a wonderful aroma. When poured, the head is full, delicious and really tasty.  It tastes just sweet enough...you can get the cherry taste, but not overwhelmed by it.  The bottle is big, and Ill admit....Im a bit buzzed right now because of it.  That always makes it better.  Im in love.
Bottle.  Poured a hazy brown with a tan head.  Aroma of fruit and alcohol.  Cherry taste was evident but not overwhelming.  The 10% was cruel but overall a good beer.
well balanced nice cherry tone, 10% always a plus, roasted malts also, low head that vanished quickly but coated the glass , a nice finish to the beer would enjoy this one again.
An extremely well balanced beer for 10%. The cherries get a little lost in all that alcohol but still prevail just enough.
A good one, very strong.  10% was noticeable, cherrries was noticeable but not overly so, smooth rounded taste which was quite complex, malts were a treat, nice finish.

Nice creamy, light brown head.  Light malt and bread, with flower, dough, grape, and big cherry.  Big pop when it opned.  Very sweet. This beer was OK.  I expected more of a quad taste, but it seemed a bit thin.  Mostly just cherry.

A clear ruby-mahogany beer with a small brownish head that doesnt last. The aroma is some spice, dark fruit (cherries, obviously), and some alcohol. The flavor is more of the same, with perhaps more emphasis on the cherries and a little sweetness. Some malty roast notes as well. Not a bad beer.

75cl bottle from Willow Bend Liquors (Tampa). Pours a dark, brown-red with one finger white-tan head that recedes slowly and provides lacing on the glass. Smells sweet and malty with notes of coffee and caramel. Flavor is malt, chocolate, caramel, with a slight bitter finish. Cherry lambic comes through more strongly as the beer warms from serving temperature.

Thick, illustrious head, deep brown pour.  Reminds me of the St. Bernardus Abt 12, but with a little more obvious cherry hint to it.  Very complex...a lot happening.  As one previous reviewer said, it hides the alcohol quite well.  Very refreshing for a quad.  Very nice mouthfeel.  Purchased in New York City, enjoyed in Alabama.

Pours a deep dark brown with small but lasting off-white head.  I poured slowly so head could have been thicker.  Aroma is nothing special but pleasant.  Taste is complex and has a nice balance of minor cherry and maybe chocolate and plum.  Many tastes going on here.  It hides the alcohol fairly well.  Im more into lighter bodied styles but this is a nice quad.

First rating ever here.  Picked up a grab bag of single bottles at Total Wine on Namans Rd in DE.  Awesome one to start with.  Rich flavor, beautiful to look at, hint of cherry.  Ill be buying another very soon.

Tried a sample at local homebrew club and again to make sure. 10% was noticeable but only just, cherrries was noticeable but not overly so, smooth rounded taste which was quite complex, malts were a treat, cherries to me were just an added extra.

Talk about a beer that packs a big buzz! 10% this beer set me off to a great night. Pours a cloudy reddish body with aromas of Caramel and oak. Cherries are evident, finishes with cherry flavor. Has a creamy mouthfeel that continues to carbonate in your mouth. and midpalate tastes like bread or biscuits or something similar.

Fantastic smelling beer, aromas of cherries, malt and sugar.  Pours a dark auburn with carbonation youd expect from a beer mixed with lambic.  Well rounded taste with a great tartness of cherry at the end (and Im not a huge fan of cherry).  Very pleasantly surprised with this, recommended.

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2008 Pours a deep ruby brown with a good head that sticks around. Aroma is wonderful - sweet fruits (cherries, grapes) balanced by yeast, light malts and brown sugar. Flavor is great, too - though the sour / bitter notes hit more strongly than in the aroma. The cherries are definitely tart, and the malts taste roastier than they smell. Mouthfeel is great, but it leaves a medicinal aftertaste - like a cherry cough drop - that really started to get irritating about halfway through the glass. Other than that, this is great stuff.

Bottle. [thank you, SecretSanta]
Pours deep mahogany with dark red edges, a big, frothy, off-white head on top. Wonderful duration and nice lacing. Great aroma with good overripe grapes, raisins, plums, very light roasted tones and a lingering cherry tone as well. Medium carbonation, great mouthfeel. Flavour is wonderfully complex, light cherry tartness hits me first, then that fruity yeastiness with some wonderfully balanced chocolate notes in the finish. Surprisingly dry, actually. And the alcohol is not felt at all! Gimme more!

From my review @ cvillebeergeek.blogspot.com.Appearance: Deep, dark reddish brown slightly cloudy pour. Three finger head dissipates fairly quickly and makes a weak effort at lacing, leaving some thin wisps just above the surface of the beer that do not stick around very long. This looks typical for a quadrupel, but uninteresting. 3.0/5.0.

Aroma: The aroma is primarily rich malts... toffee, brown sugar and caramel. The yeast imparts notes of green apple and banana. I THINK I can smell the cherries slightly, but it may be just because Im looking for them. The aroma is rich, pleasant and typical of a quadrupel. 4.0/5.0.

Taste: Much more on the tart side than I expected. Sour cherry and funk from the lambic are definitely showing up. Some toffee and chocolate notes appear at the front and back of the tongue. I feel like the tartness is overpowering the other flavors somewhat, but this is still tasty. 3.5/5.0.

Mouthfeel: There is a slight alcohol warmth, and the beer is pretty tart. It is pleasant, though, and shouldnt scare off those that havent been exposed to the more sour beer styles. 4.0/5.0.

Drinkability: Any 9.8% ABV 750 mL bottle is a big commitment. This is a complex beer... smooth and tart, fruity and malty. It inspires thought, and in that regard I suppose it lives up to its name. 4.0/5.0

Overall: 3.60/5.00. Interesting beer. Pleasant and thought-provoking. Even at only 2%, the kriek makes its presence known. While tart, this is not a beer that will scare off beginners. If its that tart at 2%, imagine a pure kriek! Not the best quadrupel around, but at $6.99 for a 750 mL bottle (at Whole Foods Market... Chris says they/we are the cheapest), you cant beat the price. This one is definitely worth a try.
Unbelievably smooth for 9.8%.  Definite hint of bananas upon a deep whiff and an undertone of cherries throughout the sip.  Finishes a little malty and definitely draws you into another swig.
Beautiful dark brown brew with a fine head, a great Belgian style ale, but the cherry flavor is a bit over the top for me.

pours dark amber with medium head that leaves some lacing.  aroma is cherries and yeast, with a little banana.  very dry and tart flavor.  alcohol is very present, warm as it goes down, pleasant.  this is a good bottle for either a hot summer night or a cold winter night.

Light thin ruby caramel color with a light tan head.  Nose like a tripel lots of spiciness and earthiness.  Taste is strong spices and noticeable alcohol.  The light cherry notes are overpowered by the stinging alcohol finish.  I was unimpressed.

Light reddish carmel color with nice head.  Aroma of dark fruit, light molasses, and lightly roasted malts with a hint of sharp alcohol and, no kidding, a hint of fresh broccoli and sugar snap peas.  Flavor complex with all of above plus some acidic sour, along with bitter hops and a touch of smoke.  Brief, sweet aftertaste morphs into a lingering sour which is a bitter over done.  Is it the cherries?
Poured to give a nice brownish red color with a thick foamy head.  Aroma is malty.  Some hints of cherry and vanilla.  Taste is a subtle cherry sour with a malt sweetness.  Very drinkable quad.

Pours a nice hazy ruby, not much head from the pour. Sweet, brown sugar and dark fruits in the aroma. A lot of nice things going on in the flavor - dark fruits, molasses, spice, and a smokey character that ties it all together. Smooth, very drinkable mouthfeel. Alcohol is very well hidden. Very good beer.

Gorgeous deep, slightly hazy red. Depending on how its poured you get either a nice billowy, off-white head or nothing at all. Scent is subtle, but sweet and caramel-like. Taste is not overly of the kriek lambic, but I found this to be more drinkable than most quadrupels Ive had. A warming alcohol taste is present, but not overpowering. Little bitterness.

I really have to love this beer. Pours reddish amber with huge blooming crown. Fruit, specifically berries and sweet dark fruit present along with thick malt notes in the nose. Taste is initially sweet, but backs off into a wonderful complex of mixed fruit,  spice, sweet bread, a bit of bacon smokiness. So smooth. Really a top notch brew. Bottle purchased at 12 Pine in Pboro.

Pours a dark hazy amber with a huge frothy head and lots of lace. Rich malt aroma with tones of cherry and sour hints. Starts rich and malty with tones of fig. Gives way to a more sour middle with cherry tones, finishes with more cherry and bit of bitterness. A noticeable alcohol presence. Really really good, the finish builds up a bit too much sour and cherry, but still exceptional.

Quads, Ahoy!!!  This is a fine, very spectacular brew.  Its aroma is not as full as would like, but it is fruity with raisins and spicy figs and oak.  Its a bit alcoholic in the nose as well.  Its visual pleasing with a dark crimson color, with a thin foam head.  Its flavor is wild, very complex, but not complicated arrangement.  It takes on a charachter of cognac, with distinct oak flavor.  It also is full of dark fruits, figs, raisins, sweet malt, and some alcohol.  The feel and complexities change in the mouth to a sweet feel, followed by an oak-warming feel.  Their is a vinuousness that lends itself to a wine, but a oak cognac burn that makes everything just come together with unbelievable gusto.

rating #800!!! Bottle frm Daknole. thanks!
Pours a beautiful dark ruby color, with a luxurious huge beige head. Aroma is dark ripe fruit. Its loaded with plums, and figs, and raisins, even some apple, and a touch of smoke, and sweet malt. Flavour is sweet, with notes of raisins, cherries, soft chocolate, and even some vanilla. Leaves a nice sweet aftertatse with hints of cherry. Nice quad!

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2008 Aroma of the flinty gunsmoke you get with pinot grigio. Smoky, fruity and soapy. Beautiful in the glass with delicate off-white  lace on top of mahogany, even though the creamy head diminished to a collar of foam after maybe 3 minutes.. Sweet flavor of chocolate, toast, cherries, white grapes, spicy apples and smoked birchwood. Reminds me of late fall in the midwest. Tangy bit of acidic, fruity pectins on the palate; but just when you think its going to be boozy- its not. Finish is tart for a moment before lingering maltiness prevails. Solid 4.0.

I have been reluctant to try "Belgian Style" brews, mostly sticking to the true Belgian Breweries. This one was very good, smooth. Do not taste the alcohol, the hint of cherries is very subtle. Will have again.
Three Philosophers is my personal favorite of what Ive had from Ommegang. It pours a deep brown/red. Hints of chocolate and cherries. No taste of the alcohol. Very good on a cold winter night.
A very strong beer with a lovely hint of cherry. Discovered it by accident, definitely glad to have tried it.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2008 I simply love this beer, from the frothy head to the deep ruby color to the complex flavors. Ive got a 750 ml bottle laid down in my cellar and will see what its like a few years.
Esta me gusto.  Un poco de fruta pero seria, no como las lambic q empalagan.  Vale la pena creo q bebere

Bottle pours a dark reddish copper color with a thin head.  Aroma of dried fruit, yeast and alcohol.  Very nice flavor!  Slightly sweet, some malt, and more dried fruits, mostly black cherries.  Smooth and drinkable.  The 9.8% is well hidden aside from the aroma.

1/5/08 notes:  12 oz bottle. Pours a dark brown with ruby red.  Definitely dark fruit in the nose.  Medium carbonation, syrupy, velvety mouthfeel.  Slightly bitter body with citrus hints and nice cherry liquor finish.  Coats tongue in wonderful mixture of hoppy bitterness, caramel malts and cherry sweets. Definitely a quality offering.

Bottle. A really luscious beer that is surprisingly good. MuttyD nailed the description on this one! I have seen this beer on the shelves so many times but for some reason have never tried it until now. It is now my favorite brew from Ommegang.
Pours dark caramel with nice foamy head.  Smells almost like a grape vine i.e. really vinous.  But so promising.  It goes down quite smooth and dry tasting like raisins.  Pretty good beer.

Chestnut color, creamy frothy head.  Brown sugar and dark fruit nose.  Roasted malt, dark fruit, oak, nutty and molasses flavor.  Smooth finish.  Highly recommend this one.  One of my favorites to date.

Dark brown/red with off-white head. Scent was dominated by cherry and mild roast, and flavor followed, hints of roast being overpowered by excessive sweet fruit, like synthetic cherry. There were slight metallic hints. The palate was all-star, but thats about it. Given the rating and hype, my experience was an unsatisfying one.

75 cl corked bottle:Pours reddish brown with medium head. Sweet marshmallow aroma with notes of cherry stones and oak. Dry oaky flavour with notes of cherries and alcohol; taste a bit like port. Drinkable but not outstanding.

Bottle - Pours a dark brown with light tan head.  Sweet malty aroma with hints of cherry and chocolate.  A very tasty beer with perfect carbonation and sweet malt flavor. The chocolate and mild cherry flavor really do well together.  This is an outstanding beer and a good value.

Pours hazy dark amber with light tan head. Aroma of yeast with a hint of sour cherries. Initial flavor is malty and finish is sour cherries and a slight metallic taste. Medium body with lively carbonation. OK, but not one I will be seeking to have again.

The pour is a deep reddish brown, with a reasonable tannish head.  The nose is true to all Belgian quads with notes of dark fruit, yeast, some malt, some nutty aromas, but all somewhat washed over by a sour cherry scent.  The flavor is much like a combination of a decent quad mixed with a sour beer.  While this makes for an interesting combination, the sour cherry detracts from what would otherwise be a good quad.
Pretty nice red color. Nice head. A bit sour and  and vinious taste with a bit of cherry in it. Aftertaste is a bit sour with some fruity notes,nothing special here.

The beer pours a hazy brown with a light brown head that is mostly lasting. The sweet nose is laced with hints of nuts dark stone fruit and an underpinning of wood mixed with alcohol. The taste is in line with the nose, tasting of nuts, prunes, plums and alcohol. The finish is a dry mix of hops and malts. Overall a great beer.

Malt and fruit aroma with a reddish-brown color. Slightly fizzy and thin - fairly easy going down. Unlike many Belgian ales Ive tried, there isnt much distinct clove or spice taste; instead, the taste is mostly malty, slightly hoppy - reminds me of a light barleywine due to its bitterness and subtle but obvious alcohol taste. I only taste the slightest hint of cherries, which helps to somewhat balance the bitterness of this brew. A heavy, full-bodied, beer-drinkers beer for sure, but slightly disappointing in its lack of complexity.

Poured darkish dull red-brown with thin, long lasting head.  Aroma is malty with a funky sharpness.  Thick, smooth, well balanced, initially the perception is the the acidity and the spritely carbonation, which yields to a broad malt profile followed by a long bitter finish with some alcohol.

Overall very tastey but not as memorable as some of the best beers in the style.  The cherry flavor comes through and adds a hint of sourness to go with the sweet carmel flavors.  The mouthfeel is smooth but i find it a bit thin.

750ml bottle poured into a tulip glass. Smelled of malts. AS it warmed the aroma only grew into something malty and carmel like. I liked it as it warmed and would drink a round room temperature. Forgot to say that it had a really nice head with good lacing. I would go back here for sure.

750ml bottle from BevMo Mission Valley.  Not quite what I was expecting from this beer, overrated. A murky mahogany pour with a creamy beige head.  Nose was a bit weak, faint cherries, Belgian yeast and booze round out the nose.  Flavor was much of the same.
Nice reddish Brown color and fair head. some Cherry and chocolate hints. Very smooth.

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2009 nose is wet lightly rotting figs and sticky alcohol. appearance is barely transparent rouge. flavor is sticky melting toffee with a light and late alcohol burn. a bit fuesely...the booze really hangs out. spicy caramel is the main pronounced note.  mouthfeel is really sticky and lingering and a bit obtrusive. a solid big and complex beer.
Bottle. Quick pop. Porous head. Dark red-amber. Moderate aromatic cherry notes. Big complex mouth feel and taste. Wood, cherries, alcohol and dry chocolate.

Ive had a bottle cellaring for four months (2007 Vintage) until consumed this past weekend.    An interesting blend of a Quad and Lambic.   I know the label says theres only 2% cherry lambic, but it does an amazing job of smoothing out the Quad and adding a fruity/cherry flavor to the beer.   Excellent full crimson body, strong head and a fusion of yeast and malts.   Ommegang has out did itself in brewing Three Philosophers.

Bottle...Pours reddish brown with a one finger, very dense head. The aroma is not as strong as some other quads, but it was pleasant with some subtle fruit and roasted malt nonetheless. Medium-bodied. Complex flavor with some caramel notes. Very warming with some alcohol present. Nice beer, but there are better quads out there.

Beer pours with a huge creamy head.  Color is an amber brown color.  Aroma of fruit, spice, and malt.  Taste is of fruit, candy, malt, and maybe a little yeast.  Finish is very smooth, with no alcohol detected.  Body is smooth & full.

Interesting beer.  Bottle poured into Grimbergen glass.  Head is decent sized and a creamy white color.  Aroma has some sweet nuances and some alchohol is certainly present on the nose and on the tongue.  The flavor is a bit sweet, but I wouldnt know it was cherries if I hadnt read the bottle.  A big malt flavor is really what sticks out.  A big powerful beer for sure.  Very good.

This beer pours with about a half inch of creamy white head.  It has a deep copper color and a fruity, candy-like aroma.  The flavor is amazing.  I at first notice the typical Belgian ale, syrupy flavor, then I get the alcohol, and finally the tart cherry flavor rounds out the flavor.  The cherry flavor does not tastes fake, which is always good.  The carbonation is about medium with a medium-heavy body.  This and Brooklyn Black Chocolate Stout are my top two.

Color: Clear, deep burnt amber color with black tones. Thin foamy white head with no lacing. 

Nose: Rich and pungent nose of cherries and soft malt. Gorgeous fresh fruit notes. 

Palate: Heavy weight. Big chewy malt, coffee, chocolate and a touch of cherry fruit toward the finish, but overall dominated by the massive malt character.

An outstanding quadrupel thats on par with the best beers from Belgium. It pours a dark reddish brown with a dark and cloudy body. The head builds up to a thick pale tan head that bubbles down to a thinner layer that just covers the body. An inviting aroma of sweet dark cherries, caramel, malts and alcohol leads you to the first sip. Sweet dried cherries mixes with caramel and chocolaty malts, sour cherries, plum and raisins. All of these flavors are surrounded by a warming alcohol that fades off slowly with some bitter notes into the finish. The palate is full bodied, smooth and a little sticky. Overall an extraordinary beer that only gets better and more complex with age.
From a bottle poured a dark amber color with a good amount of head.  Very sweet malty flavor with a lasting finish.
750 ml bottle.  Aroma and flavor are both full of banana-y esters and a touch of alcohol.  Very smooth, really tasty.

Locally this is available in grocery and liquor stores but all samples are bad. Some have hardly any head and all have heavy molasses taste and aroma. Supposed to have cherry lambic, but none discernible. Look me up when in my area and I can make something out of molasses, carbonated water, alcohol and a cherry pit for a lot less money.

Poured a nice ruby color with a decent off white head.  Looked pretty in the glass, but smelled like hell and tasted worse.  Im wondering if I got a bad bottle.  I might have to revisit this.  It was like drinking cherry cough syrup that had been aged in oak.  And this is listed as a Quadrupel?  Not like any other Quad Ive had.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2008 2006 bottle. Pours a murky candy apple red with brownish highlights. Big, fluffy head. Sticky lacing is prominent. Aromas of plum, caramel, licorice, cinnamon, fig, and chocolate. Nice. First touch on the tongue is frothy and smooth. Plum and dark candy, brown sugar, fig, and sweet banana. Dont get a lot of cherries, but the other flavors really make up for it. Very smooth-bodied, and full and savoring. Very enjoyable.
Aroma of fruits soaked in wine. Darker fruit on the palate with a nice zing. Raisins and cherries and port. A full bodied presence. Very good American brew.
Deep amber with thin tan head.  Sweet aroma of caramel, sugar and fruit.  Tastes of sweet sugary malts, caramel and spice.  Dry, slightly bitter finish.
Deep ale brown with a small dense light tan head, tons of lacing. Nose is strong Belgian spices, malts and yeast. Attack is spicy with dark sweet fruits and long clean bitter finish. very nice.

*did not like would not buy*

aroma: sugar candy fake fruit booze. ok.  app: ruby good lookin! flavor: trash ox a moxie dized funk.. sweet fruit.. sharp booze.. its not good.. not bad bad, just not good. palate fine. OA: coulda maybe been ok, get the funk out and come back to the game.

Reddish brownish, fluffy had that dissipates. Nose is tart and fruity, candy and raisins. Very interesting. This is quite drinkable with tons of dried fruits, yeast and complex sugars in the taste. Tartness is definitely there. A pretty nice beer, even if its more of a sour than an abt...

2007 Bottle. Pours a reddish brown med a beige head. Aroma is dried fruits, plums and some mature notes of madeira. Flavour has a nice sweetness and some tartness. A malty beer with notes of dried fruits, toffee (and the swedish candy kola-remmar) and some roasted notes. You can feel the high ABV just a bit. The finish is a bit roasted with fruity notes, some liquorice, some alcohol and just a hint of bitterness. Good one!

Blind at Dugges 080329. Hazy light red colour, light tan head, a bit low. Sweet aroma with strawberries (ed. perhaps that actually was the cherries from the Lindemans). Malty and fruity. Very bitter and high acidity. High alcohol taste.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2009 Pours a syrupy mahogany color topped with a nice creamy tan head. Subtle hints of cherry in a malty tangy aroma. A tangy mouthfeel. Rich flavors consisting of malts, brown sugar and cherries.  Sweet with an alcoholic rush. Bottle states that this is "98% Ale with 2% Ale with cherries added" so I was concerned about a dominant cherry flavor. That was not the case as it blended in quite well. The beer is more enjoyable the more you get through the bottle. Great head retention.  Solid.
Pours well with a nice frothy head. The aroma was lacking a bit. Its a smooth drink with a small hint in the aftertaste of cherries. I was expecting just something more in the flavor.

Ommegang Three Philosophers Belgian Style Blend 2007
ABV: 9.8%
Calories: estimated at 200 C
Volume: 12 fl oz
Glass: flute
Purchased at: Circle Liquors, Pennington
Price per fl oz: $3.50 / 12 fl oz = $0.29 per fl oz
Consumed at: home

sensory first impression: Banana Belgian aroma - intoxicating. ruby, tan head with sediment. Beautiful beer. Lots of carbonation, active beer. Nice head, attractive lacing. Frothy, cherry laced creamy texture and flavor. Complex visual appearance, with a wide range of warm hues. It may be the perfect exemplar of this style. Refined - not overwhelming like many others, and not thin or holding back like more common Belgian styles, like Hoegaarden, which is delicious, but not complex.

Aroma/Olfactory: 10 out of 10
Malt flavor is: oats, cheerios, cherries
Hop flavor is: floral, citrus, pepper
Yeast flavor is: quick bread, coated, thick
Other flavors include: alcohol, banana, cherry, pear, raisin, oats

Visuals/Appearance: 5 out of 5
Color is: bright, amber to orange to red to brown, fiery, ruby
Liquid is: clear, sparkling, immaculate
Head and lace are: minimal, off white

Taste/Flavor: 9 out of 10
Maltiness or Sweetness level is: medium
Hoppiness or Bitterness level is: medium to heavy
Sour level is: heavy

Palate/Tactile: 4 out of 5
Body or Mouthfeel is: medium to full
Texture is: creamy, sticky, papery
Carbonation is: fizzy, lively
Finish is: sweet and long

Overall experience: 18 out of 20. I liked the fruity background and foreground, the bite of bitterness, and the sweet depth. I did not like the price, but it was worth it.

12oz bottle, pours red/brown with off-white creamy head, which mostly dissipates and leaves no lacing.  Aroma is nice, with heavy malt, moderate dark fruit, and cherries.  Flavor very sweet and mildly acidic, with very dry finish.  Im not wild about the cherry lambic flavor, I was expecting a classic Abt/Quadrupel, but the dry cherry flavor throws me a bit.  Not has happy with it as I thought I would be, considering the rating.

Pours a dark, dark red with a fairly good yellow head. Smells of smoked cherries and yeast, comparable to a suttle brandy. It tastes of as a strong abbey ale but with an added sweetness. It was a little much for me. I think it would be very enjoyable as the first beer you have on a really cold night.

Pours brown with a small cream colored head.  Aroma is malty, slightly spicy and a little yeasty.  Taste is a nice extremely malty taste with a little bit of toffee aftertaste.  Dont really taste cherries that much, but that doesnt really bother me.  Great beer.
Its a very good beer, but it would be better if the cherry sweetness was a bit less prominent. Otherwise, its extremely full-flavored and well balanced. The flavor stays with it for a while.

Bomber.  Slightly hazy medium brown with a dense head.  Toasty fruit/nut aroma.  Caramel malt and raisin flavor.  I was expecting more cherry, its hidden in there.  Some bitterness and spice on the end.  Fantastic beer.

Pours a medium brown with a big creamy tan head that lasts.  Nice lacing forms on the glass.  Hefty dark fruit aromas, most notable cherry.  Some spiciness as well, and lots of brown sugar sweetness.  First taste is a bit shocking, but it mellows over time.  Lots of sweet fruitiness, with a hint of alcohol on the finish.  Really really really good.
Dry and bready.  Lots of yeasty esters.  Cinnamon, black pepper.  Some hidden cherry flavor, but really overwhelmed by the malt and yeast.

Looks great, and smells even better, this gets perfects there.  The taste is strong and good, but its too much to really get into.  Good for a taste but the whole bottle is alot to tackle.  You do get alot of bang for the buck, so that boosts the overall.

Pours tea-brown with a large tan head.  Aroma is great, cherries, citrus, alcohol, baking bread, anf faint all-spice in the bouquet.  Flavor starts bready, quickly moving through a woody section, cherries, hop "pepper", alcohol note, and a lingering, rye bread-like finish.  Very nice.

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2008 Bottle (75 cl) from Systembolaget. Hazy ruby with medium creamy yellow/beige head. Dark fruits, burnt sugar, cherries and wood in the aroma. Medium bodied and very smooth mouthfeel. Good balance, perhaps just a bit too sweet.

Bottled, 2007. Poured clear brown with ruby highlights and a tan, foamy head. Nose was cherries, yeast, and malt. Flavor was sweet malt, cherry pits, wood, soft alcohol notes. Finish was dry and nicely bitter with a finely carbonated mouthfeel.

I love this beer.  At this moment, this is my favorite beer.  Brewery Ommegang has won my heart.  I buy this at the grociery store down the street from me in the corked bottle.  It pours a very dark amber, with a scent of black cherries, and other glorious fruitiness.  The flavor of this beer hits you as soon as it enters your mouth and hangs around long after it has left.  Almost perfectly smooth.  Anytime I have friends over I share some of this with them and they are immediately overcome with the greatness of this beer.

Bottle from Total Wine, -poured into a Chimay glass. 
Handsome looking beer with a nice burnt amber color. Smallish white head. Interesting beer, the palate on this is light cause it has quite a bit of carbonation, yet that makes it more drinkable than the 9.8% would indicate. Some of the complexity of it is lost due to the carbonation though, but as it warms you get some raisin and cherries the cherry comes through more than is typical but thats to be expected because of the cherry infusion. There is a cool smoke note on the end almost like it was aged complemeted by vanilla and more cherry a tiny bit of sour funk comes through also, very welcome. A little bit of bitterness but not alot considering its an American belgian. Very classy brew from Ommegang.

bottle to glass. dark red and cloudy, the smell of berries and fruit. some sticky lacy head. immediate hit of sweetness and cherries. not as sweet as some, but sweeter than others. for the alcohol content, very little burn. ends smoky and woody with a little herbiness, but just barely a bit of bitterness. good stuff, not really re-drinkable.

Pours cloudy amber-orange with a one-finger white head. Yeasty, earthy, lightly oxidized aroma (bottle is from 2007, so I think its intentional). Faint tart cherry and alcohol. Theres a flavor somewhere past all that carbonation. Its raisiny, musty, and somewhat funky. More Bernardus than Rochefort, by which I mean more size than fruity complexity. Good, but nowhere near as delicious as the best Abts. I have some 2004 bottles that are begging to be cracked, so well see how its aged.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2009 750 ml bottle from Systembolaget, shared with a friend. Complex, vinous aroma with a lot of fruitiness. Flavour is pretty much the same. Quite sweet with a light acid note from the kriek, which makes tis very special. Ommegang seems to have catched the belgian taste (from two belgian styles) here, in a very good way. Palate is great, very smooth and nice. Very nice abt, one of the better ones Ive tasted and it carries the alcohol very well. Balanced! Reminds me a bit about Chimay Blue. To bad I doesn’t have a bottle to store.

Pours an amber color with a thick white head that thins out fast, but maintains a small head. The smell is of german yeast and bitter hops. As you take a sip the initial flavor is really earthy and nutty like almond and sweet caramel. You can really taste the belgin yeast and that barnyard funk that comes with it. The finish is smooth and full of caramel malt with other rich flavors and hop bitterness.
2007 bottle. Opaque red pour with a thick yellow head. Tons of fruit on the nose and a little alcohol. Lots of dark fruit, cherry, and a woody aftertaste. Hides its alcohol really well. Good beer.

Bottle - pours a ruddy copper with a lightly off white head that quickly dissolves into a light slim of bubbles with some lively carbonation visible.  Aroma is spicy and tart with yeasty phenols, alcohol and cherry & apple.  Flavor is initially sweet & malty then the yeasty spice and lambic character w/ cherries, raisins, cedar/woody notes and tart flavors become present.  Finishes with  a faint alcohol that becomes stronger as the glass warms with a dry, spritzy finale.
Bottle, 75cl. Reddish brown colour with a beige head. Sweetish aroma with notes of wood, yeast, candy, cherries & apples. Malty, caramelly sweet taste with slightly sourish notes.

The liquor store close to the house here just recently picked this one up so I had to give it a shot. 


Pours a beautiful coppery reddish color with a very persistent light cream colored head.  


Aroma is of sweet dark fruit and booze soaked cherries.  A bit of a boozy aroma here. 


Way too much carbonation in the mouthfeel of this one.  Taste is of booze, some cherries, some dark fruit, and maybe a little oak or something kind of woody.  


Not a favorite after having this.  It was just OK.
Drank it with Juanco at Hop Devil Grill in NYC.  Wow.  Really enjoyed it.  Spicey, raisiny,in your mouth flavors.  Complex, well balanced and warming.

I really could drink this by the pint which is way crazy, but it is all too easy to let them slide with this one. The nose is full of blood and faint cherry. The palate is tart and bubbly with a hint of chocolate. Good concealment of alcohol too.

Bottle. BB 1 june 2010. Reddish brown color. Somewhat closed aroma of raisins, dates, rye, tobacco, strawberry, some yeast and phenolics. Hints of bitter chocolate and sour cherries. Also a hint of oak. Soft, pearly and silky mouthfeel. Effervescent. Slightly sour and with a definitive yeast bite. Together with a piece of chocolate the beer feels fresher and fruitier and the bitterness fades. This one will benefit from aging.

750 ml corked bottle. Mostely lasting, medium-sized dense beige head. Ruby brown color. Aroma of fruits, mainly cherries, along with caramel, butterscotch, cookies and yeast. Medium sweet and malty taste. Lot of fruitiness, raisins, plums and cherries. Notes of chocolate, wood, burnt sugar and  alcohol. Well-bodied. Thick  mouthfeel. Malts and lingering bitterness in the finish. Excellent.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2009 Bottle. Cloudy red-brown, big head, takes a while to dissipate. Gorgeous beer. Aroma isa bit of molasses, dark fruit (cherries), some alcohol. Dry body, flavor has prominent cherry and dark malt with a sweet finish, a bit dry. Hint of alcohol burn. Lively carbonation, full bodied, bit creamy.
A dark brown ale that has a foamy head.  Smells nice, hard to pinpoint one strong scent.  Tastes nice--cherry and fruit.  Strong alcohol after taste.

Bottled.
Very complex. A ghost of a kriek playing in the background of an ale. Sweet and sour, lots of fruit.
Id love some bottles of this stacked away!

Brown/Red pour with a decent size head.  Aroma is very complex...toffee, cherry, syrupy berries, and a certain earthiness.

Taste was as complex as the aroma, with chocolate and (maybe) dates coming through.  Felt thick on the palate and it lingered, despite the sharp carbonation that become more apparent as you progress through the glass.

Somewhere between the taste and the aftertaste, the alcohol becomes overly apparent, which does take away from the overall drink.

2007 bottling. cloudy apple color with a nice head. the smells jump out at you, cherries, fruit, bubblegum. malty flavor i didnt expect and not as noticable cherry as i did expect. taste of the alcohol at the finish. first belgian ive really sat and rated, so I wasnt sure what to expect. definitely want to try more.
Trappist glass.  Aroma of toffee, raisins, cherry and yeast.  Very complex flavor notes of chocolate, dried fruits, and bread.  Has a noticeable vineous quality .  An excellent beer.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2008 12 oz. Clear, dark copper-brown with a creamy and lasting medium-sized head. Aroma is bananas, earthy-spiced clove, and cherry bubblegum. Flavor is at first clovey-bubblegum; then turning to apple-grape wine; and then to a dominating cherry-raisin bread and alcohol. Medium body is dryish and flares up with carbonation. Good beer, but none too complex; body problem and all-too-evident alcohol are a bit much to call this one remarkable.
Pours a deep burgundy color with a full lacing head. With a sweet fruity aroma. Very smooth sweet flavor with hints of cherry.

The neck label indicated a 2007 bottling date, and the pouring instructions on the side of the label were helpful.  It didnt take much vigor to create a luxurious head as suggested there.  The body was deep red and brown, and the head was quite stable and frothy.  Quite a bit of lace formed each time the glass was tilted.  The smell was floral sweet with a ton of dark fruit character showing through as well.  The taste wavered between sweet and dry and finished spicy.  The blended nature of the beer was apparent in a mellow smoothness that muted some of the edgier and earthier tones found typically in Quadrupels.  The alcohol was more of a factor in the taste than I initially expected it to be, and the warmth was quite noticeable after each sip.  This was a well built Quadrupel with a lot of good facets.  None of the qualities was really best in class, but the sum was greater than the parts, as it was a nice cohesive whole.

2006 bottling. Garnet/red color with a rich, foamy head, nice lacing. Good smell of bready malts, spices, and pit fruits. Chewy mouthfeel. Good flavors of cherries, plums and caramel malts with some cellar funk. One of my favorites from Ommegang.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Bottle at Abbey Brewing Company, Miami Beach. Amber color, small white head. Quite discreet malty aroma weith some spicy notes. Fruity malty flavor, spicy after a while and with some figs and hops.

This beer is awesome. I had a very large 24 oz. bottle, and it poured a dark color with a very large and dark head. Aroma is somewhat tart and tastes of cherries. Palate is very smooth and fills your mouth. The taste can be overpowering and I would not recommend drinking the entire 24 oz. bottle by yourself but nevertheless a great drink to be enjoyed especially in the winter.
Hazy brown color, medium head. Sweet yeasty bready malts, a bit of ripe fruit, and some alcohol spiciness. Medium palate. A bit syrupy. Seems pretty well made.

Pours a cloudy amber/copper brown with a thin layer of tan head. Aroma is of malts, caramel and cherry. Taste is light malts and caramel (just hints b/c it does not have large amounts of caramel sweetness)...more tartness to counter the sweetness. Tartness is of fruit, seemingly cherry as it is more tart than sweet. Alcohol presence is perceived to be light...well incorporated because obviously the alcohol content isnt too light. A pretty good quadruple.
Bottle. Thin head deep bronze colour. Slight cherry nose. Mild taste, very belgian, only vague hints of cherry. Carries the alcohol extremely well.

Bottle. Rich maplewood color with a mild haze and some small floating particles. Pours with a big, soapy head the slowly works its way down to a nice layer that sits on the beer the whole way down. Smells of candied apples, cherries, smoke, and maybe even a little beef. The taste is more mild than the nose and leans toward the fruit/malt side. When sipped slowly as it should be, the taste is quite refreshing and the alcohol completely masked. Bigger swigs definitely show the burn. Very sticky finish, as to be expected with a beer this fruity. Good stuff, and way too smooth and cheap to be 10% alcohol.

The pour brought forth a rich mahogany liquid with an off-white head that dropped fairly quickly. The aroma of cherries was at the forefront along with some other dark fruits and sweet malt. The dark cherry flavor comes out initially, followed by the rich, sweet malt backbone of a Belgian dark ale. It was slightly tart, and somewhat astringent. The 9.8% ABV can be faintly detected in both the aroma and taste.

Bottle, 75cl corked, from trade with the_epeeist. It poured an amber-orange, hazy body under a nice, dense beige head. Cellary start on the aroma, with fruityness, some yeast, a quite heavy malt aroma and a sugary touch. Sugary, malty and fruity flavor with a hint of cellar and yeast, as well as some beef-stock from the malt. Full, sticky body. The finish was long, sugary and malty, and had some hops to give bitterness as well. A really nice beer that grows as you enjoy it. (071228)

Bottle.  Pour is a dark brown body with a very large tan head.  Aromas are fruity (maybe my mind is playing tricks, but I think I can pick up a hint of cherry), raisins, toffee and brown sugar with a touch of cloves.  Flavor starts out fine enough... sweet brown sugar malt with a bit of yeast and some dates, but then heads a little to the sour cherry side of things and ends with a little bit of alcoholic dryness that seems a little unseemly and, to some extent, destroys the plot development leading up to it.  Strangely, it seems like Im pulling a different experience out of this one with each sip, and while some of them are pleasant, some are trainwrecks where the alcohol gets in the way.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle. Pours cloudy brown with a beige head. Aroma is rich fruity malt and yeast with notes of cherry and a hint of alcohol. Medium body. Flavor is dark fruit and raisin with a bit of yeast, dried cherry, and again a hint of alcohol which doesnt really detract from the flavor. Very tasty, very enjoyable.

2007 bottle.  Really needs to warm up to be a decent beer.  Pours an opaque reddish brown with a creamy tan head.  The nose is dusty and flat at first.  Maybe a little woody toast?  Over time some lovely cherry begins to open up, but Its very subtle.  Sweetness develops a little bit, but the malt is very dry for the style.  Low carbonation.  Not super thick, not super watery.  Substantial, but not crazy.  It works.  Sweeter than the nose suggested, but very restrained.  Big toast.  Maybe even oak?  Im just not 100% sure.  The cherry is fairly obvious, but the sweetness is so light that this comes across sharper and toastier than I think is best for this beer.  The alcohol is well hidden.  The finish is where the alcohol pops out a bit over the toasty malt.  A bit of acidity.  I wish there was a more supple malt backbone to hold this beer upright!

Pours an amber brown color with no head. Aroma of rich malt with cherries and alcohol. Flavor of cherries with rich malt and alcohol, sweet and rich, I like that ! Light to medium body, oily texture, lively carbonation. Very good !

I dont know about this.  I felt it was kind of sticky and cloying.  At times it was delicious, at times the cherry was too much.  I dont know, but as of right now I have no intentions on trying this in the near future.

Bottle:  Poured a very thick looking dark brown.  No head.  Aroma is sweet alcohol.  Taste is not really what I expected.  I was thinking this was going to be more sickly sweet than it actually is.  Cold winter day sipper.
Smell is dark cherry and apple.  Thought it would be sweet but it had a nice mellow taste... not to over the top

Ruby red color, light head. Nice lacing. Aroma of light apples, sweet cherries. Expected it to be syrupy, not the case. Well carbonated, alcohol and candy finish. Flavor of light fruits, dry cherries. Good quad.
Bottle: Not a bad Quad.  Pours yellow with a fairly large head.  Aroma of fruits (apple, etc).  However, flavor is not all that fruity.  Flavor of alcohol and a little fruit.

Draft at Maxs.  Deep red-brown color.  Real intense fruity aroma - hints of apple and cherry.  Very fruity with cherry and raisins and maple syrup.  Bitter alcohol on the finish.  Nice, but a bit too syrupy for me.
750ml Bottle. Beautiful pour with a reddish body. A nice sweet aroma. Distinctive flavor of cherry with a smooth finish. A great beer.
750 ml, pours nice mahogany reddish color with light tan head, cherry definitely comes through with dried fruit finish, very nice, would like to see this cellared

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2008 750 ml bottle. Hazy orange/reddish body with a small beige head. Aroma like sweet syrup and yeast. Flavor is also rather sweet, with fruity cherry notes and a bit dry fruit. Alcohol and candy finish. Interesting but not exactly where it should be.

750ml.  Pour is dark brown which turns to medium brown under heavy light.  Big brown head that dissipates leaving lacing on the glass.  Nose is cherries, sugars, and hops.  Nicely bubbled brew which stings and tingles the tongue.
tap, mahogany with small persistent head. Port, funk, apricots, cherry, prunes,truffles--a lot going on. Nice after dinner sipper.  Well done!

dark cherry red, sweet molasses aroma. hoppy cherry flavo, rich creamy head, longlasting complex flavor with smooth finish. this is my staple beer, after a long had day, this is the way to relax!! simply awesome.
Bottle. Brown / orange colour with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, alcohol, hop. Flavour is hop, sweet, alcohol, licorice, yeast, fruit, roasted, malt. Very nice beer.

12oz bottle. Pours brown/red with a moderate sized off-white head. Good retention, some lace. Smells of cherry syrup and some malt. Tastes sickly cherry sweet and malty. Medium body, crisp carbonation. I dont like it.

750ml bottle, 2005 vintage. Pours a deep, rich mahogony color. Topped with velvety tan foam. Thick drapey lacing. The aroma starts off dry, tangy, and slightly funky with sour cherry and an oak like acidity and oxidation. Honey and brown sugar sweetness balances things out. The flavors have really melded together pretty well over time. Starts off with sour cherry, brown sugar, and spicy yeast. Earthy, oaky tannins, sweet cherry pie filling, and butterscotch on the back end of the palate. Soft and bubbly feel, although it does become a bit grating carbonation wise after a bit. Overall, there has been some nice aging and oxidation going on, bringing forth a nice sourness and acidity that gives a touch of wild without being puckery. The big malty quad backbone reigns in the acidity as well.
Big corked bottle....hearty brownish-reddish color.  You can read all the other comments, but just drink this !  It is one awesome brew.

12 oz bottle...Dark brown w/ a slight red tint. Very slight head...smells of dark fruits, yeast, and some alcohol. Packed full of flavor...I was able to taste some chocolate, bread, a bit of cherry, and malt. This brew has a nice complexity to it. Mouthfeel was a little bitter, fairly carbonated, and quite dry. Different, but great.
12 ounce bottle purchased at Total Wine Fort Lauderdale, FL for $2.99 Excellent!

Bottle.  hazy brown beer with a light brown head. The aroma is sweet with notes of nuts, prunes, alcohol, and wood. The flavor is dry woody with notes of prunes and plums before a very hoppy and malt dry end sets in. A wonderful flavor.

A unique beer.  A bit cherry aroma, but light.  Dark reddish brown pour with small head.  The taste is unique, a tasty ale with a touch of sourness from the lambic but not overpowering. Its quite drinkable and unique, like a mild lambic.  A little too fizzy/colaish for my taste.

One of my favorite beers, and most certainly one I purchase often.  The appearance is that of a deep brown with a notably red color.  The head is a nice ruddy white.  The aromas come off as cheery and  a bit of hops.  As the beer is sipped, it goes down with a bit of carbonation.  I note the wonderful complexity of cherry and vanilla flavors, with a nice hoppy taste, and a SLIGHT bitter finish.  One should note that to pour this beer, there is a sediment at the bottom that can get mixed in and causes a not so pleasant flavor if mixed.

A dark reddish brown with a thick and lasting head.  Nose of sweet and sour cherries with spices and yeast.  A delicious malt base with just a hint of cherries.  Some vanilla and spice with a very mild bitterness at the end.  A milky thickness that makes this a very enjoyable beer for how freaking cold and windy it is outside.
Hazy orange with a nice white head. Lots of fruity, malty notes. Berries, malt, hops and some chocolate taste. full body with a warming, bittersweet finish.

Bottle at 3-små rum Göteborg: Hazy red colour, with a nice head. Aroma of citrus,caramel,dark Chocolate,alcy, and a citric yeasty nose. Flavor almost the same, medium to full body, and a nice medium fruity finish.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a dark ruby brown.  Aroma:  Complex, but the cherry notes definitely come through.  Flavor:  Cherry, chocolate, and prunes.  On a side note:  Last year I paired this beer with an Ashton VSG cigar, and it was freakin fantastic.

Bottled at 3 små rum.
Ruby red with a small head.
Light fruitiness in the aroma.. Malty with hints oc cocoa aswell.
Soft and smooth palate with fruity notes and hints of bitter-almond/cherry-seeds.
Warming alco-feel.

Poured into Ommegangs beautiful 10th anniversary glass. Body is UPS truck brown, with 2 fingers of dark tan head. Lacing abounds as the head recedes into a thin cap.

Quite a complex aroma, with a nice strong maltiness and very evident kriek influence. Standard quadrupel notes of dark fruits like raisin and prune.

The kriek manifests as a very dark black cherry flavor with a little bitterness to it. Again, the other 98% of the beer is quadrupel, so you get the standard raisin, prune, plum, dark strong malt, currant, and chocolate notes.

Smooth mouthfeel, good carbonation. Rich and luxurious body. Not a lot of booziness despite the high alcohol. Very easy to drink.

faint whiffs of dusty wood and ripe cherries. ruby red/brown, weak fluffy head settled to a creamy thin covering. dusty, even gritty texture, really captures the old abbey style. cherry notes are an welcome delicate accent and the consistent head mellows the edges.
Reddish brown body with thin white head.  Lots of malt with a bit of cherry. There is a bubblegum taste that fades into a lot of cherry and that bit of roasted malt.

Bottled. 3 Små Rum, Göteborg. 
Dark copper colour with good head retention. Rich, malty aroma with a nice blend of almond paste, alcohol, bit of toast and cocoa. Cherries are not noticed at this stage. Soft, yet lively mouthfeel with cherry stone, red berries, and bit of chocolate - the latter most prominent in the finish. Alcohol is sensed, but here it carries the flavours nicely, and contributes without being edgy or bitter. Great beer!

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2014 First samples(Big bottle shared at 3 Små Rum Göteborg on January 18, 2008. Second sample the day after in Bishops Arms, Örebro. Also shared big bottle) Clear copper color, white head. Sweet and spicy scent. Also some metal. Smooth light sweet and a tad smoke taste. Smooth mouthfeel, medium bitterness. Some cherry pips taste also.7/3/7/4/15=3.6Third rating(At a blind tasting)Shady reddish color, tan head. Sweet, vinous, alcohol, dried fruits, chocolate, almond paste scent. Phenolic, sweet. alcohol taste. Smooth mouthfeel. Phenolic and roasted aftertaste.8/4/7/4/15=3.8RerateShared bottle at Haket on November 13, 2010, during SÖ 25 year anniversaryHazy brown color, tan head. Sweet, apple, malty, slight bit acidic scent. Sweet, acidic, apple taste. Medium mouthfeel, low bitterness.7/3/7/3/13=3.3RerateBottle to end the mead tasting on November 2, 2012.Thanks to Nisse666!Marked 2009Hazy copper color, tan head. Sweet, scottish butter fudge (knäck) scent. Mineral, sweet taste. Spritzy mouthfeel, low bitterness.9/3/7/3/15=3.7RerateSampled draught as part of a flight at Palm Harbor House of Beers, on January 21, 2014.Clear dark brown color, white head. Sweet, berry, alcohol taste. Fizzy mouthfeel, low bitterness. Alcohol aftertaste. Sweet, spicy scent.7/4/6/3/12=3.2

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2009 750 mL bottle. Pours a dark brown body with decent head. I cannot really comment that much in depth about the taste or aroma because I was not sober enough to form a good opinion. Need to try this one again when more sober.

pours a really dark ruby brown with a finger or two of  light beige head.  Strong odor of plum and molasses.  Very light mouthfeel, starts off with a bit of a malty sweetness, which ends with a bit of a burnt toast aftertaste.  A good, smooth addition to the Quad family.

Wow! My first good beer! Great flowery/peachy aroma. It looks gorgeous- very red in color and perfect for a Quad. Flavor is fantastic- I hate beers that are overpowering with hops so this is just right for me. Very fruity, malty flavor. Smooth on the palate, overall a very tasty beer!!
The Ommegang beers represent a few major holes in my ratings list, as they are top quality and readily available.  Ive had this before and it is another predictably excellent Ommegang offering.
bottle. I found this beer to taste better as it warmed. It has a bitter sweet taste and it smells great. this isnt a beer your going to be able to drink a lot of but its very nice!

bottle. pours a very attractive reddish-brown color with a copper head. smells sweet and kind of like cough syrup. first sip is rather sweet and syrupy too. I think it was a bit too cold when I first poured it so i let it warm up some. after warming considerably it is much more palatable. Nice and smooth with little interference from the 9.8% alcohol content.  The cherry is definitely there in the flavor but it doesnt hit you over the head. Well made and definitely enjoyed.

Smells metallic (eric says like a nickel). The bottle is fresh, as I bought it as part of the Ommegang  10th Anniv. Gift pack. The medicinal cherry is right up front. I wish I could give ommegang a pass but this stuff sucks.  Maybe the new guy can do better.
75 cl bottle, at Yngwie´s xmas-tasting. Hazy brown color, big beige head. Sweet with yeast, fruit, hops and roasted malt.

Bottle. Nose is lots of cherry and oak. Deep ruby color. Flavor lets you know that its been mixes with a kriek but doesnt pick up any of the acidity which works well with all the malt sweetness. Smooth and drinkable. Great beer.

750ml 2007 bottle.  They say to serve at 50 degrees, I think its better even warmer as the head and mouthfeel especially really improve as the temp goes up.  I like this brew a lot, this is my 3rd (1 06 & 2 07s) and the price is right too @ $6.50.  A wonderful blend of all the Belgian Quad yeasty, fruity, malty goodness with a touch of cherries that is most certainly noticeable but not overbearing or overpowering in any way.  The aroma is a little subdued but the flavor is quite intense.  The body gets more and more rich, full, and creamy as times goes on as this last glass Im having now is the cream of the crop.  The alcohol is hidden well vs. most other 10% beers, but its impact is most certainly felt!  Havent met an Ommegang brew I didnt love.

12oz bottle at Annie Baileys Irish Pub, Lancaster, PA...poured cloudy reddish-brown...easy pour so not much head to speak of...smell is mild of malts and cherries...flavor is only slightly sweet, malts, hints of cherry, bit of an alcohol burn in the swallow...I like that the cherry was not overpowering...very good.
Smells of cherries, a little bit like cough syrup. Dark golden color. Tastes of cherries and a little bit like cough syrup. Neither overpowers the other.  Wonderful palate. Little bit syrupy.

Pours a hazy deep crimson with modest head that dissipates quickly.

Malt and cherries to the nose.

Taste is complex, seems every taste brings a little something different out. All smooth, initial taste brings plums, raisins and dates to mind. Subsequent tastes show more of the malt and cherry. The cherry never is overpowering.

Fairly full-bodied and well carbonated, a marvelous brew.

So drinkable, the alcohol is well hidden; except for the buzz. One 750ml and Im not driving a firetruck anywhere.

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2008 Purchased at Bodega Bewpub in la Crosse, Wisconsin.  Poured an amber color with a short white head.  Aroma and taste of cherries and more light fruit.  Flavor was not so much cherries but more malt, some caramel, light hops, and sweet alcohol.  Well balanced beer.  Would buy again.
Very tasty fruity tasting beer. I would most definitely buy this one again. Very good
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: I liked this one a lot. Pours a very dark red color with a thick tan head. I dont really get the cherries though. I was hoping I would. Anyway, great malty taste, I taste a little cinnamon. nice job ommegang.
Wow filled with cherries!!! Strong bite and looks great. Tastes very fruity, but good!
Strong malt aroma with a light amount of fruit. Hazy amber color with a large tan head. Light fruit malt start with a moderate to mild alcohol burn in the finish. Light bodied.

Bottle.  Coopers- Chicago.  Copper bown, cloudy.  Fluffy head with persistent lacing.  Nice "quad" taste upfront, sweet raisins.  But not sure what was with mine but the carbonation was overwhelming.  Also the aroma was more of a tripel than a quad.  Slight taste of sour apple, cinnamon, sour berries.  Didnt detect the cherry flavor all that much.  Body thinned out as it warmed.  Overcarbonation and lack of anything that stood out (other than the $8.50 per bottle that I paid) leads me to just an average rating for this one.

(750 ml bottle (2006) from <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/massachusetts/w target=blank>Julios Liquors, cellared for 1 year after purchase) Pours dark rusty amberish brown with a finger or so of tan head. A good looking beer. Aroma of red wine, yeast, brown sugar, dark fruits and port. Mouthfeel quite soft and smooth, lightly sticky. Nice fine rings of lacing. Flavor is medium-light brown sugary maltiness with hints of red wine, port and yeast. Light note of lightly sour-tart cherry emerges towards finish. Very lightly hot but alcohol is pretty well-covered. All in all a very pleasant-tasting, excellent beer.

Bottled
Dark opaque muddy brown color, small brownish head. Dry oaky, cherry fruity aroma. Medium to full bodied. Caramelly (toffee) with fruits added - cherries tip to rhum ... Alcoholic warming in the aftertaste with bitterness. Very unique beer which is challenging to describe.

Bottled (thanks jjpm74!). Deep rubyish brown colourwith mediumsized beige head. Lacing. Aroma is cherries, alcohol, some malts and mild raisins. Flavour is alcohol, cherries, wood, some yeast and raisins. Also some bready notes. A quite pleasant brew, where the alcohol burns nicely in the aftertaste.

Aroma: Cherry is the first scent to greet the nose. Then come chocolate, prune, and vanilla. The alcohol is apparent but not overpowering. Purple raisin yet green grape scents. Lighter and more floral than the classic, port-like quad aroma. Reminiscent of brandy or sherry. A chalky dry smell develops later. Complex, intriguing, and appetizing aroma. Yeast and cherry scents are the ones that linger upon sipping.

Appearance: Pours a hazy, medium brown with a red hue. Almost burgundy or maroon in color. Many tiny bubbles race to the surface from the bottom. Moderate to large amount of beige head with a tight arrangement of small bubbles. Produces a modicum of lacing.

Flavor: Grainy flavor; you can really taste the barley! Vegetal (broccoli, asparagus, avocado) and earthy. Baked or dried apple flavor. A pleasant, sharp, almost vinegar-sour bitterness in the finish. As is the case in the aroma, the alcohol is noticeable, but it is not unpleasant. Surprisingly subtle taste but in a sophisticated rather than a boring way.
