Palate: Lingering dry and cherry-flavored aftertaste. Light to medium body, much lighter than I expected. Soft, smooth, and borderline oily in the palate.

Overall: Brewed in 2006. Poured from a 25.4 oz. bottle. Three Philosophers reminds me of a Cabernet Sauvignon wine, as it is fruity, meaty, and hearty with a dry finish. It is just what I needed after tasting several disappointing, lackluster beers in the last few days. I was close to giving it a 9 for flavor, and this is a balanced, complex, and solid beer across the board, so Ill give it an impressive 17 overall score.

750 ml bottle, 2007 vintage.  Pours dark brown with a two-inch beige head which lingered to create great lacing.  Aroma is yeast, alcohol and wine-like fruit.  Flavor is Belgian with fruit, including cherries and yeast.  Alcohol is well hidden in the taste.  Mouthfeel is medium-to-thick and creamy with carbonation apparent.

The best of the Ommegang brews I have had. Available in North Carolina. Nutty, malty, and at the bottom, yeasty. Occasionally your tongue may flitter over a taste of fruit, from the 2% lambic subtly mixed in.

Bottle. Pleasant aroma of sweeter malt, some light, tart cherry juice, just a hint of funk and a good dash of dry yeast. Pours dark maroon/brown with a creamy head. Balanced flavor. Sweeter caramel malt, definite cherry presence, other dark fruits and a nice amount of yeast. Leaning toward full bodied. Good carbonation and very creamy.

Bottle. Pours brown with a small head.  The aroma is of cherries and alcohol.  The taste is dark fruit, a little bitter and a little sweet, with a lot of alcohol that mixes easily with the depth of the tastes.  The carbonation is heavy and just right.  Great beer.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2008 Bottle. Pours a dark amber with a nice head. The aroma is quite mixed; some fruit, a bit of wood, and yeast. At the first sip you know its a Belgian-style; the yeast is strong. Later the dark fruit and sweet malt come in. The cherry addition grows over time, and is never anything but natural. No strange artificial flavors here. A awesome beer. Really a lot to love, complex, and the alcohol is not noticeable. Great.

Pours dark brown with a moderate beige head.  Aromas of plum, nut, and red wine.  No hop bouquet.  Not as sweet as I expected (a good thing); big malty flavors with just a hint of cherry.  Full body. Fruity in the finish.  Excellent holiday beer.

98% Domestic ale, 2% imported Kriek (cherry) from Duvel in Belgium.
An acidic, dark nose, like a cherry cordial.
Tastes like a cherry cordial, too. Caramelly, and warm, definitely a dessert beer -- was excellent with dark-chocolate brownies; would also pair up well with shortbread, and perhaps pork chops with a cherry sauce.
12oz - Good, solid ale.  Wood palate, dark color, creamy head.  Cherries really only show up on the first sip.  Its good., really nice in this wintery time of year

This is one that Ommengang gets right on the money.  A 2007 vintage popped open after a long work week.  This quadrupel with 2% ale brewed with cherries wastrue Belgian style.  Less fruity than most quadrupels--pours with a a dark brown and nice head.  Flavors are rich brown sugar, molasses, and hints of cherry.  Very tasty.

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2008 750ml(2006 version)- A dark red body with a nice tan head which has an aroma of cherries, roasted malt, and a little alcohol. Taste started out with a little caramel and cherries and the alcohol started coming out in the middle and end along with more cherries Great tasting beer.
750ml(05 Version)6/27/08-A medium cloudy body with a nice small tan head and an aroma of  malt, raisin, and brown sugar.  Taste of the same with a little cherries and sweetness. A good tasting brew that aged pretty well. The same rating as the 06. 8/3/8/3/16
750ml(’07 Version)7/10/08-A cloudy amber body with a nice tight off white head. Aroma of cherries, malt, and raisins. Taste is of the same with cherries, alcohol, and a little malt. Reminds me of the previous years even after I let the ’05 age. Same rating 8/3/8/3/16

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2008 The beer is beautiful, pouring with a large, fluffy, off-white head. Cloudy color with tiny particles bubbling around, color is somewhere between amber and red. Nose is moderately yeasty with a cherry funk, as well as dark fruits,  elements of Casis, port wine and cinnamon. Taste starts lightly bitter with elements of fruit and over the long duration finishes moderatly sweet. Wait even longer and there is a slight nutty aftertaste on the finish. Texture is some what creamy. Carbonation is lively which makes the beer seem lighter bodied than it should feel. Alcoholic notes on the finish. Very refreshing, quite good!

Great beer.  The dark cherry flavor is obviously very clear, but the strangest thing I noticed is that the beer seems to evaporate before a developed aftertaste can occur.  This is great for smoothness, but counteractive for developing a full flavor.
Pours crisp with a foamy head, yeasty aroma.  Complex palate - yeast, cherries and ripe fruit.  Vestiges of malt to a warm alcohol finish.  Great beer.

UPDATED: APR 7, 2009 Nice head at the beginning, though it doesnt last long. Strong mix of flavors in the aroma, excellent taste. Nice, alcoholic bite, excellent ale.

Re-rate: 09 bottle
1 finger beige head. Smells of yeast, sweet bread, bananas. Taste is yeasty with light coffee malts and a bready finish.
Pours a dark red color. Smells of cherries, malt, and alcohol.  Tastes more of cherries and hides the alcohol very well.

Dark amber color, beige firm head, good lace. Very sweet, madeira, raisin, hint of licorice, bitter finish. Full, soft, powerful and flavorful. Thanks Kramer17801.
Pours dark brown with nice foamy head. Aroma is sweet cherry, anise, citrus. Flavor is fruity, caramel, licorice, nuts, cherry. Smooth body. Dangerously drinkable at 10% ABV. Delicious.

Pours a dark brown, with maybe a slight hint of purple. nice light tan head. strong aroma of citrus, star anise, and cherry. nice mouthfeel and strong flavor. each sip will result in finding a new flavor.

Brown hazy with particles with a beige lacing head.  Sweet smelling, fruity, nuts, a bit alcoholic (no surprise).  Flavour is also sweet and fruity with a nice bite from the alcohol.  Natural, woody, and dry.  Pretty nice and smooth.
warming going down, not truly remarkable. Enjoyed the cherry aspect of it, as it is a bit of a twist on the usual estery aspects in this style, but it took away from the balance of the beer. Okay.

750 ml bottle.  MASSIVE HEAD!.  pours about jet brown.  aromas of prunes, slight anise, and prominent licorice, and over-ripe citrus.  on the flavor, i get bright fruits; bing cherry, but mixed with caramel, as well as more licorice, over-ripened plum and berries, and the finish has just a hint of spice mixed with baking chocolate and the sweet side of pecan.  great.  phenomenal.  its easy to drink, and a wonderful production.

On draft at Zenos.  Pours a dark rusty brown orange with a medium beige head.  Aroma of dark fruit, dates, figs, orange peel and brown sugar.  Taste is dark fruity with hints of orange peel, marmalade, brown sugar, toffee and caramel candy.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2009 Cloudy red-brown with good, fizzy tan head / Mellow nose of cocoa, cherries, amd dates / Medium body, some sweetness, fizzy carbonation, slightly acidic, and with fair, somewhat hot, finish / Restrained, slightly cooked flavors of cherry, banana, cinnamon, toffee, fig, and cocoa / Pleasant, but lacks complexity.

750ml.  I had a higher hopes and I think that is probably resulting in a lower score than this one deserves.  Poured murky brown with a light brown head.  Aroma is mostly sweetness with some earthiness, alcohol, and the much expected cherry.  Pretty dry body with good fruit, dry malt and cherry.  Very complex and distinct, all in all, not as intense as the heavier quads I have had.

This is a great beer.  Has a lovely deep amber color with ample head.  Nice fruity, phenolic nose.  Dont expect a load of cherry in the taste.  Theres just a hint of tartness and funk to suggest the presence of the lambic.  Has all the usual caramel, fig and spice of a strong dark.

Deep ruby pour with lasting and creamy off-white head.  Caramel, ripe fruit, and oak on the nose.  Sweet malt, cherries, brown sugar, dates and cider in the taste.  Medium mouthfeel.  Tart finish.  Great pairing with turkey on Thanksgiving.

Sample, at the Mondial de la biere 2006, savoured on June 2 2006; eye: dark caramel with orangey yellow reflections, tiny caramel head; nose: caramel, not much odours, a bit of alcohol; mouth : caramelized malt, carbonation, caramel explosion, finale is lightly liqueur-like, medium body, quite sweet, a bit bitter

FRANÇAIS

Échantillon, bue au Mondial de la bière 2006 le 2 juin 2006; oeil : caramel fonce avec des reflets jaune orange, petite mousse caramel; nez : caramel, peu dodeurs, un peu dalcool; bouche : malt caramélisé, carbonatation, explosion de caramel, finale douce légèrement liquoreuse, corps moyen, très sucrée, peu amère

Smells of dark roasted chocolate malts with hints of coffee. Pours a deep dark reddish brown with a generous brown head. Taste is creamy and sweet, dark bitter chocolate with that yeasty ommegang taste. Very tasty

Bottle.  Also first rating.  Not as cloying as some other high alcohol beers.  The cherry is very subtle.  More of it shows in the color than in the taste.  Bought a 4 pack of 12-ounce bottles, excited to try this one again.
Deep red color, nicely formed head, great malty aroma. Fruity/spice flavor, not as much malt as the aroma would have you believe. Still a very good beer.

750 ml courtesy of Naka, split with him.  Pours brown with a "cherry red" hue when held up to the light.  Huge frothy head, great lacing.  Big malty startcarmel and biscuit, thats cut through quickly by acidic cherry.  No hop prescence at all.  Great sour/acidic finish that lingers.  Not something I could have all the time (Id be hammered from asshole to earlobe all day long), but a definate treat on a cold November day while brewing.  Kudos.

Im not a big fan of high gravity Belgian style beers, but I do drink them on occasion.  This one was well made and clearly shows pretty clearly that Ommegang is at the forefront of brewing these style beers in the US.  Lots of fruit, some spice, yeast too ... a nicely flavored beer.

Poured a dark brown and ruby with a two-finger tall off-white head that lingered for a bit before collapsing into a galaxy swirl of thn white foam that sat atop the beer for the duration.  Spotty lacing.  The aroma was grapes, raisins, malt, spice and a nice helping of Belgian yeast.  The flavor is mild in terms of the Belgian yeast, but spice and dark fruit (raisin and cherry) came through.  A bit of fizzy, lively carbonation and a pretty unremarkable mouthfeel.
aged caramel like aroma -- mahogany like pour -thin head - smooth- aftertaste reminded of roasted malts  great beer smooth drinking not harsh at all

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2009 old rating:
7/5/7/4/16 - 3.9

pours a semi-clear dark burgundy, almost purplish with a large tan head, and really good lacing.

smell is of dark fruit, malts, burnt caramel, freshly cut firewood, a little cocoa, and cherry-cola.

taste is complex, there is a lot there, its fruity (dark pitted fruit), tingles the tongue, some roasted nuts, a cherry or two, somewhat sour, caramel, and malts, leaves the mouth dry, slightly bitter in the end.

12 oz. Pours a deep rich brown with a white 1" head, which then fades slowly. Fruity and malty aromas. Great mouthfeel. Hint of cherry lingers, very enjoyable. Doesnt quite hide the alcohol as much as some other bug beers. All-in-all, very good.

Bottle/Cave-aged. Apparently, Ommegang has been storing ale in Howe Caverns in NY to age and stabilize the the taste. The dark brown ale really comes alive with a great head when poured and the distinct aromas of apples and champagne mixed with dark malts invited me to the taste. Sweet caramel and baked fruits for a pie came to mind with a hint of hops in the aftertaste. I barely noticed the 9.8 abv as the dark ale really took me by surprise. A great selection for me.

From bottle : Pours dark brown with some red highlights when held to the light, with a half finger of off-white foamy head.  Wonderful fruity aroma, almost as if it was actually brewed in Belgium.  But the smell isnt quite as strong as some others, it smells great, you just gotta get your nose down in there and root around a little.  Nice medium palate that feels alive on the tongue.  Flavor isnt as impressive as the aroma, but it is far from bad.  Nice sweet fruits, and some malty like tastes.  Pretty good for an American Belgian.

Sample @ BJCP tasting. Very complex aromas, just couldnt get it. Tart, warm with wood aged kind of notes. Perhaps a little candy sugar sweetness but overall it didnt quite do it for me. Perhaps the sample we had was a little dated?

Maybe I shouldnt rate this and screw up the average, but this is just about undrinkable to me. Ive had one in front of me for an hour now and I just cant work through it. But it may just be the style I dont like, not necessarily this particular beer. Its so thick and syrupy. I know its sacrelige, but I had to cut it with some water! Ugh, its just so sweet and strong. Its too much. I think its making my stomach a little uncertain. Same thing last night. I dont want the other two in the four pack. Kudos to them for going for it, but its just too much for me. Ive tried other strong Trappist beers, and theyre really all kind of borderline for me, but I can work through the strength to appreciate the flavor and other qualities. Not so this one.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2008 Im a big fan of this beer. The palate is somethig to behold. Very thick with carbonation but also in character. It wasnt thin or vinagery like many high alcohols. The flavors are complex, but it does taste more like a belgian strong than a Abt. There are less fruit sweet notes and more yeasty malty notes. Either way, very complex.

Cork and capped 750mL 2007.  couple of days later I saw a 2006.  I should have bought that instead.  Big head of medium to small bubbles that quickly fades to wisps on the surface.  Deep read amber color.  The aroma is mild, and I want to say I smell a little bit of Brett.  The taste is very dry, like a brett beer.  Sourness is very mild as if just a bit of sour cherry juice was added. I only drank a little, then drank the rest the next day. It was still very carbonated and more tasty.  Nice drinkability.  Very nice beer. Great with cheese, or good by itself.
Bottle.  Cloudy, dark rubby brownish tint.  Very thin layer of head.   Initial aroma is a sweet maltiness with a hint of cherries.  The flavor corresponded nicely with the aroma.  A nice beer.

750ml bottle. tawny brown and quite dense in its appearance. brown sugar and caramel. toasty bread malts and soapy hops. cry somewhat tannic finish with a hint of tart fruit. a little like cherry cough syrup. plenty of esters and alcohol. a rich and luxurious quad with a velvety smooth palate.

This Belgian brew can be tasted in layers.  Think bitter, malty base sustaining a sweet fruity "cherrylicious" body, and topped with a lovely live yeast involved finish.  Three philosophers?  More like one philosopher with multiple personalities.

Draft of the 2004 version at the Blind Tiger.  The aroma was mostly cherries, not the candied kind, but the real kind, and maybe a little sourness.  The flavor is mostly cherry also, and what I thought was some bitter chocolate malt.  Well done compared to the bottle I had awhile ago.

Pours a very dark ruby, good looking when held to the light.  Small, effervescent head.  Strong cherry nose, some treacle, sourness, follows through on the palate, along with some bitter chocolate, plums and other dark fruits.  Ends with a zesty yeast finish, minimal bittering. Interesting, though can be overpowering.

Cloudy reddish brown tint. Medium sized tan head, no real carbonation visible.  Fruity plum, raisin aroma heavily accented with brown sugar.  So many smells in there they jumble together - all that stuff overpowers any malts or hops noticed in average ales.  Thick consistency, but highly carbonated leading to a curious combo.  Despite its floral / fruity aroma this beer has many ale-like qualitites, malty then cherry comes out.  Finally, the alcohol makes its play in the end.  A satisfying journey.

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2008 Cloudy/hazy brownish red in appearance.  Beautiful aroma, with all the yeastiness of a belgian ale, but a nice undercurrent of cherry and other fruit.  Flavor is typical of the trappist ales, and yet has a nice cherry component.  This beer tastes very much the way its aroma implies.  Nice fruity finish on the palate.  Alcohol is extremely well hidden.  Medium to thick mouthfeel.  Easily one of the best in its class.  
NOTE:  I went to Ommegang and got the Cave-aged version of this beer...aged in Howe cavern.  While its not radically different than the regular one, it clearly is smoother, and the nose is more enjoyable.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2009 Bottle.  Cloudy deep reddish brown color, large lasting off-white head.  Dark, heavy fruit smell/taste.  Medium body with a nice finish.  The alcohol is noticeable, but barely.  Very strong aftertaste.

Deep rusty brown color, thin fizzy head. A mostly fruity nose. Apricot, banana, raisins. Hints of sweet malt and brewers yeast. Wheres the cherries everyones talking about??  Light to medium in body with strong carbonation. Expected some bitterness from the cherries but not there. Finishes nicley. Not my favorite style, but a better then average brew.
Warm chocolately, with a bit of brown sugar.  A little thin in the mouth with very subtle cherry flavors blended in with the maltiness.  A wonderful experience.

Bottle previously and recently an aged version.  Thought I had previously rated it.  Definitely liked it the second time; the fruit flavor had mellowed a bit.  Last time I found the cherry too assertive.  This time the blend and complexity worked very well.  Other flavor included dark fruit, yeast and a slight hint of alcohol although it was well hidden.

Rated while drinking: Pours a murky cloud of amber and red. There is a large magnificent off-white head on top, that slowly dissipates. Sweet alcoholic malt in the nose, but there is a whiff of cherries as well. Flavor is a mirror of the aroma. Much stronger aftertaste than expected though.
So far my favorite of the Belgiun style beers. Godd fruity flavor, more of a cherry taste but not overwhelming. Number one with me so far.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2007 Poured a dark brown/amber color with generous off-white head.  Aroma was a malty sweetness with a bit of fruit.  Flavor is very much like the aroma except the cherry tartness is more evident.  Mouthfeel is good.  Alcohol is pretty well hidden.  An enjoyable experience.

Cloudy dark brown, frothy tan head. Initially low aroma, but as the head settles and the beer warms aromas of brown sugar, chocolate (light), dates, and sour cherries emerge. Palate is sweet and yeasty, with added elements of fresh cut wood and tart cherries in addition to those present in the aroma. The cherry lambic adds a nice dimension.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Open the bottle and pour, releasing the scent of cherries.  The beautiful dark coloring brings excellent contrast to the creamy slightly browned-white head.  The taste is similar to the aroma but with a larger punch in the beginning, leading to a warm mellow and dry cherry flavoring after.  I had the distinct impression after my tasting that I had just drank a frothy dry red wine.  It was a pleasant surprise, and I look forward to sampling it again.

beautiful pour, dark rich color with a frothy off-white head.  the aroma is a fairely standard quad smell of heavier fruits: black currant, dried apricots, with a sutle hint of cherry.  The taste very much matches the aroma.  Nothing spectacular but a very solid brew, flavorful and rich.  im not very fond of fruit in beer but this brewery does it very well with the small amount of cherry lambic adding to its complexity.
Bottle.  Hazy brown beer with light brown head.  Aroma is very sweet strong on prunes and very woody.  Flavor is dry wood and quite plummy.  Very hoppy and dry finish.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2009 pours a dark reddish copper with huge fluffy head. aroma is of yeast and malt with a hint of tartness. mouthful is a bit tart with a quick crisp finish. abv is very well hidden. This is great easy drinking, but not a rich or memorable experience....

A nice balance of tart cherries, yeast and spice.  Alcohol is initially well hidden, but tends to pucker your mouth after a while.  Very warming.  Enjoyable to sip.  The aftertaste is pleasant and mild, and there is some good dimension to the body of the beer.  Yeasty-bread flavor, not overly sweet, and a hint of tart cherries makes for a very enjoyable beer.

2007. pours a ruby red with a nice two finger fluffy light brown head. aroma is yeast, candy sugar, and a touch of cherry. has a light to medium body with good lacing and tremendous amount of carbonation. flavor is the same as aroma but with a little more of the cherry coming forward. again very lively carbonation on the tongue and the cherry just sits on the tongue for awhile. i like this quad it is not as sweet as others and i like the cherry addition. has a small dry aftertaste and as it warms there is some bread aroma and flavor that appear. very nice!
Dark brown.  Tartness in the aroma and fruity.  Malty and tart in flavor.  Alcohol comes out as it warms and helps this beer really shine.
Pours brown with off white head. Aroma has pleasing balance of sweetness and alcohol. Taste has the slightest hint of cherries along with slight tartness. Good aftertaste
dark brown/amber with a huge head. malty aroma with a hint of sweetness and alcohol. rich dark fruit flavor with a warming alcohol feel. slightly dry finish with a hint of cherry. very enjoyable.

Brownish amber. Tons of head. Smell of Malt and lots of alcohol. Watery texture. Tastes of malt, lots of it. The alcohol is covered well. Strong on the cherry and dry on the end. A super dry bitter. Im puckering after four sips.
user_location: Heart of the Rockies, Colorado, USA

text: Color is a beautiful reddish-brown. When I first popped open the bottle, the aroma was very strong and malty with an alcohol nip - it said "Drink me!" very clearly. Flavor is rich, mainly malty with some hop bitterness and hints of cherry and caramel with just a touch of sweetness. Smooth and mouth-filling, this is one delightful ale.

Thanks to johnycorkscrew for this sample.  Pours a mahoganny brown with a small tan head.  Fruity aroma .. lots of red fruits, a touch of brown sugar and spice.  Flavors are well layered with cherries, sour and fresh, carmels, dark fruits, and a hint of bakers chocolate.  Im surprised by how tasty this was.  Ill have to pick this up more often.

Thanks johnycorkscrew (and wife) for bringing this one to the shindig.  Dark brown with medium tan head.  Aroma was a lot of red fruit, very sweet, dough, lots of malt.  Flavor was dark fruit, cherry, mild alc, some spice, very nice indeed.  Medium body with average carbonation.  Very pleasing, thanks Johny.

Had this beer on 5/20/2007.  Aroma is a faint sweet malt scent.  Color is a deep brown/amber with light carbonation and thin head.  Taste is rich and hard.  Starting with a medium body it goes down hard.  Finish  comes on with a malty sweet flavor and very faint back tones of chreey, this is backed by a mellow hop flavor and bitterness.  Im disappointed the chreey flavor doesnt stand out and overall it is just to mellow.
Reddish copper color with a generous head.  Interesting beer, the lambic adds a twist.  Noticable alcohol strength.  Cherry and sweet maltiness in the flavors and the aromas.
Nice dark brown colour, light brown head. Taste is initially malty, but the cherry flavours sneak up on you. Bitter, dry finish. Good stuff!

2006 bottle.  Above average quad - especially for America.  Nothing really to knock on this one except it is no where near the great quads on Belgium - but I suppose this was expected.  Nice creamy smooth palate dark fruits and some spice.  I wish the sour cherries had shown through a bit more...

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2008 2007 bottle.  nice dark amber color on the pour with a great caramel head that stayed for a while.  smelled of cherries and malts.  taste was a hint of cherries and some alcohol.  thick on the palate but not thick like a stout .  very good beer.  ill be buying another bottle to cellar.

2006 vintage, 750mL. Thanks J. This beer impressed me by a longshot. I had seen it available in so many places, notably BevMo on a regular basis. Good amount of carbonation, its got that Belgian yeast thing goin on in the aroma with raisin and spice. jarspag made a good description as a lesser St. Bernardy. Interesting finish as the small portion of lambic added gives the palate a faint acidic touch, nicely done. Cinnamon, banana & raisin in the flavor with lots of dark Belgian malt. Warm, dry finish. Good one.

Poured from a vintage 2005 caged and corked 750ml bottle and served in a tulip.  This quad poured a hazy brown color with a large, tight, light tan head.  Excellent retention with some faint lacing.  The aroma of the beer consisted of dark fruits, apples, cherries, light caramel, and earthy yeast esthers.  The flavor included yeast spiciness, dark fruits, cherries, and a touch of light candy sugar.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied with a good amount of carbonation.  Overall, this was a very enjoyable quad.  Not the best, but very well done, nonetheless.
Good stuff, but not great. Complex flavor of sweet plums and raisins. I really didnt notice much cherry flavor. Very full bodied and thick mouthfeel. The alcohol content shows up in the finish.

750 ml bottle from Bevmo. Poured a gorgeous coffee brown with red around the edges, there is just a slight haze. Head is khaki colored, three fingers large, sudsy and long lingering. Aroma was light with cherries and allspice. Flavor is ripe with raisins, sour cherries, something floral, coffee, chocolate, and musty yeast. This brew has a good balance of spicy, sweet and sour. Mouthfeel is full and satisfying, carbonation is light and prickly. Finish is dry, weak and short with a bit of alcohol showing. Overall something is missing that would make this a truly great beer, even so, it commands a lot of respect.

Bottle. Plenty of adjectives needed to describe this beer. Fantastic mix of aromas include heavy malt notes of caramel milk chocolate, flowers for the hops, and earthy/musty for the yeast. In the background theres prune, ripe pear, brown sugar, alcohol and chalk. Head is frothy/fizzy, brown with fair lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is a hazy red/brown. Balance in flavors is almost perfect and each component unfolds nicely into the others. It starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic then finishes lightly sweet, acidic and bitter. Palate is medium to full, chewy, between oily and creamy with a carbonation between lively and fizzy, and it finishes dry in the mouth and sticky on the lips. An excellent quadrupel from an American company.

Pours a clouded ruby with a light tan head. Nose is heavy with sugar and alcohol. Flavor is extremely sweet. Pungent cherry tones. Strong quad tones with that very noticeable cherry lambic presence. Feel is thin. Lacks body and grace. Drinkability stays low due to extreme mix of flavors. Overall it is an okay brew IMO. I dont feel as though it holds any character that helps it stand out against the rest of those of its kind. Ommegang is good, but this time for me they are not good enough to warrant a return to this one.

This was a good beer...  I got it in Vegas at Lees.... there were so many great beers that we dont get in Oklahoma...  I had to try this one.

hazy brown, aroma of...  nuts, prunes, sweet cherry, cherry and other fruits in the taste...  a little coffee...   a lot of chocolate....
Reddish Brown colour. Heavy malt taste with hints of cherry and chocolate. Nice and full of flavour.

2006 bottle-- sour cherries, alcohol aroma, caramel, wheat
dark amber with reddish tones, active head that quickly fades
almost stratified carbonation, so the beer feels lighter near the top of the flow than the bottom I taste cherries, alcohol, licorice, oak. wont let the mouth rest, makes it want to be bigger to hold more fumes
this was a pretty damn good beer.  I wasnt a fan of how it looked, the smell was interesting, and the taste was great.  i was really surprised to see how high the ac was.
Brown/amber cloudy appearance. Sweet honey aroma. Taste of a lambic with cherry tones.  Subtle but strong alcohol content.
It had a dark amber body with brown head, it did a very nice job at covering up the high 9.8% abv.  I really enjoyed this beer.

Cloudy brown with medium brown head. Strong fruity aroma.  Creamy. Sweetness that tickles on the tongue.  Smooth. Fruitness lingers on sides of mouth.  Slight spiciness.  Good balance of spice and fruit.
Bold cherry in the aroma and flavor. This iscomplex with a great balance of sweet, spicey, and tart. While the alcohol is nice and warming, it is barely noticeable in the taste. This was good.

Date: 02/21/2004
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting, RateBeer SE Gathering, 2004

dark amber, whispy head, big sweet malt aroma, rich malt flavor, good carmel sweetness, light bitterness in the finish, spices sneak out of the woodwork when your back is turned to distract you from the figs that show up at the end
-------- />
Date: 05/22/2005

nice sweet cherry character mixed in with the dark malts
-------- />
Date: 06/22/2006
Mode: bottle
Vintage: 2003 vintage

blood red, fine brown head that easily rouses to produce a bit of lace, sweet aroma of dark ripe fruits and tart cherry, big yet lively body, rich blend of flavors with a ripe figs and cherry, good interplay between the sweetness and the tartness

Aroma: 8/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 16/20
Rating: 4/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **4

Id be very interested in trying the original version as the later ones are said to be completely different.  Sad as this one overall is quite poor.  Musty, cagey aroma with the scent of tart cherries.  Heavily cloudy appearance with minimal head and lacing.  Some caramel malt and chocolate notes, but just a bit of vegetal on the side.  Off, a bit fusel, some funk tossed in without any thought.  Some complexity in the taste, but overall execution is very lacking.

cloudy brown-red, thin tan head.  malty aroma, some chocolate and sour cherry.  nice carbonation - small, tight bubbles.  first taste is malt, tart dark fruits (cherry, plum), wood, and bitter sweet chocolate. crisp despite the intense initial malts. nice warming but no alcohol taste.
Bottle... a very complex beer that I enjoyed very much. Its a good beer to sit and sip on for a while. You cant really drink this beer too fast.

Pours a Dark Amber to burgandy color with a white head with great lacing.  Very pleasant aroma.  Taste finishes sweet with a hint of a roasted/smoky flavoring.  Alcohol is hidden well and deceptively strong.

2006 bottle.  Aroma of red wine, malt, and cherries.  Frothy tan head, deep reddish brown color, good lacing. Woody cherry flavors with hints of chocolate and dried fruits.  Mellows on the tongue, fairly complex.  Light for a quadrupel.  Dry on the palate but well balanced.  Not overly thick and very drinkable.  Good flavor changes and a wide range of flavors.
Full aroma, excellent appearance, & full flavor.  I thoroughly enjoyed this brew.
Good stuff, but the cherry flavor is a little too present. Then again, Im not a big fan of cherry

Great appearance and tons of aroma. Been looking forward to this one. Wish I liked it more. Sweet dark Belgian Ales just arent my thing anymore. This is a good brew even though I couldnt finish it. Alcohol is hidden great, good flavors and is a really easy drinker if youre into these brews.

2006 from a 750ml bottle. Has a deep copper color (I like the term ruby used in other ratings to describe it) with a off white billowy head that laced the glass nicely. There was a certain complexity to the taste that will require a rerate from me to get it down better. There was a fruity/floral taste that mingled very well with the slightly roasted malt flavor. The alcohol content was only apparent on the finish. Otherwise the finish was a little heavier on the malt than the fruit. Very enjoyable and I will be rerating it.

Brown/ruby with off white, lasting head and nice lacing.  Fruity yeast notes, figs, toffee roasted malts, light alcohol aromas.  Smooth, almost velvety body, with a quiet malt flavor and delicate fruit tastes throughout the palate.  Cherry, berry and a light crisping towards the end provide a nicely balanced brew which hides its strength well.

Pours cloudy amber with a fluffy tan head. Aroma is strong with cherries. Flavor is sweet and fruity. Lots of carbonation, almost too much. Im not catching much of the alcohol in this one. 

Im wondering if I got a bad bottle. The fizz is an indicator, and it kind of has that off taste. Its not improving in quality as it warms up. Eh.
user_location: Waco (Buckle of the Bible Belt), Texas, USA

text: bottle.  Very cloudy - it does not look like beer should look - very unappealing.  Looks similar to freshly brewed iced tea with too many tea bags put into it.  Slightly malty smell.  Can smell and taste the alcohol instantly.  Tart, almost flat taste.  Not enjoyable.

Damn, i wish i had had this a long time ago.  Pours out a nice reddish brown color with a larger biege head.  aroma is sweet, fruity, and full of wheat.  flavor is fantastic as the lambic gives this beer a nice zing at the finish.  Damn fine brew.

2005 bottle thanks to David!  Poured a slightly hazy medium orangey-caramel with a rather well-retained cap of beige head.  The aroma was sweet and on the dusty side, with some cherry dust, toasty caramel malts, a bit of spicy yeast, and some enhancement from the booze-factor.  The flavor had toasty chocolate, caramel, and dried, very sweetened cherries.. left a sweet caramel and cherry finish accented by a hefty booze factor.. didnt enjoy it too much.  Wanted to be heavier in the body, but the dried cherry undertones made it a touch slick.. heavy booze-laden caramel and cherry dust rode through the finish, leaving a sharper, yet well-sweetened cherry finish.  OK all-around.. not really good, though.

Poured dark brownish red with decent head and nice lacing. This is one rich beer. Very complex taste with obvious cherry (but not overdone) and yeasty taste. So rich I dont think I could drink more than one, but thats not always a bad thing

so my taste was a little thrown off by the 2 bottles of two heart ale i enjoyed just before this great brew but i still found it very complex and enjoyable. smell was sweet and licorice. the taste was of dark sweet cherries but with alcohol lingering and being very sweet and thick. texture was thick. the apperance was near opaque red. hope to grab another bottle sometime soon.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2007 Wow! This is a beer worthy of elite rankings of Rochefort 10! Awesome, complex, and simply delicious!  Heavy ripe raisen, plum, and small subtle chocolate notes on the palate. Enjoy this beer, it is worth a taste.
Pours brown with light brown head.  Flavor is a subtle cherry.  Reasonable carbonation.  Not my favorite style of beer, but not bad.

Bottle. Pours with fine, creamy brown head that remains as the beer continually fizzes and a body that is a dark opaque brown. The aroma is malty, smells of dust, some alcohol and licorice. Medium bodied with that nice fizzy light carbonation that never seems to stop. Flavor has some light cherry notes and with the warmth of the alcohol reminds me a touch of the old cough syrup. It has some brandy notes and red wine flavors. Has a mild sweet and alcohol finish, with a fairly yeasty note hanging in there. Some tartness as well in a slightly cherryish fashion I guess. Its not entirely interesting but its quite good. Bottle says 2006.
bottle. i was excited about this one, but did not care for it.  deep read pour with nice head.  sour malt nose. thick feel with slight cherry in the finish.

Looks like murky sewage and V8.  Reddish brown pour with no head,  floating chunks, and overall not appealing.  Smells like a heller bock.  Sweet sour maltiness but with a hint of alcohol as well.  As it warms it smells a bit more of rubbing alcohol.  Not a terribly appealing smell either.  Taste is really rather dry, muddy and bland actually with alcohol definitely noticeable but ive had stronger alcohol tastes in less alcoholic beers.  Cherry isnt really noticeable, but maybe comes through it the tartness rather than big cherry flavor.  Reminds me of a cross between beer and wine.  Like a carbonated wine almost.  This isnt awful, but I dont see it being anybodys dream beer as its story and creation indicates.  The best thing about this to me was that it didnt have the awful belgian yeast taste and smell that I really abhor.  I actually liked it better than I thought I would, and it grew on me a touch.

The 12 ounce bottle poured a clear brownish amber beverage with a small frothy head that was mostly diminishing and left some lacing on the glass. The aroma was wonderfully complex with caramel and dark sweet dried fruits mixing with subtle notes of vanilla and Belgian candy sugar. The body is medium full with lively carbonation and a refreshing dry texture. The flavor was ever so slightly sweet (not nearly as sweet as I was expecting). As it settles on the palate it becomes dry and takes on a warmth on the tongue and back of the throat. The finish is long.

Pours a rich brown with a thick, billowy head.  Aroma of malt and fruit.  The flavor is dreamy.  A silky maltiness carries away the taste buds with a perfect balance of sweet, sour, and bitter.  The palate is creamy and full, yet assertive and flows down the throat with ease.  Try this beer if you have not already.

[bottle] Sugary, sweet aroma. Plenty of malt and yeast presence, with some slight fruit and spice as well. Ruby/brown in color, with a lumpy off-white head. Very interesting flavors, fruity, complex belgian yeast character, with some subtle spices. Sugary, dense mouthfeel. The blended kriek seems to really come through in the finish, providing some tart flavors and additional sweetness. Finishes with some nice alcohol warmth.
God brew. My first quad.  Thicker than the tripels ive had and not as spicy. Had in 12 oz and big bottle.

12 oz bottle purchased at the brewery during BCTC 2007. Poured a clear reddish/brown with subtle carbonation and a dense off white head. Aroma of very slight chocolate covered cherries, wine and oak. The cherry lambic was barely detectable in the flavor and just seemed to be a malty belgian style strong ale. Palate was nice and full with lively carbonation. I would have liked to see the Kriek coming through a little bit stronger especailly in the flavor.
Wow, that is one interesting beer; a quadrupel-lambic hybrid.  A mellow taste of cherries but not very syrupy and it had a nice dry finish.  Not a daily drinker but Ill have it again.
Amber pour with big head.  Nose of dried fruit.  Flavor was light cherry with hints of raisins and a lot of yeast.  Hugh on the carbination, be ready for that, finish was nice and dry.
Caramel smell, dark broen red color. champagne taste with fruity flavor and a sweet finish. Very carbonated, cherry notes
UPDATED: MAR 1, 2009 This beer has secrets to tell.  If you taste it often, it gets better every time.  Only problem is that it is very heavy, but if the mood is right this beer is nearly perfect.

Not fond of this beer! If you are not a wine fan, you will not like this. (obviously i dont like wine). Tasted like a mix of red wine and champagne to me. On the other hand, if you like/love wine, youll probably love this beer. Has great red hue, even smells pretty good, but, to beat a dead horse, i dont like wine (thats why i drink beer!!!!)"

Oh wow, I cant believe I havent rated this before!  Delicously dark and fruity, it has a nice fluffy white head on top of a dark ruby brown body.  Sweet malty caramel flavours as well as syrupy sweet fruit.  There is some nice yeasty presence as well as a nice smooth finish.  Its very deceptive, could not believe that its almost 10 percent.

Rated 7/23/07.  Dark amber to brown in color with some purple hues when held to the light.  Fluffy off-white head that starts off big but settles to a quarter inch layer.  Decent lacing noted.  Aroma was heavy on brown sugar and rum soaked dark fruits.  The flavor had that same brown sugar malty backbone, but the fruits became a bit more defined.  I picked up some dark cherry, some fig, and some raison.  I also got quite a bit of bread pudding, which lent some smoothness to this brew.  The alcohol is noticable, but not unpleasant.  A little sweet for me, but its not just an avalanche of sugar like many are.  There is actually some substance behind its sweetness.  Would make a good desert beer.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2007 750 ml bottle.  Wonderful!  A slight taste of cherry, which adds to the complexity of this beer... pours a deep amber with a decent head that quickly becomes a thin lacing.  Aromas and flavors of cherry, prunes and malts.  Highly recommended.

Poured a dark brown with a foamy creamy off-white head that has really good retention. Aroma of carmolized fruits. Sweet complex flavours of fruits, cherries being the strongest with finishing flavours of prunes and raisins. A very interesting and tasty beer. Perfect amount of carbonation and medium body, with a warm lingering alcohol feeling between sips.

Poured from bottle. Very cloudy dark brown with amber tints. Smelled real strong of prunes! Taste was sweet fruit, cherries, plums, and raisins. I did not quite taste the chocolate, but it was a slightly tart finish.

750 ml bottle 2006 bottling Pours a slightly cloudy deep brown body with a good beige head that leaves some sheet lacing. Aroma of chocolate, dark fruits, Belgian yeast, and a hint of clove. Medium body and carbonation and a touch of hot alcohol. The cherry lambic finally shows up in the taste but is eclipsed by darker fruits like raisins and prunes. Anise, pepper and clove add a spicy dimension. Lots of chocolate, but just a hint of cherries. Not bad, but I would have liked the cherry lambic to be more prominent in the mix.
Pours a murky amber brown with a thin tan head. Aroma brings a cherry, alcoholic and belgian yeasty nose. Flavour is belgian yeast combined with a cherry tart note.  Nice take on an Abt.

What could be bad? A well made quad infused with some delicously sweet and tart lambic. Like eating a chocolate covered cherry. 
Love it. And with Ommegang back in the MN market- love it often. I will now proudly click the "I can get this beer today" box and then add this rating.

750 ml bottle, brewed in 2006.
Dark brown with a foamy tan head.
Aroma is prune, alcohol, chocolate cherries, dry yeast.
Flavor is caramel and sweet tart cherries.
A little bit of alcohol heat on the finish.
Pours dark brown with foaming tan head; aromas are sweet and thick; flavors dont quite live up to the aromas and you can taste the strength of the alcohol and it comes off slightly bitter

poured from bottle a dirty reddish color with a dirty white head.  Flavor was that o fruit, but i would not cherries.  Interesting it says seasonal beer of winter, i had it out on my deck in the middle of summer and really enjoyed it.
Pours a reddish brown color with an odd orange colored sparkely head. Tastes of caramel malt and cherries. The flavors to too subtle to be significant. Decent to try but I would not buy again.

Poured a medium brown color with little head.  Aroma is of strong malt with a touch of cocoa.  It has a sweet start to the taste and then chocolate and caramel malt flavor. The alcohol is hidden well at the finish.
it had a nice color and smell but it left something to be desired for taste. tasted of old burnt cherries that is amped up with a bad taste of chocolate.

Bottle. Silty brown appearance but definitely better under light with ruby amber tones. Large off white head on top. In the aroma the cherry is definitely noticeable giving it a sweetness that is offset by notes of coffee, chocolate and olives. The beer coats the tongue with a fruity sweetness that turns into a wierd acidic taste. The cherry flavor doesnt work well with the high alcohol content. Think Robitussin

Pours dark and cloudy with a big white head. Aroma has cherry and chocolate in it. Nice carbonation. Great mixture of ale and lambic. A nice bite in the taste that is smoothed out by the cherry. A really interesting beer that can be sneaky strong.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2007 poured into tulip.  good stuff, the cherry blend makes this Quad easy to drink for 9.8 ABV, be careful, it is good... pours a brown with high frothy light tan head.  yeasty sour fruity aroma.  very yeastie presence, more so than anything else, almost to a chocolate malty mocha finish.  cherry lamibic is not an immediate presence, it presents itself slowly thru the middle.  good and complex, not as initially fruity as you may think...

Chocolate cherry malt with a creamy foam on top?  Okay, as long as its 9.8% ABV.  What a find this was.  They just started to distribute Ommegang in MN and I am very pleased with what I have tried so far.  Along with being a very tasty beer, Ommegang offerings tend to be a dollar or two less than other 750ml of the same caliber.  Cheers!
Nice cherry scent and flavor.  Alcohol is very prominent.  Good mouthfeel with a sweet but somewhat short finish.

Heres a beer that will knock you on your butt. It has a nice aroma with a hint of cherry. Flavor is about the same and it has a great taste. 

This is a strong beer, as most quads are, and a bottle of this stuff will put you down if you are not careful

THOUGHTS: Not the best quad flavors and aroma, but a really nice beer. A lot of cherry flavor but not in a sickening sweet juice way. Rather light and easy to drink for a quad. Packed with flavor but not much aroma. Every time I drink this it seems a little diferent. I liked the aroma but it was very weak and one-sided. Highly carbonated, which led to quite a few burps. More malt flavor came out as it warmed.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a clear, dark red with a small to average creamy, off-white head that fully lasted and left excellent lacing. The aroma was lightly malty and yeasty but mostly cherry. The initial flavor was light to moderate sweetness, while the finish was heavily sweet with a short duration. The medium body was dry with fizzy carbonation and the finish was a little metallic and moderately alcoholic.

Pours dark red-brown with a medium, bubbly tan head.  Nose is sweet and sharp with alcohol, mild cherry, horseblanket.  Flavor is strongly sweet, dark fruit and cherries, ending with a sour lambic note.  Pretty good stuff.
Really good beer. Dark copper red. Hint of cherries in the aroma. Taste is sweet and fruity. The alcohol is not as hidden as in others. It really comes through when the beer warms. This is a must.

Pours a deep, brownish-red.  Aroma is a mix of fruit and spicy notes.  Flavor is a perfect balance of lambic and quadrupel with the Belgian "funk" mixed in with the spices and a slight fruit aftertaste.  A smooth beer and a winner all around.

Brewed 2004. Pours hazy brown with nice yellow head. Aroma is dried fruit, roasted grains and alcohol. Flavor is strong Flavor is dried figs, cherries roasted almonds. Alcohol and hop balance the brew well. Mouthfeel is chewy and thick.
Dark copper color. Aroma of cherries and raisins. Sweet and sour flavor consisting of raisins, caramel, and cherries. A very nice beer!

12 oz bottle-dark ruby red w/a moderate head. Sweet belgian aroma. Sweet taste of yeast & caramel malt w/a touch of dark fruit; tasted a little darker than straight cherries, maybe a little black cherry/raspberry. The fruit definatly gave it a little different flavor, but as someone whos favorite style is a classic Belgian I wouldnt say it added to it. This beer was ok, but I wasnt all that crazy @ it; seemed like an odd combo to me. Thin, watery mouthfeel w/a long fruit finish.
xxx i dont think there is anything bad you can say about any brew from ommegang, great name, great beer

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2010 pours a nice reddish color with nice lacing on the glass. smells of cherries, yeasts, and alcohol. taste is great,  just the right cherry fruit in the limbic to balance the Belgian yeast and alcohol flavors. nice balance of everything in here, the sweet and sour tastes complement each other and just the right carbonation. A must try brew!

Looks outstanding: deep red color with a very full off-white foamy head.  Aroma is a little weak but whats there hints at alcohol, caramelly malt, and dark cherries.  Cherry flavor isnt too apparent at first but becomes more so as it warms.  Very different but not bad at all.

25 ounce bottle. Tulip glass. Aroma was of dark fruit and malt. The alcohol hits you right up front, but it mellows as it goes. Taste is dominated by dark fruit with some malt. There is a hint of cherry and some sourness, but it is not overwhelming. Very smooth with subtle flavors. One of the better ones Ive had.

Bottle. Tulip. Ive sampled this beer before, and was not impressed at first taste. Since that time, my judgment of this beer has not improved by much. Pours a hazy brown/orange ale with a condensed and thick orange/cream head.  Aromas of cherry and alcohol are clearly perceptible over notes of yeast and caramel. There is a bit of alcohol flavor, which lends to a medicinal quality to the darker cherry notes. Refreshing characteristics of a witbier with a somewhat lemony aspect can be perceived, but the mix of a strong Belgian ale, witbier and brown ale really follow a confused waltz rather than a harmonious triumph. Drinkable.

Pours a dark reddish-amber color with an initially fizzy tan head that settles into a thin layer of bubbles on the surface.  The aroma is very sweet and fruity with some maltiness, caramel, and had a strange medicinal "cherry cough drop" quality.  Flavors were very sweet and fruity, with an unusual (but pleasant) sourness to it.  Sour cherries, apple, dried fruits (dates, raisins), brown sugar, caramel, and a nice bitterness.  Definitely a hint of the alcohol.  Pretty much a lot of fruity sugariness, alcohol, and then the bitterness.  Not exactly very subtle or complex.  Fairly full-bodied, but a bit thin for the style.  Finish is quite dry and bitter, however.  I was surprised by this, its actually pretty good... but it lacks the complexity and range of flavors needed to compete with other beers of this style.

12 ounce bottle in generic goblet.  Pours deep dark red with flat light tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, red wine, bread, slight alcohol.  Flavors of chocolate, caramel, tobacco, raisiny tang, with extensive warming alcohol.  Medium-full bodied with medium carbonation.  An extremely complex beer, and a delicious nightcap.
750 mL bottle.  Copper brown with big fluffy off-white head.  Aroma of sour cherry and malt.  Lively sticky palate.  Caramel and slightly sour cherry taste  with a mildly bready finish.
Pours a dark reddish brown with a good sized light tan head. Aroma seems a little weak, caramel and cherries. Nice full palate, flavor is tart and sour. Alcohol is well hidden.

750ml bottle poured into a Trappist glass.  Pours redish brown with a huge creamy off white head.  The lacing is excellent and the head shrinks back a little, but it is fully lasting.  The aroma is awsome, sour cherrys, with a little malt sweetness.  Takeing a drink I am blown away.  What hits you first is some caramel maltiness, followed by a very distinct belgian fruity yeast, then thirdly a tartness of cherries.  In the finish there is a slight sweetness of brown sugar or maple syrup.  The duration of the finish is quite long, the sourness of the lambic and the sweetness go back and forth.  The body is medium to full with a creamy texture and lively carbonation.  One word can describe this beer Awsome!

Pours a medium brown with lots of head. Not a very strong smell on this. Some Belgian yeast aroma and maybe a little caramel malt. Flavor hs alot of caramel malt flavor with other hidden flavor like sour cherries, medicine, and Belgian yeast.

750ml - Poured a quite dark reddish brown in color with a hefty light tan head that stuck around until the end.  Some very nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma is heavy of malt with definite cherries and some dark fruit.  Fruity yeast mixed in (this got stronger as it warmed).  Flavor is malty and more than slightly sweet, but with an underlying tartness.  Dark fruit with cherry and hints of caramel and vanilla. Finish was malty and sweet, but with a lingering sourness; perhaps from the yeast.  Surprisingly, alcohol was not apparent all the way through.  I really liked this!  What a nice Fathers Day treat...

Bottle. Unclear medium red brown color with a average to large frothy good lacing mostly lasting beige head. Aroma is heavy malty, caramel, moderate yeasty, cherry, sugar, dark fruits. Initial flavor is moderate to heavy sweet, finish flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and light acidic with a average to long duration. Body is medium to full texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Dark and strong and tasty. As far as quads go, this is more in the vein of a St. Berny rather than a Westy--lighter, livelier mouthfeel, not creamy or heavy. Dark malts, cherries and dark fruits finish sweetly but not cloyingly, even a bit tart.

Definitely could tell this was a quad, without looking at the bottle. Nice aromas of cherries, malt and dark fruit. Candied sugar and cherry in the flavor. Smooth mouthfeel. A solid attempt and a good beer.
Poured a dark brown color with a off white head. Has pretty good lacing. Has hints of dark fruits, caramel, cherries, and heavy amount of malts. Finishes with a thick sour malty taste on the tongue.
Sampled at Mondial de la Biere. Malt aroma up front, followed by cherry. I normally hate things that are cherry flavored but I really enjoyed this. It was nice and complex.

I was a little let down by this beer.  With all the hype perhaps I was just expecting more.. it smelled nice, I really couldnt taste the cherry lambic aspect of the beer.. I could smell a hint of it though.. at first it had a very nutty taste.. and as the beer warmed a bit it smoothed out a lot and was more pleasant to drink.. overall it packs a punch and isnt bad.. I probably wouldnt buy it again, but I also dont necessarily regret tasting it..

750 ml...very carbonated, a little more watery than what I would have liked, but I was not disappointed. The cherry flavor comes through nicely. I would probably go for other Belgians though instead of this one.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2009 Brewed 2005. Poured a deep redish brown color with a thick rich head.  Intense cherry aroma hinted with some caramel and and a light hidden citrus.  The caramel smoothness takes over with the first sip which then leads to the taste of cherries followed by a lingering walnut on the tongue.   So smooth and rich. A hint of lingering alcohol.  Good carbonation and lace.
Rich and full of malt.  Black cherries, concord grape, a hint of alcohol, but not too much.  Good looking beer - dark with good carbonation and nice lacing.
Dark brown.  Nice sweet aroma and flavor of berries.  Alcohol well masked. An excellet Quadrupel.
Vinegar and berry aroma. Some fruits, apples, dried fruits. Brown reddish appearence. Very small head. Somewhat oaky and woody finish. Smoke and burn. Dry finish. Subtle and nice

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2008 Poured a reddish brown color.  Smelled of some funk, cherry, and distant sweetness.  Taste was much the same with some dark fruits in their as well..  It ends fairly dry and funky, no overpowering sweetness.  Good flavor, quite different from other Quads.  Doesnt hang with the best, but worth a try.

Pours a dark red/brown with a yellowy tan head.  Musty aroma of dark fruit, leaves, light cherry, brown sugar and faint traces of cheese and sweat.  Flavor was a lot more mellow than I thought it would be.  Some toffee and brown sugar, earth, chocolate mix with some dark fruit and just a vague funkiness.  Finishes lightly dry and tastes of some funky earth and spoiled fruit.  The medium mouthfeel was too light for me and the carbonation was overdone.  I see how this idea could be someones dream beer, but I dont know if it was necessarily executed just right.

Aroma of dark malts and cherries with faint hint of plum.  Thick tan head with moderate lacing.  Considering its strength it is a fairly drinkable beer.  As sit warmed the cherry flavor intensified.  It was better cold.  Subdued bitterness and extremely smooth.  All in all, really good.

Pours a deep red with a generous head, although not as thick as some abbots.  Nice aroma of fig, dark fruit, cherry, bubblegum, light smoke, tobacco, and vanilla wafers.  This is good.  Nice and complex, and a sweet caramel finish.  Memorable.  Nice touch on the cherry lambic.
Bottle.  I remembered this being much better, but this bottle was average @ best.  Didnt like it.

Murky reddish-brown beer, thin khaki head. Sweet aroma. Initial sour taste, then the usual quad sweetness. Candi sugar, plummy. Boozy cherry finish, if that makes sense. Good quad, yet alcohol and candi sugar still too apparent. Now, if youre really looking for it, you can kind of see some "cherry lambic" influence, but otherwise there isnt really anything particularly identifiable as lambic, which might have been nice (or it might have been a disaster, who knows). Anyway, Id really like to cellar some of these for a few years.

Brewed in 2004. Aroma of mixed lactic sour and cherry. Dark fruit hints. Ruby amber color with a tan head that is firm and vigorous. Starts with brown malt, hint of brown sugar, the cherry is rather faint, and the sour is hardly detectable. The finish is brown, lightly roasted malt. It is fairly dry, and its not got a lot of bitter, arguably none. Different and quite enjoyable.

Dark reddish brown pour with a off white head. Aroma was malt and fruit with some nice spice as well. Flavor was full and lasting with sweet spices and a faint cherry smack. Finished sweet with malt and sugar.

bottle...appearance: poured a dark and cloud reddish-brown with a tan head....aroma: sweet and bready with a fruit presence - im guessing thats the cherry.....taste: sweet, malty, sugary, with a subtle cherry flavoring thrown into the mix. low level of carbonation.  nice, full mouthfeel.  little bit too sweet for me but but a nice quad nonetheless

Pour from 05 bottle. WOW!  Pours a beautiful dark brown with what almost seems like a deep red silhouette and a thick cream-colored head. Good lacing.  Scents of dark cherries, malt, dough, and a prominent alcohol linger.  This could be the most exquis......Oh, sorry I almost fainted.  Taste of, again, dark cherries which Ive got to believe is the lambic aspects coming through, kick-ass hops and sweet malt with a slow, mild, sweet burn.  I actually aged this on accident, and Im now sure that this was a blessing.  Hands down, one of the best beers Ive ever had.

This is a wonderful beer.  It shows notes of the great hops that then blend with it the very nice cherry lambic style flavor.  This creates a wonderful balance that allows for a wonderfuil experience.

Smooth vanilla and chocolate aroma, sweet roasted malt.  Pours dark amber with red notes and a thin tan head.  Oh man, great roasted malt flavor, biscuity, dry and sugary, chocolatey and hints of the kreik.  I recommend having a little dark chocolate with this one.
Bottle @ MrGoodbar GBC. Deep amber color. Fruity, cherry, fig with malty ending. Port wine like.Ful bodied & delicious

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2007 Thanks to Ron, on tap at Vintage Estates. Smells fruity almost like specialty liquor or whiskey. Cloudy brown appearance and has a creamy thin lightish blanket for a head. The taste is wet woodlike and strong. However, you would not think of it as high alky. This is much more mild and well behaved for 10 percent. Lower carbonation. Has a winish initial impression that leads to rotten fruity. Smooth without allot of offensiveness. Medium to thin lacing.  If this wasnt so intoxicating, I would almost say it was watered down. Very deceiving, cannot taste the alky after a few sips, must numb the taste buds. Cannot detect the lambic within.  Somewhat creamy at times. Interesting, dizzying and complex.  More manners than Weyers.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Musty, roasty, yeasty, earthy fruit and malt flavors. Cherry also comes through in the nose but is not over done.  Soapy fluffy bubbles. Quite good yet the sweetness puts me off.

Rated 2/4/06:  mmmm, mmmm, good! This is one of the best all around beers I have ever had the priveledge of drinking. A complex blend of flavors creates a wonderful taste that cant be completely described. Bought a 750ml bottle and poured into a merlot glass. This beer pours a nice color that resembles a fine mohogany. The head is like a fluffy cloud that sits atop a cherry sky. The aromas are chock full of malty sweetness, cherries and raisins can be detected along with caramel and other sweet malts. The aroma alone is enough to satisfy. The intense flavor is bursting with sweet malts complimented by cherries. Overall this beer is very smooth and drinks easily with much satisfaction. I cant wait to get another bottle, this is a must have.

Shared with gunso and theReverend.
dark amber brown with a nice lasting khaki head. nice lacing. chocolate toffee vanilla light cherry aroma. very nice. like a chocolate covered cherry.....or raison. sweet tart cherry flavor with nice chocolate covered raison and toffee notes. tart chocolate dried cherry finish with some toffee notes. medium to full body. moderate carbonation. this one surprised me. it seems like everyone i know hates this beer but i found it quite nice. interesting.
Very good beer. Very thick head. slight cherry flavor through out with a nice alcohol finish...a nice warming beer
Bottle. Pours a deep reddish brown with a light tan fluffy head. Nose is of alcohol with hints of cherries. Flavor is strong malts and light cherries with an alcohol finish.

Pours a very dark ruby with a tint of brown and a very thick, porous tan head. The head starts tight and thick and slowly gives way to larger bubbles until left with a thin, speckled foam - but the bubbles arent quite large enough to be called soapy. The aroma first hits with tart cherries and alcohol. Then it hits with malts, yeast, soft fruit (banana), and more alcohol. The beer starts off sweet and malty with a hint of sour fruit. The middle of the tongue picks up more soft fruit, malts, tart berries, and more alcohol. The Belgian character shines in the middle - lots of soft fruit, peppery malt profile, flavors of toffee, and just a hint of funk (brettanomyces I think). The finish is strangely dry and dusty (more brett?) with flavors of malts, roasted grain, and hints of cherries. The after-taste is sticky and sweetnsour on the back of the tongue (caramel-covered sour cherries), and it causes burps that taste like sour cherries, alcohol, and the dust off of an old, unread library book (not that I really know what that tastes like - but thats the image I get in my head when I try to identify the flavor). Though the alcohol is definitely noticable - in aroma, flavor, after-taste, and the quick buzz - the beer doesnt taste "boozey". The mouthfeel is medium in body and nicely lightened by the tight and soft carbonation. Overall, a very interesting beer. I dont think Id call it my "dream beer" (as would Noel Blake who, in essence, designed the beer), but it is very good.
2005 bottle. drank alone. alcohol got me by the time i finished. it really comes through as it warms up.  brown dried fruit flavors and bitey black pepper.

2006 Bottle from Specs, Kehma, TX; Nose of brown sugar, caramel, and cherries; Dark rusty cherry red with a big beige head; spritzy caramel taste with a twist of tartness and cherries. good but not my favorite quad! Not a Rochefort 10!
Bottle Dark red/amber pour with huge tan head and good lacing. Aroma of sweet fruits, mainly cherry, and some sweet malts. Flavor definately has a bit of lambic. Very well brewed beer.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2007 2006 750 ml bottle. Poured a dark amberish color with a tan colored head and nice lacing.  Aroma is of dark fruits, caramel, malts, and cherries.  Has a good kick as the alcohol is noticeable. A good mouthfeel where you can really taste the malts and cherries.  Nice finish to a good beer.
Very toasty flavour.  Heavy on the alcohol, but that might be more of the lambic coming through.  This is some good stuff

2006 750ml bottle. Pours a hazy dark amber with a large long lasting light tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of plums, cherries, caramel, and a hint of chocolate. Taste is sweet caramel and cherries with notes of plums, raisins, and chocolate. Med-full mouthfeel with a mild hop bitterness. The cherry lambic is a nice touch. Very good.

Corked 750 thanks to Ross. Pours a hazy deep amber red with a retentive, frothy camel colored head. Aroma of wheat malt, brown sugar, cherry, and plums. Initial flavor of cherries and wheat malt, that transitions to a very musty and yeasty middle. The finish is very aggressive and slightly "bitey", with a mix of alcohol, pepper, yeast, chalk, and more cherry. This one is a head scratcher. Some sips are good, and others are bad as this beer warms. It did give me a real good buzz though. Sleepy time!

2005 edition 750ml bottle.  Dark, with a thick tan head.  Sweet malt aroma, with a hint of wheat and cherries.  Smooth and rich tasting, with a full mouth feel.  The flavor is sweet and heavy, with malt, raisins and cherries.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: Cold 12oz bottle:  Pours a hazy amber color with a foamy tan head.  Aroma is of rich malts, dark cherries, spice, grass and alcohol notes.  Taste is of rich malts, dark fruit, spice, brown sugar, grass, earth, caramel....very complex!   Full bodied and smooth with lively carbonation.  Ending is of rich malts and honey notes with a slight alcohol burn.  Very nice!

A darker belgium.  Nice head.  "A malty bastard," as the beer guy at the local liquor store called it.  It has a little bite to it--over the entire tongue--which dissipates quickly, leaving a faint alcohol taste behind.  I barely taste the cherry lambic.  Good brew.

On tap at Mile Square in Hoboken. Very warming and sweet, but the tartness of the cherry lambic shines through.  Very drinkable, but not quite a session beer.  great for the winter, but during the spring / summer you might want to try their hennepin.
Pours amber/red, with a tan head. Aroma is cherries, and malt. Flavor is cherries, malt, brown sugar, and some oak/wood. Alcohol is pretty well hidden.

750 ml. corked bottle.Amber red color with a quickly dissapearing moderate head. aroma as expected of cherry and malt caramel. Quite carbonated on the palate. Lovely flavors with the cherry and belgian malt, and yeast. Very enjoyable beer.
Thanks for the sample Skyview.  Ice tea color with some cloudiness.  Sweet caramel and brown sugar on the nows.  Brown sugar and faint caramel in the body with a hint of sour cherry.

750ml caged and corked bottle,  2005 vintage.  Murky brown bottle with slight ruby-red highlights and a half an inch of light tan head.  Smells like raisin, roasty caramel and brown sugar.  Tastes like raisin, caramel, with a bit of a woody character.  Full creamy mouthfeel with a fair bit of carbonation.  Very well balanced and extremely drinkable.  By far and away one of the finest beers I have ever had the pleasure of having and the best Quad I have ever had.  Practically perfect in every way.

Pours a quite dark ruby colour..very smooth..has a nice amount of bitters..has a regal sweetness to it..lacing is low, but present..intriguing smell..quadrific!..cherries add a different twist...wl cross off.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2010 Dark mahogony with foamy tan head.  Smells of cherry flavored nailpolish slightly nutty.  Extremely complex flavor,  delicate roasted mal on one sidet,  hint of cherry lambic on the other.  Great beer... keeps you guessing.. i would have preferred lighter malts though.. .very good 7.5.8.5.17 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .[wow what a rating I gave this before =p]  2007 Bottle.  Pours a murky dull brown with a fizzy frothy cream colored head.  Aroma is doughy, tootsie-roll, trappist yeast, a slight bit of cherry acidity.  Flavor is much the same, bit nutty, doughy, yeasty, light bit of chocolate, light acidity, some faint cherry.  Warming booze. 7.4.7.3.14
12 ounce bottle.  Poured a nice reddish color with a white head.  Berry aroma.  Smooth, crisp, sweet, and altogether delightful.

Picked up a four pack of 12-oz bottles at Trigs liquor store in Wausau, Wisconsin. Pours a deep reddish brown brew with a thick white head and spotty lace. Aroma is like sweet sherry, sour cherries, caramel and brown sugar. Flavor is like fresh pumpernickel bread and sweet yeasty rye. A very sweet aftertaste. But wow, the alcohol is a bit high.

Its all about the raspberry lambic!!  Ive never seen in 12 oz bottles but thats what it came as.  Very pleasent smelling with a strong head and wonderful bold but sweet taste!  Been to the Ommegang Brewery in Cooperstown a great little place!

Bottled sample via my friend Trevor. Deep red in colour with some spritzy carbonation. Aromas of caramel, banana, cherry, red berries, grape, bubblegum, and a bit of booze. Flavors of old wood, cherry pits, earth, and a hint of sourness. This beer achieves a really nice balance between the malt and fruit flavors. Quite approachable for a quadrupel. Almost in the same class as Chimay Bleu or St. Bernardus.

There is a definite presence of cherry and alcohol to this interesting beer.  Actually, the flavors work well together and create this weirdly belgian fruit and alcohol monstrosity that tastes nothing of the 9.8 percent that it claims.  A good beer with a lot of character, but overall does not have the characteristics that endorse a higher rating.  Aroma is nice,  but not fantastic, flavor is the same way, and it just does not sit as well on the palate.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a toffee brown with adequate head.  Hints of cherry and figs in the nose.  Highly carbonated with a huge presence.  Medium sweet body with complex cherry, toffee and plums.  Very slight sourness adds to the character.  Lots going on in this beer.
This beer is nice and sweet with hints of dates and figs. Had on tap. Pours a reddish brown. Very sweet on the nose.

the quality cherry taste really goes over well with me. this beer has some substance and reveals itself in magic. gentlemans sipping beer great as a distraction. great mouthfeel. a really well made niche beer.

aroma of caramel and cherries.  a rich brown amber color with an ivory cream head with great lacing.  flavors of caramel amlt, toffee, and chocolate covered bing cherries.  very active in the mouth, really quie delicious.

Mature Oak, coffee and dark cherries dominate with some old banana and plums in the background. An anoying metalic twinge destroys this beer and probably comes with some bad use of bittering hops. Its a more sweet than sour combo with noticeable belgium beet candy, A dark and alcoholic brew which would have been great if i didnt feel the rust in my mouth.

(750mL bottle, brewed 2006, @FS HOU) Pours a dark red color ruby, light reddish head, diminishing.  Some sour cherry aroma, but hard to distinguish in the bar.  Sour, fizzy some cherry taste.  Floral, dark fruit like plums, only some cherry, weakish.  A dark heavy beer.

Bottle. 12 Fluid OZ.  Dark ruby brown color with small off-white head.  Can definitelely smell the cherry-lambic, but not too much, along with some malts. Good mouthfeel, carbonbation, and lacing.  Sweet flavor conceals the high alcohol level nicely.

Wow!  This is one impressive brew!  While you can just barely make out the taste of the cherry lambic, it gives this beer a complex taste that is extremely satisfying.  I must admit, due to to thickness and strength of the beer, one 12 oz bottle was enough for me.  Any more than that, and I would have needed a spoon to finish the rest.

12oz pour. Dark amber color with nice creamy tan head that disipates fast but laces nicely. Nose of sour cherries and lots of malt. Cheery disapears on the palate to be replaced by figs and Belgian candy. Cherries come back at the finish. The alcohol not even eveident, well hidden. This is  nice and complex for a American beer. Better than many made in Belgium. I would call this St Benardus little brother.
This is a good beer.  Although they say it has cherry lambic in it, I taste none of it.  Give it a try, you may like it.
user_location: The United States of Texas, Texas, USA

text:
Aroma: sourish, floral raspberry/cherry aroma, vanilla, powerful, malty... vaguely of hops... spicy liquoricelike yeast. 
Appearance: light yellow brown head that quickly sets...red like currant cordial w/ brown tone, slightly dim.  
Flavour: burnt malt profile, berry... sweet and slightly bitter in an elegant way... dry aftertaste. 
Palate: nice body w/ appearant co2... the more I drink the more I like it... thin yet full-bodied & slimy
Poured from 750ml bottle into a chalice glass.  Mahogany color with one finger off-white head.   Malty with subtle cherry flavor.  Very easy to drink.

doggy, musky, sweet aroma. solid beige head that doesnt go away, very thick. flavor is woody, some ripe fruits with a trace of sour. feels highly carbonated and goes down easy, warming feeling in the stomach. great stuff.
Brown pour with slight tan head with good lacing. Nose has sweet malts with fig, cherry, some apple and belgian yeast flavor. Nice carbontation and medium bodies mouth feel.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2008 Bottle at Winking Lizard. Medium brown in color with a light brown diminishing head and little lacing. Aroma was nice, malty and fruit filled. Flavor also good malt flavor with a nice blend of the cherry lambic. The lambic was not overwhelming, a good balance, that still tasted like an ale.
Rerate: 750ml 2005 vintage ($6 at Chucks).   Medium brownish orange color with small off-white head. Fruity aroma with cherry notes. Sour cherry and light malts. Not as good as I remember, but still okay.

vintage 2005; 750 mL bottle: Hue is a deep amber/mahogany coloring and gives a small head as an decoration. Nose is a sweet and chewy combination of caramel, toffee, flower, and light yeast. The drink has started to become flat but will onyl display minor notes of a big malts and spicey yeast. Sticky is the palate and the finish is wholesome with big alcohol presence.

Bottle. Sweet aroma, nice head, not too persistent, not overly carbonated. Felt a little thin in the palate for me. Sweet flavors dominate with spices and fruit mingling in as well. Overall a good Abt.

Bottle.   Pours a brownish ruby color with a thick creamy beige colored head.   Aroma is sweet malts, tart cherries, floral hops, raisins.   Flavor is tart cherries, malt, dried fruits, citrus.   Palate is medium bodied, highly carbonated, warming, dry finish.   Nice stuff, the cherry and the quad blend seamlessly!

Bottle. Reddish brown colour with a fine creamy head. Nice aroma of sweetness, berries, fruit, caramel and hints of alcohol. Nice tasty flavour of yeast, fruitness, malt, caramel, sweetness, spicy diacetyl and alcohol. Ends up very tasty endeed.
Pours an opaque, dark brown. Very smooth with velvety mouth-feel. Cherry aroma with some dates. The cherry mixes with milk chocolate in the mouth but is not really present in the aroma.

brewed in 2005  750 ml. bottle- color of deep reddish mahogany , with a thick frothy tan head - nose of malt , dark cherries , white flowers , and assorted red fruit   taste of deep red cherries , bitter chocolate , roasted , dried apricots , slightly sour , and milky - body is medium , and well carbonated  aftertaste of sweet/ sour , red fruit , berries , and hints of chocolate

Pours a really cloudy brown color with not much of a head at all. Aroma was of yeast, dark fruit, and a little sourness. Flavor was rich, yeasty, and fruity sweet. Cool concept to mix lambic and quad though.

Very lively mouthfeel with a taste that jumps out at you.  At first I was sceptical of the "cherry lambic infusion" but when I tasted it it works amazingly well.  It blends in very well with the rest of the beer, so well that I never would have picked it out if it wasnt on the bottle.  Highly recommended.

750 ml bottle - pours a clear dark ruby shade, kind of like youd imagine raspberry juice to be.  Sweet aroma of prune, fig, some light cherry and sour apple.  Flavours a bit more typically Belgian, yeasty, spicy, with a very faint hint of cherry that comes in right before the finish.  Also, a sort of dry twigginess in there as well.  Woodsy. Very delicate carbonation.  Nice.  Alcohol shows itself as the glass warms.  Good stuff - not great, but very good.

A smoggy sunset in San Francisco. Toasted amber. The clouds that dapple the sky other this fair city are pale brown, the most beautiful polution to date. These clouds cling and slide. The air smells of sweet loveliness, malt, almond alcohol and grapefruit. The flavor is mysterious. Beautiful malts. Cherry love. Subtle, light with a light dry finish. I cant wait to visit again.

Pours a dark raspberry brown with a large, brown, creamy head.  Relatively thick in the mouth.  Drier than i was expecting, with a strong yeast and pepper presence.  Cherry flavor does not hit right away, but rather develops a few seconds later.  A beer that does not overpower the tounge with cherry essence.

22oz bottle.  2006.  Aroma:  Light cherry and some raisins and plums.  Caramel, light spice, Belgian yeast, and very light chocolate.  Appearance:  Dark reddish brown in color and cloudy.  Light beige head was full and creamy with good retention.  Good lacing.  Flavor:  The cherries are subtle, but nice.  Raisins and plums, caramel, peppery spiciness, chocolate, belgian yeast, and some sweet candi sugariness.  Fairly dry finish with a little lingering sweetness.  Palate:  Medium-full bodied.  Medium-high carbonation.  Alcohol warming in back of mouth.  Overall:  Havent had this in awhile and I forgot how good it is.  The cherry and Quad pairs well together, without stepping on each other.

The aroma was caramel, oak and dark fruits when first poured.  Cherries, raisins and prunes came to mind with a subtle kick of alcohol. Dark caramel and a bit of chocolate existed in the aroma which was deeply complex. The beer poured into the chalice crystal clear deep amber with a dark tan head which rose well and lasted enough to lace the glass. The flavor was dark fruits, again raisins, prunes and dried cherries, with a strong earthy presence and a bit of peppery spice.
