The dark fruits and perhaps a hint of oak worked very well together and had a nice caramel aspect. The body was medium full and with a fairly high carbonation level, seemed a bit less. The finish was dry with a slightly tart acidity and a lasting light cherry impression long and dry into the aftertaste and beyond. The beer was nicely complex and interesting and the alcohol was restrained from start to finish with only mild warming after consumption. 750 ml bottle, Brewed 2004 on neck label - $6.79.
user_location: North of Raleigh, North Carolina, USA

text: UPDATED: MAR 23, 2007 Exploding tan head on top of a deep mahogany pour.  Nice aroma that is relatively unique with obvious hints of cherry and more subtle hints of chocolate and spice.  Very pleasant, smooth drink that gets much better as it warms...again, the cherry flavor is definitely there, but its not too overpowering to detract from the brew (not a big fan of cherry flavor, but this was very enjoyable)...plan on picking up one more 750 ml to cellar...definitely recommend, particularly at the price (comparable to brews twice its price!)

I like that the cherry flavor isnt overpowering, rather it is subtle. It has a kind of spritzy mouthfeel that is a little on the thin, but still very nice. The finish is dry and fragrant. Pretty good stuff. I was surprised.
UPDATED: MAR 16, 2007 Red amber color. Cherry in the aroma. Good medium body. Typical Belgian taste---but with a touch of cherry. Unique brew that I will try again.

Bottle: Pours a deep reddish color with a light tan head. Aroma, fruits, some yeast and some spices. Flavor, soft and smooth, some fruity notes, a trace of alcohol, some spice, a dry floral finish to it. Not bad.

Bottle, 2005.  Drank half the bottle the night before last, made the mistake of serving it too cold. First impression was not good, not pleasant at all. Drank the rest last night, served at about 60, much, much better. Cherry aroma. Flavor was a wonderful mix of cherry, chocolate and berrys. Very warming. Excellent !!!

Bottle, fresh.  Luscious faint cherry aroma with prunes/plums, light Belgian yeast in the corners.  Caramel, wood, and lots of malt.  Red berries and a touch of chocolate.  Lightly sweet nose on the whole.  Dark red body with a short, sticky beige head.  All notes of the aroma are accounted for here, but the taste is much dryer and slightly more alcoholic than expected.  Cherries seem to darken.  Full peppery body with a velvety-smooth malt feel, bone-dry warming finish with light woody hops and just a hint of Belgian yeast.  Superb, classy offering.
Apricot in color.  Very little head.  Great balance.  Nice amount of malt and alcohol.  My wife said honey wheatish.
Scent of oak and cherries.Tastes like oak, vanilla, malt, and cherries.Tastes like a juice not a beer. Similar to Juicy Juice. Very smooth. One of my favorites

Pours a reddish brown color with a light tan head.  I smelled cider and dark cherries on the nose of this beer.  The taste is amazing, like a good trappist Abt/Quad.  I tasted cherries and malt when I sipped it.  Three Philosophers has a great mouthfeel that sticks around a while after you swallow.  You can definitely taste the cherries for a while.  Not as good as Rochefort or St. Bernadus, but pretty damn close.  I would highly recommend this beer.

Pours a muddy-type brown color, with a quickly dissipating head.  Aroma is almost cidery, with a significant alcohol pinch.  The flavor is about as described on the bottle -- 98% abt, with about 2% tart cherry zing.  The beer finishes more dry, and leaves a mild tart aftertaste.  The carbonation is sharp, making the beer kinda light on the palate.  Not bad.
Pours a murky brown. Head was an inch thick on pour. Lacing is long lasting. The taste is of caramel or vanilla. The mouthfeel is very creamy and tasty! Great aftertaste. I love this beer.

750ml. Bottle
Poured into Ommegang goblet
2005

Three Philosophers poured a muddy copper. Bright ruby highlights when held to the light. There was 1 finger off white head that faded fairly quickly to a light sprinkling of foam along the top. Looks like it will be very flavorful. Kind of mysterious and inviting. I cant wait to see what flavors will come out of this.

When I popped the cork I smelled the bottle and it smelled exactly like a chocolate covered cherry. When poured into the glass a lot more scents came along. I still smell the chocolat although it did die down slightly. Theres damp soil, spice from the yeasts, a sweetness, and cherries coming through faintly at the end. For some reason every now and then Ill smell it and get scents I associate with a spiced cider but only occasionally.

The taste is really good. Theres so much going on its hard to describe but Ill give it a shot. There is a punch in the mouth right up front which quickly mellows into all kinds of flavors. Im picking up sweet malts, an earthiness/musty, spice, chocolate every now and then, and cherries. I pick up something new with every drink. As it warms theres a touch of alcohol. Just enough so it warms your throat. Very complex.

The mouthfeel is perfect. Velvety and creamy. A nice touch of carbonation. Hits quickly and vanishes. Coats my mouth and is slick as I drink.

Drinkability is ridiculous. This beer is so smooth and so easy drinking for a 9+%. 

Sampled 10/2/06
Cloudy reddish brown. Sweet, fruity aroma. Medium bodied. Taste is a complex assortment of sweet notes, with only mild bitterness and slightly alcoholic finish.

Pours out (from 12 oz bottle) a murky dark brown with an aroma of the usual, malts, brown sugars, vanilla with a slight hint of hops.  Forms small, quickly dissipated foam head.  Very smooth flavor, vanilla malts with cherries and figs.  This beer lives up to the hype.  Alcohol is not evident, as the flavorful malts and carbonation make this a fine ale.
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: One of the best beers I have ever had. Aroma is nice, pour is great with a dark brown appearance. This beer is incredibly smooth, with a sweet aftertaste. The flavor is great, a nice quad with a sampling of kreik. Oh what an excellent beer. Drank in a Westmalle glass, which gave its thin nice head that disappated.

Deep, yeasty-hazed reddish-brown pour, with an initial froth head, diminishes to a mere ring.  Alcohol, vanilla, a definitive cherry lambic and confectioners sugar to the nose.  I was honestly expecting more malty substance to this, instead of relying on a thin palate of (close to cloyingly sweet) malt with a cherry lambic back.  What is supposed to register as a complementary flavor palate instead ends up contradicting itself somewhat, ending with a hollow and unfinished character.  The vinegar and peppered alcohol finish, which isnt terribly out of character for the rest of the offering, leaves me somewhat like the rest of the brew, non-satiated.  Again, the fruity esters, mild sweet malt (muddy and indistinct) and alcohol are present, but Im afraid the substance of palate just doesnt live up to my expectations.  I would feel somewhat remiss giving a "higher than deserved" rating, just because this happens to be a higher ABV brew, and released by a decent brewer.  Not a terrible beer at all, mind you, just a bit out of balance and lacking of substance for the style.
Murky red brown with nice light colored head. Oak, vanilla, and cherry and malt. My favorite quad so far

Looked like cola except for a giant spongy head.  Aroma of vanilla, oak, sugar, yeast, malt, and hops.  Flavor was very similar and very well blended.  Smooth on the palate.  The finish was wonderful with oak and mild hop bitterness.  This was a very enjoyable quadruple, one that I will definitely add into a regular rotation.

750 ml bottle.  Poured a dark and murky reddish brown with a fizzy, almost cola-like beige head.  Turns a brighter ruby color after some settling.  Sweet cookie malt aroma with dried cherry, raisin, yeast, spice and herbs.  Bittersweet dark bread and cakey malt flavor with a slight sourness.  A bit of spice and peppercorn throughout as well.  Yeast noticeable on the finish, though alcohol is well covered.  Medium bodied with fine carbonation.  Pretty good overall, but not one of my go-to styles.
750 bottle 2005 pours out a very dark red topped with a nice off white head. A sweet aroma of vanilla and some pit fruit maybe. Tast is nice and sweet very good

Immediate nose of lemon, sour cherry and yeast.  Softly sedimented, luminous volcanic red color.  Aromas of vanilla oak, brown sugar and hay arrive with time.  Only a mild hint of sour cherry leads the flavor, more of the dried type that makes cereal more interesting than something powerfully acetic.  Cinnamon and dry black tea with honey.  Ruined to some degree by a degenerate palate that is surprisingly thin and sawdusty, becoming virtually lifeless far too quickly.

Bottle brewed 2006. Amber/ruby color, large off white head. Sweet bubblegum aroma with spicy yeast scents. Strong flavor balanced by spicy hop character. Cherries hard to detect, slight fruitiness, raisin, caramel. Somewhat dry and with a bite. Didnt have a sour edge or tartness I expected. Maybe lacking in complexity but smooth for the acohol content.

What a different beer! This is my first abt/quad and my first offering from Ommegang. Where have I been!!?? The pour was a beautiful red/burnt orange with a thick puffy off white head what didnt lace much. The taste was a carbonated mix of cherry, malt and caramel. This was not as sweet as I feared. Beautiful all around!
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Great Quadrupel.  Very familiar with Ommegang, as I am a huge baseball fan and always am quick to sample from Cooperstowns finest.

Bottle.  Small off-white head that dissapated very quickly after pour.  Speaking of pour, it has a unique color of hazy red, black, and brown.  Aroma is very malty with sweet fruits (cherries).  Complex flavor - malty with a cherry kick.  Alcohol is well hidden.  Different than any of the quads that I have tried but good.
Bottle.  Pours an orange-red with a bubbly head, I didnt pick up much aroma, malty with a hint of dark cherry, a touch sour.  Worth buying again.
Pours an attractive ruby-amber with minimal head. Full malty body with subtly complex sweet flavors, rounded out with a distinct note of cherry. That 9.8% ABV is completely hidden. Tasty stuff.

This beer is a muddled haze of red-orange-brown topped with a thin white head that quickly vanishes. (SRM: 17?)  The aroma is of smooth sweet grain and malt-- a tight and solid smell.  It is quite full-bodied and very smooth!  It is a lightly sweet roll of grain with a delicately bitter bite  that finishes roundly with a subtle sour cherry.  Nice!
Pours a dark brown, with a thick tan head.  Aroma is a bit yeasty and roasty.  Very, very drinkable, the cherry lambic is subtle and the flavors are not overpowering.

Pours a nice dark amber color, with a suprisingly white foam head. The smell was simple, yet strong. Nothing really stood out. The taste was very refreashing and had a solid maltiness to it. Very very good flavor that went down smooth with a nice after taste.

2004 bottle. Pours a hazy, yeasty, dark amber or light brown.  Medium white head.  The smell on this one isnt very big.  Some dark malts, and roastiness detected along with a hint of citrus in there as well.  For a quadrupel, its pretty interesting.  Slight dourness detected, along with some dark fruits, and malts.  Pretty sweet in the finish.  A little different than other quads Ive had, but its an American brewery trying one, and a damn good one in Ommegang.

Pours a carmel brown with a slight sweet cherry, malty  aroma. Plesent!
Lightly carboniiated. Not a hint of alcohol. Very enjoyable. A great after dinner drink.
A very solid offering. The cherries are very subtle, and complement the nice caramel malt and fizziness. Not too sweet either.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2007 Pours a beautiful dark cherry color with a medium sized light brown head.  Nice sweet aroma with traces of cherry.  Flavorful and complex taste with a nice dry finish. A great, smooth beer.

Just tasted this 2005 bottle.  Pour is a clear dark reddish brown.  Tan head and nice lacing.  Sweet malt, caramel, dark fruit, and cherry nose.  The sweet dark cherry flavor is there, with caramel, malt,  and dark fruit.  No noticable sourness or bitterness, maybe the few years have tamed it.  Nice smooth mouthfeel, and very drinkable for the abv.  Interesting brew, quite enjoyable.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2007 Jan. 22, 2007; 750ml bottle; 2006 ed.  First-ever tasting of this local offering.  Wasnt sure Id like this after reading about the lambic portion of an unusual recipe.  It almost works, but there is still disharmony here, with more sour fruit/cherry than I want to taste in this otherwise excellent brew.  The alcohol is also a bit more prominent than it seems to be in the very best examples of the style.  May be an acquired taste.

Re-rate on Apr. 2, 2007: Well, if this is an "acquired" taste, Ive certainly acquired it.  This is a best American example of a Quad Ive yet tried.  Just wonderful, and I now pick up it every chance I get.  A bottle of this is an excellent partner for a "chill session with a good film or couple of CDs.  Definitely planning a pilgrimage to the brewery in nearby Cooperstown this summer.
2005 Bottle. Hazy red-brown. Aroma of yeast and cork. A not too carbonated. Complex aroma of malt, yeast and cherries

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2007 Im quite fond of this beer.  While Im a big fan of sour cherry (Kriek) flavor, I think it can easily become overpowering. Fortunately, the yeasty-ness of this beer balances out the initial sour-sweetness beautifully. While other raters have argued that this beer lacks complexity, Im very unconvinced. For me, there are a few key elements -- Kriek flavor, sourness, and a hoppiness that remaines throughout the taste -- and these flavors create an exceptionally balanced beer.  A pretty great beverage and one of my favorites, especially for its inexpensive price tag.

750 shared with brie.  This one reminds me of going to an Allman Brothers concert a couple of years ago.  I love the sweet and complex quads from Belgium and I have always enjoyed beers from Ommegang over in NY.  This is a very unique take on the style with a light mouth feel and the subtle cherry flavor melted into the rich malt.  This beer is unique and always brings back good memories.

This pours a deep auburn color with a very pungent aroma.  Sweet cherries and butterscotch hide the alcohol flavor very well.  Also a hint of smokey wood and hazelnut.  I found this to be very drinkable and enjoyable and I highly recommend it.  Num nums.

Cloudy deep amber colour with a small dense tan head. Malty, sweet aroma with notes of caramel and fruit and vague hints of yeast. Malty, sweet and light buttery flavor. Finish is fruity and vague alcohol sweet.

I really dont care for this beer. To me the cherry flavor is overpowering. If beers are flavored tastefully they can and be quite good but it this case I got the impression I was drinking  an  Dr Pepper with alcohol. Lots of carbonation lots of cherry little to cause one to drink it a second tim,e, or in my case to finish the first bottle.

Pours a murky ruddy brown, topped by about three quarters of an inch of soft tan foam. Okay head retention, good lacing. Light malt and nice tart fruit in the aroma, with a touch of alcohol and yeast.

Tasty strong toffee malt, brown sugar, and molasses flavor blends exceptionally well with a nice tart cherry flavor. Cherry tartness becomes more prominent in the finish, with a touch of hoppy bitterness. Medium full body, smooth and gentle carbonation.

(Bottle 75 cl) Pours a slightly hazy, reddish amber with a creamy, off-white head. Fairly complex aroma of yeast, overripe fruit and diacetyl. Full-bodied with fruity notes, sherry-like and again some diacetyl. Almost no bitterness. Interesting. 080107

Bottle. Hazy dark red-brown colour with an average head. Quite sweet caramel and alcoholic aroma, citrus and wheat. Flavour of caramel, roasted malts, bit yeasty, plums, chocolate, bit smokiness, alcohol.

Vintage 2005.  Pour is a dark a transluscent brown-amber color; head is average, off-white, and pillowy while being mostly diminishing and leaving a very tight, creamy lace.  Nose is somewhat subdued for a quad, but very pleasant; notes of rum-soaked-cherries, carmelized raisins, brown sugar, plum, and slight yeast and oak.  Flavor is interesting and wildly unique; its almost like the lamic and the quad are competing, but somehow the flavors are unique enough to make it all worth while.  Cherry is prominant but never overpowering, other notes of carmelized raisin, tart cherry notes, more oak than the nose would have suggested, slight herbal, light sourness, light coffee notes, maybe some toasted grain.  Palate is medium full, very lively, and prickly and a little syrupy in texture.  Finshes average length and mostly sweet with more oak, tart cherry, and the herbal/earthy funky bitterness of the lambic.  Good solid beer, with intriguing qualites from the cherry lamic and the quad.  The lambic and the quad are not really complimentary but they do find qualities in there to make the beer pleasant to drink.  Definately unique and unlike any other quad Ive had.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2013 Pours an beautiful amber color with ruby red highlights and an off white, fluffy head.  The tartness of the cherries come through right off the bat. Malt sweetness, slight oak notes, and a touch of alcohol round out the awesome aroma.  The flavor starts out like the aroma with the cherry tartness.  The oak is a little more noticeable in the flavor as well.  This beer finishes with a slight alcohol warming and more tart bitterness.  The flavor is very original and complex.  I enjoyed this to no end.  Will have again.

Pours an amber color with a ruby redness on the outside with an off-white head.  Aroma is of cherries, other dark fruits, sweet malts, and a hint of wood an alcohol.  Starts off very tart but settles down to the more subtle flavors of the caramel and oak.  Finishes with some alcohol warming and bitterness. Very impressed with this brew.

2005 vintage, from a caged corked 750 ml. bottle with a blurb along the right side of front label, serving and cellaring instructions on the back label, sampled at a cooler cellar temperature in a chalice.

Poured cherry red hued cola brown with fluffy, foamy tan head that settled into a thin sudsy lacing, small amount of ringed, laced sticking.

Aromas of sweet caramel, candied sugar and cherry lambic, minty herbs and whiffs of sweet alcohol.

Good, steady carbonation and a crisp, textured, creamy smooth full bodied mouthfeel.

A nice mix of sweet maltiness, sourness from the lambic and a hop bite at end, sweet caramel, Belgian sugariness, toasted grainy malts, a soft sour cherry, the alcohol is kept in the background and provides a subtle warming presence in the palate, towards the end a light herbal hoppiness that provides a slight cleansing bitterness, and a dry toasted, earthy malty finish with the herbs and caramel reemerging in the aftertaste.

A wonderful, tasty, complex ale, a pleasure to drink, great with dark chocolate.
___

A/4 S/4 T/4 M/4.5 D/4

Vintage 2006, from a 750 ml. bottle, the labels appear to same as the 2005.

Much more minty herbal in the aroma, some earthy mustiness as well, more solvent in the alcohol scent.

The toasted maltiness is more in the forefront, taste is bit more earthy, the sour dark cherry is more at the edges, the herbal hop bitterness is a bit rougher in the palate and is more a green herbal, the alcohol has a slight solvent flavor, more warming in the mouth, a bit less dry in the finish.

On the limited sampling Ive taken tonight with my girlfriend, this is a quadrupel that improves with a little aging, smoothes out and becomes more balanced.

[Bottled, January 2007] Very deep reddish brown appearance. Medium airy head. Woody and cherry aroma. Tastes like cherry and berries mixed with champagne. Strong champagne feeling. Finish is more oakey/wood.

750ml bottle 2005 edition.  pours an amber brown color with a foamy head.  Aroma is sweet with a hint of cherry.  A very smooth  , easy drinking beer with an amazing sweet caramel malty flavor with just a hint of cherry detected, but only when really paying attention.  Excellent beer, one of my personal favorites.

Pours a medium to thin head with lazy lacing.  Similar malty nose to regular ommegang abbey ale but with a hint of cherries.  Sweet caramel body with sherry like estery tones. Lambic well balanced and not overpowering.  Alcohol seems more like 7% instead of the 9.6%.  The use of power tools is not advised, although you may feel like you can fix anything....you still cant.

nice reddish brown appearance with light brownish white head.  scent is of cherry.  the flavor begins malty then finishes with such a strong cherry flavor that it overshadows any possible complexities of the beer.  too sweet

Cloudy red brown with light fizz.  Light sour-sweet aroma.  Can taste both a bit of abbey ales dark fruits and a lot of cherry lambic, very well-hidden alcohol.  Not much body or finish, but interesting mix, though lambic overpowers abbey a bit.

UPDATED: APR 7, 2007 Bottle. Pours cloudy mahogany with a huge head, turning rocky. Good lacing. Aroma of dark fruits, brown sugar and cherries. Very sweet, hard candy taste. Also can taste alcohol,  raisins and cherries. Heavy to medium body. Sticky texture. Long, sweet finish.
Dark brown pour with creamy brown head. initial aromas of cherry and coffee, great mouthfeel with light zezty finish

I really need to remember my feelings about Belgian ales.  I go in with the highest of expectations only to feel let down.  This 2006 version poured a dark ruby chocolate with a creamy brown head.  It smelled of malt and alcohol.  The flavour was heavily alcoholic and only at the end could I detect the smallest amount of cherry ( 2% cherry lambic will do that, I guess).  I am glad I had this but I wont have it again.

750ml bottle, 2006 edition - poured reddish brown with a decent off-white/tan head on top. Colour is fairly nice. Aroma is Belgian malt, some yeastiness, dark fruit, cherries, all of it a little subdued. The flavour amps this up however, and is really quite sweet, but doesnt all add up in the best way. Vinous and port like, sweet with dark fruit, but the addition of cherry lambic creates a weird funkiness, a sort of sickly tart quality. Hard to describe, but sort of "rotten" lingering in the middle. Its not overtly cloying however, and doesnt spoil the drink, but is still a bit off-putting. Quite boozy as well, but this could have to do with the fact that bottle is still quite young. Palate is okay. It would probably improve well with age, but I wont know because this isnt something Ill likely pick up again. Certainly not bad, just not my thing. Sort of felt like an interesting experiment that just doesnt quite work. Fine and decent, but not great or overly special.
Bottle:  Pours a reddish color with a nice tan head.  I did not notice any cherry aroma and very little in the taste.  That said... this is not bad, just not what I was looking for.

OK! Great Belgian malt nose, and taste. I love the hint of cherry in this. Lively mouthfeel. Slight peaty notes as well. Moist soil? Perhaps. Everything about this brew is distinctly belgian, however the water, its the WATER that you can tell is American.

12 oz bottle. Id read the mixed reviews of this and had wanted to try it for quite a long time - finally found one. Poured an appealing ruby hue with a very large foaming khaki head. Aroma was nice-ish, with a cherry component to go with a very mild phenol. The flavor was a big disappointment though - an initial sweetness that hinted at classic Belgian ale, with a touch of cherries, followed by a brief tartness - but then it settled into an unusually bitter finish that seemed very out of place. Also the palate was rather thick and dull, heavy. No liveliness, and lacking carbonation despite the huge head. Really a poor mouthfeel, especially for a beer this big and flavorful.
Poured from 12oz. bottle into tulip glass. Good color, head and aroma. Cherry flavors dominate aroma and taste. Decent finish.
leather, brown, lightly bitter, full body, creamy, lively, long finish, full body,
Beatiful colour and head from bottle pour. Delicious flavour love the lambic touch. Could this beer be anymore delicious?

Poured a dark ruby gold. The smell is very sweet with notes of anise and cherry. Very sweet taste combining raisins, clove, apricot, and fig. The flavors linger around for a while after swallowing. A relatively smooth palate round out this beer nicely.

rather grainy, pretty opaque appearance.  pretty good head. some cherries upon aroma, but it generally isnt that great.  ill say its colder than it should be.  not much happening in the flavor.  little cherries, but nothing that really draws me in.  nothing in the finish at all.  almost feels like some off-tastes.

rerate: not at all a quad despite plenty of cherry character.  way too empty in flavor, and not enough flavor for what it wants to be.   i taste cherries, some hops and not a lot of belgian.

750 ml bottle, pours a deep, cloudy mahogany with a thick head.  Rich fruity aromas laced with a yeasty smell.  Creamy mouthfeel that allows the delicate, almost port like, flavors coat the mouth.  Raisins, dried stone fruits and of course the subtle spice from the yeast.  Nice finish for an overall very good beer.
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text:
Beer pours a dark ruby brownish color. With a half inch head that has good retention. Beer looks good just in the glass.
It has a sort of a "wine" smell to the nose. There is some fruity undertones with the obvious representation of alcohol.
Taste is incredibly creamy and smooth with a good amount of carbonation in the mouthfeel.
There is a good amount of cherry coming out midway through the taste. This is a really good beer. The alcohol was quite apparent in the nose, but nowhere to be found in the taste. Absolutely no burn.
This is a fine offering from Brewery Ommegang and at a price point that makes it a very easy buying decision.
If you have access to this beer, it is a must try. This will be a regular in my beer rotation.

750ml bottle via my Secret Santa - Thanks! - Pours dark red with a short tan head that fades back to a ring pretty quickly.  Good aroma of cherry, candi sugar, raisin, caramel, and some vanilla.  Flavor blends wonderfully sour cherries with sweet candi sugar, caramel, raisin, and vanilla and oak notes.  Sticky palate that is pleasant in the mouth.  no sign of alcohol.. This is nice..

Pours dark reddish amber with a thin, mostly receding tan head. Aroma of sticky tart cherries, fruity esters, and cough syrup. Taste is syrupy cherry, dark candy, and caramelized wort. Mouthfeel is full bodied with lively, foamy carbonation. Too sweet and candyish. Not exactly an exciting Quad yeast, also dont appreciate the artificial-tasting cherry lambic.

UPDATED: FEB 29, 2008 Very good brew. Has hints of cherries,nuts, has very nice woody aftertaste. Pours a dark brown with a nice head. Thumbs up
Second Rating
Really great beer. Not too expensive very full bodied beer that has hints of cherries. Easy to drink. Excellent!!!!

Bottle- this brew pours out a fizzy, cloudy, muddy brown. The head last a long time starting off a bit brownish to finish off a nice tan white. I cant get over the smell butter scotch, banana, and vanilla. You know what a tootsie roll taste like? This is the same after taste with a bit of oak aged hops. The yeast seems to absorb some of the taste when you bite into this beer.

2004 edition.  Poured a cloudy mahogany with a small fizzy light tan head.  Aroma is complex and consists of yeast, pepper, cherry pie, molasses.  Flavor is subtle and dry, with notes of brown sugar, cherry cough medicine, and a hint of acidity.  Finish is quite dry and carries with it a slight unfortunate metallic character.  Body is full with a moderate, if not slightly aggressive, level of carbonation.  Definitely a good beer with its share of ups and downs.  Im wondering if aging has hurt the beer, making it too dry.

First off if anyone knows where I can find this in AL beermail me.  The beer pours well (provided you know how, one of my pints looked lovely the other not so much).  It has a nice 2 plus finger head that has a creamy color, and sustains rather well.  Most of the sweetness comes from the cherry lambic and caramel malts, but there is a hint of citrus.  The sweetness is offset by the bitterness of the hops, which is not overwhelming, but balanced.  As I was about halfway done the caramel seemed more apparent, but your nose would be buried in the glass with the nice aroma of the cherries.  Nice and smooth and a pleasure to pour and drink!
GBof A PA-750 ml bottle-pours no head and cloudy brown color.  Aroma is dark fermented fruit.  Taste is dark fermented fruit, dark malt.  Good effervescence.
Very similar flavor to Ommegang, although slightly more of a fruit flavoring. A rudy hazed appearance with a cherry maly flavoring.

750 ml 2005 bottle.  Pours a dark brownish-red.  Aroma of malt and fruit.  Flavor is rich, roasted malt, caramel, and cherry, with a slight alcoholic presence in the finish.  Bitter aftertaste.  Overall a very solid offering from Ommegang.
Bottle at "American Tasting #2". Clear brown - offwhite head. A lot of dried fruits/berries. Plums, raisins, cherry, licorice, winey, sweet, lovely yeasty, sourish. Very nice.

Bottle. Pours a hazy brownish colour with an off-white head. Malty yeasty spicy flavor. Sweet malty, roasted flavor with some fruity acid hints and some weak hints of cherry. Long malty bitter aftertaste.
Nice full flavor of roasted malt and interesting fruit mixture (citrus-cherry-others).  Sweetness and alcohol mix well with other flavors and create an inviting experience.

Overall, Ive been underwhelmed by Ommegangs beers, but this one is excellent. Pours a dark, murky brownish red with a thin, off-white head. Aroma is sweet malt, candied sugar and a dash of cherries. Flavor is rich: roasted malt, maybe a touch of oak, sweet and fruity with just an undercurrent of cherries. Solid and full-bodied on the palate. very, very nice.

This is a personal favorite.  Have had it periodically, but never rated it.  This beer pours a caramel brown color with an off-white head.  Aroma of fruit, and roasted  malts.  Taste is complex with roasted malts, orange and other fruits blending together with a slight alcohol after taste.

Pours very dark bronze with a bubbly tan head.  The aroma has some sweet Belgium malt, some earthiness and bits of fruit that is somewhere between cherry and orange.  Medium / full body with a lot of fizzy carbonation and some cloyingness.  The taste starts with a dirty malt taste that is quickly overtaken by earthy yeast and malt along with some sour fruitiness, cherries and vinegar.  The finish has a spicy flash, tart cherries and a crispness that is not normally associated with a quad.  Nice different take on the style.

Beer #100!  Chosen because it was a) a style I havent rated, b) a highly regarded product, and c) in my collection!  2005 vintage, 750 mL bottel.  App.: pours deep red-burgundy brown with small flecks of yeast.  A slightly reddish-beige head.  Aroma: some roasted malts, cherries, dried fruits, 
Palate: not much carbonation, but whats there is fairly fine and sharp.  Med., slightly syrupy mouthfeel.  Flav.: butterscoth, those roasted malts, some cherry, dried fruit and spice, a light sweetness.  A warm, slightly alcoholic finish.  Overall, a very pleasant experience!

Aroma of sweet malt, coco bitterness, some spice and clove hints from the yeast and a tart cherry fruitiness. A firm, lasting, off white head tops the brown body interlaced with red highlights. Malty sweetness up front, followed by cherry cough syrup, and a hint of mustiness. Left a candy coating in my mouth. A interesting beer... would like to see more sourness and less sweetness though.

2003 Vintage courtesy of Rob. Enjoyed after a weekend of heavy alcohol consumption. Thanks RooftopRogue! Notes of cherry and vanilla on the nose lead into candied citrus, brown sugar, fig, and leather. Could probably go a few more years as there was plenty of hop bite left to it. Thanks again, Rob!

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2008 750 by the kind hand of BitBucket. Thanks! Reddish brown body with a big tan head. Super orange/citrus nose, maybe a little black tea in there as well. Sharply bitter on the attack and all through the palate, but the bitter tastes more like lemon pith than the less-player hop note it brings along. Definite cherry note in the mid-palate as it warms. Good stuff but so oddly bitter that it might be tough to get in the mood for.Had an 05 tonight, that Marcs generous friend Matt aged pretty much by accident for 3 years. Wow, it was phenomenal. Port-like nose, whisper-soft body, lots of gentle and complex fruit notes layered elegantly atop one another. This beer should not be drunk fresh.

750ml bottle. Aroma of apples and cherries. Full body and light carbonation. Lots of chewy malt balanced by a really nice sweet/tart taste with fruit, cherries, nuts. Maybe a bit astringent in the finish.

A blend of a belgian ale with a cherry-lambic. Works very well. The cherry flavor is just enough, and not overbearing. Wonderful palate and balance, even with the sweetness. Close to a dessert beer, but suitable for every day drinking.

When I tried this, I was certain that this beer was a Beligian beer. It was only when I cam to this site did I realize that it was in fact an American beer. Really, it is an excellent imitation, with a very strong taste (I think it was the strongest beer I had tried to that point) and an intensely complex flavor. Poured it and a huge head came up next to a nice and dark body. Definately had a really fruity flavour (more so than the other beers of this style that I tried), apparently it is mixed with a lambic, so that would explain it. Strong complex taste with a very nice palate. Will probably try this again some time in my life, as it is always sold at Varsity Pizza.

Millenium Hotel, Durham.  Deep red, thin, short-lived head.  I am not a big fan of lambics, but found this hybrid delicious.  Black cherry, candy, faint alcohol aroma. Sweet more than sour, black cherry, malty, old leather, full mouthfeel.  A real winner!

Pours a nice hazy ruby with a decent head.  Nosea little to lambic for me and I was  worried about this as I dont usually like lambics.  But this quad did not dissapoint.   Bread,  yeast,  raisins, cherry, and oak all roll  around on the tongue.  Nice bite at the end, good solid mouthfeel.  And best of all the name. A keeper.

12 oz. bottle - Stumbled into this one at a local  homebrew shop where they had a few in a fridge (set at 50ish temp).  First taste you have is of belgian ale, which is what Ommegang is known for. The label indicates its mixed with cherry lambic. There is some flavor of cherry lambic, but not what youd expect if it was a full on lambic with no ale added to it. The lambic nose can be found in the glass. Very fine head that mainatins a bit even after starting to drink it. Cloudy beer. It had been i my fridge for a couple of weeks so it shouldnt have been much in the way of shaking it up and there was a fair amount of yeast still in the bottle. Nice ruby color. Alcoholly aftertaste on the pallate as would be expected of this beer, which lingers with a light raisin-apple flavor. I can see how someone might consider this their "dream beer." I like Belgians and every once in awhile (due to cost) I enjoy a lambic. Mixing the two together is pretty cool, especially since it was though of by a homebrewer!! BTW: The label says Ommegang is a member of the Duval family of beers. Hadnt heard that before.

12 oz Bottle -   Not a big fan of this one... i dunno i prefer a real belgian quad.. pours a reddish brown... with a fluffy tan head..  smell is sweet alcohol.. def a good beer for the winter.. but just didnt do anything for me..

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2007 Sampled with Stegosaurus and beerded_one at Newtown brewfest. Absolutley fantastic.Pours a reddish brown. Aroma of molasses and dark malt sweetness. Taste of Belgian spices and yeast. Really melts in your mouth. Good body, good brew!

UPDATED: APR 12, 2007 Pours a velvety, deep orange mohogany color w/ full semi creamy froth. Aroma of baked fruit rollup and metal. Full nectar w/ ample residual effers. Flavor profile starts w/ a huge malty backbone and ripe black cherries. Throw in some dried stone fruit, leather, aged apple, oak, fig. finish is long and fruity w/ a nice bittering that takes a bit to settle in. Becomes more herbal w/ tobacco as it warms. Semi sweet. Alcohol is undetectable. Nice brew.
I did not love this.  Thied the 05 bottle.  Very heave carbination and no head to speak of.  Not a lot of flavors going on and not very much like a Belgium.

750ml bottle. Pours orange with a large white head. Aroma of black cherry and Trappist style maltiness and yeastiness. Taste is much the same, alcohol is present but not overwhelming. Mouthfeel is creamy but a bit dry. A good blend, but not something I would actively seek.

This stuff was ok. I think it might be a little overrated. I dont pick up the cherry flavor as much as I thought I would. Of course I only got to try a sample of this so I think I would like to come back a re-rate it after I get a bottle of this.

Bottle.  This is one of the few perfect beers to me.  I cant describe the joy this beer brings to me.  Theres only one other beer Ive had that is this amazing and that is Weyerbachers Quad.  This has a thick maople syrup appearance with a strong, sweet, honey and alchoholic aroma.  The taste is just too complex and original to compare to anything else. I want to marry it.

750mL Brewed in 2005 from NachlamSie.  Pours a hazy orange red with a one finger yellow beige head.  Aroma of figs, brown sugar, very yeasty, dust, chocolate covered cherries (though not terribly strong), candy sugar, and alcohol.  Flavor is a lot more candied sugar and yeast, then some chocolate and alcohol.  Also has some oakiness to it.  I cant pick out the cherries in the taste.  Some of the darker fruits and other characteristics of this kinda remind me of a good dubbel--maybe Im just a big fool though, too.  Highly carbonated, medium to full bodied.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: burnt copper color thick dense tan head w/ great lacing.  Aroma of alcohol bread, belgian yeasts and hints of light fruits.  Palate is well coated and sticky.  Flavor is extremly sweet lots of candied sugars and carmels some breads and other grains and a warm alcohol in the swallow.  Pretty good stuff.

Poured a clear dark ruby color witha thick lasting tan head and good lacing.  Aromas of chocolate, cherries, fig, and spices.  Flavor is very deep and rich.  A spiced cherry cordial would be a good start but would not accurately describe the complex flavors.  Mouthfeel is smooth and rich though not enough to be cloying.  An absolutely fantastic beer.

2005 vintage 750 mL.  Pours to a deep reddish mahogany body with a lasting light beige/gray head.  Nice lacing.  The aroma is yeasty, raisins, earthy mace and some other spices, prunes on the back end mixed with cherries.  A lingering dry yeasty spice is in the flavor.  Tart cherries, yeasty dark lagery malt, dark fruit, did I say yeasty?  Light molasses and bitter powder chocolate.  Dry and tart palate that seems chalky or something like that.  Astringent?  Perhaps thats just the yeast.  Very hidden alcohol content.  The more I drink this and the more it warms up, the more I like it and keep re-rating it.

Tap at Concordia.  Deep brown in color, a bit opaque.  Nice sized off-white head and nice lacing left behind.  Prunish aroma with just a hint of what I percieve as smoke.  Body is a little light for what I was expecting/wanting.  Pit fruit flavors, sweetish with a nice carbonation.  Overall, very nice.

12 oz bottle. Pour is crimson/brown with a small white head. Ive had the bigger bottles every other time, and I usually get a bigger head with those. This one was minimal and faded fast. aroma is yeasty, sweet malt--a lot like many of the quads i have enjoyed--with notes of tart cherries.  Aroma is a bit deceiving as this brew only hints on sweetness at the end of the chewy palate but rather tastes very full, spicey, and tart (again from the cherry lambic) as it first enters my tastebuds. I generally love quads and I love fruit lambics so this should be the perfect beer for me. I definitely like it. The alcohol (9.8%) is hidden extremely well.  Very well done and my favorite beer from Ommegang that Ive had.

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2006 05 dark red beige head. i smell the kriek. and some spicebut not too much. its kinda weak on taste. kind of all over the place but no where. all it tastes is bitter. i would have like more sour cherry. this beer is kind of a mess

Winking Lizard Ohio beerfest 2006.  Like Wow!  This beer is dangerous.  Murky red with a swift golden head.  Smells of liquer and woods, with hints of cherry, plum and orange.  Spicy on the palate bordering on sweet.  I was blown away.  This is a rave beer.

Pour a light red brew with a minimal head, possibly due to non agressive pouring in order to avoid stirring up the yeast. Smelled of alcohol and slight cherries. Tasted like wine meets beer, very interesting. Didnt taste the cherry lambic as much as Id hoped, but still a great beer.

I dont know what to think of this beer.  Visually, it is stunning.  It pours a deep red with tones of brown - but what really sets it apart in my eyes is the head, which is tinged a pinkish red that is aesthetically incredible.  Aroma is similarly nice:  brown sugar, cherries of course, and some faint characteristically Belgian notes.  The taste is where this one seems to fall a little short, or fall apart.  Cherries and other dark pit fruits are noticeable, as well as a decent kick of alcohol and a faint malty backbone.  But theres nothing much here that excites me - it was one-dimensional to the extreme.  On the palate this was average, a bit thin comparatively.  This was not bad at all, but I have some reservations.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2007 Re-Rate...05 Vintage. Ruby-hued amber pour with a moderate tan head. Strong aroma of caramel, anise, light chocolate, and very nice notes of figs, plums, and berries. Flavor follows nicely with semi-sweet caramel/toffee notes, fruity overtones throughout, very light but noticeable bitterness, and pleasant warming alcohol. Palate is full, a bit sticky, and all aspects of the flavor linger in the long finish.

very dark, rich, reddish brown, with a foamy tan head. chocholate, plums, vanilla and bubblegum in the nose.. alcohol quite apparent. tastes piney, with prunes, grapes/grapeskins, grass, malt. nice mouthfeel.

this beer poured alive i could here the head fizzle as i poured the appearance is lovely a nice alive head the goes away quickly and a beaytiful brown red colour. the aroma was sweet and fruity but seemed to leave after a few minutes. i love the palate of this beer i can feel it all over my mouth and as i swallow. the flovour is alot weaker than i expected very nice but weak. it is slightly fruity and sweet i dont taste much cherry or the alcohol. a very good beer tha i will have to try again.  2006 12oz. bottle

2005 750ml bottle into a brandy snifter.  Very slow pourer as not to upset the yeast, dark brown / burgundy color that let just a touch of light in.  Dark tan head that swelled and left pretty quickly.  Very pleasant aroma that even pleased the non-beer drinkers I was with smelled of sugar and cherries.  Surprisingly the beer itself didnt taste anywhere near as sweet but had a very heavy flavor of caramel and orchards with a lingering cherry aftertaste.  I made the odd pairing of having this before and during spicy southwestern food, which I know is weird, but I was happy to find that a small drink of this killed off the spicyness of the food without tasting bad at all.  Had two quality pours while leaving a quarter inch in the bottom of the bottle, as I could tell the yeast was still prevailant in the base of the bottle.  Luckily my waitress knew what she was doing.  Would definately try again.

The presentation is a classy 750ml corked and caged bottle. Cleary dated 2004 across the top label.

Appearance: Pours a dark orange brown plumby color. It is hazy in appearance. A little light might squeak through but it not transparent at all. Id call it barely translucent to nearly opaque. A light tan head fades quickly.

Smell: Sugary! Dark! The smell is really good. The first thing that hit my nose was a brown sugar followed by a dark fruit smell. There is a subtle yeast hint in the aroma and in the taste as well.

Taste: As in the smell the taste is sugary sweet but not over sweet. Its just right. After the brown sugar maple syrup flavor there is a fantastic plum mango apricot sweet fruit taste that slides so incredibly smoothly across the palate. There are also hints of yeast, apples, caramel, black cherries (and dark fruits in general). The malt character is very bold and defined and the hop character is pleasantly gentle and barely showing itself through the sweet sugar aftertaste. 

Mouthfeel & Drinkability: This is remarkably smooth and enticing. The mouthfeel is a medium bodied somewhat slippery and superbly easy to swallow. It is a highly drinkable beer. Each sip is such a treat for the palate (taste) and the mouth (texture). However you must be careful! The 9.80% ABV will sneak up on you like an evil bastard and next thing you know the bottle is empty and cant remember you own phone number :)
That problem is not always a bad thing but wow this is a freaking awesome beer! I highly recommend!!

Hope this is helpful.
Cheers!

750mL bottle.  Met Noel on on of my trips to Portland.  Dark colored.  Malt and hint of cherry in the aroma.  Very sweet beer with a hint of Belgian yeast.  Cherry and lots of port wine in the finish.  This is my favorate Quadrupel ever !!!!  I will give this beer as special occation gifts forever!

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2006 aroma of  dark malts, dark fruit, earthy yeast....Taste is dark fruits such as raisins, plums, grapes, earthy, with some alcohol and a light amount of tart red fruit in the finish.  As this warms it tastes alot more balanced, cherry lambic makes itself  apparent in the late finish but is still light and not overpowering....

Pours deep red with a thin off white head.  Aroma is a bit of yeast, some sour cherries.  Flavor is yeast, some sweetness, cherries, some vinous notes, bit of sourness in the finish.  Mouthfeel is a bit thin, bit overly carbonated.  Decently complex, I just dont think the flavors are that well done or particuarly well balanced.

750ml Bottle.  Deep caramel coloring.  Very smooth pour that quickly foams and quickly fades.  Sweet, sugar/molasses taste to the tongue with pleasant alcohol aroma that warms the nostrils post-swallow.  Met the high expectations I had.  Best to share among with two other friends

From a 12oz bottle a brownish/amber pour. An aroma that says alcohol but hints of maltiness. A sweet flavor of mucho malt with a light frutiness. A palate that is smooth with just a tad on the fizzy side keeps it from being a 5.  This is a beer that is truely after my heart and liver. I love a beer where you can taste alcohol and other flavors (fruit and malt in this case). I really like this beer.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2007 On tap: (Vintage 2004) Pours a burgundy color with small off-white head. Aroma is sweet & lively with cherries and mint. A nicely balanced flavor of black cherries, a touch of milk chocolate, alcohol, a peppery spicyness and an herbal character. Finishes smooth.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2008 750ml bottle, brewed in 2005 - Pours a huge head.  I had to pour it in stages even though I kept the pours slow.  Some of the head lingers and leaves decent lacing.  The aroma malty with yeast, a little cherry, and a trace of alcohol.  The teast is sweet and yeasty with mild cherries, though the fruit wasnt nearly as noticeable as I expected.  Theres a medium body and too fizzy carbonation.  What puzzled me most though was an odd, off tasting finish that lingered at the back of my mouth.  Were my taste buds screwy that day or my bottle a little off from age/improper storage (I dont have a cellar)?  I dont know.  I guess Id have to try another bottle sometime.  The finish notwithstanding, this is a good beer, but Id heard such strong word of mouth on it that I was expecting a really great beer.  Like stoutlover72, I didnt think it lived up to the hype.

Corked and caged bottle. Huge light tan frothy head that mostly lasted, very nice lacing, hazy, carbonated, and a brown hue. Malty, caramel, sweet, and cherry nose. Very inticing. Flavor was sweet, malty, caramel, cherries, vinuous but not over done. Very tasty and satisfying. Nicely done!  Smooth mouthfeel and medium body. A very quaffable brew and one that I will seek out again.  This hit the spot indeed! Definitely worthy of a try!

This is the peoples beer and the people will drink thus. Likingly, loving we shall love this beer and the people. Said the people, "yes, we like this beer." And, all was well in the kingdom of man for years to come.
Poured a deep red almost black with a off white lasting head. Spicy malt aroma with a hint of grass. Strong roasted malt flavor with high alcohol burn finish.

2005 bottle. pours a deep red with a huge white head. aroma of yeast malt fruit and spice. taste is fruity, spicy and highly alcoholic. the mouth feel is what ruins this beer for me. way too carbonated and the alcohol as also too strong. not bad but i dont think i would buy it again.

pours beutifuly, nice amount of head. although it dissipates quickly. laces the glass well. wonderful cherrie colour. Alcohol becoming stronger as it warms up especially in the nose. very nice beer. lived up to expectations

Rated 05 bottle - While this beer was tasty, I had much higher expectations due to word of mouth with this. Its sort of like getting geeked up to watch a summer movie youve been waiting to see only to finally watch it and wonder why the hell were you so geeked up in the first place. Aroma was malty, sweet, cherries, and some nutmeg. Appearance was like black cherry puree with a nice fluffy head with great lacing. Mouthfeel was just okay for me, nothing extraordinary and nothing inheriantly wrong but I did think it was over-carbonated for my tastes. Flavors were cinnamon, cherries, green apples, malts and slightly peppery. I felt comparitively speaking for a quad it should have had a much richer profile, but it didnt carry that at all. Overall, a good beer but I just didnt find it extraordinarly good.

This was really good. Poured from the bomber to a reddish brown color with off-white head, that lingered and left very good lacing. Aroma was strongly cherry, with malty sweetness evident. Body was medium, and at first, highly carbonated. Taste was more of the cherry, mixed well with the traditional ale taste. As beer warmed, the alcohol became more evident in the nose and taste, but still well blended with the cherry ale. Excellent warming finish as the alcohol took hold, and a very smooth after-taste. I will look for more of this in the coming winter.
I really love this one,  Nice aroma with a palate of candis, strong and i dont taste any alcohol.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2007 12oz bottle @ Wits End in San Diego, CA, on 8/10/06.  I really love this brew.  Ive had it many times.  Sadly this time I drank it in a pint glass but the flavor shown through.  Pours Amber with a slightly red puffy head.  Sweet tasty brew, sadly the lambic tastes like the "fake" modern lambics of Lindemans rather then the true lambic of Cantillon.  My question for Ommegang is, the origin of this lambic.  Otherwise always fun, try it.

Delightful.  Pours dirty brown with hints of red.  Creamy head.  Smells of raisins and cherries.  Lots of esters at first.  Alcohol shows through as it warms, but pleasantly.  The finish is full flavored and lingers with the most amazing fruitiness......

What can I say.....  Im speechless....
Kudos to the lot of you!!!!!!
Great Job!!!!!
Carry on chaps...

On the pour... burnt rootbeer aromaevolved to .....dark chocolate aroma...sweet chocola
te, all included in the palate.... (J.B.) evolves into into a sweet candy-like love only to change to a sour malt discintion

12 fl oz boitle, The Gingerman, NYC. Dark amber almost brown with a reddish hue. Figs, raisins, dark malts, candy sugar and some cherries in the nose. Somewhat thin-bodied. It also has some tart burnt maltiness to it that I dont quite like. The alcohol is quite prominent as well.

12 oz bottle.  Not as cloudy as Id thought, and not that much of a head.  Other thant that, it looked great.  Light aroma, but I did detect some cherry, banana esters, a small maltiness and that all too familiar Belgian yeast thing.  Very dry in the mouth.  Like a nice dry wine.  I get some cherries (obviously), as well as a bit of astringency.  The flavor started to take off as it warmed, but by that point, the glass was almost empty.  I guess Ill learn for next time ...  Anyway, as it warmed, other dark fruit (fig, prune) joined the party, and the dryness faded a bit, and as a whole, became a little sweeter.  Very malty toward the end.  Pretty good, and one I might want to cellar for a bit, to see what may come.

12 oz bottle into a St. Bernardus Semi-Trappist style glass.  Pours a murky amber brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma brings a cherry, alcoholic and Belgian yeasty nose.  Somewhat estringent actually.  Flavor is belgian yeast combined with a cherry tart (almost putrid) taste.  Definitely an interesting blend, and they pulled it off fairly well.  Might be worth it to age...

06 State College Brew Expo.  Pours a hazy golden amber with an average bubbly tan head that left some slight lacing.  Aroma of cherry, dark fruits, yeast, caramel, toffee and maple syrup.  Flavor of cherry, slight tart, dark fruits and yeast.  An interesting mix. I have a bottle of this to open so I will revisit when I get to that.

Olney Beer & Fine Wine tasting.  Reddish, cherry-cola appearance; medium, fading head.  Light nose shows candy sugar, little bit of cherries and roasted malt.  Full, malty straightforwardness, nice round mouthfeel.  Long finish.

Deep burgundy with a rocky, tan head. Rich aromas of dried fruits and caramel. Hints of sweet chocolate malt wrapped in caramel. Complex and beyond full-bodied with sweet spices, dried fruits, dark breads, and earthy, woody notes.  Like having toast with cherry preserves. Very nicely done.

While I actually tasted this beer for the first time in the summer with a nice steak I am certain that I would be even more impressed by its richness and fine cherry fininsh if I were to drink it again with a robust stew or wild game meal in the autumn/winter.

I know some people might not have liked it, but I was able to tour the Ommegang Brewery and have this beer fresh.  I was thoroughly impressed with it.  Afterward I purchased a bottle from the brewery and took it home, and I still was impressed with the taste,smell, and appearance.

Might have had a bad sample. Amber color, almost no head, very low carbonation. Aroma of cherry. Flavor was disappointing, reminds me of cherry-flavored cough syrup, very medicinal and a litlle tart. Body is a bit thin. It is my second experience with Ommegang and another disappointment...

This is a fantastic beer. It is complex, yet easy to drink. Every phase of this beer is satisfying, starting with the incredible aroma. The scent of this brew is full of sweetness and tartness at the same time. The pour is a dark amber with a long lasting head. The taste is very complex, but you can definitely get the tart cherry flavors mixed with a dry belgian type of style. The finish is very smooth and clean. I could easily drink this brew all day long. One of the best belgian styles Ive had to date."

Bottle. Pours dark opaque amber, cream colored head. Aroma is complex and fruity: cherry, mango, peach, banana, malt, and a bit of spice. Flavor is equally complex, I definitely taste the cherries, although theyre not too sweet. Theres a bit of sourness which compliments the tartness of the fruitiness. However, this is not a "fruit" beer (thank god). Smooth finish with minimal alcohol taste.
Bottle. Ruby colour with a big beige head. Fruity, light cherries aroma and taste, sweet. Medium body with a light dry, sweet light alcoholic finish.

Bottle at Carrabas. A very unique beerto say the least. Aroma of cherries, malts, toffee. Flavor was complex much like the aroma -- blend of cherries, malts, caramel. No taste was overpowering the other and all worked in harmony to produce a nice beer.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2008 Bottle.
Cloudy red brown coloured with a beige head.
Aroma of caramel, dried fruits, cherries and marzipan.
Flavour of caramel, dried fruits and marzipan.

This beer has a lot going on. I usually dont like lambics too much but this was just the right blend. The cherry flavors were not overpowering but not too subtle either. The most interesting thing was the fact that unlike some high content beers the alcohol flavor  was not evident. A very nice beer.
Very unique beer. Very good mixture of a lambic and quad. I didnt know how this would taste and it turned out to be excellent. Tasting cherries, yeast, malty flavors. Very nice beer overall.
This is one of my favorites.  I know that it is a celebration beer but i could drink it more that that.  Nice cherry flavor, you can smell the flavor. Nice color. Excellent.

Very good quad / cherry lambic produced by Ommegang. Nice complex mixed bag here. You get the yeasty, dark fruity and musky flavors from the quad end, but you also get a nice sour cherry flavor from the lambic side. I was unsure on how a quad and a lambic would be together. Its good though, trust me. Finishes sour from the lambic and a bit dry. Very nice beer.

12 oz bottle. Clear amber color (if you ignore the sediment that will eventually settle). Lasting head with large bubbles. High carbonation. I let the beers temperature rise well above refrigeration levels. Full complex aroma: notes of sugar beets (or maybe thats the cherries), fruity yeast, sugar cane maybe and some sweet malt. Sweet malty flavor, cherry fruitiness and a sweet vegetable flavor too. Some bitterness rises up midway in an attempt to be distinguished from the medley of flavors. I cant discern all the flavors going on here. Nice drinkable beer.

First beer of Belgian beer night tasting.  Murky brown color with  a off-white head.  Aroma is alcohol, belgian yeast, and maybe a little cherries.  Flavor is dirt, bready yeast,  good amount of alcohol, very little if any cherries.  An interesting idea for a Quad but not well executed.

Bottle with cmubeerman, zeswaft, and sersdf.  Honey/caramel brown color with a tan head.  Aroma is cherry-ish...  Confusing aroma for me, not really all that special - lots of competing smells.  Flavor was the opposite; little complexity in my opinion.  Over rated.

Bottled in 2005, hazy mahogany hue, with a frothy tan head, caramelized malt, toasted malt, dried black cherry fruitiness, chocolatey note, toffeeish accent, with a hint of kirsch liqueur in the aroma follow through on a full-bodied palate with a caramelized malt, dark dried fruits and candied cheerryish character, chocolatey, toasted malt, and an alcoholic note, touch of spiciness, nutmeg, cinnamon, leading towards a malty, cherry marzipan finish.

Pours a rich mahogany color with a cheery hue, and a big frothy tan head.  Aroma of bannana, brown sugar, and a note of cherry.  Lots of brown sugar, earhty malt and cherries upfront with a tartness in the finish.  A slight dry bitter finish.  Wondefully complex flavor.  Nice creamy, smooth, full mouthfeel.  This is an excellent brew.

Bottle. Pours a dark cloudy amber with tan head. The malty aroma conveys cherries, raisins, some winter spices, and quite a bit of caramel. The flavor has a deep malty element, with caramel and chocolate, and even a hint of coffee. Dark fruits, maybe prunes, are there, also. The finish is woody and faintly bitter.  I am noticing some toast, too, as I get farther down the glass. Tasty.

Bottle. Pours brown with a nice off white head that lasts for a while. Aromas of dough and malts, flavors are fairly complex: There is a maltiness combined with strong flavors of dough and bread, in addition chocolate.
The cherry lambic is only noticeable in the finsih and stick a bit on the palate. Excellent beer but not your typical Belgian style ale.

Pours a dark, brownish ruby red with a thick, fluffy head that dissipates down to a thin layer of top foam.  Gorgeous lacing.  Cherry, almost winelike nose with alcohol notes.  Taste is black cherries, malt, yeast, plum, maybe raisin.  Definite alcohol kick but not over-pronounced, merges well with the flavors.  I was expecting the cherry lambic to overpower the quad and make it too sweet, but its blended wonderfully for a nice amalgam of aromas and flavors and not over sweetened.  Nice, slightly bubbly, palate.  Reasonable late palate with aftertastes of cherry and alcohol.  A very interesting and unique beer.

Walked by this beer a bunch of times in the bottle shop and finally picked it up. Pours out a deep ruby color with a nice head. Aroma is fruity with some spice and vinious notes. Taste is multi-leveled with notes of spice and yeast that fade into a fruity dried cherry/raisin flavor. Very interesting beer, would definitely try again
What a good example of a Belgium style beer. The nice dark brown color, the taste of spice and fruit. The alcohol % is not that noticeable.. Super beer.
Ruby color with frothy head. Fruits and malts in the aroma. Hoppy bittery at the end. Great beer
Super dark ruby color with a medium sized frothy head. Malty aroma with a fruit background. Yeast and cherry flavor. Finishes with a bit of hoppy bitterness. Nice.

Bottle - 750ml. Dark brown cloudy body topped with an average brown frothy head. Enjoyable malty aroma with plummy, yeasty and spicy hints. Alcohol is very well hidden. Taste is robust and complex. It has a vineous texture and carries many fruity (raisin, dark cherries, plum) and yeasty hints as well. Ends with a long warming finish. Very good choice for my 800th rating.
Bottle: Could compete with any Blegian brew; complex body with spices (cloves, nutmeg, fruits) all well balanced with a present but not overwhelming alcohol presence.

Vintage 2005, corked bottleDark color; huge and compact head. Malt aroma, with light noble vanilla notes and very light spices. A light hop note. Subtle.Round taste, correct soft malt, a lot of caramel (getting more bitter at the end), warming. At the end there is also a presence of roasted malt, roasted nuts and liquorice.A very good example of Strong Belgian Ale, malty enough, with some interesting hints, and every element is well blended together.
UPDATED: JAN 4, 2007 This is a wonderful Belgian style. A deep brown reddish color with a medium head. Super sticky lacing. A nice malty taste with a big Belgian spice mixed in. I liked it alot.

This was an outstanding Belgian with an aroma that was sweet and wine-like. Nice dark brown-red color and a head that was appreciable. Head lasted throughout the drink with great lacing (can still see it at the top of the glass). The alcohol was noticeable in the flavor but blended right in. Flavor was sweet, to dry, and finished with a slight bitterness to keep the drink sharp. A great American version of outstanding Belgian brewing. Two thumbs up.
Bu au Mondial de la Bière 06. Belle brune, mini collet. Arome un peu épicé et caramel très plaisant. Goût dépice réchaufant. Très bon.

Massive frothy tan head on a deep mahogany pour. Fruity, spicy aroma with notes of sweet caramel. Light carbonation complements a medium body. Notable flavor of cherries, but htere are some other fruit flavors of raisins, and even apple. On the sweet side, I can taste some molasses and some earthy flavors. There are some light bitter hops in the finish, but there is more of a sweet/sour character at the end. Very enjoyable.
750ml from 2005. Has a very deep red color with a very thin head. Slightly fruity taste with a malty aftertaste. Very good and worth a try. Strong alcohol presence in first glass.

Very nice reddish body in first glass; less cloudy than most from Ommegang.  Good nose.  Good flavor with cherries present throughout and in aftertaste.  Alcohol noticeable but not overbearing, with a nice warm afterglow.

750 mL bottle from 2005.  Pours a deep ruby red with a thin off-white head. I can see bits of cherry at the bottom of the glass.  Nose is of malts, cherries, and alcohol.  A real unique combination of flavor - the candy-like quadrupel with tart cherries and pretty noticeable warming alcohol.  Cherry aftertaste lingers.
Great, cherry infused ale, with robust head, fruity aftertaste, and very pleasurable!

A tan and creamy head starts large and holds thickly above a well-hazed garnet body. Heavy yeastiness produces banana aromas with heavy alcohol and a splash of sour cherry. Cheek-pinching tartness in an otherwise simple flavor profile. Dry, estery, lingering sourness.  La Trappe was the first quad I tried and now all others fail in comparison as I know the heights they can achieve.
<font size=-4><a href=
http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.as Binnys Beverage Depot/DiCarlos Armanetti, Willowbrook, IL 60527<font size=-1><font size=-1>

Bottle.
Sweet aroma with no strong notes.
Pours a generous head.
Great flavor, sweet cherry aftertatse.
A great after-dinner ale.
Great palate, very drinkable. Recommended.
Cheers!
Pours reddish brown with thin head.  Aroma is sweet with cherry and hints of oak.  Slightly malty with sour fruit and carmel.  Warm, full mouth that lasts.  Slight alcohol bite at the finish.
Solid beer. Pours a liight brown with small tan head.  Vinous.  Cheeries.  Lemon and citrusy.  Slightly malty.  Alcohol could be masked better.

2005: Poured dark redish with a creamy off-white head, very foamy when pouring, be careful! Mild fruit aroma. The fruit wasnt as noticeable in the taste as I expected. Good mouth coat. Full-bodied, easy to drink, but not something to drink quickly.

750 ml bottle. 2005 Vintage. Pours a somewhat hazy deep ruby with an effervescent head.  Must be poured very slowly. I thought the aroma was light for a quadruple. Very flavorful with lots of cherry, plum, and bourbon present. A fun bottle to sample.

750ml corked bottle:  Aroma is a nose full of cheries, dark malt, alcohol.  pours a dark brown with a fine bubbly head.  Flavor is of cheries, caramel malt, rasins, plum, and wood on the back of the tongue.  nice mouth coat.  can feel the frothiness of the fine bubbles.  overy all a very nice beer.

A good Americanized Belgian strong ale or Quadruple.  Has hints of dark fruit and a nice caramelized sweetness with a lot of flavor depth in there. Its not Chimay Blue Grand reserve.. but it  is a good brew for an Americanized quad!

750ml bottle. 2005 vintage. Ruddy brown color with thick light brown head. Assertive malty caramel nose with a dash of spice. Flavors include dried fruit, caramel, and a strong alcohol accent. Moderate effervescence with a touch of sweetness. Decent beer.
Bottle shared by GiBrew. Red with a creamy diminishing tan head. Cherry, malty, raisin, and orange aroma. Cherry, oaky, woody, raisin, and citrus flavours. Full bodied and smooth.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2006 Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus at work, he was so messed up he broke his thumb working. Pours a hazy  bronze color, with an off-white head. Aroma of alcohol, spices, and citrus. Sweet flavor, carbonated, smooth, citrus, and fruit.

75 cl into Duvel tulip, sometime in 2004 (just found my notes).  Smells of orange peel, malted milk and burnt sugar cane, all blending together for an appetizing quaff.  Hazy orange-brown in the glass, with a huge beige head of fluffy foam; patchy lacing.  Tastes sourish; doesnt have the full creamy maltiness of St. Bernardus or Westy, but does have a nice level of sweetness and a velvety texture.  The finish sports a corky woodiness late, which is nice.  Medium to full bodied.  Solid.

UPDATED: AUG 23, 2009 2003 750 mL Bottle Flickr(http:[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Pour of clouded ruddy amber brow, with a touch of haze and a tawny cream head. Aroma of heavy vinous notes, with some pear, rich bread and light phenolic fruit. Flavor very similiar, but with some orange zest and lime peel over a warm fruit concotion of fermented pound cake. Warm, but not unpleasently so. Fairly one dimensional, with a straightforward presentation. More fruit and a touch of port. Distant sourness and like oak. Finishes of silky raisins and cream. Sugary sweet, and it leaves a coating of dryer dark belgian chocolate on the tounge. Towards the end, a flavor develops of apple cider like sourness, with a touch of cork and funky yeasts. Almost as if a lambic quality has developed with time. Theres certainly a factor of age in this particular sample. Tasty and quite drinkable.

Great aroma.  Nice, smooth, not a bitter smell.  Reminds me of fresh baked bread.  Nice dark amber color with a light carmel head.  Head is dense and holds up well..  The beer is a fairly dark amber, but there is a fine carbination present.  The flavor is a good blend of sweet and tart.  There is a definite bite when you first taste this beer.  Id have to say this is a full, creamy beer with a nutty aftertaste.  I would definitely compare this to a hearty red wine like a merlot.  The aftertaste, while nutty, also hints at other earthy tones such as tobacco.
Pours deep mahogany into a trappist glass.  Date, fig and cherry notes.  Consistent conglomerate head.  Full and fizzy with upfront caramel and a distinct lingering cherry finish.
This was my first Ommegang attempt, all I have to say is Whoa! Great beer, I highly recommend..... Have to agree with herzon; caramel, cherry, chocolate.....

Light aroma: muted caramel, touch of cherry and a touch of chocolate.  Decent, but very light. Bright ruby-red with a creamy, off-white head that lasts.  Flat flavors of caramel with a touch of cherries and minerals in the finish.  Sort of stale tasting.  Lively mouthfeel, fairly high carbonation with a lighter body.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2006 Bottle. Pours a cloudy cider brown with a very small, quickly dissipating white head. Initial aroma very sweet; condensed milk, pear, slightly funky raisins. Flavor is very sweet. Red apples, pears, blueberry, fig, date; but there is a slight bitterness in the back ground...like apple skin, or dry lemon zest. After taste is where the light bitterness becomes more assertive: Granny Smith apple skin, hazelnut (?). Feels a bit thick in the back of the throat afterward, with the mouth feels clean. Decent body, feels heavy in the glass, but not as creamy other Belgian Triple and Quadrupels Ive had before. Distinct lack of that rotten fruit kick many Belgian Abbey style beers have gives this one a distinct drinkability others lack. Like drinking an orchard. Yum.

Ruby, red/orange pour with a powdered sugar, cherry vanilla aroma.  Smooth body with a very simple, if not unfortunate weak cherry flavor.  The first sip had some metallic, mineral quality to it, but that was the only interesting part of the body.  The finish wasnt complex, but there was a slight, sour yeast note on bottom.  Id like to try this again at some point because I had high hopes for it.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2006 Very good strong ale.  The cherry taste and aroma is very good,but not over-done.  quite enjoyable with the high alcohol content pretty well hidden.  Another reason to go to Cooperstown
Clear very dark brown with a fluffy light tan head. Rich malty spicy cherry flavour with a lively mouthfeel.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2007 Originally sampled at the 4th Boulder Strong Ale Fest. Resampled from bottle more than a year later. Original rating was 6.4.5.3.11.

Beer is clear, medium warm-brown. Head is initally small, off-white, frothy. Diminishes quickly into a ring.

Malty with light-to-moderate note of toasted grain, light cookie; Hoppy with moderate notes of herb; Yeasty with a light note of dough; Trace miscellaneous notes of dried currents and stonefruit, cherry, oak.

The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter, lightly acidic with a longer-than-average, lightly sweet, lightly acidic/tangy, slightly warm finish.

The body is medium, the texture is watery and the carbonation is lively.

Appreciate it more this time around than the first, but it still isnt a show-stopper.

From 750mL Bottle, 2005 Vintage.  Slightly hazy, cherry brown pour with a tall, creamy tan head.  Earthy, vinous aromas of caramel, black cherry liquore, raisins, and a pleasant yeasty cinnimon spice.  Some fig notes as well.  Leathery bouquet with a bit of a musty smell, along with some rochefort cheese.  Thick, syrupy texture with some hints of brandy.  Initial mouthfeel is of a finely balanced port, but that gives way to cheap brandy after the nice dark fruits give way.  Alcohol is a bit too hot on the finish.  Final smack of frangelico, plums, and mild green pepper.  Nice and complex overall, but the alcohol is a bit stinging, and could stand to be softened up a little.

12 oz bottle.  Copper-pink.  Kicks up a big woody head that recedes to bubbles and lacing.  Smell is yeast at first and then earthy cherries.  A little watery, a little sour, some scotchy alcohol.  Cherry sneaks around in the back but never steps up.

Pours a hazy glowing brown with a strange offwhite/brown head.  Smells of sweet caramel.  Tastes like dark fruits which apparently are cherries, very smooth, sweet bite at end.  Quite enjoyable.  Be careful with this one though, it is to be slow sipped, hit me hard with the weight and warmth of the alcohol.

2004 75cl bottle. This dark brown ale poured with a frothy tan head, eliciting a caramel  malt aroma. The flavor is full and malty with a hint of cherry, a carbonated mouthfeel and an alcohol finish. The flavor mellowed out as the beer warmed, with the cherry notes becoming more noticeable. This is a unique brew that is well worth trying.

Head has a fuity complex aroma with a taste of maple syrup and nuts.  I was expecting more of the cherry to come through, but still like it.  Thick foamy head, especially since I gave it a bit of a high pour.  Cloudy brown/amber body.  Full of flavors come with heavy breaths after tasting.

Red-brown with a solid tan head. Potent caramel and liquorice aroma. Lots of sweet liquorice flavours. Dry cherries come through towards the end together with warming alcohol. Full-bodied, medium carbonation. A deliciously different quadruppel (I thought La Trappe had a copyright for that style,though).
The last review puzzles me, but to each his own, especially when we are talking beer. Three Philosophers is a treat, great taste, great look, great body etc...mmm cant wait to take that ride again.

Pours a slightly hazy dark cherry color. Nice sized off white head. Aroma is hay sour wheat, lemon cherry, funk. Flavor is funky lemon zest, caramel. A little banana, the kriek is rather subdued, a little cherry and funk in the finish. Not a fan of this one.

This was a delightful quadrupel that seemed to reveal different tastes the further I got into it. The pour was dark copper with an off-white head that formed a nice ring. The aroma was filled with sugars, ripe plums, bananas and a tinge of alcohol. The flavor was fruity  prunes and plums  with a slightly woody taste. There were also some notes of pepper from the alcohol and bit of spice though its more sweet than spicy. Moderate carbonation offered a clean mouthfeel and a clean finish with a tad of stickiness.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2006 The one that started it all fo me.  First beer Ive rated on this site, and fourth or fifth really GOOD beer Ive had.  Liked it enough to Google it, if that tells you anything.  Just the perfect amount of sweet, comes in four packs (the perfect amount of this type to drink), just really good all around.

2005 Bottle .dark ruby color , big off white head that doesnt hang around long . nice citrus /cherry aroma . slight cherry flavor but not really a fruit beer , woody/caramel flavor , little tart and dry but good medium body. little or no alcohol burn for 10% ,good beer

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown with an off-white fizzy head.  The aroma has a bit of citrus, cherry.  The flavor is lighter on the cherry than I expected, but the yeast and malts are strong and flavorful.  Excellent beer.

Apperance: Dark brown that is mostly opaque, and shows off a heavy haze when held up to the light. Moderate thick light tan extra fizzy head on pour that fades quickly. Also moderate lacing.
Aroma: Big belgiany phenol that smells has a little bit of a thick banana smell. Slight citric tart bite that hints of cherry and lime. 
Flavor profile: Definately a quadrupel, big yeasty character, tart, and a touch of cocoa. Gets a bit smoother as it warms and the cocoa comes out a bit more and the banana phenol that was in the nose comes out. 
Palate: Moderate weight, a little fizzy and rather wet, sticks around on your tongue for a while in a good way.
Im normally not a fan of these thicker complex belgians but this one grew on me. Ill have to pick up another one and see what its like a second time around.

Happy Day after St. Pattys Day!  After finishing up at the Smokehouse last night, we
meandered over to the Winking Lizard.  This was my fourth brew of St. Pattys Day. 
Interesting nose of fruit & berries, cherry & wheat, and after maturation and breathing for
a bit, a heavy toffee presence was easily detected.  The brew pours with a nice stout-ish
cascade that blooms into a tall frothy tan head with excellent retention and good lace.  The
brew is a cloudy dark ruby.  The flavor has such nice depth and balance that the high ABV
is totally incognito.  The flavor is again somewhat different for the style probably because
of the infusion of lambic that provides a noticeable tang at the finish.  The medium body is
creamy and lively yet feels dry at the finish.

this one threw me for a loop.  Im thinking you konw some big cherry flavors and nose.  reminisent of a great belgian.  na, not really.  more of a malty , dark fruit deal going on here, some tobacco and wood laden fluids.  not really a fruit beer that i thought it would be.  however, good in its own right with little to no alcohol burn.
