A hazy brown/amber with a thick lasting tan head.  Very nice aroma of caramel, citrus, raisin, plum, banana, clove, pepper and spice.  Velvety medium body.  Creamy and syrupy with a moderate amount of carbonation.  Nice flavor that is very floral and woody.  Lots of caramel, pepper, molasses, dark fruit, and spice also make an appearance.  Excellent.  Big thanks to Slikwily for this one!

Ommegang is a great belgian house - this partcular version has real "blood" taste - iron oxide like. Nice color (blood red?) - wonderfully rich - the candi sugar is really muted and the cherry lambic is well-blended. Yummy.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Three words to describe this; Belgium, chocolate, and cherries. Absolutely wonderful stuff. I was wayyyyy suprised considering I am from upstate NY and while Ommegang's other products are good, their not great. Long live the 3 philosophers!

Again, props to Slikwily for this one!  Coppery brown with orange and reddish highlights under a lasting tannish head.  Caramel malts, bananas, and and raisins are the most notable aromas at first.  A moderate buttery aroma (diacetyl) appears as it warms slightly, as well as a lightly bready yeasty aroma and toasted malt and alcohol.    Malty flavors and bananas start out the flavor as it does in the aroma.  Good think I like bananas!  Then a vinous raisin character with the same toasted malt notes as in the aroma.  The buttery flavors don't seem to be as predominant in the flavor as in the aroma, but it's there in just a hint.  A slightly solventy alcohol flavor creeps into the finish of this very well balanced beer.  Aftertaste is of raisins and toasted malt.  Medium bodied with surprisingly moderate carbonation for a Belgian ale.  There is a slight astringency that I'm not terribly keen on, but it seems to be one of the few flaws this beer has.  Alcohol is warming and adds nicely to the complexity.  This is a bitter sweet beer for me.  Sweet because I like and have gotten the chance to taste it.  Bitter because it will probably not be available for very long!

Holy-moly. Heavy sweet malt body laced with dark fruits like figs and raisins. A sweeter ending than I normally enjoy but that didn't matter - this is a very successfully balanced beer. Lovely, attractive red-brown color. Complex and just delicious.

Dark garnet. The dark beige head rises to magnificent heights and then subsides abruptly. Nose is black cherries, raisons and alcohol. Taste is dark fruits and port wine, with a hint of black cherry soda.

Deep and dark red in color. Smooth tasting beer. Tan head. Strong ale. Very pleasant. Very good. Mix of alcohol and fruity flavors, including raisins, and some dried fruit. Good beer to lay away for a few years. Would really be good aged.
Nice raosted malt with fruit tones. Medium red amber with a little layer of a head. Malty figs taste, smoked in the middle, alcohol comes slightly through. Kicks on the tip of the tongue.

Aroma remins me of cherry cough drops with zinc added - weird. Color is reddish-brown. Flavor is slihtly sweet/tart up front with an overly hoppy finish. Mouthfeel is ok. I don't like the hop character of this mixed with the cherry flavors - seems off. Had this one at the Southern Ratebeer Gathering in Austin, TX on December 6, 2003.

This was an really interesting beer. Started off too cold so I let it sit around for a while before tasting it to let it warm up. When cold, it's a bit thin and bitter, but when it warmed up, it became much more complex. Nicely spicy/yeasty and a really full cherry nose. Tartness from the kriek lambic it was mixed with was mild and only came through when warmed to the point where it should have been served. Easily drinkable and quite tasty.

strong brew, could tell a little bit - not too good in masking alcohol. a little thin, yeasty, dark tart cherries over a bit of smooth caramel chocolate. a little sweet. it's subtle. i enjoyed it. a bit of a gimmick though, egh that's my opinion.
2003 edition:  Nice dark brown colour, light brown head.  Taste is initially malty, but the cherry flavours sneak up on you.  Bitter, dry finish.   Good stuff!

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2003 Deep red-brown color with a tan head. Aroma of a big Belgian with a slight fermented cherry note. Slightly sharp flavor with a mix of alcohol, cherry, raisin, and mixed dry fruit. In many ways, has the character of a St Bernardus 12, or Rochfort 10, or several other of the big Belgian strong ales. I will be cellaring several of these and I look forward to future tastings. YUM
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: 2003 bottle:  hazy brown, beige head.  nice aroma with jelly candy, liquorice, icing sugar, yeast, dark bread and cherry.  big chewy malt up front leading to complex toffee and yeasty notes.  finishes with a bit of alcohol and bitterness.  very nice.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2004 2003 bottle.  A masterwork.  Pours clear deep red with thick head.  Malty aroma, and malty flavor with distinct cherry and chocolate base.  Alcohol is noticeable, but in the background.
Aroma upgraded on March 15, 2004

Absolutely excellent--a beautiful fruity ale.  Deep red color with a bit of head.  rich and warming.  There is alcohol there but a vital cherry undercurrent, port-like grape flavors, and that wealth of malt.  Frothy, foam palate.  A hint of bitterness is there in the end, but as JoeT said at the time, it's a lesson in finding phenols. (Sampled at Southern Ratebeer Gathering, Austin, TX, December 6, 2003)

Slightly hazy auburn beneath a light foamy tan head.  The nose is alcohol with fruity red licorice.  Candyish, peppered with fruit - maltily sweet.  The body is really quite sweet, yet manageable, cherry notes behind a solid malt backbone.  Warming alcohol with a touch of yeast that finishes the beer.  Complex, manageable, sweet ale.

Bottle, consumed at the point where my handwriting is getting quite sloppy.  Amber, big head.  Deliciously sweet, a cornucoupia (yes, I wrote that while drunk) of fruit!  Nice.  Prominent tangerines, peaches, a bit of grape.  Some hints of alcohol, and sourness that add to the deliciousness (I must have been really inspired). ..nice.  (That's two "nices")  A little tobacco, but it's not crappy like a normal tobaccoish beer.
I like the sour fruityness.  Very little head (probably because of the high ABV) but pours a dark cola.  Mostly fruit and bready tastes.
(750ml bottle) Deep red body with a thin, almond head. Nose of plum, bubblegum and iodine. An almost muted taste. Smooth, fruity with a slight whiskey-alcohol burn. Good, lingering burn. Excellent!

Thanks to Brenda for lugging this to Austin on a plane....you rock!  Hazy red with yellow edges.  Aroma was very alcoholic, apples, berries.  Very full fruity and yeasty flavors.  I got lots of bread and hops towards the finish, it all meshed well on the tongue for a beer of its magnitude.  This is a big beer, a winter warmer for sure.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2005 Aroma:  smells of finger nail polish, sour cherries and strawberries, and cough syrup filter up from the glass.  Also, hints of fruitiness and medicine.
Appearance:  dark-reddish in colour
Flavor:  sour cherries, cotton candy, hops, and slightly floral. A bit too hopped for me.
Palate: dry, sour, tart, with a good mix of cherries and hops

Re-rated 7/14/2005

Aroma:  8/10 red grape skins, ginger, alcohol, apple skins, cotton candy, vanilla bean, and oak

Appearance:  4/5 reddish-brown, light head, lacing

Flavor:  8/10 oak, sweet cherries, red grapes, brown sugar, maple syrup, and flowers

Palate:  4/5 sweet bubbly with oak, and cherry pit aftertaste; very smooth

Overall:  18/20
Dark amber in color, spicy scent, this is a very good winter beer.  Warms you all over.  Lots of flavors and goes down extra smooth.  Very good!!

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2014 Dark murky brown appearance.  Smells of pine, rye and "holiday spices"... maybe gingerbread.  Strong mouthfeel, strong alcohol presence.  A small chemical-like flavor mixes with rye, cherries, wood and other spices, with a full body and a beautifully roasted flavor on the tongue.  Its very pleasent in that the kriek is really subdued, but the fact remains that the quadrupel qualities are lacking... the expected complexity does not exist.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2003 White Labelled 2003 Release (bottle 2):
Ruby tinted amber colour with a super dense tan head. Aroma slightly of cherries, but favouring malt, raisins, plums and alcohol. Medium-bodied; Sweet caster sugar/caramel sweetness. Slight sourness midway through, but not lasting long. Aftertaste bittered from the malt, not left clean. Overall, not pleasing, not a great value, and therefore a pretty big dissapointment! This 75 cL bottle was purchased at Beers of the World in Rochester, New York and sampled on 11-December-2003. 

White Labelled 2003 Release (bottle 1):
Ruby-tinted brown coloured body. Slight smokey aroma, malt cherries and metal. Medium to Light-bodied; Spicey malty taste with some cherries. Aftertaste bittered-some peppery and not terribly pleasant. Overall, decent-but less than what I had expected. Quite simply, yet another unsatisfying beer from Ommegang. This one isn't even a great value at $8 a 75 cL bottle. I had this bottle at the Winter Party at Oakes' place in Toronto, Canada on 05-December-2003.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2005 Re-rate July 2005. 341 mL. Ruby tinged brown body, small beige head. Funky alcoholic aroma, mild notes of fruit. Dry flavour, malty middle. Phantom fruit throughout. Medium palate. Decent but not really in tune with my palate. Meh. 6/3/6/3/12

Original Rating Dec 2003. 750 mL. Hazy dark amber colour, with a film of a head on mine. Big alcohol aroma with a fruity tartness. Mouthfeel was vinuous and interesting. I cant say I enjoyed this one as much as I had hoped. 6/4/5/3/12

Brewed 2003 - 750 ml. Bottle. Poured with a long lasting, medium sized tan head.  The beer was a deep reddish brown in color.  This is an absolutely delicious beer with a delicious blend of malt and cherries.  It isn't overly sweet like a lambic, and it has a nice 9.8% ABV which is masked very well.  I found a new and unusual winter warmer.

Winey, Belgian brune aroma -- some cocoa and tart fruit.  Good bottle, label and deep chestnut brown beer with darkish oatmeal-like foam.  New, the beer is sweet, though I imagine this dries out some during cellared conditioning.  Vanilla, nuts, tartness, prominent alcohol, sturdy woody bittering in the flavor profile.  Alcohol bittering is a bit too clingy in the roof of the mouth sometimes.  Medium-long finish.  Good weight for a cold winter night -- just a tad over medium body.
Malty, strong alcoholic beer, with a good tart bite from the Lindemans Kriek.  Noticable cherry aftertaste.  Overall, has many winelike qualities, some similar to port.  My fav from Ommegang.

2003 white label. Deep dark amber color, some sediment but no haze, thin but firm tan head. Sweet malt and plum/raisin aroma with a touch of cinnamon. Flavor is malty and sweet with raisin again and a touch of cherry. Cherry flavor is like that of a dark-chocolate covered cherry, slightly tart. Medium to full body, slightly dry finish. Pretty good.
Mahogney colored. Malty, raisin aroma with a hint of cherries. Dry malty raisin flavors, with a slight tartness and chocolatey cherry flavors in the finish.

Clearish dark orange-amber. Some sediment. Tan head of small, tight bubbles. Malty (caramel), rum & raisin aroma w/ some cinnamony spiciness. Medium-full bodied. Flavour profile is similar to aroma (malt, rum, raisin, cinnamon) but with a chocolate coated cherry character.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2006 Rerate Just all around better this time around - pick up some prunes, dark chocolate and caramel - much thick er this time around as well and stronger aroma - good raisiny muskiness. Original - 3.3 2003 - 750 ml bottle. Pours with a light amber color, sparkles in the light. Thin, off-white head with a fair amount of lacing. Very faint aroma - but it is reminiscent of cherry cola. Mouthfeel is a bit thin in texture, but has some elements of licorice. Flavor has some elements of cherry with light hints of muted spices and not much else. I really wanted to like this one - but it is sadly lacking in many respects. Very smooth and goes down easy considering the 9.8 ABV - just not a whole lof of excitement here.

2003.  Rich mahogony with a nice thick froth.  Sour cherries and yeast in the nose.  Very rich burnt flavor.  The alcohol overpowers any other flavors that might be there.  Cherry aftertaste.  I'm glad I tried this, but I'd much rather get one of this brewery's other products.
I don't like this brew too much way too sweet for my tastes.  Overly burnt, sweet, and bitter flavors.  Finishes chewy, sticky, and thick.

My wifes first words," this is wonderful" - I got excited. It smelled pretty good, little hints of cherries and spicy plumb notes. Red brown orange hue, quickly disspating head. First sip - where's the Kriek? Second sip etc. where's the Kriek.
It has a pretty extreme spiciness and a whollop from the alcohol. Thought it tasted like a Leffe Blonde mixed with a little old wine. 
I didn't detect any banana like others did. Just alcohol, SPICE, and winelike notes. Didn't really taste any cherry. I figured since it was blended from Lindemans Kriek it would have some of that syrupy cherry flavor (which I thought would be balanced by the Ommegang brew) didn't really taste it.
I also wanted to like this beer more than I did. I think it is probably a very good beer, just not up my alley.

2003 vintage. Dark garnet body, tan head receding quickly, banana estery nose. Sweet, alcohol too evident, banana notes, some cherry. Improves as it warms. Too much alcohol in the finish. I really want to like this New York product, especially since I am a fan of their other beers, but this is disappointing. The new label is a big improvement over the pictured bottle, though. ;)

UPDATED: APR 7, 2004 The beauty of this beer in the finish. Lingering spice and the cherry really starts to emerge - very dry finish. Texture is wonderfully rich - creamy and a little slick. Aroma has a touch cherry with malt and spice and flowers - smells a bit like a fine cigar. Hint of banana. Sweet with hops popping in toward the middle and lingering nicely - again for that spicey, ashen finish. Appearance is reddish brown and hazy. The color on the head is beautiful - deep golden brown - toffee colored. Very nice and I feel the warmth of the 9.8% taking over. Very nice!

Dark brown in color with a small dense light brown head.Aroma is amazing,fruit,malt,spices,soy sauce?? Sweet,rich a filling beer.Extremely complex and should age well and hopefully change it's course.

This beer is exceptional. Ruby-red with a hint of cloudiness.   Immediatetly after poppoing the bottle you get a beautiful barley-wine scent.  It smells and tastes very much like a tawny port.  You can also taste the slight hint of plums, raisons and grapes.  Rich chewy and robust in flavor.  Very smooth scintillating aftertaste that just keeps you asking for more.  Alcohol is well hidden but also apparant. Lightly carbonated.
Ruby colored.  Big sweet maltiness, lots of sweet cherry flavor. Cloying, actually.  Some alcohol presence.  Lindeman's Kriek presence makes a lot of sense.  Thanks, Slikwily!

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2004 This is the original vintage a few years before the Lindemans Blend:  Deep orange-ruby hue.  Wood, dark fruit, sweet nose.  Small beige head.  Very sweet, dark fruit, woody, figs, cherry, almost tart towards the middle.  Medium bodied, finishing with a dry lingering dried apricot and candy sugar flavor.  I was supposed to trade 6 bottles of this crap to someone, but they backed out, so I have 5 more to deal with...Anybody interested?!
Dark ruby red color wiht a small tan head.  A sweet fruity( brandied cherries) aroma.  A swet fruit malt taste, alcohol, raisins.  This finishes a little too sweet for me.

Ooohhh...this is a sultry brew!  Seductive vanilla pulls you in, and then the robust dark chocolate holds onto you...hmmm...Perfect malty finish, and spicy plums in the aroma.  A somewhat chewy mouthfeel, and I'm definetly tasting bananas somewhere.  Highly complex.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2004 Original TP - 4.3 - Dark brown with hints of red - very low carbonation - inviting aroma of yeast, plums prunes, brown sugar and alcohol - flavor is a delicious mixture of chocolate, plums, dark cherries and some molassas - silky mouthfeel, lingering malty finish - great beer.  New TP (with kriek) - there really isn't much difference between this and the original, besides the slight, tart cherry flavor added by the lambic, which is actually difficult to detect - there's a bit more chocolate in this one, esp. in the finish, and the body appears to be a bit thinner - still a great beer, though.

Pours a rich reddish-brown, somewhat translucent, with small brown head.  Aroma is sweet like prunes and/or figs brown sugar, bread yeast and slight scent of alcohol.  Flavor is carmelly sweet more than I would prefer wtih a dryness on the finish from the alcohol.  Good Belguim, but not world class.

POurs a deep dark brown with very little head and almost no lacing.  The aroma is very winey, and the taste closely resembles a port.  Tastes very much like carmelized brown sugar.  Overall I was not impressed but definitely something to try.

Pours dark brown with a nice head and not much lacing. Aroma of port, bananas and bubblegum. Flavor has detectable alcohol with complex caramel malt seeping through. Finishes with lots of alcohol and a light banana presece. Overall this is good, but I think ommeganag is a tad better.

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2005 Re-Rate 9/10/2005 - Even better than I remember it being before!  Too bad Im living in Alabama now and I cant get Ommegang in this state.  Re-rate 4/11/2004 - This is so much better than I remember it being.  A beautifully-crafted beer.  First rating:  Luv that Ommegang!  Nice label, nice cork, etc.  The aroma was earthy, molassasy and complex...with a huge alcohol smell.  Each swig went down with wonderfull warmth.  Wonderful dizzying mix of flavors.  Thanks to Volgon for sharing!

Pours a very nice deep red-brown with little brownish head.  Sweet fruity nose, some alcohol.  Flavorful apples and caramel, with a slightly bitter finish.  Nice palate leaves the mouth full of fruit.  A very nice refreshing Belgian strong.

Interesting but not great.  I prefer the other Ommengang brews. Cloudy orange. Complex aromas and tastes are the story. Spicy and sweet. Caramel and fruit flavors are detectable. Somewhat fizzy carbonation, probably from all the candi sugars. Alcohol and sweet are dominate on the finish.
Dried fruit and alcohol aroma, which was great. Very cidery taste, like a lot of apples. Good finish, not too bitter. I'll have to try this again, because it was so awesome!
intense raisin aroma with candy notes, plum colored, stinging alcohol bite, raisins, choclate malt finish, silky body

A dark reddish brown reminiscent of the juice from plums or red grapes.  Very little head.  The aroma is quite sweet with tons of sticky, ripe fruit.  Plums, raisins, pears, apples, cherries, fig, sugar, caramel and a bit of chocolate.   Pretty full in the mouth, but with little effervescence.  The flavor is also quite sweet, dominated by the sticky fruit and a bit of alcohol.  Warming in the finish.  An incredible flavor profile is slightly tainted by too much sweetness.  Otherwise this would be world class.

HSSSG2003 Part 1
This beer rocks!
Sparkling clear mohogany brew. Small, white, creamy head with nice lacing.
The aroma holds notes of prune, toffee, pecans, dark raisins, banana bread, alcohol, butter, red candied apple and cinnamon.
The flavor contains blasts of prune, pear, heavy molasses, maple syrup, vanilla and fuzzy fruit.
Full-bodied with an oily mouthfeel and lively carbonation.
Long, bittersweet finish.
World Class Brew!
Thanks go out to Slikwily for this bottle of beer.

Caramel, butterscotch, dried fruit and alcohol aromas. Opaque ruby, with a small toffee head. Flavours of candied malt, treacle, touch of licorice, demerara, tobacco, plums and raisins, woody too. Complex, rich texture, full bodied, extremely  dry finish. Well built, top notch! Gotta love these big bottles.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2004 dar red-brown. candied fruit aroma. no head other than ring around the glass. Lightly carbonated and full bodied with berries, chocolate, malt. medium ry, somewhat spicy,finish.
NEW: Had this recently and enjoyed it a bit more. Not sure if it has been changed with the new ownership but if so I would say for the better. Upping palate from 3 to 4.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2003 White label 2003 edition.  Bright golden brown; aroma of plum, candy and banana.  Slightly astringent notes in the body.  Chewy. Alcoholic.  Slight yeast note, with a bitter ashy note in the finish.  Alcohol is too dominant.
Original, burgundy label edition:  Orangey-burgundy colour.  Deep sense of plum, blood orange, deep caramel, stale wood, cherries.  Some tartness comes into the mix mid-palate.  Overall, though, it's quite sweet, slightly candyish even.  Warming, slightly spicy finish.

This beer was so super sweet.  Light  bodied with a maple syrup and alcoholic burn in the finish. No real complexity, quick and over before I knew it.  Stick to their regular brews, this one was too sweet and thin.

Color of rich juicy amber, high aroma s, some malt- yeasty aroma and alcohol mixed with it. Super big Belgian that in this case is not that good. Alcoholic, sweet ale. Sharp and intense. Alcohol is over exposed.
Summer Gathering 2003: Tangy sweetness, some orange. Musty. <poopshoot></poopshoot>

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2006 (draft) Clear dark red-brown body with beige head.  Aroma is medium sweet, cherry, wood, caramel, light sour.  Taste is medium sweet, wood, cherry, light vinous, chocolate, alcohol.  Smooth medium body with light stickiness. (7/4/7/4/14)

(RBSG2003):  CLoudy copper with minimal off-white head.  Aroma is bubblegum and banana, sweet, maple.  Taste is sweet (bubblegum), banana, light coconut/maple.  Medium body.  (7/4/6/3/12)

Brought for the summer party, which I had brought more...Dark brown hue with a small tan creamy head, fair lacing. Yet another wonderful smelling beer I had this weekend. Hints of caramel, vanilla, tawny port, and very floral. Nice sweet, vinous/port taste. Hoppy enough to clean palate. A bit malty aftertaste. Oily yet lively mouthfeel. Another great beer from this New York brewery.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2006 Original Rating 7-4-5-2-13:
This brew pours a small head of light brown bubbles and a brown body.  It had a strong bubblegum and alcohol aroma with an overpowering alcohol flavor.

Re-rate 5-5-8-4-17:
Poured an extremely large sized head of almost all foam in my mug.  Foamy light brown very long lasting finely sized bubbles.  Very hazy brown with finely sized yeast particles,  Poor lacing.  Mild malty cherry aroma with a mild vinous note.  Tingly start strong tingly vinous finish soon fades into its aftertaste.  Not as overpowering as first rating.  Vinous mild alcohol burn mild dark cherry malt burning hops.  Little to no-lambic like tart sweetness as the label suggested.

Pours a dark garnet color with a medium sized, but eventually diminishing, beige head. The aroma was dominated by sweet grapes, dark fruit...with some nice wood (roasted?) tones. The flavor was again very sweet, grapes, plums, vanilla, wood, very floral/perfumey. Unfortunately, this brew had an odd watery feel on the tongue...odd because of the immense flavors present. Lively carbonation. Overall, a very finely crafted beer.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2009 750mL 2009 bottle. Head is initially average sized, frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing. Body is hazy medium to dark amber, bottle conditioned. Aroma is moderately malty (toasted bread, cookie, caramel), lightly yeasty (cobwebs, basement), with light notes of cherry, sugar/icing/honey, gum. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, lightly to moderately alcoholic. Surprisingly watery and light-bodied for its size and professed style.  Nice enough aroma, but nothing exciting.

This ale pours a dark, ruby red color with a thin, diminishing, off-white head. The aroma is malty with lots of fruity notes including banana. It has a full body with light carbonation. The flavor is very malty and fruity with banana, vanilla, bread, and alcohol notes. The finish is lingering sweet. Very good, almost like a stronger version of the regular Ommegang.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2008 In Cotton Candy Meadows, a palaver of young polymaths is stimulated by sweet emanations of mulled cherry wine and red licorice...The subject is perilous yet essential, and consists of mapping the underflesh world of adult emotions...Between two arguments on the lunacy of a lunar sea, caramelized pears are greeted by lip smackings and chocolate mousses are devoured eagerly...Toasty pancakes then overflow as cognitive sparks point to a bitter twist...The prevalent mind rattling and tongue wagging at the exit of the candy store concludes as follows : delete the obsolete and salute the absolute for youthful vigor and a healthy life...

Dark amber color,strong head that is long lasting,and lite tan in color.Nice aroma of malt ,raisin,some alcohol and i know i'm wrong but it almost smells like there's some maple syrup in there some where IMHO.Slight wine like aroma in there but,not being a wine nut i can't say what kind of wine it could be.slight syrup feel to it.Malty taste,licorice,lots of licorice,slightly sweet some fruit tones hard to put my fingure on which one exactly but in my unintelligent opinion it seems like raisin maybe some dryed prune,with a very slight alcohol taste that is not over powering at all.It had an after taste that was quite pleasant slight alcohol with some sweet prune to it with a some what syrupy feel that make the finish of sweet malt last a long time.this is definately a brew worth keeping for some ageing to see if the flavor's come together better which i feel they will.I'm glad to say that i have a 6-pack of these and will be trying them 1 year at a time to see how they age,because a brew like this is well worth waiting for.It's not very complex but it definately has the potential to be even better with age,and i have plenty of time to wait for it to blossom into something special,For those of you who haven't tryed on yet.Eat you heart out.muhahahaha

Nice dark foxy-red colour, clear; slight orange-brown head. Fruity nose: sweet cherries, strawberry. 
Later Port or Marssala - like nose, vineous, alcoholy. Bitter-sweet  taste, alternating between a nauseating liquorice sweetness and an outspoken burnt toffee&malt flavour. Fruit is reduced to a jam-like flavour (Japanese cherries-jam?). After a time, one gets accustomed, but I cannot even start to like it. Medium-bodied, diminishing effect by the alcohol, augmented by the jam-fruitiness. After a while, the vineous character from the nose reappears. But the vile burnt liquorice keeps hanging on. I'm sure this beer was on a Mission. For me, it failed. What I mostly blame it for, is for the unfullfilled promesses made by the nose, resulting in a complete unbalance between nose and taste.
Strong malt aroma. Mild alcohol. Slight hop bitterness and flavor. Crystal malt sweetness. Very creamy. Nice!!

Smelled like a Tootsie Roll and tasted like one too. Vanilla characteristics burst forth. Nice caramely (sp) coloring and quite malty. I like mine malty and this carries that quality very well, but also has a underlying bitterness that forced me to rate it a bit lower than I would have cared to. C'est la vie. I waited years to try this thing and I'm still not sure if it was worth the wait.
An amber color with strong malty and alcohol aroma. Tastes of caramel and malts. Very strong malts. Too much malts for my liking.
Mahogany brew with a very yeasty nose. Big malty backbone for a spicy, fruity brew. Another highlight of the fest for me.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2004 alcohol, licorice, and honeydue melons make appearances in the aroma..licorice, banana-spice, overripe apples, and honeydue flavors too with a little alcohol effect too..quite fricken' nice.
A nice nut brown color to it.  Mild white head. Smells like alcohol, and alcohol with caramel is the flavor.  It has a long island iced tea feel to it. An interesting brew.
Mellon, butter, fermenting fruit, vannila and peppery alcohol in the nose.  A little alcoholic with mellon, raisons, rum, oak and fermented fruit.  Moderatly spicey with a fermented fruit finish.

Sweet banana rum aroma.Not much of a head or sediment.Sweet bitter flavors of raisans,peppers,caramel,figs,bananas and chocolate.Spicy peppery finish.Nice sweet- hoppy-sweet-pepper-sweet layering.Thanks to capt.Couger for obtaining thes rare treasure for me.

Aroma of caramel, toffee, and oak with some alcoholic notes.  Pours a dark brown with off-white head.  Flavor is best characterized as smooth, sweet, and mellow. A silky mouthfeel leads to a light candi sugar finish.  Incredibly balanced beer which conceals most of its alcohol.  I am quite impressed with this concoction.

Dark amber color.  Thick, rocky head and a strong intensely fruity aroma.  Pears, figs, banana, raisin and spice.  Alcohol well hidden but present slightly in the finish.  My favorite beer from Ommegang.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2004 Dark brown body with red accents topped by a medium thick quickly disappearing head that leaves behind a good amount of lace.  Slightly sweet and smalty aroma with a spicy note, a touch of caramel and a little yeast.  Sweet and malty flavor with notes of spice a slight yeastiness, a touch of fruit and some caramel.  Full bodied, slightly dry and warming.

Beautiful dark reddish brown with light offwhite head.  Nose of fruit and malt, taste of fruit, spice, caramel, and malt backbone.  Since there really are no fruits in the beer, we may differ in how we interpret the fruitiness; to me it was raisins, figs, and cherries.  Finish of malt with fruit and an alcohol burn.  Like Dogfish Raison d'extra, this is not a casual beer or a beer that matches easily with food ... but at less than half the alcohol it is going to be easier to drink.  Not easy to find, but worth looking for.

This is an unbelievable beer.  It pours a hazy deep amber with an eggshell colored head.  The taste is reminscent of dried fruits (I picked up raisens, apples, and pears) and of a nice clean malt.  The finish is clean and similar to the fruitiness mentioned above.  This beer of very limited availablity is definitly worth seeking out for a guaranteed wonderful beer experience.

UPDATED: FEB 29, 2004 Ruby/amber color with a thick tan head. Aromas of dates, figs, plums and other fruits abound along with a whiff of alcohol.  Thick, chewy and mouthcoating.  Swet fruity flavors.  Seems to lack the maltiness I prefer (but that could just be a personal preferance). Warming and burning alcohol in the finish.  A substancial brew. Aroma-9, Appearance-4, Flavor-8, Palate-4, Overall-17.  

In my opinion the new white label is a completely a different brew.  The label indicates "Ale with cherry-lambic added".  Brown with amber hues. Moderate light tan head. Aromas of rich malt, light cherries and alcohol.  Malt and light fruity backdrop. More biting then I remember the original.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2004 Copper/red color w/ a thick tan head. Lots of banana in the nose. The taste has Lots of complex fruits: plums, apples & others. A slightly sweet malthy finish makes this an all around world class beer. THANKS slushy!

Re-rate 1 May 2004:
Very nice looking; slightly spicey aroma; nice cherry background flavor, slightly over carbonated

Amazing.  The things they can do with malts and yeast.  Strong banana aroma.  Deep ochre brown, hazy, with a thick off white head.  Initial flavor is banana and a bit of paint thinner, something strong, like xylol, and a touch of pineapple.  Flavor tapers off to a crispy dry apricot and a little pruney flavor.  Very complex, with a great sourness in the end.  Alcohol is evident.  Id rate this beer higher if it was hidden.  Definitely a rare treat from one of the best breweries in the United States.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2004 11/03/02:  Ruby with ample creamy head.  Spicy, sweet dark fruit, malty aroma.  Full almost syrupy mouthfeel.  Complex sweet flavor.  This rocks!  First rating:  Bottle sample Boston Beer Summit '02:  There's a lot going on with this one.  Plum, cask wood, and other dark fruits.  Very rich tasting.

This is an amazing belgian produced by Ommegang.  It is a completely different beast from the Ommegang that I am used to tasting.  Tastes of apples and syrup.  But a tart tannic that puckers your mouth.  This is a complex ale but is very smooth.  Get your hands on some of this!

UPDATED: APR 6, 2004 The white labeled 2004 version sure tastes a whole lot different than the old brown-labeled version. I am not quite sure just where the differences are; perhaps the older version was a little fruitier with a more definite earthiness. The newer version seems a little maltier and a little tarter. I would really like to do a side by side tastingof the two.....The Winner of the Brew your dream beer contest. Dark brown color, smallish head, lacy with some arabesques. Figs and apricots in the nose. Very complex flavors. Malts, spices, figs, earthy and fruity. Well balanced. Very smooth taste, a slightly alcohol bite at 9.8%. Great mix of complex subtle flavors. Mouthfeel is smooth and smooth. Finish is very clean and smooth. Aftertaste is malty and sweet. WOW. Great beer from a great brewery.  Please make more of this.

The star of the evening. The ratings here got me down abt this beer but it was the star in an evening of tasting that included some very nice brews. Apple plumes, interesting grape seed aromas, arabesques atop, clean and true, beautiful, figgy, soft smooth winey feel complete with a tannic finish. Very different from Ommegang. Light maple and tobacco/pepper aromas arrive as it warms.

Red Garnet color; Head was thin and whispy; Nose strongly of raisins and oak. The alcohol does make itself known early, but is not unpleasent in the least. Heavy dark fruit flavors that are too numerous for this palate to discern. Warming. Oaky. I am really excited to see how this does with age.

Quite possibly the longest commercial description for any beer, let alone one that really wasnt all that great. Too much alcohol in the aroma and flavor. The fruity flavors seemed to be dominated by alcohol, as did the aroma. Compared to the rest of the Ommegang brews this one falls way below par.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2005 First batch. Pop of cork exhibited no life.  Aroma is dominated by alcohol. Underlying sweet prunes, maple/brown sugar, rum, dates, and caramel.  Becomes port-like and toffeeish as it nears room temp.  Dense and creamy foam floats atop a plum color.  Spritzy, semi-full mouthfeel.  Warming alcohol makes itself very apparent, initially.  Apples and caramel lead the way before strange fishy notes and a delectable dry/bitter chocolate that lingers for an ample amount of time.  Lush biscuity malt residuals.  Complexity really awakens at room temp.    A shining example.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: This is a good beer, but honestly it tasted exactly like regular Ommegang to me.  Thanks to jayme in Buffalo for the brew!

Semi-clear dark amber with notes of burgundy red. Thin foamy light tan head. Moderate carbonation. Aroma of plums, raisins, grains of paradise. Smooth and fluffy with noticeable alcohol and the typical Ommegang flavors. Loaded with lip smacking sweetness, grains of paradise and a marshmallow like fluffiness. Airy body with a light effervescence. Nice plummy fruitiness and toffee malt underbelly. Smoother with a lighter body than I expected. Apple like cider quality emerges as you sip. Turns a bit drier and thicker bodied towards the finish, where the alcohol and tart apple fruity quality melds with the grains of paradise and spiciness to finish this off nicely. An interesting but solid offering.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2003 (2003) Deep ruby red, thin, diminshing beige head, nose of soft malt, tart yeast, cocoa, bit of anis, grains of paradise, marshmellow, winey notes and hints of oranges, plums and vanlla. Medium bodied, dry, with hints of cherries, strong yeast presence, cocoa, spices, alcohol and raisons. Its ok but just seems to yeasty and dry to me. Any real cherry flavor comes very late. Smells better then it tastes, improves as it warms. 8/3/6/3/15


A deep cloudy (might not have settled long enough),burning  red with orange hues. Fizzy,quickly dissipating head. Strong fruity aroma of apricots, maybe apple, spices,yeast and many others. Similar to regular Ommegang. Seems very accurate to the description but that may be power of suggestion. Beautifully thick mouthfeel, a steady and mellow carbonation with an array of tastes. Dark fruits (raisons, figs), hint of bubblegum,orange,lots of fine yeast character. Alcohol is felt but infused masterfully. Finished fairly dry with hints of cocoa, orange and leather(maybe in nose as well) The flavors are all there equally in a wave of subtleness but at the sametime complete and refined. Sight bitter bite at end to add to an already balanced beer. Maybe a bit heavy with the yeast but why complain, a damn fine drink. I swear I taste cedar as well, I should not have read the freakin description!!Very complex IMHO.  Watch out boys, it has a kick thats felt immediatley. Worth seeking out if you can get it.
